allegation_sentence_2:
Specifically, he complains of the prosecutor's
repeated references to Johnson as a firefighter, of the introduction in evidence of a photograph of Johnson and his
family, of references to Johnson's family and of repeated
characterizations (over sustained defense objections) of
Johnson as “the victim.”
allegation_term_2:
complains of the prosecutor's
repeated references
allegation_sentence_3: First, with respect to his argument that the trial court did not allow him to probe one witness about current drug usage and a past conviction for such use, the Appellate Court held that he had failed to preserve the issue for appeal.

not so
inflammatory or prejudicial that the trial was unfair.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Second,
DeSavieu's challenge to the length of his sentence presents
no cognizable federal constitutional issue.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:

no constitutional error concerning the conduct of voir dire.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Finally, we have examined DeSavieu's remaining claims and
find them similarly lacking in merit.

geography_entities: Southern District of Iowa
allegation_sentence_1:
Leonos argued that a new trial was appropriate because of
an alleged incident of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Leonos appeals, contending that
the evidence presented was insufficient to convict him of
the distribution charges, that the district court erred by
dismissing his motion for a new trial, and that the instructions
submitted to the jury addressing the conspiracy charge
constructively amended the indictment in violation of his
Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights. L
allegation_sentence_3:
Leonos also challenges
his sentence, arguing that the district court erred in granting
a two-point sentence adjustment for organizer/leader status
under U.S.S.G. § 3B1.1(c).
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court of Appeals, Wollman,
Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to
support convictions; (2) defendant was not entitled to new
trial; (3) imposition of sentencing increase under leadership
role sentencing guideline was warranted; and (4) imposition
of sentencing increase for obstruction of justice was not
warranted.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Our review of the record satisfies us that the district
court did not commit clear error in so ruling.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accordingly, we
conclude that the district court did not abuse its discretion in
denying Leonos's motion for a new trial.

allegation_sentence_1:
PROSECUTORIAL MISCONDUCT-(Calling witness
who invokes Fifth Amendment)
allegation_sentence_2:
Christensen argues that his conviction should be reversed
because the prosecutor improperly vouched for Strachan's
credibility.
allegation_sentence_3:
It is Christensen's position that even if the prosecutorial
vouching was not plain error, it amounted to reversible error
when considered together with other errors.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The prosecutor's conduct, in light of Christensen's
failure to object, did not seriously affect the fairness or
integrity of the district court proceedings.
misconduct_determination_term1: did not seriously affect the fairness
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Although Strachan's testimony was improperly bolstered, the
prosecutor's limited statements did not rise to the level of
plain error.
misconduct_determination_term2: did not rise to the level of plain error
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Here, the error was more
probably harmless than not.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: AFFIRMED in all respects

allegation_sentence_1:
Finally, James argues that the trial court erred in not
granting a mistrial for prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
James argues that the trial court conducted an inadequate
voir dire because the vast majority of jurors had read or heard
about the ongoing investigation of county commissioners.
allegation_sentence_3:
James contends that the evidence on the extortion counts
failed to establish the effect on commerce required under
the Hobbs Act, and that the trial court committed prejudicial
error by instructing the jury that if “any supplies, materials,
or equipment [were] purchased or obtained” from outside
Oklahoma and brought into the state as a result of an
extortionate transaction, then the government would have
carried its burden of proof on nexus with interstate commerce.
allegation_sentence_4:
James asserts that the government failed to show the mailings
in this case were in furtherance of a scheme to defraud.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
While we agree that at
least two of the questions were improper they do not require
reversal.
misconduct_determination_term1: two of the questions were improper
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
There was abundant evidence of guilt in the record, and we
believe the trial court's actions were sufficient to prevent
prejudice in this case.
misconduct_determination_term2: abundant evidence of guilt in the record
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
On the basis of the authorities and analyses set out in
those cases, we conclude that James' arguments are meritless.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
. Based on our review of the record, which indicates
that none of the jurors were exposed to pretrial publicity
specifically mentioning James' name, and on the authorities
and analysis set out in Whitt, we conclude that the voir dire
was adequate.

allegation_sentence_1:
On October 14, 1994, defendant
filed a series of motions, seeking, among other things:
(1) a continuance of trial; (2) dismissal of the indictment
for prosecutorial misconduct and abuse of process; (3)
dismissal of counts fourteen and fifteen of the indictment; and
(4) discovery.
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant claims that two portions of the prosecution's
rebuttal argument prejudiced her and denied her right to a fair
trial.
allegation_term_2:
portions of the prosecution's
rebuttal argument prejudiced
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendant claims that she was prejudiced when the
prosecutor argued that “it's time that it stops. It shouldn't
be allowed to go on.”
allegation_sentence_4:
Defendant argues that the Government engaged in
outrageous conduct when it contacted her cousin, Dr. Rubin
Ruiz, without her consent.
allegation_term_4:
the Government engaged in
outrageous conduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Viewed in context, the prosecutor's statements do not
constitute error, let alone plain error.
misconduct_determination_term1:
prosecutor's statements do not
constitute error
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Because there is no evidence that the allegedly
improper prosecutorial comments affected the jury's ability to
judge the evidence fairly, we hold that any misconduct was
harmless.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
However, we hold that the comments were
harmless and therefore do not constitute grounds for reversal
of the conviction.
misconduct_determination_term3:
do not constitute grounds for reversal
of the conviction.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
It is undisputed that this
conduct by the Government was improper.
misconduct_determination_term4:
this
conduct by the Government was improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Defendant has failed to demonstrate any prejudice suffered
as a result of the Government's misconduct.
notes:
NOT AN AAG — While we use the
term “prosecutorial” misconduct, this label encompasses
actions of Government agents for which the “prosecution”
must account. The contact here in question was not made by
an Assistant United States Attorney, but by an Immigration
and Naturalization Service special agent.)

United States Court of Appeals,
Eighth Circuit.
defendant: Marcus Q. DAVIS, Appellant//Stephen L. Edwards, Appellant
attorneys_judges:
Clemens A. Erdahl, Nidey, Peterson, Erdahl & Tindal,
PLC, Cedar Rapids, IA, argued, for appellant Marcus Q.
Davis//Donovan S. Robertson, Rock Island, IL, argued, for appellant
Stephen L. Edwards//
Stephen Patrick O'Meara, Asst. U.S. Atty., Des Moines,
IA, argued (Matthew G. Whitaker, U.S. Atty., Richard E.
Rothrock, Richard D. Westphal, Shannon L. Olson, Asst. U.S.
Attys., on the brief), for appellee//
Before WOLLMAN, BRIGHT, and SMITH, Circuit Judges//WOLLMAN, Circuit Judge.
geography_entities: Southern District of Iowa// Rock Island, IL//Cedar Rapids, IA// Iowa City, Iowa// Chicago//Illinois//
allegation_sentence_1:
The defendants assert that their convictions should
be reversed because the prosecutor's conduct and statements
during closing argument were improper and should have led
to a mistrial.
allegation_term_1: prosecutor's conduct and statements during closing argument were improper
allegation_sentence_2:
The defendants assert that the use of their out-ofcourt
statements during the prosecutor's closing argument
violated Bruton because it invited the jury to use statements
made by one defendant against the other.
allegation_term_2:
invited the jury to use statements
made by one defendant against the other
allegation_sentence_3:
Specifically, the
defendants argue that the prosecutor's closing argument made
it impossible for the jury to compartmentalize the evidence
that related to each defendant.
allegation_term_3:
prosecutor's closing argument made
it impossible for the jury to compartmentalize the evidence
allegation_sentence_4:
The defendants argue that the district court abused
its discretion in denying their motions to sever and that
they suffered real prejudice as a result.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Thus, the admission of the statements was not an obvious
error under Richardson and its progeny.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Accordingly, although we do not condone the manner in
which the prosecutor utilized the previously undisclosed
demonstrative aid, we conclude that the district court did not
abuse its discretion in denying the defendants' motions for
mistrial
misconduct_determination_term2:
condone the manner in
which the prosecutor utilized the previously undisclosed
demonstrative aid
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In any event, we conclude that the prosecutor's use of
the demonstrative aid did not affect the defendants' substantial rights, nor did it deprive them of a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term3: did not affect the defendants' substantial rights
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Because we have
already concluded that the government presented sufficient
evidence to uphold the convictions and that the defendants'
substantial rights were not affected by the prosecutor's
closing argument, we conclude that the defendants have not
established that they suffered real prejudice from the denial
of their motion to sever.
misconduct_determination_term4:
defendants have not
established that they suffered real prejudice
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
Indeed, the error here
was so egregious and prejudicial it amounted to plain error. I
would therefore reverse the convictions.
concur_dissent_term_1:
error here
was so egregious and prejudicial
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
The Government's case consisted almost entirely of
circumstantial evidence with the exception of two
incriminating statements, one made by Davis, and the other
made by Edwards.
concur_dissent_sentence_3:
Under these circumstances, the error
was not harmless.
concur_dissent_sentence_4:
The conduct of the prosecutor here produced a Bruton error,
which seriously affected the fairness, integrity, and public
reputation of the judicial proceedings.
concur_dissent_term_4:
seriously affected the fairness, integrity, and public
reputation of the judicial proceedings

allegation_sentence_1:
Movant asserts that Respondent (1) “failed to apply
for permission to prosecute” Movant; (2) failed to apply
for permission “to submit any evidence to a Federal Grand
Jury;” and (3) engaged in prosecutorial misconduct by
Respondent's “failure to correct the false testimony of a
government witness.” (Docket No. 86 at 1).

Respondent introduced false testimony of DEA Special Agent
Bevins regarding the packaging of the $20,000 discovered
in Claimant's love seat

Respondent introduced false testimony

of false or perjured testimony at Movant's sentencing hearing.

of false or perjured testimony
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Having considered all of the evidence before
the Court, the undersigned determines that Movant clearly is
not entitled to relief under 28 U.S.C. § 2255; therefore, the
undersigned finds that Movant is not entitled to an evidentiary
hearing and respectfully recommends that his Motion be
denied and this matter be dismissed from the docket of the
Court.
misconduct_determination_term1:
the undersigned determines that Movant clearly is
not entitled to relief
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In the present case, the alleged prosecutorial
misconduct does not rise to the level of a constitutional error
misconduct_determination_term2:
alleged prosecutorial
misconduct does not rise to the level of a constitutional error
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
As Movant failed to raise his claim
of prosecutorial misconduct on direct appeal, that claim is
procedurally defaulted and should be dismissed.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Even if Movant were able to
establish cause that excuses his procedural default, Movant
is unable to demonstrate that Respondent's presentation of
Bevins' testimony resulted in actual prejudice.
misconduct_determination_term4:
unable to demonstrate that Respondent's presentation of
Bevins' testimony resulted in actual prejudice.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Therefore, Movant suffered no “actual and
substantial disadvantage” as a result of Bevins' testimony
and his claim of prosecutorial misconduct was procedurally
defaulted by his failure to raise it on direct appeal.
misconduct_determination_term5:
claim of prosecutorial misconduct was procedurally

allegation_sentence_1:
The appellants' various claims can be grouped into several
categories: sufficiency of the evidence as to certain counts,
admissibility of specific evidence, alleged prosecutorial
misconduct, improper jury instructions, sentencing rulings,
and new trial claims based on new or withheld evidence
allegation_sentence_2:
All three appellants allege that the trial was tainted by
improper remarks by the prosecutor in summation.
allegation_sentence_3:
The appellants claim that the prosecutor improperly vouched
for witnesses' credibility on several occasions.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We affirm the appellants' convictions and sentences in all
respects.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Although several of the
remarks were highly improper, none calls for a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
These comments were plainly improper appeals to the jury's
emotions and role as the conscience of the community.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The reference
to the defendants as animals is especially inflammatory
and improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Although the issue
is close, the prosecutor's inexcusable remarks do not warrant
a new trial.
misconduct_determination_term5: do not warrant a new trial
notes:
We do not condone the continuing disregard for our
precedents by federal prosecutors in Puerto Rico. // concurring opinion: Puerto Rico has been highlighted in several reviews as particularly bad on closing arguments // footnote 12 lists cases of improper closings in PR

allegation_sentence_1:
This matter is before the court on motions to dismiss
the superseding indictment against defendants LUTHER
LANGFORD TAYLOR, LARRY BLANDING and
BENJAMIN J. GORDON, JR., and the indictments against
defendants PAUL WAYNE DERRICK and JEFFERSON
MARION LONG, JR., on the grounds of prosecutorial,
agency and/or investigative misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
On the day jury selection
commenced in the Blanding/Gordon case, 14 February 25,
1991, the defendant Gordon filed a motion to dismiss for
prosecutorial misconduct on the ground that Brady material
furnished by the government only three days earlier 15 would
show that the government's key witness had perjured himself
both at the Taylor trial and before the Grand Jury and that
the government had taken no steps to correct the matter.
allegation_sentence_3:
Derrick filed his motion claiming prosecutorial misconduct
in the withholding of Brady materials on April 19, 1995, and
supplemented this motion on September 5, 1995.
allegation_sentence_4:
Taylor filed a Second Supplemental Memorandum to his
motion to dismiss on August 25, 1995, in which he
expands his argument that the government was guilty
of outrageous misconduct in that, among other things, it
failed to supervise adequately a paid government informer,
disregarded FBI regulations by questioning a target without
Miranda warnings, delayed in transcribing interviews of
witnesses, allowed false declarations before the Grand
Jury and false testimony at trial which it did not correct,
communicated with the defendant after trial without prior
notice to his counsel, participated in prejudicial pretrial
publicity, engaged in a pattern of conduct calculated to
infringe on the Grand Jury's ability to exercise independent
judgment; *629 misrepresented facts proven false by
documents later found in the government's file, failed to
present exculpatory evidence to the Grand Jury, withheld
prior exculpatory testimony and misrepresented to the court
and the defense that the prior testimony existed; tainted
the proceedings by misrepresentations and indiscretions of
government agents, failed to provide proper warning to a
Grand Jury target prior to his testifying before the Grand Jury,
and perjury by a government agent.
allegation_sentence_5:
Taylor filed a Second Supplemental Memorandum to his
motion to dismiss on August 25, 1995, in which he
expands his argument that the government was guilty
of outrageous misconduct in that, among other things, it
failed to supervise adequately a paid government informer,
disregarded FBI regulations by questioning a target without
Miranda warnings, delayed in transcribing interviews of
witnesses, allowed false declarations before the Grand
Jury and false testimony at trial which it did not correct,
communicated with the defendant after trial without prior
notice to his counsel, participated in prejudicial pretrial
publicity, engaged in a pattern of conduct calculated to
infringe on the Grand Jury's ability to exercise independent
judgment; *629 misrepresented facts proven false by
documents later found in the government's file, failed to
present exculpatory evidence to the Grand Jury, withheld
prior exculpatory testimony and misrepresented to the court
and the defense that the prior testimony existed; tainted
the proceedings by misrepresentations and indiscretions of
government agents, failed to provide proper warning to a
Grand Jury target prior to his testifying before the Grand Jury,
and perjury by a government agent.
allegation_sentence_6:
"Taylor filed a Second Supplemental Memorandum to his
motion to dismiss on August 25, 1995, in which he
expands his argument that the government was guilty
of outrageous misconduct in that, among other things, it
failed to supervise adequately a paid government informer,
disregarded FBI regulations by questioning a target without
Miranda warnings, delayed in transcribing interviews of
witnesses, allowed false declarations before the Grand
Jury and false testimony at trial which it did not correct,
communicated with the defendant after trial without prior
notice to his counsel, participated in prejudicial pretrial
publicity, engaged in a pattern of conduct calculated to
infringe on the Grand Jury's ability to exercise independent
judgment; *629 misrepresented facts proven false by
documents later found in the government's file, failed to
present exculpatory evidence to the Grand Jury, withheld
prior exculpatory testimony and misrepresented to the court
and the defense that the prior testimony existed; tainted
the proceedings by misrepresentations and indiscretions of
government agents, failed to provide proper warning to a
Grand Jury target prior to his testifying before the Grand Jury,
and perjury by a government agent."
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The court is convinced that the
totality of the government's actions in these matters rises to
the level of egregious prosecutorial misconduct, and that
this is a sufficient finding on which the court can exercise its
supervisory power.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
I have wrestled with some sanction short of dismissal, but find
that the only remedy available to these defendants that would
be commensurate with the misconduct of the government is
in the dismissal of these indictments.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
I am of the opinion
that the nature and breadth of its misconduct is indicative
of the drastic steps the prosecution took to win these cases,
and that the resultant injustice to these defendants cannot be
fully remedied by new trials.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Therefore, the court must take
the equally drastic step of invoking its supervisory power to
dismiss these indictments with prejudice
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The strongest arguments the defendants make as to the
significance of the withholding of Brady materials and other
exculpatory evidence are found in the arguments relating to
several of the issues to be addressed by the court at this
time.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
In addition, defendants' allegations of perjury by certain
witnesses and the government's knowledge thereof, as well as
alleged misrepresentations to the defendants, the Grand Jury
and the court, rising to the level of fraud upon the court, as
revealed by the post-remand disclosure of evidence, must also
be addressed.

allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, defendants claim (1) the
evidence was insufficient to sustain the jury's verdict, and (2)
the government's prosecutorial misconduct deprived them
of their right to a fair trial.
allegation_term_2:
Defendants contend that the government's failure to timely
disclose exculpatory material
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendants claim that the government's
failure to disclose, in a timely manner, *654 the grand jury
testimony of Sylvia Schmidt violated Brady v. Maryland, 373
U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194, 10 L.Ed.2d 215 (1963).
allegation_sentence_4:
Defendants contend that the government knowingly
presented false and prejudicial testimony before the jury when
they had Dale Campbell testify regarding his alleged purchase
of a deputy sheriff commission.
allegation_term_4:
Defendants contend that the government knowingly
presented false and prejudicial testimony
allegation_sentence_5:
Finally, defendants contend that the prosecutor
engaged in misconduct during his closing argument by
suggesting to the jury that defendants had personally
benefitted from the sale of the deputy sheriff commissions.
allegation_term_5:
the prosecutor
engaged in misconduct during his closing argument
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Thus, the timing of the government's disclosure did
not deprive the defendants of a fair trial
misconduct_determination_term1:
timing of the government's disclosure did
not deprive the defendants of a fair trial
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
For the aforementioned reasons, defendants' convictions are
AFFIRMED.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Thus, we find that the
prosecutor's remark was not “so pronounced and persistent
that it permeate[d] the entire atmosphere of the trial,” nor
“so gross as probably to prejudice” the defendants.
misconduct_determination_term3: nor so gross as probably to prejudice the defendants

allegation_sentence_1:
In his motion to dismiss, the defendant contends that
the indictment against him should be dismissed because
it was obtained in a “fundamental unfair manner due to
prosecutorial misconduct.”
allegation_sentence_2:
Specifically,
he alleges that grand jurors were given “potentially false,
incomplete, or erroneous evidence information regarding
[him] and the law.” (D.I. 16 at 1–2.)
allegation_sentence_3:
He contends that the release
of this information is necessary to determine whether the
government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_4:
Specifically, he claims
that the government should not have presented information
concerning his prior arrests and/or convictions to the grand
jury.
allegation_sentence_5:
He further claims that, in doing
so, the government engaged in an “improper method” 2
of presenting evidence, and that this alleged misconduct
substantially influenced the grand jury's decision to indict
allegation_sentence_6:
The defendant further claims that the government
erred in failing to give a mens rea or credibility instruction to
the grand jury. (Id. at 3.)
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The court does not agree.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
As the government correctly notes,
beyond mere speculation, the defendant fails to identify what,
if any, violation occurred.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
First, contrary to the defendant's
blanket assertion, the court is not persuaded that there is
anything irregular or “improper” about the production of the
DELJIS printout by the government to the grand jury or
the manner in which traffic offenses are characterized in the
printout.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Even assuming
arguendo, that this conduct is in some way improper, the court
is, nonetheless, not satisfied that it rises to a level that warrants
dismissal of the indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Second, the court is not convinced that the government's
failure to give a mens rea or credibility instruction to the grand
jury constitutes error—let alone misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Because the defendant has failed to establish that
the alleged errors “substantially influenced that grand jury's
decision to indict,” or that there is “grave doubt that the
decision to indict was free from substantial influence” of
alleged prosecutorial misconduct, see Bank of Nova Scotia,
487 U.S. at 256, defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment
must be denied.

decision_court:
United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina,
Western Division
attorneys_judges: WILLIAM A. WEBB, United States Magistrate Judge
allegation_sentence_1:
On October 17, 2012, Batts filed the instant motion asserting
error based on claims of: (1) prosecutorial misconduct; (2)
sentencing error; (3) ineffective assistance of counsel; (4)
breach of the plea agreement; (5) violation of due process;
and (6) sentence imposed in violation of 18 U.S.C. § 3742(g)
(2).
allegation_sentence_2:
Batts further alleges that the prosecutor misrepresented
the facts of the underlying offense to the district court, and
that the factual summary he presented at the sentencing
hearing differed from the factual basis offered at the
arraignment hearing
allegation_term_2:
alleges that the prosecutor misrepresented
the facts
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Even if considered timely, the motion to vacate should
nevertheless be denied because Batts fails to state a
cognizable claim for prosecutorial misconduct, as alleged
in Ground One of the 2255 motion
misconduct_determination_term1:
fails to state a
cognizable claim for prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Because Batts fails to allege
any facts to show that the prosecutor engaged in any improper
behavior to obtain the plea agreement, he fails to state a
claim of prosecutorial misconduct based on inducement.
misconduct_determination_term2:
fails to allege
any facts to show that the prosecutor engaged in any improper
behavior
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because Batts fails to allege sufficient facts to state a plausible
claim of prosecutorial misconduct, Twombly, 550 U.S. at
570, the undersigned recommends that the motion to vacate
be denied as to Ground One, and that the government's motion
to dismiss be granted
misconduct_determination_term3:
fails to allege sufficient facts to state a plausible
claim of prosecutorial misconduct

allegation_sentence_1:
It is the position of the defendants that the summary procedure
utilized by the Government in presenting its case to the grand
jury was so abused as to constitute a totally unjustifiable
manipulation of the indicting grand jury all to the prejudice
of the defendants.
allegation_sentence_2:
By a highly selective and deceptively prejudicial
summary of only a fraction of the prior grand jury
testimony and evidence
allegation_sentence_3:
In support of their motions the defendants point to numerous
examples of what is asserted as prosecutorial misconduct
during the course of proceedings before the indicting grand
jury and further have designated several portions of testimony
given before the Special Grand Jury as false.
allegation_sentence_4:
The Government prosecutor improperly appeared as an
unsworn witness before the indicting grand jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The facts presented to the court in both Chanen
and Samango differ materially from the instant case and in the
eyes of this Court the level of prosecutorial misconduct, if
it can be called that, in this case falls somewhere in between
the gross indiscretions presented in Samango which the court
found sufficient to dismiss and those in Chanen which were
not.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Contrary to the
insistence of defendant, the Court finds that neither of
these statements were made for the purpose of intentionally
deceiving or misleading the grand jury and taken in toto such
remarks do not constitute knowing use of perjured testimony
before a grand jury.
misconduct_determination_term2: contrary to the insistence of the defendant
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Although none of the errors and misstatements discussed
above, especially the representation that the architectural
redesign clause was placed in the general contract against the
advice of the defendant's legal counsel, are to be commended
and can be viewed as anything other than unfortunate if not
inexcusable mistakes, taken together these alleged errors do
not constitute a case of serious prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term3: do not constitute a case of serious prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
There were
some things said by the prosecutor to the grand jury which
probably would have been better left unsaid.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
But these
statements by no means rise to the level of prosecutorial
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term5: no means rise to the level

allegation_sentence_1: Alleged Brady Violation
allegation_sentence_2:
Thus,
since the Government did not give the defense Beamus's prior
inconsistent statement until shortly before her testimony,
Crayton's due process rights are said to have been violated
under Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194, 10
L.Ed.2d 215 (1963).
allegation_sentence_3:
Crayton contends that the prosecution did not provide
him with a prior statement by Beamus, in which she
corroborated Crayton's story, until shortly before she testified
allegation_sentence_4:
Crayton contends that the prosecutor then improperly asked
Beamus if her cousin had “been involved with the distribution
of cocaine?”, to which Beamus replied, “Yes, sir, I think so.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Government also did not illegally withhold
exculpatory evidence from Crayton.
misconduct_determination_term1: did not illegally withhold exculpatory evidence
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
However, Crayton suffered no prejudice because the
Government did produce the impeachment material in a
manner consistent with the requirements of Brady
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Thus,
there appears to have been no Brady violation.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
There was therefore clearly no violation of
Crayton's constitutional rights under Brady.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The statements made by the prosecutor during his direct
examination of Beamus did not amount to prosecutorial
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term5: did not amount to prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Since the defendant has
not shown that the prosecution's question was improper,
much less that it rose to the level of flagrant misconduct,
prosecutorial misconduct does not warrant reversal in this
case.

EUGENE A. WRIGHT, WALLACE, and DAVID R.

geography_entities:
United States District Court for the District

allegation_sentence_1:
Ross asserts that the prosecutor's questions concerning the
kidnapping constituted (1) inadmissible “[e]vidence of other
crimes” in violation of Rule 404(b) of the Federal Rules of
Evidence; (2) inadmissible uncharged misconduct evidence
under Rule 608(b) of the Federal Rules of Evidence; and
(3) prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
We review the
claim of prosecutorial misconduct to determine whether it
appears more probable than not that the alleged misconduct
affected the jurors' verdict or the fairness of the trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Ross's allegations of prosecutorial misconduct are also
without merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
First, because the district court did not abuse its
discretion in allowing the prosecutor's questions, it is manifest
that the posing of those questions was not prosecutorial
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Second, because we find that even if error had
been committed, it would have been harmless, it clearly is
more probable than not that the alleged misconduct did not
affect the jurors' verdict or the fairness of the trial.
misconduct_determination_term3:
even if error had
been committed, it would have been harmless

and that he was denied a fair trial based on prosecutorial

allegation_sentence_2:
He alleges that the government improperly
targeted Messrs. Tyack and Haller as potential targets of
criminal investigation in order to effect their withdrawal from
the case, thus placing Petitioner at an unfair and significant
disadvantage in his attempt to secure a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
When
viewed collectively, Petitioner contends, these actions on
the part of the prosecution denied him due process.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the reasons
just discussed, that claim is without support in the record.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The record fails to support Petitioner's claim that he was
denied a fair trial on the basis of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The fact that the government opposed requests for
continuances of the trial date is neither improper nor evidence
of improper intent.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
For all these reasons, Petitioner has failed to establish
that the government denied him a fair trial, or that the
combined actions of the prosecution resulted in a denial of
due process.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
For all of these reasons, the Court concludes that
Petitioner has failed to establish a basis for relief in either
Case No. 2:07–cr–209 or Case No. 2:06–cr–129 based on
the denial of his right to counsel of choice or prosecutorial
misconduct.

allegation_sentence_1:
Drake points to several instances of alleged
prosecutorial misconduct during closing arguments, which
she contends denied her a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
First, Drake challenges the prosecutor's remark in
his rebuttal argument that Belmar's house had no heat.
allegation_sentence_3:
Next, Drake disputes a number of other prosecutorial
statements, but these concerns were not raised at trial.
allegation_sentence_4:
Drake also
objects to the prosecutor's statement that Devon Hudgins's
mother died of a crack overdose and submits that the
prosecutor improperly attacked Drake's character “by linking
her supposed disregard for the welfare of others” to Hudgins's
mother's death.
allegation_sentence_5:
Finally, Drake argues that the prosecutor grossly
mischaracterized her defense arguments, thereby inflaming
and prejudicing the jury against her.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
However, we find that the court's error did not negatively
impact the fairness of Drake's trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Thus the prosecutor's characterization of the house as
a “crack house” was appropriate.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Once again,
the prosecutor mischaracterized trial testimony. We expect
greater precision and care by government lawyers.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
But Drake
cannot show that she was prejudiced by this remark such that
her trial was unfair. The misstatement did not concern an
important fact.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
And while calling
Drake a “predator” may have been harsh, “so long as the
evidence supports the comments, prosecutors may speak
harshly about the actions and conduct of the accused.”
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Furthermore, the weight of the government's
case against Drake negates any concern that these remarks
denied her a fair trial.

allegation_sentence_1: The first ground is that the government allegedly “engaged in a secret public relations campaign” designed to make the NOPD “the household name for corruption,” inflame public opinion against the defendants and others involved with NOPD, establish community acceptance of the government's version of the facts “before anyone set foot in a courtroom,” urge defendants and others to plead “guilty” as a result, and prejudice the defendants during trial through online activities designed to secure their convictions.
allegation_sentence_2:
The second ground
for new trial is that the government, or someone associated
with the government, allegedly improperly disclosed, to
The Times–Picayune, L.L.C. (“Times–Picayune”) and the
Associated Press (“AP”), the government's theories regarding
the defendants' alleged guilt, the status of plea negotiations,
and the upcoming guilty plea of cooperating defendant and
former NOPD lieutenant Michael Lohman, all in violation of
Rule 6(e) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure.
allegation_sentence_3:
At that time, the Court indicated that defendants were surely
correct in their suspicions of prosecutorial misconduct, but
concluded that the facts, as of November 2012, still did not yet
warrant an evidentiary hearing or the relief requested by the
defendants.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Additionally, United States v. Ugalde, 861 F.2d 802 (5th
Cir.1988), a case cited by the government, is easily
distinguishable. In Ugalde, the defendant observed all the
grounds for his motion during the trial itself, unlike in
this case, wherein the prosecutorial misconduct occurred
surreptitiously and covertly, and with every intent for it to remain so, as the poster's “little secret” or “little
downtime thing.”
misconduct_determination_term1:
prosecutorial misconduct occurred
surreptitiously and covertly

allegation_sentence_1:
He now appeals his conviction on the grounds
that: (1) the district court gave a coercive Allen charge, (2)
the government committed prosecutorial misconduct during the voir dire and (3) the government improperly used a
peremptory challenge.
allegation_sentence_2:
On appeal, Steele argues that the district court abused its
discretion in refusing to grant the motion for mistrial because:
(1) the prosecutor engaged in misconduct when she created
the misconception that defense counsel would defend clearly
guilty defendants, and (2) the voir dire of Ahearn tainted the
whole jury pool by communicating this misconception.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court of Appeals,
Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) submission of Allen
instruction was not premature or coercive; (2) prosecutor's
question to prospective juror did not constitute prosecutorial
misconduct; and (3) government's use of peremptory
challenge to excuse minority prospective juror did not violate
Batson.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The prosecutor's questions in the
present case may not have been the best way to elicit
signs of bias, but the circumstances do not support the
conclusion that there was prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2:
do not support the
conclusion that there was prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Thus, the district court did not abuse its
discretion in denying the motion for a mistrial.

allegation_sentence_1:
McCloud next argues that the prosecution engaged in
misconduct throughout the trial by (1) soliciting false
testimony by the prosecution's witnesses; (2) failing to
conduct a thorough investigation (3) using prejudicial
language; and (4) withholding the production of discovery
material until too late in the trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
“Allegations of
prosecutorial misconduct contain mixed questions of law
and fact that we usually review de novo.”
allegation_sentence_3:
The second basis advanced to support McCloud's claim
of prosecutorial misconduct is the prosecutor's alleged
“failure to investigate” a litany of various people and events
connected to McCloud's real-estate practices.
allegation_sentence_4:
McCloud also argues prosecutorial misconduct on
the basis of prejudicial statements by the prosecutor at
trial.
allegation_sentence_5:
The final basis alleged in support of McCloud's claim
of prosecutorial misconduct was the prosecutor's alleged
failure to turn over discovery material.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
There is no merit in McCloud's
failure-to-investigate claim.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
As an initial matter, it is doubtful whether the prosecutor's use
of the term “kickback” was improper at all.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
It is certain that
under Bates there was no flagrancy and thus no prosecutorial
misconduct based on prejudicial statements.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Despite its characterization by McCloud, neither of the
production claims are true Brady claims.

allegation_sentence_1: Appellant claims that the government's closing argument deprived him of a fair trial by disparaging the credibility of the witnesses for the defense and infringing upon the fact-finding function reserved to the jury.
allegation_term_1: deprived him of a fair trial
allegation_sentence_2:
According to appellant, the prosecutor's statements in closing
argument-that Sacco did not exist, appellant and Machado
were lying, and appellant was guilty-improperly implied that
the prosecutor possessed knowledge beyond the purview of
the evidence and improperly invoked the authority of his
office to bolster his interpretation of the evidence.
allegation_sentence_3:
The crux
of appellant's claim is that his and Machado's testimony
concerning George Sacco's role was uncontradicted and,
therefore, there was no evidence on which to predicate the
prosecutor's contention that he and Machado were lying;
accordingly, were the jury to credit their testimony, there was
sufficient evidence to acquit on the justification defense.
allegation_term_3:
no evidence on which to predicate the
prosecutor's contention
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Even more importantly, however, the prosecutor's statements
must be considered harmless error in view of the uncontested
evidence against appellant.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Nor did the overzealous statement that the prosecutor “welcome[d]” the burden of proof constitute reversible error, as its context did not suggest that the prosecutor's confidence was founded on knowledge or evidence unavailable to the jury.
misconduct_determination_term2: Nor did the overzealous statement that the prosecutor “welcome[d]” the burden of proof constitute reversible error
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Given that appellant's justification defense was fatally
deficient, as a matter of law, without regard to whether
the roles of George Sacco and Deirdre Machado were real
or concocted, the government's closing argument affected
no substantial right
misconduct_determination_term3:
government's closing argument affected
no substantial right
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Thus, we have the utmost confidence
that any alleged prosecutorial misconduct did not affect the
outcome of the trial.
misconduct_determination_term4:
alleged prosecutorial misconduct did not affect the
outcome of the trial
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Although appellant did not have a perfect trial, he most
assuredly received a fair one, see United States v. HodgeBalwing,
952 F.2d 607, 611 (1st Cir.1991), and is not entitled
to a new one. SeeFed.R.Crim.P. 52(b) (no “plain error” unless
it “affect[s] substantial rights”).
misconduct_determination_term5:
did not have a perfect trial, he most
assuredly received a fair one
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Although the phrasing of the prosecutor's argument left
something to be desired, it was not improper to urge the jury
to evaluate the plausibility of the justification defense in light
of the other evidence (and the lack thereof), as well as the
motivations and biases of the defense witnesses, including
misconduct_determination_term6:
prosecutor's argument left
something to be desired

allegation_sentence_1:

allegation_sentence_2:

 Santiago asserts

allegation_sentence_3:

the prosecutor because the agent gave testimony particularly

misconduct_determination_sentence1: We affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
This is not
prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
But even more important in

allegation_sentence_1:
The appellee has attempted to explain the remark as “an
inartfully-worded reference to the fact that the government
was not the sole evaluator of Gaviria's credibility: the jury would be required to assess his credibility during its
deliberations, and Judge Glasser would be required to assess
his credibility when imposing sentence.”
allegation_sentence_2:
Turning to the last factor, we are unable to say that Melendez's
conviction was certain in the absence of the prosecutor's
misconduct, though it was highly likely.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court of Appeals, Jon O. Newman, Chief Judge, held
that prosecutor's remark during summation, telling jury they
should believe testimony of key prosecution witness because
trial judge “knows he is telling the truth,” though clearly
improper, was not prejudicial error requiring reversal
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
With regard to the severity of the misconduct, we have
already stated that the remark was highly improper and
created a risk of prejudice for the defendant.
misconduct_determination_term2: created a risk of prejudice for the defendant
misconduct_determination_sentence3: On the other hand, the severity was mitigated somewhat in this case because the remark appears to have been an aberration in an otherwise fair proceeding.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
At oral
argument the prosecutor who uttered the remark forthrightly
acknowledged that it was “error.” We are satisfied that the
risk of recurrence is virtually non-existent.
misconduct_determination_term4: prosecutor who uttered the remark forthrightly acknowledged that it was “error.

allegation_sentence_1: Cruz appeals his *624 conviction and sentence.
allegation_sentence_2:
We review prosecutorial misconduct claims for plain error
where defense counsel failed to object before the district
court.
allegation_sentence_3:
In rebuttal, the prosecutor argued “[Cruz] is guilty of what
he is charged with. Find him guilty and do the right thing
and make him finally take responsibility for what he did.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
By stating “do the right thing” the prosecutor improperly
expressed his personal opinion to the jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Third, the prosecutor's
rebuttal argument was the last thing the jury heard before
beginning deliberation; this timing increased the risk that the
prosecutor's improper statement influenced the jurors.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We reverse Cruz's convictions and remand for a new
trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The prosecutor's “do the right thing” statement was
prejudicial to Cruz for several reasons.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
First, because the
prosecutor is the sovereign's representative, the jury may have
been misled into thinking his “do the right thing” statement
was validated by the government.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
I agree that the prosecutor's “do the right thing” statement
clearly constitutes prosecutorial misconduct. However,
under plain error review, we may only reverse when
“prosecutorial misconduct has deprived a defendant of a
fair trial,” which we determine by “look[ing] to the substance
of any curative instructions and the strength of the case
against the defendant absent the misconduct.”
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
However, there's no basis for reversal, not on this or the three
other claims that Cruz also raised on appeal. I therefore would
affirm.
concur_dissent_sentence_3:
The single
instance of argument error during the government's rebuttal
did not affect Cruz's substantial rights.

Accordingly, petitioner has failed to show that his attorney

agreement.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
There is insufficient evidence before the court of a prior
immunity agreement entered into by petitioner and the
government.

allegation_sentence_1: On November 17, 2003, Petitioner timely filed this § 2255 motion raising as grounds for relief ineffective assistance of counsel and prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2: Finally, the Petitioner argues that the prosecutor presented his 1996 tax return to the grand jury in order to obtain an indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The test for prosecutorial misconduct has two elements: (1) whether the prosecutor's conduct was improper; and (2) whether such conduct prejudicially affected the defendant's substantial rights. United States v. Francisco, 35 F.3d 116, 120 (4th Cir.1994).
misconduct_determination_sentence2: In view of the fact that *438 the Fourth Circuit has held that the Petitioner submitted false tax returns, the prosecutor's use of those returns before a grand jury cannot be misconduct. As a result, the Court rejects this conclusory allegation on the part of the Petitioner.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: In view of the fact that *438 the Fourth Circuit has held that the Petitioner submitted false tax returns, the prosecutor's use of those returns before a grand jury cannot be misconduct. As a result, the Court rejects this conclusory allegation on the part of the Petitioner.

allegation_sentence_1:
The petitioner alleges
prosecutorial misconduct and ineffective assistance of
counsel as grounds for his motion.
allegation_sentence_2:
In
Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194, 10 L.Ed.2d
215 (1963), the Supreme Court held that “suppression by the
prosecution of evidence favorable to an accused upon request
violates due process where the evidence is material either
to guilt or to punishment.”
allegation_sentence_3:
The question presented by the petitioner's third and fourth
claims is whether the evidence that the petitioner contends
was wrongly withheld by the prosecutor was material to
the guilt or punishment of the petitioner, so as to “taint
the criminal proceeding so substantially that the defendant's
decision to plead guilty could not fairly be called knowing and
intelligent.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The evidence which the petitioner alleges was withheld by the
prosecution in this case falls below the standard of materiality
required for a collateral attack on a guilty plea by a 2255
motion.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Therefore, as the alleged evidence
of prosecutorial misconduct is immaterial to the guilt or
punishment of the petitioner, he is procedurally barred from
raising these claims on collateral attack.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Nothing in the evidence
goes to undermine the confidence of the court that this
sentence was appropriate.

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Fifth Circuit
attorneys_judges:
Renata Ann Gowie, Assistant U.S. Attorney, U.S.
Attorney's Office, Houston, TX, for Plaintiff–Appellee// Ralph R. Martinez, Martinez & Martinez, Houston, TX, for
Defendant–Appellant//DAVIS, DeMOSS, and BENAVIDES, Circuit Judges
geography_entities:
Houston, TX//United States District Court for the Southern
District of Texas
allegation_sentence_1:
For the
first time on appeal, Linares argues that the Government
committed prosecutorial misconduct amounting to plain
error by impermissibly bolstering witness testimony during
its examination of witnesses and jury argument
allegation_sentence_2:
He maintains
that counsel for the Government improperly imputed the
existence of a drug conspiracy during the questioning of
witnesses when the existence of a conspiracy was an
issue for the jury to determine.
allegation_sentence_3:
He asserts that counsel
for the Government improperly bolstered the credibility of
witnesses by personally vouching that witnesses would testify
truthfully during opening arguments, by asking a witness
why he truthfully spoke to law enforcement officers and
why he testified truthfully, and by introducing evidence
that prosecutors and law enforcement officers stressed to
witnesses that they must testify truthfully.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Linares's challenge to the statements made by a
prosecutor during opening arguments is not supported
by the record.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Linares
has not shown that counsel for the Government committed
prosecutorial misconduct, whether constituting plain error
or otherwise, by asking improper questions or making
improper arguments.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
While eliciting this type of testimony may sometimes be
inappropriate, it was not improper in the present case because
Linares's defense strategy involved challenging the credibility
of the co-conspirators who testified against him.

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Fifth Circuit
defendant:
Joe Henry CARTER, Jr., Joseph Estel
Hammack, Defendants–Appellants.
attorneys_judges: Alex R. Tandy, // Timothy W. Crooks // Frank D. Able, // Marvin Collins, // Before REYNALDO G. GARZA // GARWOOD // MAHON
geography_entities:
Texas, // UNITED STATES of America // Fort Worth, Tex // Tarrant County // Old Fort
Worth Highway // Parker County
allegation_sentence_1:
Hammack
joins in Carter's first argument, challenging the admission
not only of his weapon conviction, but also of four prior
narcotics convictions, and arguing that introduction of the
evidence of the weapon conviction was effected by deception
amounting to prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2:
He additionally
argues: (1) that in referring to, and eliciting testimony about,
his silence after he received Miranda warnings, the prosecutor
deprived him of due process under Doyle v. Ohio, 426 U.S.
610, 96 S.Ct. 2240, 49 L.Ed.2d 91 (1976);
allegation_sentence_3:
that the
prosecutor during closing argument impermissibly sought
to bolster government witnesses and to inflame community
passions and prejudices;
allegation_sentence_4:
that the decision to refer his
case for federal rather than state prosecution, made without
reference to any objective or reviewable standards, violated
due process.
allegation_sentence_5:
In this appeal, Hammack contends that the government
committed prosecutorial misconduct warranting reversal
by misleading the district court about the circumstances of
Hammack's 1990 conviction in order to get it admitted into
evidence.
allegation_sentence_6:
Hammack contends that the government's closing argument
amounted to prosecutorial misconduct in two respects: (1)
the prosecutor impermissibly sought to bolster government
witnesses, and (2) the prosecutor sought to inflame the jurors'
passions with an improper appeal to community sentiment.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Applying those factors here, we conclude that any
adverse effect to the defendant from the prosecutor's
misrepresentations to the district court (whether accidental
or deliberate) was not so great as to warrant reversal.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Judged according to the principles discussed above, however,
the prosecutor's statements in this case are not nearly so
egregious and fall short of plain error
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Hammack's second challenge to the closing argument
—that it contained an improperly inflammatory call for
general law enforcement—is also unavailing.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Therefore, we hold that Comment
2 did not result in any likelihood of a grave miscarriage of
justice.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
We again find no
basis for concluding that there is any likelihood of a grave
miscarriage of justice having resulted from this comment.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Finally, we are unable to conclude that the cumulative effect
of the three comments (or any of the other matters complained
of) was such as to have denied Hammack a fair trial or have
likely resulted in a miscarriage of justice, particularly in light
of the very strong evidence of his guilt.
misconduct_determination_term6: resulted in a miscarriage of justice

allegation_sentence_1:
Jones's motion to vacate, set aside, or correct his sentence
is based on four claims: (1) Ineffective assistance of
counsel in violation of his Sixth Amendment rights; (2)
Incorrect calculation of petitioner's sentence under the
Advisory Federal Sentencing Guidelines; (3) Prosecutorial
misconduct; and (4) Unknowing and involuntary guilty plea
because he was legally incompetent due to his illiteracy.
allegation_sentence_2:
Jones also claims that his conviction was involuntary
because he was coerced into the guilty plea by improper
threats by the Government.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Even if the Court assumed
that such a claim is exempt from a general waiver, Jones's
claim fails because his assertions do not give rise to an
inference of prosecutorial misconduct and are not credible.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Although Jones's counsel's affidavit states
that the Assistant United States Attorney told him that she
would charge Jones and his wife with perjury if there were
“variation[s] in their testimony,” 5
 this is not misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
No proof of actual or presumptive
prosecutorial vindictiveness exists.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The
claim of prosecutorial misconduct has no basis for relief.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Third, Petitioner's § 2255 motion based
on prosecutorial misconduct is Denied

allegation_sentence_1:

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant's primary contention is that he was deprived
of a fair trial by the prosecutor's characterization, during
opening and closing, of the alleged drug transaction as a
“rip off” and by other words denoting theft.
allegation_sentence_2:
"Defendant's primary contention is that he was deprived
of a fair trial by the prosecutor's characterization, during
opening and closing, of the alleged drug transaction as a
“rip off” and by other words denoting theft. "
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendant
alleges prosecutorial misconduct on the ground that any
evidence of defendant's theft from Awdish was inadmissible
under Fed.R.Evid. 404(b) and, therefore, any reference to
such evidence was improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
In this case,
the prosecutor's characterization of the drug transaction was
warranted by admissible evidence and, therefore, we find no

misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In this case,
the prosecutor's characterization of the drug transaction was

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Sixth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: Before: SUTTON, GRIFFIN, and WHITE, Circuit Judges//HELENE N. WHITE, Circuit Judge
geography_entities: Western District of Tennessee//
allegation_sentence_1:
Walker asserts that the district court should have granted a
mistrial on three grounds: (1) the introduction of improper
statements regarding drugs, drug dealing and drug buys
that should have been excluded based on Walker's motion
in limine; (2) prosecutorial misconduct based on the
introduction of evidence regarding Walker's prior felony
convictions despite his Old Chief stipulation; and (3) a
violation of due process based on cumulative error.
allegation_sentence_2:
Finally, Walker argues that even if no single assignment of
error is sufficient to warrant a new trial, the totality of errors
deprived him of his constitutional right to a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
Walker also challenges the proportionality of his 180–
month sentence under the Eighth Amendment. Constitutional
challenges to a sentence present questions of law that
are reviewed de novo.
allegation_term_3:
challenges the proportionality of his 180–
month sentence
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
In sum, although evidence of Walker's prior convictions
was improper, the prosecutor did not deprive Walker of his
substantial rights.
misconduct_determination_term1:
prosecutor did not deprive Walker of his
substantial rights
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Rather, the relevant evidence was overwhelming
and the improper evidence and comments likely had no effect
on the verdict.
misconduct_determination_term2: improper evidence and comments likely had no effect
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Here, Walker has failed to demonstrate that his 180–month
statutory minimum sentence for possessing ammunition
is grossly disproportionate to the gravity of his crime.
“Eighth Amendment jurisprudence *
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We conclude, nevertheless, that the district
court did not abuse its discretion in denying Walker's
motion for a mistrial.
misconduct_determination_term4: district court did not abuse its discretion
notes: In this case (and in some others) the judge's opinion says even though prosecutor made some improper comments, it didn't affect anything in the trial. Is this harmless error or no misconduct?

misconduct_determination_sentence1:
As set forth previously, the fact that
various witnesses testified inconsistently with each other is

misconduct_determination_term1: insufficient to show that the prosecutor
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Again,

the Petitioner has failed to

allegation_sentence_1:
Estrada-Fernandez avers that during the Government's
rebuttal, the prosecutor not only personally vouched for the
credibility of the witnesses but also made comments that
were beyond the scope of the evidence presented at trial
and that were designed to cloak the witness with the mantle
of governmental authority.
allegation_sentence_2:
Estrada-Fernandez also challenges the prosecutor's later
statement: “how much sense does it make that he is going to
put his 12-year career on the line just so you will find that this
dangerous weapon was used? It makes no sense.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the
reasons that follow, we affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We conclude that the prosecutor's remarks did not
prejudice Estrada-Fernandez's substantial rights.
misconduct_determination_term2: the prosecutor's remarks did not prejudice
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The district court further mitigated any prejudicial effect
by instructing the jury to base their decision solely upon the
evidence presented, rather than upon the arguments made by
lawyers.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Viewing the prosecutor's statements in the context
of the entire case, we conclude that the prosecutor's rebuttal
argument did not prejudice Estrada-Fernandez's substantial
rights.

decision_court: United States District Court, S.D. New York
defendant:
Herman TORRES and Luigi Tarantino,
a/k/a “Tony Tarantino,” Defendants.
attorneys_judges: KIMBA M. WOOD, District Judge.
geography_entities: New York
allegation_sentence_1:
In his motion to dismiss the indictment, Tarantino alleges the
following types of prosecutorial misconduct in the grand
jury proceedings: 1) inappropriate use of hearsay testimony;
2) inadequate warnings regarding hearsay testimony; 3)
presentation of testimony that the prosecutor knew or should
have known was inaccurate; 4) impermissible use of leading
questions; and 5) inappropriate presentation of opinion
testimony.
allegation_sentence_2:
Tarantino's primary objection to the use of a secondhand
witness in the grand jury proceedings is that it forces the
jurors to rely on hearsay evidence.
allegation_term_2:
forces the
jurors to rely on hearsay evidence
allegation_sentence_3: In addition to alleged problems with hearsay and inaccuracies in the testimony, Tarantino claims that the grand jury proceedings were marred by the impermissible use of leading questions and opinion testimony.
allegation_sentence_4:
Tarantino's motion to dismiss the indictment rests not
only on the particular allegations of misconduct discussed
above, but also on a claim that the alleged defects in this
case are symptomatic of pervasive misconduct that calls into
question the fundamental fairness of the grand jury system
in this district.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the foregoing reasons, the court denies Tarantino's motion
for an evidentiary hearing and his motion to dismiss the
indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The court concludes that defendant's claims do not implicate fundamental fairness, as conceived by the Bank of Nova Scotia Court in its initial discussion of the issue.
misconduct_determination_term2: claims do not implicate fundamental fairness
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Applying the Second Circuit's two-prong test, the court finds
that the use of hearsay testimony in this case does not
warrant dismissal of the indictment.
misconduct_determination_term3:
use of hearsay testimony in this case does not
warrant dismissal

allegation_sentence_1:
Gregory alleges two instances of prosecutorial
misconduct arising from items presented to the jury on the
courtroom's video monitors.
allegation_sentence_2:

that the district court erred when it denied his motion to
suppress and erred again when it found there was probable
cause to support arrest.

district court erred when it denied his motion to

He argues that proximity to

misconduct_determination_sentence1:
In any case, the
evidence overwhelmingly supports Gregory's conviction
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In any case, the prosecution submitted a

misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Given

misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The timing of these events and the actions
themselves demonstrate that Gregory was conscious of guilt
and knew that drugs were hidden in Millard's radio.

allegation_sentence_1:
Related to Thurston's double jeopardy claim is his
allegation that the Government engaged in improper conduct
by deliberately misleading the district court regarding the necessary elements of 18 U.S.C. § 1115.
allegation_sentence_2:
Thurston moved
to dismiss the second indictment, arguing that the reindictment
violated the Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth
Amendment of the United States Constitution.
allegation_term_2:
reindictment
violated the Double Jeopardy Clause
allegation_sentence_3:
According to Thurston, the Government is subjecting
him to repeated prosecutions by prosecuting him based on
the same facts and law for which he was already adjudicated
guilty under the original indictment.
allegation_sentence_4:
Thurston asserts that the Government was aware that
gross negligence was the correct standard from the beginning
and knew all along that the original indictment was defective.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
"We find that Thurston's charge of prosecutorial misconduct
is frivolous and completely without merit. "
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
There is no
credible evidence that Government attempted to mislead the
district court in any way.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We hold that the second indictment does not violate the
Double Jeopardy Clause even if jeopardy attached in the
proceedings under the original indictment.
misconduct_determination_term3: does not violate the Double Jeopardy Clause

allegation_sentence_1:
Petitioner Santiago and his co-defendants filed a consolidated
appeal to the Illinois Appellate Court, First District, in
which petitioner raised the following six issues: (1) he was
not proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt; (2) the State
improperly used its peremptory challenges during voir dire
to exclude minorities from the jury; (3) he was prejudiced by
the State's discovery violation which resulted in ineffective
assistance of counsel; (4) prosecutorial misconduct during
trial resulted in reversible error; (5) the trial court erred in
allowing the State to present a certain unanticipated witness
in aggravation and in denying petitioner's motion for a
continuance to investigate the witness; and (6) his sentence
was excessive.

decision_court:

E.D. Michigan,
Southern Division
attorneys_judges: Matthew J. Schneider,  // Timothy S. Barkovic //PAUL J. KOMIVES, United States Magistrate Judge
geography_entities: St. Clair Shores, MI // United States // Elkton, Ohio //  Detroit, MI // Clinton Township
allegation_sentence_1:
In this motion, defendant
contends that he has new evidence that Lt. Greene lied in his
search warrant affidavit, justifying a new trial. On July 17,
2008, defendant filed a motion to vacate sentence pursuant
to 28 U.S.C. § 2255, asserting claims of invalid indictment;
ineffective assistance of trial counsel; ineffective assistance
of appellate counsel; illegal search; denial of impartial
jury, right to compulsory process, right to confrontation,
and discovery of exculpatory evidence; and prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
And in Ground Three, he contends that he was denied
a fair trial by prosecutorial misconduct and malicious
prosecution.
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendant next contends that the prosecutor committed
misconduct in several respects.
allegation_sentence_4:
First, he contends that the
prosecutor suppressed exculpatory evidence and presented
perjured testimony
allegation_sentence_5:
Second, he contends that the prosecutor
intimidated a witness into invoking his Fifth Amendment
privilege against self-incrimination.
allegation_sentence_6:
Third, he argues that
the prosecutor made improper statements during closing
argument
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Here, defendant has failed to show either that the government
suppressed evidence within the meaning of Brady or
knowingly presented perjured testimony
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Therefore, defendant cannot show that the
prosecution unconstitutionally suppressed this evidence, or
that it constituted material, exculpatory evidence under
Brady.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Likewise, the prosecutor did not suppress evidence
by failing to grant McCarthy immunity, nor did McCarthy's
invocation of his right to remain silent deprive defendant
of a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Finally, defendant has failed to establish that the
prosecutor knowingly presented any perjured testimony

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Ninth Circuit
attorneys_judges:
Harry E. Claiborne, Las Vegas, Nev., for defendant-appellant//
Raymond D. Pike, Asst. U. S. Atty., Reno, Nev., for plaintiff-appellee//
HUFSTEDLER, SNEED and KENNEDY, Circuit
Judges
geography_entities: Mexico//
allegation_sentence_1:
On this appeal we must decide, first, whether the perjury
prosecution was barred either by the doctrine of collateral
estoppel or by the prosecutorial misconduct and, second,
if not so barred, whether there was sufficient evidence
introduced at the perjury trial to establish the materiality of
the allegedly false testimony in the initial trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Appellant also alleges that prosecutorial misconduct in the
first trial (1) in using perjured testimony from Finefrock and
(2) in failing to reveal a tape of a conversation between
Finefrock and Dipp, pursuant to a broad discovery order,
should bar the subsequent perjury prosecution.
allegation_sentence_3:
Appellant further argues that the governmental
misconduct here denied him the effective assistance of
counsel, since if everything had been disclosed his counsel
would have advised him not to take the stand.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
There is no evidence that the prosecutor knew of the tape's
existence and intentionally withheld it in order to induce
Dipp to commit perjury.
misconduct_determination_term2: no evidence that the prosecutor knew
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We reject this
argument

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit
attorneys_judges: DeMascio, J.// KENNEDY, MILBURN and GUY, Circuit Judges//
geography_entities:
United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Michigan//Troy Police Department
allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, defendant contends:
(1) that remarks by the prosecutor constituted prosecutorial
misconduct and denied him a fair trial; (2) that the District
Court's statements to the jury panel during voir dire also
resulted in denial of his right to a fair trial; and (3) that he was
denied effective assistance of counsel at trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Initially, the defendant contends that the government
made improper statements during its opening and closing
arguments which denied the defendant his constitutional right
to a fair trial.
allegation_term_2:
government
made improper statements during its opening and closing
arguments
allegation_sentence_3:
Since no contemporaneous objections were made, this panel
reviews the allegation of prosecutorial misconduct for plain
error.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Finding, to the
extent there was error in the conduct of the trial, it was either
waived or harmless, we affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The reference to machine guns was arguably
improper, however, the error is not plain nor does it meet the
standard which would justify reversal.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
To the extent the prosecutor raised a point not argued
by defense counsel, the prosecutor's rebuttal comment was
improper.
misconduct_determination_term3:
the prosecutor's rebuttal comment was
improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
This statement simply was not egregious
and did not undermine the jury's ability to judge the evidence
fairly.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Thus, while a few of the statements by the prosecutor were
inappropriate, none, either alone or together, reached the
egregious level required to reverse a conviction for plain
error.
misconduct_determination_term5:
a few of the statements by the prosecutor were
inappropriate
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Accordingly, the judgment of the District Court is
AFFIRMED.

allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, Caldwell raises the following issues, whether: (1)
the Government failed to provide discovery; (2) the district
court erred by denying Caldwell's motion to withdraw his
guilty plea; (3) the district court erred at sentencing by
relying on evidence withheld by the Government; (4) his
sentence was reasonable; and (5) the Government committed
prosecutorial misconduct *820 at sentencing.
allegation_sentence_2:
Next, Caldwell alleges that his eight-four-month sentence
is unreasonable.
allegation_sentence_3:
Third, there is insufficient record evidence to support Caldwell's claim that the Government
withheld evidence used against him at sentencing.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
First, we find that the district court did not abuse its discretion
by delaying Caldwell's sentencing hearing so that his counsel
could be sure he received the disputed discovery items.
misconduct_determination_term1: court did not abuse its discretion
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Second, we find no abuse of discretion in the district court's
decision to deny Caldwell's motion to withdraw his plea.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Finally, we find Caldwell's claims of prosecutorial
misconduct without foundation.
misconduct_determination_term3:
claims of prosecutorial
misconduct without foundation

allegation_sentence_1:
Azubike's second argument on appeal is that the prosecutor's
misstatements prejudiced the outcome of the case, warranting
a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Here it is clear that the prosecutor's
statements were incorrect.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The government admits that
this recitation of the evidence was factually inaccurate.
See Appellee's Br. at 29.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accordingly, the misstatements
constituted prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
However, the prosecutor made the misstatement
twice in front of the jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
This error
was compounded when the prosecutor later interrupted the
court's jury instruction.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
However, since there
was no such correction, and since the evidence was close and
the misstatement went to a central issue and was repeated,
we conclude that “the prosecutor's misconduct ‘so poisoned
the well’ that the trial's outcome was likely affected, thus
warranting a new trial.”
notes: do we include terms for dissenting opinions that would not reverse conviction due to prosecutorial misconduct?

allegation_sentence_1:
Gutierrez alleges three different instances of prosecutorial
misconduct that he claims tainted his trial.
allegation_sentence_2:

cross-examination, the prosecutor improperly asked him to
comment on Agent Frilles' veracity.
allegation_sentence_3:
Gutierrez maintains that the prosecutor made two statements
during summation that had the effect of misleading the jury
regarding the government's burden to prove its case beyond
a reasonable doubt.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the foregoing reasons, the judgment and sentence of the
trial court should be AFFIRMED.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The prosecutor's questions do not warrant reversal.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Still, even if the trial court stopped the prosecutor from
improperly using Gutierrez's silence against him, it was
inappropriate for the prosecutor to start down that road in
the first place.

defendant:
First Lieutenant Timothy J. RUSHATZ, XXX–

attorneys_judges:

geography_entities: Fort Knox, Kentucky//
allegation_sentence_1:
Appellant alleges that trial counsel engaged in prosecutorial
misconduct by making disparaging and disruptive facial
gestures during the direct examination of defense witnesses.
allegation_sentence_2:
Although the record contains no other indication of improper
conduct by trial counsel, appellant has submitted to this court
two affidavits by individuals who attended the trial and who
aver that trial counsel made other gestures, including “looks
of disgust and/or disbelief” that the military judge could not
see, but which were visible to the panel members.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Accordingly, we need only examine the two instances of
improper behavior on the part of the trial counsel appearing in
the record to determine whether prosecutorial misconduct
occurred.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Considered in context, these two instances simply
do not rise to the level of an intentional and underhanded
effort to convince the members of appellant's guilt or to
discredit witnesses.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Further,
we find no prejudice to the accused on the basis of trial
counsel's behavior.

the district court erred in denying his petition because
the Government committed prosecutorial misconduct by

misconduct_determination_sentence1:

comments on closing argument did not substantially affect

did not have a substantial
prejudicial effect
