allegation_sentence_1:
Petitioner claims ineffective assistance of counsel, citing his
attorney's (1) failure to clearly articulate the consequences
of his plea and sentencing range, (2) inadequate review
of discovery materials and failure to obtain all documents
provided by the United States, (3) inexperience and lack of
understanding of Petitioner's case combined with improper
delegation to an associate, (4) failure to raise the issue
of prosecutorial misconduct, and (5) failure to assert
Petitioner's acceptance of responsibility after he had pleaded
guilty in support of his claim.
allegation_term_1:
failure to raise the issue
of prosecutorial misconduct

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Fourth Circuit
attorneys_judges: David C. Sutton, James & Sutton, P.A., Greenville, North Carolina, for Appellant.//Frank D. Whitney, United States Attorney, John H. Bennett, John Stuart Bruce, Christine Witcover Dean, Assistant United States Attorneys, Raleigh, North Carolina, for Appellee.//Before WIDENER, WILLIAMS, and TRAXLER, Circuit Judges
geography_entities:
United States District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina//Greenville, North
Carolina//Raleigh, North Carolina
allegation_sentence_1:
The Court of Appeals held that district court did not abuse its discretion in denying defendant's motion for new
trial based on prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_term_1:
The sole issue on appeal is whether the district court should
have granted Cahoon's motion for a new trial because the
government improperly brought a number of guns into the
courtroom that proved to be inadmissible.
allegation_sentence_2: government improperly
allegation_term_2: To obtain a new trial on a claim of prosecutorial misconduct, a defendant must show that the prosecutor's conduct or remarks were improper, and that the conduct or remarks prejudicially affected his substantial rights so as to deprive him of a fair
allegation_sentence_3: prosecutor's conduct or remarks were improper
allegation_term_3:
government brought guns into
courtroom in good faith
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
District court did not abuse its discretion in
denying defendant's motion for new trial in
firearms prosecution due to fact that government
improperly brought number of guns into
courtroom that proved to be inadmissible, where
there was substantial evidence supporting jury's
guilty verdict, and government brought guns into
courtroom in good faith.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
District court did not abuse its discretion in
denying defendant's motion for new trial in
firearms prosecution due to fact that government
improperly brought number of guns into
courtroom that proved to be inadmissible, where
there was substantial evidence supporting jury's
guilty verdict, and government brought guns into
courtroom in good faith.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We find, as did the district court, that the prosecution
acted improperly in bringing the guns into the courtroom.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Given the substantial evidence supporting the jury's guilty verdict, the fact that the district court found as a fact that the guns were brought into the
courtroom in good faith, and taking the remaining factors
into consideration, we find that the prosecutor's conduct did
not prejudicially affect Cahoon's substantial rights so as to
deprive him of a fair trial.

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant argues, through new counsel 1
 appointed on
September 21, 2006, he is entitled to a new trial
because of “numerous improper examples of prosecutorial
misconduct.”
allegation_sentence_2:
More specifically,
Defendant states that the Assistant United States Attorney
improperly made comments to arouse the passions and
prejudices of the jury as well as shift the burden of proof.
allegation_sentence_3:
The Defendant asserts that the prosecutor
made excuses for the government's failure to meet its burden
re: lack of Defendant Wade's print on the weapon, by stating
the resources were going to Iraq.
allegation_sentence_4:
Defendant also asserts that
the government argued for a lessened burden by improperly
attacking defense counsel during closing with regard to
counsel's chart of legal standards and its misrepresentation
of the elements of proof. F
allegation_sentence_5:
Defendant argues again
that the government vouched for Officer Aparicio's credibility when the prosecutor told the jury his testimony was consistent
and that he was a credible witness.
allegation_sentence_6:
Defendant additionally suggests that the government did
not disclose all Brady materials in this case and that the
government opposed the gathering of new evidence.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Despite Defendant's suggestion that the prosecutor
attacked the credibility of defense counsel and told the jury
not to trust defense counsel, the Court does not find in the
record that the prosecutor told the jury not to trust defense
counsel or acted in an inappropriate manner as Defendant
suggests.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Despite Defendant's suggestion that the prosecutor
attacked the credibility of defense counsel and told the jury
not to trust defense counsel, the Court does not find in the
record that the prosecutor told the jury not to trust defense
counsel or acted in an inappropriate manner as Defendant
suggests.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The Court cannot conclude that comments made
by government counsel rose to the level of legal prejudice
precluding a fair trial in this case.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The Court cannot conclude that comments made
by government counsel rose to the level of legal prejudice
precluding a fair trial in this case.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Defendant's re-argument that the prosecutor improperly
vouched for or attempted to bolster the testimony of
a government witness in arguments to the jury is not
convincing.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
The Court does not find any prosecutorial misconduct with
respect to the release of these items

case_outcome: affirm in part, reverse in part and remanded for evidentiary hearing
allegation_sentence_1:
Westerdahl argues that his due process right to a fair
trial was violated by the government's failure to grant use
immunity to proposed defense witness Artie Goldsberry.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The use
of this testimony, while effectively denying Westerdahl the
right to contradict it with Goldsberry's testimony, may have
distorted the fact-finding process, and an evidentiary hearing
should have been held to determine whether the denial of use
immunity for Goldsberry denied Westerdahl his due process
rights.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
A prosecutor's refusal to immunize a defendant's proposed
witness is not misconduct unless the refusal intentionally
distorts the fact-finding process.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
For the government to grant
immunity to a witness in order to obtain his testimony, while
denying immunity to a defense witness whose testimony
would directly contradict that of the government witness, is
the type of fact-finding distortion we intended to prevent in
Lord.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
In my view, no
prosecutorial misconduct occurred here.

allegation_sentence_1:
Second, he
claims he was denied a constitutionally fair trial because the
prosecutor vouched for the truthfulness of the government's
witnesses during closing argument.
allegation_sentence_2:
Mr. Broomfield claims the district court erred by failing to
sustain an objection to the government's closing argument,
which he says impermissibly offered personal opinion as
to the truthfulness of its witnesses, Agent Thrower and
Shyndona Dickerson
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Under these circumstances, we conclude the prosecutor's
closing statements were not so egregious as to influence the
jury to convict Mr. Broomfield on improper grounds.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
For the foregoing reasons, the district court's order denying
the motion to suppress and denying Mr. Broomfield a new
trial are AFFIRMED.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
As
the district court properly noted, however, even assuming
the government's argument in this case was improper, it
does not warrant a new trial unless it influenced the jury's
*1277 verdict.
misconduct_determination_term3: does not warrant a new trial
notes:

we want to take this opportunity to advise prosecutors
against what we perceive to be an increasing willingness to
unnecessarily push the envelope of improper vouching"

allegation_sentence_1:
Fell raises sixteen claims of ineffective assistance of
counsel that individually or cumulatively require vacating
his convictions and sentence and ordering a new trial;
eight claims of prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2:
In addition to his claim of ineffective assistance
of counsel, Fell claims that the government committed
misconduct with respect to the Eike assault.
allegation_sentence_3:
Fell alleges that the
failure to disclose Pelkey's history of misconduct was a Brady
violation.
allegation_sentence_4:
This claim asserts that counsel for the
government misstated the law, misstated the evidence,
and made inflammatory and impermissible remarks in
their summations.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Although not every error, even in combination, warrants a
new trial, see Fell, 531 F.3d at 233, the cumulative effect
of alleged multiple instances of prosecutorial misconduct
presents a plausible non-frivolous claim that does not warrant
summary dismissal.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
If favorable evidence
was withheld, then the Court will assess the collective impact
of the suppressed evidence, in determining whether there was
prejudice.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Within thirty days of the filing of this order
the parties will submit for the Court's approval a discovery
plan with respect to the remaining ineffective assistance of
counsel and prosecutorial misconduct claims.

allegation_sentence_1:
Sutherland also alleges that there was prosecutorial
misconduct in the form of presenting perjurous testimony,
material misstatements of evidence, and use of inflamatory
tactics (Claim IX).
allegation_sentence_2:
Sutherland argues that the prosecution violated the rules
of discovery by failing to disclose expert testimony and
identification testimony prior to the testimony at trial (Claim
VIII).
allegation_sentence_3:
Sutherland contends that the trial court improperly admitted
the prejudicial identification testimony by the eyewitness
(Claim II).
allegation_term_3:
improperly admitted
the prejudicial identification testimony
allegation_sentence_4:
Sutherland argues that the trial court erred by giving improper
jury instructions regarding the weighing of identification
testimony and the reasonable doubt standard (Claims V and
VI).
allegation_sentence_5:
Sutherland argues that he was denied effective assistance of
counsel at trial and denied the right to prepare his defense
because the trial court held his trial counsel in contempt,
jailed his counsel for one night, and further restricted his
counsel to the courtroom on the following day.
allegation_sentence_6: Sutherland argues that he received ineffective assistance of counsel at trial due to the failure of his trial counsel to object to prosecutorial misconduct (Claim XI), and that he received ineffective assistance of counsel on appeal due to the failure of his appellate counsel to raise the prosecutorial misconduct argument on appeal (Claim XII).
allegation_term_6: failure of his trial counsel to object to prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We have also considered
Sutherland's arguments and conclude that even if the claim
was not procedurally defaulted, the claim lacks any merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Even if such a claim could
be construed from the Petition, it is procedurally defaulted
and Sutherland has not provided sufficient justification for
this court to hear the claim despite the procedural default.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
However, Sutherland fails to explain why his
counsel could not speak with witnesses and discuss the
defense strategy with Sutherland in the courtroom during
a recess.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
There is
ample evidence in the record to support this conclusion
and there is not sufficient evidence to support a contrary
conclusion.
misconduct_determination_term4:
not sufficient evidence to support a contrary
conclusion

allegation_sentence_1:
Dominic Barrera appeals his conviction for two counts of
assault, arguing that two instances of alleged prosecutorial
misconduct entitle him to a new trial
allegation_sentence_2:
Barrera first argues that the prosecutor acted improperly by
eliciting testimony that he contends referred to allegations of
domestic violence committed by him against Ms. LaPointe.
allegation_sentence_3:
The second alleged instance of misconduct occurred during
the rebuttal portion of the Government's closing argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In this case, however, we believe that
Barrera has overstated the cumulative effect of the alleged
improprieties.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because we find it unlikely that the jury understood Ms.
LaPointe's testimony to refer to allegations of past domestic
violence, Barrera's argument that the prosecutor's question
“set the stage for further misconduct” in the closing argument
that resulted in “a compounded cumulative prejudicial effect”
fails to persuade.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Accordingly,
we find the evidence against Barrera to be overwhelming, and
we conclude that even if either or both instances of alleged
misconduct were actually improper, such misconduct was
unlikely to have affected the verdict.
misconduct_determination_term4: unlikely to have affected the verdict
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Even assuming that the prosecutor's challenged conduct
was improper, considering the strength of the evidence, the
cumulative effect of the two alleged improprieties was not
so prejudicial that Barrera “was unable to obtain a fair trial.”

be without merit, counsel submits the following issues for
review: 1) whether Brown received ineffective assistance of
counsel; and 2) whether Brown's guilty plea was coerced by
prosecutorial misconduct.

misconduct_determination_sentence1:

misconduct_determination_sentence2:

and affirm the district court's judgment pursuant to Rule 34(j)
(2)(C), Rules of the Sixth Circuit

defendant: Dean William COTNAM and Phillip Zadurski, Defendants
attorneys_judges:
Thomas J. Curran, J.//Flaum, Circuit Judge//Isaias Ortiz, Thomas P. Schneider, Michele Leslie (argued), Office of the U.S. Atty., Milwaukee, WI, for U.S.//
Robin Shellow, Angela Conrad (argued), Milwaukee, WI, for Dean W. Cotnam//James R. Troupis, Timothy Finley (argued), Michael, Best & Friedrich, Madison, WI, for Phillip Zadurski.//POSNER, Chief Judge//FLAUM and KANNE, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: Milwaukee, Wisconsin//
allegation_sentence_1: He appeals the LSD convictions, claiming that prosecutorial misconduct, particularly remarks that implicitly commented upon his failure to take the stand, resulted in a constitutionally deficient trial.
allegation_sentence_2: Zadurski argues that various remarks during the prosecutor's closing argument unconstitutionally infringed upon his Fifth Amendment right not to testify.
allegation_sentence_3:
He also argues that the
prosecutor's vouching for the strength of the government's
case and the testimony of David Martin violated his due
process right to a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_4:
As the *498 Supreme Court recognized in Darden v.
Wainwright, 477 U.S. 168, 181–82, 106 S.Ct. 2464, 2471–
72, 91 L.Ed.2d 144 (1986), improper prosecutorial comments
that do not implicate specific constitutional rights of the
accused, such as the right to counsel and the right to remain
silent, are evaluated to determine whether they deprived the
defendant of a fair trial
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We applaud the district court's vigilance in calling the mistrial hearing sua sponte and in specifically noting the prosecutor's numerous improper remarks, without the aid of any objections by defense counsel.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: At least some of the prosecutor's remarks about uncontroverted evidence unconstitutionally infringed
misconduct_determination_term2: upon Zadurski's Fifth Amendment right not to testify.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: unconstitutionally infringed upon
misconduct_determination_term3:
Because
the prosecutor's comments infringed upon the defendant's
right not to testify and were not harmless—at least not in
combination with the extensive vouching—we conclude that
the district court abused its discretion in not declaring a
mistrial for Zadurski.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: prosecutor's comments infringed
misconduct_determination_term4:
While various of the aforementioned
remarks by the prosecutor standing alone would not have
*501 necessitated a new trial, the combined impact of all of
the remarks mandated that a mistrial be declared.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: combined impact

geography_entities:
Marion,
IA//Linn County, Iowa// Iowa District
Court
allegation_sentence_1:
Dicus next asserted that he wished to argue the
“reasonableness” of the sentence in light of the misconduct on
the part of the prosecution in breaching the plea agreement
allegation_term_1:
misconduct on
the part of the prosecution
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
I now enter this
memorandum opinion and order to memorialize more fully
my rationale for granting a sentence reduction as a targeted
remedy for serious and recidivist prosecutorialmisconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In light of the prosecution's egregious misconduct, and
the relief from that misconduct already provided-however
serendipitously-by the Supreme Court's decision in Begay,
Dicus argued for some “positive benefit” in the form of a
sentence at the low end of the advisory guidelines range.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Thus, I find that there was not only a breach of the plea
agreement by the prosecution, but an egregious breach.
notes:
KEY CASE — outlines issues of sanctions + disincentives for defense attorneys to even raise prosecutorial misconduct: "However, I note that at no time during the sentencing hearing did the prosecution object to my sentence at the low end of the guidelines range based upon the serious and recidivist prosecutorialmisconduct. [....] Because of the seriousness of the prosecution's breach of a plea agreement, it is unfortunate that such incidents are not unheard of, either in this Circuit or this District. Indeed, just before the breach of *1151 the plea agreement occurred in this case, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals held on October 12, 2007, in United States v. Mosley, 505 F.3d 804 (8th Cir.2007), that the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Iowa had also breached a plea agreement in another case before Chief Judge Reade by making improper sentencing arguments [....] Both the interests of justice and recognition of the duties of the prosecution in relation to promises made in the negotiation of pleas of guilty require a response to the repeated misconduct of the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Iowa. [....] No other sanction would be a deterrent to official misconduct, because a fine against the prosecutor personally would inflict a private sanction for official misconduct, and a fine against the United States would be no deterrent at all, no matter how large." ; "Even in cases in which a defendant may have some incentive to assert prosecutorialmisconduct, it is rare
that the defendant's counsel does not have some disincentives
for asserting such a claim arising from the possibility of
friction in future relations with the prosecutor's office in
question, which could result in a detriment to other clients." ; "Nor are these the only two incidents of serious prosecutorialmisconduct in this District during my tenure as a United
States District Court Judge. Although there are other examples of serious prosecutorialmisconduct in this District, it is
not necessary to catalogue them for purposes of the present ruling"

allegation_sentence_1:
Crosgrove does articulate one specific argument with
regard to prosecutorial misconduct: that the prosecutor
improperly stated that shredded documents found in the
dumpster behind Crosgrove's office were likely AREA/Noble
papers that Crosgrove had previously stored at his home and
sought to dispose.
allegation_sentence_2:
On appeal, Crosgrove argues that the trial court
abused its discretion in excluding Murphy's testimony.
Crosgrove contends that the testimony was clearly relevant
because “Murphy would have offered the jury an expert's
understanding of how claims adjusters operate thereby
neutralizing the government's case.”
allegation_sentence_3:
Crosgrove also renews several evidentiary objections from
his trial and raises two new trial issues on appeal: he argues
that certain evidence introduced at trial was gathered in
violation of the Fourth Amendment and that the prosecutor
engaged in misconduct.
allegation_term_3:
evidence introduced at trial was gathered in
violation of the Fourth Amendment
allegation_sentence_4:
Crosgrove also argues that his trial
counsel was ineffective and that the district court committed
several errors in calculating Crosgrove's sentence.
allegation_sentence_5:
Crosgrove summarily argues in his reply brief that he
was unjustifiably sentenced to a longer prison term than
Haukedahl.
allegation_term_5: unjustifiably sentenced to a longer prison term
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Therefore, even if the statements had been improper,
that impropriety would likely have been corrected by the
jury instruction, and Crosgrove's claim of prosecutorial
misconduct fails.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Therefore, Crosgrove's
argument that the district court committed error in applying an
amount-of-loss enhancement without a jury finding is without
merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Therefore, while he did not assist
in the creation of Midwest, his role in the conspiracy was
certainly not isolated from the use of offshore entities, and the district court did not commit error in applying a sophisticated means
enhancement.
misconduct_determination_term3: district court did not commit error
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Therefore, Crosgrove's ineffective assistance
of counsel claim is premature.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Crosgrove's conviction for conspiracy to commit mail/wire
fraud is affirmed, while *668 his conviction for conspiracy
to commit money laundering is vacated.
misconduct_determination_term5:
conviction for conspiracy
to commit money laundering is vacated
notes: Mail fraud and money laundering can be classified as either, right? I didn't know where exactly to determine whether it was a civil case or a criminal case.

allegation_sentence_1:
GROUND THREE: Mr. Owens was denied a fair trial due
to prosecutorial misconduct

broadened the indictment and the material elements of
the crime during both the opening and closing arguments.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Like the due process issue analyzed above, Mr. Owens
should have, but did not, raise his prosecutorial misconduct
argument on appeal. Accordingly, he has procedurally
defaulted this ground for relief.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Consequently, Mr. Owens' third ground for relief is meritless; thus, it is denied
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In fact, prosecutors, like defense attorneys, are
permitted to make reasonable inferences from the evidence.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The Government concedes that it introduced
circumstantial evidence of the fact that Mr. Owens possessed
a gun and asked the jury to consider that fact when
determining whether he possessed the ammunition in the
indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Consequently, Mr. Owens' third ground for relief is meritless;
thus, it is denied

allegation_sentence_1:
At issue here, however, is more
than merely a Brady violation
allegation_sentence_2:
After some discussion between the Court and counsel,
Defendant made an oral motion for a mistrial with prejudice.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Prosecution's Explanation of Misconduct and
Objection to Retrial
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Finding that the government had elicited testimony to the
jury regarding Mr. Archibald's address that it had reason to
know was incorrect, had repeatedly demonstrated a failure
to turn over evidence to defense counsel, and, thereby,
had irreparably prejudiced the Defendant, the Court granted
Defendant's oral motion for mistrial.
notes:
"If this were a civil case, I would have no compunction in assessing costs against a law firm that behaved as the government did in this case. The law, however, would require me to impose such a sanction against the prosecutor personally and I am hesitant to take such a punitive measure against one individual. It is my distinct hope and expectation that the government will in the future refrain from the sort of misconduct that characterized its prosecution of this case and will
take appropriate steps specifically here."

allegation_sentence_1:
Appellants argue, however, that the successive
Oklahoma mistrials reflect a pattern of prosecutorial
misconduct that should satisfy the Kennedy standard.
allegation_sentence_2:
Finally, Kirk and Ivy allege that the government
should be equitably estopped by reason of the Idaho plea
bargaining negotiations to prosecute the Arkansas indictment.
allegation_sentence_3:
Appellants argue that the two requested mistrials
resulted from a pattern of prosecutorial overreaching that
should preclude their retrial on the same charges in Arkansas.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
But we find no such evidence in this case, in
which the successive mistakes were made during discovery
by different prosecutors, and there is nothing to suggest
that the prosecution provoked either mistrial because the
trial was proceeding favorably to defendants.
misconduct_determination_term1:
nothing to suggest
that the prosecution provoked either mistrial
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Therefore, we agree with the district court that prior
statements allegedly made during the course of the Idaho
negotiations cannot be the basis for an estoppel.
misconduct_determination_term2: cannot be the basis for an estoppel
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Finally, we find it significant that appellants failed
to make this argument to the district judge in Oklahoma,
who was in the best position to judge whether the Kennedy
standard had been violated.
misconduct_determination_term3:
appellants failed
to make this argument to the district judge

allegation_sentence_1: In the present case, movant alleges several points of error: (1) he was denied the right to allocution; (2) he was denied due process due to prosecutorial misconduct of introducing “false and fraudulent” testimony; and (3) he was denied the right to effective assistance of counsel for failure to: (a) object to inadmissible hearsay testimony, (b) object to the prosecution's appeal to jurors to act as conscious of community, (c) object to prosecution's improper vouching and bolstering, (d) object to inadmissible expert and lay witness testimony, (e) investigate the phone number on allegedly consensual monitored calls and obtain evidence to impeach the Government's cell phone evidence, (f) challenge venue and request a venue instruction at trial, (g) object to flight evidence, (h) move for judgment of acquittal, (i) object to Apprendi error at sentencing, (j) raise the issue that the Government did not prove whether the offense involved actual methamphetamine and object to 2.5 kilos of methamphetamine, and (k) properly request a downward departure for the escape enhancement at sentencing.
allegation_sentence_2:
Movant asserts his counsel was ineffective for failing
to object to inadmissible hearsay under Federal Rule
of Evidence 804(b)(3).
allegation_sentence_3:
Movant next asserts his counsel was ineffective for failing to
object to evidence of movant's escape and for failing to object
to the flight instruction.
allegation_sentence_4:
Movant next asserts his counsel was ineffective for
failing to challenge venue and request a venue instruction.
allegation_sentence_5:
Movant further argues that, at sentencing, counsel was
ineffective for failing to raise the issue that the government
did not prove whether the conspiracy involved a total of
2.05 kilograms of actual methamphetamine or a mixture of
methamphetamine and that counsel did not object to the
government's use of the 2.05 kilograms of methamphetamine
allegation_term_5:
failing to raise the issue that the government
did not prove
allegation_sentence_6:
Movant alleges that the cumulative errors of ineffective
assistance of counsel denied him a fair trial and denied
him due process, warranting a reversal of his conviction.
allegation_term_6:
cumulative errors of ineffective
assistance of counsel denied him a fair trial
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Moreover, even if this ground were properly before the court, it would be without merit because, for reasons set out briefly below, movant fails to establish a meritorious claim of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term1: fails to establish a meritorious claim of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
As such, movant's counsel cannot be deemed deficient
for failing to raise this issue.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Movant's claim that his counsel was insufficient for
failing to properly request a downward departure pursuant to
U.S.S.G. § 5G1.3(c), for the escape conviction at sentencing,
should be denied as without merit.
misconduct_determination_term3: should be denied as without merit
notes: Grounds 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 are DENIED. An evidentiary hearing will be necessary to resolve the remaining issue raised by Petitioner in Ground 1.

disagrees with Mr. Poulin's
strongly-worded contention that the Magistrate Judge erred.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Mr. Poulin's
trial counsel vigorously and professionally defended him.

allegation_sentence_1: In this case, defendant-appellant Curtis Babb claims that his conviction for committing perjury before a United States grand jury is fundamentally unfair because the prosecutor falsely assured him, immediately before his grand jury testimony and in the presence of the grand jury, that he was neither a subject nor a target of the grand jury's inquiry.
allegation_sentence_2:
Babb argues that the prosecutor's
misrepresentations taint any supposed waiver by him of his
fifth amendment privilege against self-incrimination because,
under the circumstances, his waiver cannot be found to be
knowing and intelligent.
allegation_term_2:
prosecutor's
misrepresentations taint any supposed waiver
allegation_sentence_3:
Nevertheless, he seeks to excuse
this perjury by pointing out that the prosecutor affirmatively
misrepresented to him that he was neither a target nor
a subject of the grand jury investigation.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
. Because we find
that Babb's perjury and his subsequent conviction for that
crime were not a “product” of the prosecutorial misconduct,
this is not a proper case in which to exercise our supervisory
powers
misconduct_determination_term1: not a “product” of the prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In sum, we find the prosecutor's
behavior to be more than “quite troublesome;” we find it to
be unprofessional and worthy of severe condemnation
misconduct_determination_term2:
prosecutor's
behavior to be more than “quite troublesome
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We have considered Babb's other arguments and find
them without merit.

allegation_sentence_1:

The Petitioner alleges that (5) the
District Court erred when it miscalculated his sentence
under the Sentencing Guidelines because the offense
level was increased by two-levels due to the presence
of a firearm and (6) the Government committed
prosecutorial misconduct by failing to submit any
evidence at the sentencing hearing about the Petitioner's

counsel failed to file a notice of appeal and (2) counsel

unreasonable sentence

argument is baseless, however, because the government did

allegation_sentence_1:
In their brief, defendants argue that the government's “prosecutorial negligent conduct” in bringing the second superseding
indictment (without including the proper robbery) amounts to prosecutorial misconduct and that the resulting delay was
used by the government to widen the scope of admissible evidence by adding the March robbery in the fourth superseding
indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because the finding relating to any prosecutorial
misconduct was premised solely on the government's
disruption of the district court's calendar (without any intent
to harm the court), that finding is clearly erroneous, rendering
the district court's dismissal of the indictment an abuse of
discretion.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The district court clearly erred in finding the prejudice
requirement met, and therefore abused its discretion in
dismissing the indictment with prejudice.

District of North Carolina, Charlotte, NC, for Respondents.//RICHARD L. VOORHEES, District Judge.
geography_entities: Raleigh, NC//Charlotte, NC
allegation_sentence_1:
On October 15, 2003 Petitioner filed the instant motion
alleging that his trial counsel was ineffective and the
prosecution engaged in prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Petitioner alleges that the government engaged in
prosecutorial misconduct by fabricating and presenting
false testimony and by invading the Petitioner's attorney client
privilege.
allegation_sentence_3:
With respect to fabricating and presenting false testimony,
Petitioner alleges that the government must have forced
his co-defendants into making false statements against him
because their first two statements did not implicate him in
the robbery and then each made a third statement following
a plea agreement which included an agreement to testify
against Petitioner, in which they each altered their original
statements and implicated Petitioner in the robbery.
allegation_sentence_4:
Next, Petitioner claims that the prosecutor invaded
Petitioner's attorney client privilege by calling Petitioner's
first attorney, Mr. Exum, to testify during Petitioner's motion
to withdraw his plea.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Upon careful consideration of the foregoing documents and
the controlling legal precedent, the Court concludes that the
Petitioner's Motion to Vacate should be dismissed. That is, the
Court finds that the instant record makes it clear that counsel
was not deficient and that the prosecution did not engage in
prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The
mere fact that a co-defendant changed his story does not
equal prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Petitioner's claim in this
regard is completely conclusory and again in sharp contrast
to his admission of guilt at his Rule 11 hearing. Petitioner's
claim of prosecutorial misconduct based on fabricating and
presenting false testimony is DENIED.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
This claim is wholly unsupported by
the record.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Therefore, Petitioner's claim that the government
interfered with the attorney client privilege is DENEID.

California, 386 U.S. 738, 744, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 18 L.Ed.2d 493 (1967), asserting that there are no meritorious issues for appeal, but addressing the possibility that Brown's sentence was improper and that Dupont was provided ineffective assistance of counsel or that his case was affected by prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: In his written plea agreement, Dupont waived his right to appeal, except for claims of ineffective assistance of counsel or prosecutorial misconduct. We find this waiver valid.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Further, our review of the record discloses no prosecutorial misconduct.

allegation_sentence_1:
Relying on United States v. Serubo, 604 F.2d 807,
814-19 (3d Cir.1979), Busk urges that use of illegally
obtained evidence before a grand jury is a form of
prosecutorial misconduct which warrants the sanction of
dismissal of the indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
If, following the grant of a suppression
motion, a federal prosecutor were to present the same
evidence to a grand jury, the application of the Serubo
supervisory power rule might well be appropriate. But where,
as here, the illegally obtained evidence is presented to the
grand jury long before any suppression motion is made, that
rule has no application. Thus the trial court did not err in
denying Busk's motion to quash the indictment.
notes: get his original appeal, which granted new trial

allegation_sentence_1:
We have examined each of the instances that Byrd
claims as examples of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Some of
these instances involved questions that violated evidentiary
rules, e.g. asking leading questions, but did not constitute
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The others, although arguably or undoubtedly
improper, either (1) resulted in testimony that did not harm
the defendant or (2) were not allowed by the court.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: We therefore affirm the judgment of conviction.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We therefore conclude that a new trial is
not required.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
While we do not condone the
questions suggesting that the defendant was involved in the
drug trade and that he was a member of a gang, questions
are not evidence.

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant's
Motion To Dismiss Due To Prosecutorial Misconduct
Before The Grand Jury (“Motion to Dismiss”)
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant requests that the Court dismiss the indictment
returned against him due to prosecutorial misconduct before
the grand jury
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendant claims that the Assistant United
States Attorney (“AUSA”) improperly presented hearsay
evidence to the grand jury and led the grand jury to
believe that Defendant had threatened his daughter, Brooke
Boettcher, a key witness against Defendant.
allegation_sentence_4:
Defendant also suggests that the use of hearsay evidence
before the grand jury constituted or at least contributed
to prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court finds that Defendant has not proven the
existence of prosecutorial misconduct under the standard
outlined by the Sixth Circuit in Griffith.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
First, Defendant
has not addressed the issue of whether “ ‘prosecutorial
misconduct is a long-standing or common problem in grand
jury proceedings in [the] district.’ ”
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In the present case, it
appears clear that the AUSA did not attempt to deceive the
grand jury as to the quality of the hearsay testimony.

allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, Demby alleges prosecutorial misconduct and
also challenges certain evidentiary decisions by the district
court, the sufficiency of the evidence, her sentence, and the
district court's decision not to grant her a new trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
She contends that the prosecutor's statement
constituted misconduct and that the court also erred by not
giving a curative instruction at that moment to the jury.
allegation_sentence_3:
(5) asked Demby a series of “isn't
it true” questions on cross-examination, which were designed
to inflame the jury and depict Demby as loathsome and in
denial
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We find
that all of Demby's claims are meritless.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
However, Demby failed to establish that
the Government's characterization of the “crossed signals”
prejudiced her and, in light of the overwhelming evidence
against her, the Government's characterization did not render
the trial fundamentally unfair.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accordingly, because all of Demby's claims are meritless,
we affirm her conviction and sentence and affirm the district
court's decision not to grant her a new trial.

S.D. New York.
attorneys_judges: Hon. HAROLD BAER, JR., District Judge.//Antonio Scott (“Petitioner”), proceeding pro se
geography_entities: New York
alleged_pros_misconduct:
Although it is not clear whether Petitioner brings separate
ineffective assistance of counsel claims and prosecutorial
misconduct claims, both types of claims will be considered.
allegation_sentence_1:
In the context of an alleged failure to object to prosecutorial
misconduct, “if there is no merit to the underlying charge
of prosecutorial misconduct, an attorney is not ineffective
for his or her failure to object on such grounds.”
allegation_sentence_2:
The Prosecutor's Purported Expression of Personal
Knowledge of the Defendant's Guilt and Endorsement of
Two Witnesses
allegation_sentence_3:
Petitioner first argues that his counsel should have objected
to statements by the prosecutor that, he says, expressed
the government's personal knowledge of his guilt and its
endorsement of two witnesses.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The underlying claim of prosecutorial misconduct
cannot be established because the prosecutor's statements
were neither patently improper nor prejudicial.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The
prosecutor's remarks during the opening statement, closing
statement, and rebuttal were not improper because—when
viewed in context—it was clear that the prosecutor was
making arguments based on the evidence rather than personal
convictions.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because Petitioner
cannot establish the underlying claim for prosecutorial
misconduct, his counsel could not have been ineffective
for failing to object that conduct
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Similarly, the prosecutor's comments concerning the
credibility of Rajiem Black and Stacy Roberts were not
improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Finally, even if the prosecutor's statements were improper,
they did not create substantial prejudice.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Nevertheless, there was no prosecutorial misconduct based
on these remarks.
notes: see issue re whether or not defendant alleged prosecutorial misconduct. court considered it.

allegation_sentence_1:
Herein the abovenamed Richard Kayne has pressed his
motion to dismiss this Indictment because of prosecutorial
misconduct as to the evidence presented—or, rather, not
presented—to the United States Grand Jury which returned
the charging instrument.
allegation_sentence_2:
The urging is that
what then and there occurred is exculpatory of any criminality
on the parts of Messrs. Kayne and Kalp and that, if such had
been presented to the Grand Jury, the latter would not have
indicted them
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Further, the contention is that such a quantum
of prosecutorial misconduct was inherent in such omission
that the Indictment should be dismissed as a prophylactic
sanction.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:

urgings for dismissal, but is the view that what occurred
pre–Indictment in and with the investigating agents and
the prosecutor amounts merely to misfeasance and does
not justify the pretrial dismissal of an indictment.

geography_entities: Atlanta, Georgia
allegation_sentence_1:
He contended that he had
been forced to move for a mistrial because of prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Alternatively, Wright requested dismissal of the
indictment directly because of the prosecutorial misconduct
which denied him a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
According to Wright, the Government engaged in the
following conduct which amounted to prosecutorial
overreaching: (1) the loss of a photospread shown to one
of the witnesses who identified Wright as the assailant,
(2) nondisclosure of the name of a witness who could
have testified that Wright was taking a shower at the
time of the murder, (3) nondisclosure of prison basketball
records which would have shown that Wright was not
playing basketball with the victim immediately before the
murder, (4) nondisclosure of the impeachable character of a
key Government witness, (5) introduction of contradictory
testimony that another key Government witness was in two
different places at the time of the murder and (6) improper
statements to the jury during trial and at closing argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Alternatively, assuming the Court had authority
to dismiss the indictment on grounds of prosecutorial
misconduct, the District Court found that no such misconduct
occurred.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
This error was not of the magnitude that
indicates a deliberate attempt by the prosecution to taint the
trial proceedings and force the defendant to request a mistrial.
misconduct_determination_term2: error was not of the magnitude
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Moreover, although it is possible that the inconsistency of this
evidence could have confused the jury, we re-emphasize that
it was impossible for Wright to know if this was the reason
they were unable to reach a verdict.
misconduct_determination_term3:
impossible for Wright to know if this was the reason
they were unable to reach a verdict

allegation_sentence_1:
Arias-Izquierdo also argues that his conviction should
be reversed because the district court erred in denying
his motion for mistrial, which was based on alleged
prosecutorial misconduct during closing arguments
allegation_sentence_2:
AriasIzquierdo
alleges two instances of prosecutorial misconduct
during closing arguments: first, he challenges the prosecutor's
statement that the evidence showed that Arias-Izquierdo was
“the person who made all the announcements, and this is the
person in the green shirt that also talked to Officer Madiedo,”
and second, he challenges the prosecutor's statement that
“there is no evidence of anyone else with a green shirt in
this case.”
allegation_sentence_3:
Arias-Izquierdo argues
that the prosecutor misstated the evidence and vouched for
witnesses, so his conviction must be reversed.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We find no merit in Arias-Izquierdo's contention that
the prosecutor's statements were improper or prejudicial.
notes: multiple defendants. some convictions affirmed. others vacated

allegation_sentence_1:
Dinzey then moved to dismiss the
indictment, arguing that the prosecutor deliberately provoked
a mistrial to preserve the opportunity for a second trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Dinzey argues that the prosecutor intentionally
acted to provoke a mistrial by eliciting testimony of a postarrest
statement defendant Francois made, thereby causing a
Bruton error.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We will affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
However, there is no evidence on this record
to indicate that the prosecutor did anything to provoke
a mistrial-indeed the *511 prosecutor opposed Dinzey's
motion.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because Dinzey moved for the mistrial and there is no
evidence of bad faith, his re-prosecution does not violate any
Constitutional proscription.

allegation_sentence_1:
Elias argues (1) that the
trial evidence was insufficient to establish the jurisdictional
element of the Hobbs Act conviction because the government
failed to prove the requisite effect on interstate commerce
and (2) that improper remarks made by the prosecutor during
rebuttal summation were prejudicial.
allegation_term_1: improper remarks made by the prosecutor
allegation_sentence_2:
Elias seeks a reversal of his conviction on the ground that
he was prejudiced by improper remarks in the prosecutor's
summation.
allegation_sentence_3:
To
prevail, Elias had to show that, absent the isolated impropriety
of the prosecutor in rebuttal summation (taken in the context
of the entire trial), Elias would not have been convicted.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
While
these remarks grossly misrepresented the point urged in the
defense summation, and were calculated to inflame the jury,
we conclude that no retrial is justified because (1) the remarks
were an aberration in an otherwise fair proceeding; (2) the
defense summation included comments on the same witness
that could fairly have provoked the prosecutor's “insult”
comment; (3) some steps were taken to mitigate any impact
of the remarks cited by the defendant; and (4) conviction was
certain even in the absence of the claimed misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term1: were calculated to inflame the jury
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
This mischaracterization
was clearly designed to inflame the passions
of the jury and was an improper tactic.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In sum, although the prosecutor's remarks were improper,
they did not result in substantial prejudice to Elias or deprive
him of a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term3: did not result in substantial prejudice
misconduct_determination_sentence4: For the foregoing reasons, we affirm

allegation_sentence_1:
whether prosecutorial misconduct deprived
defendant of a fair trial
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant Dandy argues that the government engaged in
prosecutorial misconduct which warrants a reversal of his
conviction.
allegation_sentence_3:
These instances can be grouped into five
categories: (1) inflammatory language which prejudiced the
jury against defendant, (2) gestures and facial expressions
calculated to *1352 be prejudicial to defendant, (3)
interjection by government counsel of himself as a witness
at trial and asking questions without a factual basis, (4)
interruptions designed to disrupt defense counsel, and (5)
improper comments on the evidence.
allegation_sentence_4:
These instances can be grouped into five
categories: (1) inflammatory language which prejudiced the
jury against defendant, (2) gestures and facial expressions
calculated to *1352 be prejudicial to defendant, (3)
interjection by government counsel of himself as a witness
at trial and asking questions without a factual basis, (4)
interruptions designed to disrupt defense counsel, and (5)
improper comments on the evidence.
allegation_sentence_5:
These instances can be grouped into five
categories: (1) inflammatory language which prejudiced the
jury against defendant, (2) gestures and facial expressions
calculated to *1352 be prejudicial to defendant, (3)
interjection by government counsel of himself as a witness
at trial and asking questions without a factual basis, (4)
interruptions designed to disrupt defense counsel, and (5)
improper comments on the evidence.
allegation_sentence_6:
As previously stated, defendant argues that the prosecutor
interjected himself as a witness in the trial and asked questions
for which there was absolutely no factual basis.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: It was improper for the prosecutor to state that Mr. McColgan is honest.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Moreover, while the prosecutor's statement was
improper, it was not as egregious as it might have been
had the prosecutor used the phrase “I believe” that Mr.
McColgan is honest.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Given the degree
of egregiousness of the prosecutor's statement, the weight
of the evidence against defendant, and the district court's
immediate curative instruction to the jury, the prosecutor's
misconduct did not constitute reversible error.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Given the degree
of egregiousness of the prosecutor's statement, the weight
of the evidence against defendant, and the district court's
immediate curative instruction to the jury, the prosecutor's
misconduct did not constitute reversible error.

decision_court:
United States District Court,
N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
attorneys_judges:
Alejandro Ruvalcaba, pro se, Hill-Hil, Galesburg, IL, //Notices
to Prisoner, Correspondence,// Carl Peter Clavelli, Attorney at
Law, Chicago, IL, for petitioner.//
Melville Nickerson, Rusin, Patton, Maciorowski & Friedman,
Ltd., Chicago, IL, for respondent.//LEFKOW, J.
geography_entities:
Chicago, IL//Hill
Correctional Center,
allegation_sentence_1:
In his habeas petition Ruvalcaba
argued that prosecutorial misconduct existed because of
the prosecutor's statements made in closing arguments.
allegation_sentence_2:
According to Ruvalcaba, the prosecutor incorrectly informed
the jury that the prosecution did not have the burden of
proving that Ruvalcaba's conduct was not justified.
allegation_sentence_3:
He also
asserts that this error was compounded when the prosecution
told the jury that it had to prove only two elements for a guilty
verdict of first degree murder when, in fact, the judge included
as a third element the requirement that the State prove beyond
a reasonable doubt that Ruvalcaba “was not justified in
using the force which he used.”
allegation_sentence_4:
Finally, Ruvalcaba asserts
that in rebuttal the prosecutor told the jury that Ruvalcaba
was attempting to put the State's witnesses on trial and
inappropriately told the jury that his defense counsel placed
witnesses on the stand to elicit sympathy in contradiction
to the instructions from the court.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
This court concluded that
the Illinois Appellate Court's decision that prosecutorial
misconduct was not present was not unreasonable.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Finally, this court noted that
given the amount of evidence presented against Ruvalcaba
at trial, he would not have been able to show that any
of the improper statements affected the jury's verdict.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
While Ruvalcaba's claim that
the prosecutor improperly told the jury that it only had to
prove two elements for first degree murder is somewhat
persuasive, given the fact that instructions were tendered
to the jury establishing the relevant standards of proof, see
United States v. Bell, 980 F.2d 1095, 1098 (7th Cir.1992)
(it is presumed that juries follow court directed instructions);
Hough v. Anderson, 272 F.3d 878, 902 (7th Cir.2001) (finding
that trial court's instructions put jury on notice that the
arguments were nothing more than counsel's interpretation of
the evidence), and given the Darden standard set out above,
the court does not believe its determination of the issue was
either debatable or wrong.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Wherefore, for the reasons set out above, Ruvalcaba's
motion for a COA is granted and denied in part [# 31]. A COA
is granted for his claim that his confession was involuntary,
but denied for his claim of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term4: denied for his claim of prosecutorial misconduct.

allegation_sentence_1:
Scott first contends that the government engaged
in prosecutorial misconduct by allegedly intercepting
subpoenas, obtaining his Fed.R.Crim.P. 17(b) motion, and
referencing false statements during closing argument.
allegation_sentence_2:
Scott next contends that the district court erred when it
admitted Fed.R.Evid. 404(b) evidence introduced by the
government.
allegation_sentence_3:
Scott next contends that the district court improperly amended
the indictment when it permitted the jury to return a guilty
verdict for only one one-hundred dollar counterfeit bill, when
the indictment charged him with uttering two one-hundred
dollar counterfeit bills.
allegation_sentence_4:
Scott finally contends that the district court abused its
discretion when it imposed the terms of his supervised
release.
allegation_term_4:
imposed the terms of his supervised
release
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Because the record shows that Scott has a history of drug abuse and the psychological counseling would inure to his benefit, the district court did not abuse its discretion by imposing these terms
misconduct_determination_term1: court did not abuse its discretion
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Because the district court's actions
narrowed the scope of the indictment and did not broaden the
crimes charged, Scott's substantial rights were not affected.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because
Scott has failed to demonstrate that he was prejudiced by any
alleged misconduct, his contention lacks merit.

allegation_sentence_1:
The district court concluded that a dismissal of Counts Six
through Ten was compelled because the Government had
inadvertently violated Rule 16 by failing to disclose these
exhibits before Parris had exposed his theory of defense and
because the Government had engaged in two prior incidents
of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
In arguing for a dismissal of each count in the
indictment, Parris's counsel stated that the conduct of the
prosecutor was “extremely prejudicial” because the defense's
strategy had been revealed to the jury and it had been
informed that Parris would take the stand.
allegation_sentence_3:
In the present case, in successfully arguing for
a dismissal of each of the counts of the indictment Parris
took the position that the prosecutor's conduct was extremely
prejudicial
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Specifically, before trial, the
Government had violated Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83,
83 S.Ct. 1194, 10 L.Ed.2d 215 (1963), by failing to disclose
a report from an F.B.I. handwriting expert comparing known
samples of Parris's handwriting with handwriting on certain
bank documents.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The district court had previously remedied
the Brady violation by permitting Parris to depose the F.B.I.
expert and introduce the deposition into evidence.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In addition,
earlier in the trial, the Government had inadvertently violated
the court's order sequestering witnesses.

allegation_sentence_1:
The
appellant asks us to set aside his conviction and sentence due
to prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
The appellant claims that the witnesses against him lied in
order to preserve their pretrial agreements because they were
threatened by prosecutors at Elmendorf AFB.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Upon reconsideration, we again deny appellant's motion, and
affirm the findings and sentence.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
There
is no evidence SrA Leavitt was coached or encouraged
by prosecutors to give false testimony in appellant's courtmartial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: We find no evidence of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The findings are correct in law and fact, and no error
prejudicial to the substantial rights of the appellant occurred.

allegation_sentence_1:
There were several events during trial that factored into the
district court's ultimate finding of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
The district court found that the prosecutor's reference
during closing argument to Agent Cromer's response on
cross-examination that Mexican drug traffickers “don't allow
people in a stash house unless they are involved, particularly
in this situation,” was improper because it violated the district
court's pre-trial ruling prohibiting the Government from
introducing such testimony.
allegation_sentence_3:
The district court also found that
the prosecutor misstated the substance of Cuevas' testimony
concerning the same subject, and that such misstatement was
material and improper.
allegation_sentence_4:
The district court then concluded that
these improper statements had a reasonable probability of
changing the outcome of Miranda's trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
After careful review, we have an abiding conviction that
the prosecutor's comments were not improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Thus it is entirely reasonable for the
prosecutor to have believed not only that he did not violate
the district court's pretrial ruling, but that the evidence had
at last been admitted and was fair game-i.e. circumstances
had changed.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
And, as the district court
recognized, there is no evidence to suggest that Agent Cromer
was coached, or that the prosecutor failed to inform him of
the district court's pre-trial ruling.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Moreover, we cannot find
anything in the record to support the district court's finding
that the prosecutor's comments misled the jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
We
also find that there is no indication in the record that the
prosecutor committed an intentional violation of the district
court's pre-trial ruling or an intentional misrepresentation of
Cuevas' testimony.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
We
also find that there is no indication in the record that the
prosecutor committed an intentional violation of the district
court's pre-trial ruling or an intentional misrepresentation of
Cuevas' testimony.

allegation_sentence_1:
Broussard filed a motion for an evidentiary hearing to
determine the extent of the government's prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Broussard brings the single claim that his attorney Robert
Jenkins provided ineffective assistance of counsel “due in
large part to the insurmountable interference” of the U.S.
Attorney's office for the Eastern District of Louisiana, the Department of Justice, and Section “N” of the Eastern
District.
allegation_sentence_3:
Broussard claims that the full extent of the misconduct of the
members of the United States Attorney's Office in the Eastern
District, including that of high level supervisory attorneys,
was withheld from his counsel before he pled guilty.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Although the prosecutorial misconduct in Broussard's case
could rise to the level of a due process violation in some
instances, Broussard waived his right to assert such a
violation by his guilty plea.
misconduct_determination_term1:
waived his right to assert such a
violation by his guilty plea
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Unlike in the Bowen
case, the prosecutorial misconduct here did not implicate
grand jury misconduct, false testimony, or potential poisoning
of the jury pool and the jury during trial.
misconduct_determination_term2:
did not implicate
grand jury misconduct, false testimony, or potential poisoning
of the jury pool
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The information available to the Court
indicated that Broussard did not appear to be unfairly singled
out
notes: this case relates to the Danziger bridge prosecutors. they found misconduct, but he pleaded guilty so was barred from getting relief.

United States District Court,
D. South Carolina,
Charleston Division.
defendant:
Rashad Saleem MUHAMMAD, Damon Leon
Milford, and Gary Terril Milford, Defendant.
attorneys_judges:
Matthew J. Modica, Nathan Stuart Williams, U.S. Attorneys
Office, Charleston, SC, for Plaintiff.// Pamela Jeanne Polzin, Pamela J. Polzin Law Office,
Marco Tulio Torres, Torres Law Firm, Charleston, SC, for
Defendants.//PATRICK MICHAEL DUFFY, District Judge.
geography_entities: Charleston, SC
allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant Muhammad argued that the court should “dismiss
this Indictment and/or declare a mistrial and attach jeopardy
to that mistrial based on what I believe is prosecutorial
misconduct.” [Trial Tr. 179: 7–10].
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendants argue that (1) the
indictment should be dismissed because none of Defendants
consented to the mistrial and the mistrial was not manifestly
necessary. (2) the indictment should be dismissed because the
government's conduct was intended to goad Defendants
into asking for a mistrial and (3) the indictment should
be dismissed based upon the inaccuracy of the testimony
presented to the grand jury.
allegation_sentence_3:
Much like Shafer, this case involves the government's failure
to produce important documents before trial and the resulting
pediment the court is placed in when those documents, not
produced until the trial has begun, are important.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Defendant Milford is unable to show that government
suborned perjury in order to obtain the indictment, and that
had the grand jury been presented with that evidence it would
probably not have indicted Defendant Milford.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Therefore, his
argument that the indictment should be dismissed based on
alleged inaccuracy of the testimony at the grand jury does not
provide a basis for dismissal of the indictment in this case.
misconduct_determination_term2:
does not
provide a basis for dismissal
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The statement is not exculpatory as to
Defendant Damon Milford.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
To be sure, in the absence of an unequivocal waiver
by Muhammad of his constitutional rights under Bruton, the
court was left with no other alternative than to order a mistrial
and sever the cases. Therefore, the mistrial was manifestly
necessary.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Additionally, because this problem was of constitutional
magnitude, no curative instruction could have remedied
the situation and a continuance could not have solved the
problem.
misconduct_determination_term5:
continuance could not have solved the
problem.
prosecutor_named:
Matthew
Modica, Assistant United States Attorney

allegation_sentence_1:
John Serubo claims that the prosecutor's
remarks were unprovoked. We disagree.
allegation_sentence_2:
These appellants did
not argue that the prosecutor's closing was an improper
response to the attack by counsel for Anthony and counsel for
John Serubo. Rather, they moved for severance, arguing that
they had been prejudiced by inflammatory remarks that they
did not provoke.
allegation_sentence_3:
Peter Serubo claims that he
objected to the prosecutor's summation at trial, but he does not
cite the record, and we can find no trace of his objection or of a
similar objection by John Serubo or by Anthony DiPasquale.
We review for plain error.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Time and again, we have emphasized that a prosecutor bears
a special responsibility not to abuse the prestige that accrues
to his office
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Here, a fair reading of the prosecutor's remarks leads
us to conclude that “the prosecution was only meeting the
defense on a level of the defense's own choosing.”
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Here, a fair reading of the prosecutor's remarks leads
us to conclude that “the prosecution was only meeting the
defense on a level of the defense's own choosing.”
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We hold that even if there was error,
it was harmless because there was no substantial prejudice
to Anthony or the Serubos. Specifically, the prosecutor's
statements, which can impliedly be taken as seeking to
vindicate his own credibility, did not permeate the three-
*1297 week trial; the trial court took curative measures
in its charge to the jury; 14 and the case against Anthony
and the Serubos was strong.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
By contrast, the prosecutor's remarks in this case, although
rhetorically phrased, were essentially a denial of the defense
counsel's accusation that the government wrote its witnesses'
testimony. We cannot say that it was plain error for the district
court to deny Anthony's and the Serubos' motions for a new
trial based on the prosecutor's summation.
misconduct_determination_term5: cannot say that it was plain error
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
We hold that even if there was error,
it was harmless because there was no substantial prejudice
to Anthony or the Serubos. Specifically, the prosecutor's
statements, which can impliedly be taken as seeking to
vindicate his own credibility, did not permeate the three-
*1297 week trial; the trial court took curative measures
in its charge to the jury; 14 and the case against Anthony
and the Serubos was strong.
notes:
Good harmless error case warning: We take occasion, once again, to remind the district courts
of their responsibility to forestall unfair provocation and to
constrain prosecutorial misconduct.

allegation_sentence_1:
the government committed prosecutorial
misconduct in its closing argument;
allegation_sentence_2:
First, we find no merit to Pedron's contention that
the government engaged in misconduct during its closing
argument by making three “misstatements”: (1) vouching
for its position by stating “[o]f course [Pedron] knowingly
possessed those pills”; (2) “belittl[ing]” defense counsel
and strategy by comparing a portion of counsel's defense
to a “grade school playground tactic”; and (3) shifting the
burden of proof by telling the jury that it had to weigh
the defense's case in making its decision.
allegation_sentence_3:
First, we find no merit to Pedron's contention that
the government engaged in misconduct during its closing
argument by making three “misstatements”: (1) vouching
for its position by stating “[o]f course [Pedron] knowingly
possessed those pills”; (2) “belittl[ing]” defense counsel
and strategy by comparing a portion of counsel's defense
to a “grade school playground tactic”; and (3) shifting the
burden of proof by telling the jury that it had to weigh
the defense's case in making its decision.
allegation_sentence_4:
First, we find no merit to Pedron's contention that
the government engaged in misconduct during its closing
argument by making three “misstatements”: (1) vouching
for its position by stating “[o]f course [Pedron] knowingly
possessed those pills”; (2) “belittl[ing]” defense counsel
and strategy by comparing a portion of counsel's defense
to a “grade school playground tactic”; and (3) shifting the
burden of proof by telling the jury that it had to weigh
the defense's case in making its decision.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Here, none
of the comments were improper-the vouching comment was
simply an argument based on the evidentiary circumstances,
the alleged personal attack comment was a valid remark
on the defense strategy, and the burden-shifting comment
properly addressed the defense's subpoena power.
misconduct_determination_term1:
none
of the comments were improper
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Here, none
of the comments were improper-the vouching comment was
simply an argument based on the evidentiary circumstances,
the alleged personal attack comment was a valid remark
on the defense strategy, and the burden-shifting comment
properly addressed the defense's subpoena power.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accordingly, we find no error-let alone plain errorin
Pedron's claims of prosecutorial misconduct.

allegation_sentence_1:
Perez claims that the prosecutor violated her Fifth
Amendment due process rights by commenting on her
decision to not testify
allegation_sentence_2:
Perez also argues that the prosecutor improperly
vouched on behalf of his key witness, Postal Inspector
Lorretta Cummings, when he told the jury:
allegation_sentence_3:
Perez argues that the district court inadequately investigated
the possibility of juror bias and that her sentence must
be vacated because the prosecutor improperly vouched and
committed Griffin error by commenting on her failure to
testify.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
No plain error occurred here
because the prosecutor's comment was isolated
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The prosecutor appears to have improperly vouched by
implying that Cummings' inspection had been independently
reviewed *671 and validated by the United States Attorney's
office, thereby placing the prestige of the government behind her conclusions
misconduct_determination_term2: prosecutor appears to have improperly vouched
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The vouching was
isolated, see Hermanek, 289 F.3d at 1102, and it is unlikely
that the jury was improperly influenced by the prosecutor's
remarks because the evidence against Perez was so strong,
see United States v. Laurins, 857 F.2d 529, 539–40 (9th
Cir.1988).
misconduct_determination_term3: unlikely that the jury was improperly influenced

not shown that his appellate counsel was ineffective.

allegation_sentence_1: Bilzerian now argues that this statement (the government's alternative version of events) constituted “prosecutorial misconduct” and that his counsel should have objected to the government's statement.
allegation_sentence_2:
Bilzerian argues that defense counsel did not object
when the prosecutor asked guilt-assuming questions in
the government's cross-examination of character witnesses.
Under United States v. Oshatz, a prosecutor may not ask
questions that assume the guilt of a defendant. 912 F.2d
534, 539 (2d Cir.1990).
allegation_sentence_3:
Bilzerian contends that the prosecution's
opening statement was argumentative and prejudicial because
the prosecutor called him a “liar.”
allegation_term_3:
prosecution's
opening statement was argumentative and prejudicial
allegation_sentence_4: Bilzerian argues that the district court erred by denying his claim that he was deprived of an impartial judge in violation of the Fifth Amendment.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
These
types of statements have been held not to exceed the bounds of
propriety when this is essentially what was proved at trial.
misconduct_determination_term1:
held not to exceed the bounds of
propriety
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Therefore, defense counsel
could not have failed to object to prosecutorial misconduct
if there was none.
misconduct_determination_term2:
defense counsel
could not have failed
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We have considered all the additional arguments raised by
Bilzerian, and find them to be without merit

allegation_sentence_1: She appeals alleged instances of prosecutorial misconduct and alleged ineffectiveness of her defense counsel for failing to object to the certain actions by the prosecutor and failing to obtain a proper transcript of a taped conversation used against her at trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Reed contends that prosecutor Hurst intimidated
witness Dorothy McGruder with a threat of perjury so that
McGruder was prevented from testifying that Reed's stockboy
Joe Corpus had threatened to burn down the store.
allegation_term_2:
prosecutor Hurst intimidated
witness Dorothy McGruder with a threat of perjury
allegation_sentence_3:
Reed next contends that it was improper for the prosecutor
to introduce evidence that she had stolen money and
clothing from the Dollar Store
allegation_term_3:
improper for the prosecutor
to introduce evidence
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We find no merit to these contentions and affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Considering that evidence
and the other testimony of Corpus's knowledge of the crime,
it is most unlikely that any threats the prosecutor made to
McGruder substantially prejudiced her right to a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term2:
unlikely that any threats the prosecutor made to
McGruder substantially prejudiced
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because it was cumulative evidence, the
letter cannot have affected the result of the trial
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Certainly there was no plain error in his closing
argument.

allegation_sentence_1:
Romero first argues that the District Court erred in
calculating his sentence based on 4.5 kilograms of cocaine.
allegation_sentence_2:
Romero argues that this
statement creates ambiguity that precluded the District Court
from determining the quantity of drugs by a preponderance
of the evidence
allegation_term_2: creates ambiguity that precluded the District Court
allegation_sentence_3:
Romero's second argument is that the District Court
erred when it imposed a sentence that differed from
the sentences his co-defendants received.
allegation_term_3:
sentence that differed from
the sentences his co-defendants received
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We see no basis to give weight to the
distinction Romero urges.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Romero's admission was
more than adequate for the District Court to find by a
preponderance of the evidence that 4.5 kilograms of cocaine
were involved.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Suffice it to say that when a person possesses
illegal drugs with the intent to distribute them, that person's
culpability is no less however he finally disposes of the drugs.

allegation_sentence_1: Mr. McKinnon alleges prosecutorial misconduct on the grounds that the government had “full knowledge that the charges [against him] could not be substantiated at trial,” but he offers no evidence that such an assertion could not have been made earlier.
allegation_sentence_2:
With respect to the
charge of ineffective assistance of counsel, Mr. McKinnon
asserts that his counsel failed to “investigate the factuality
of [the government's] claims,” particularly regarding a
corroborating witness, and erroneously encouraged Mr.
McKinnon to accept a plea agreement.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Although Mr. McKinnon has not explicitly argued that his
petition is entitled to equitable tolling, such an argument
also would be futile.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Mr.
McKinnon has not made the requisite showing for this court
to issue a certificate of appealability.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
As a result, the court will not reach the
merits of Mr. McKinnon's ineffective assistance of counsel
and prosecutorial misconduct claims.

allegation_sentence_1: Movant asserts two grounds for review in his motion to vacate, set aside, or correct sentence under 28 U.S.C. § 2255: (1) prosecutorial misconduct and (2) ineffective assistance of counsel.
allegation_sentence_2:
Specifically, movant contends Assistant United
States Attorney John Craft, willfully, knowingly and
intentionally withheld evidence that was vital to movant's
case, namely the identity of co-conspirator(s).
allegation_sentence_3:
With respect to
his claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, movant argues
his counsel failed to file a motion requesting the prosecutor
disclose the identities of the alleged co-conspirator(s) and
similarly, that without this information, he could not make an
informed decision regarding his defense.
allegation_term_3:
failed to file a motion requesting the prosecutor
disclose the identities
allegation_sentence_4: In the case at bar, movant contends that the failure of the prosecutor to disclose the identity of the alleged coconspirator(s) prevented him from properly preparing a defense and, in turn, “constructively coerced” movant to enter a guilty plea
allegation_term_4: failure of the prosecutor to disclose
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Movant, however, has not established that prosecutorial misconduct
did, in fact, exist.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Movant has failed to demonstrate how
the identity of the co-conspirator(s) is exculpatory, let alone
favorable to his defense.
misconduct_determination_term2:
failed to demonstrate how
the identity of the co-conspirator(s) is exculpatory
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The Government,
therefore, had no duty to voluntarily disclose the identity of
the alleged co-conspirator in advance of trial.
misconduct_determination_term3: Government had no duty to voluntarily disclose
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
In the present case, movant has shown neither deficient
performance nor prejudice stemming from the alleged
ineffective assistance of counsel for failing to file a motion seeking the identity of the co-conspirator(s).
