allegation_sentence_1: Defendant contends that the Court should use its supervisory powers to both investigate and sanction Mahajan for what Defendant contends is prosecutorial misconduct in regard to the Rothbart recording.
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant contends, and this
Court has informally indicated, that this recording contains
exculpatory evidence and is Brady material.
allegation_sentence_3:
. Defendant seeks the subpoena to continue
the investigation into the delay in disclosing the Rothbart
recording—an investigation which this Court has already
pursued in five days of evidentiary hearings—yet Defendant's
briefs do not provide a legal justification for further
investigation.
allegation_sentence_4:
Defendant's latest brief summarizes the basis for
Defendant's position that the Government knowingly and
willfully concealed evidence.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
There is also no
dispute that the Government did not disclose the recording
in a timely fashion, and that the recording was physically
damaged by the actions of Government employees.
misconduct_determination_term1: Government did not disclose the recording
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The investigation conducted by this Court has not discovered
new evidence of prosecutorial misconduct that might justify
continuing an inquiry that has already been exhaustive.
misconduct_determination_term2: not discovered new evidence of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Thus, even if Defendant could demonstrate willful
prosecutorial misconduct, in the absence of a demonstration
of prejudice, dismissal is not an available option.
misconduct_determination_term3:
absence of a demonstration
of prejudice
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Defendant has not persuaded this Court that the information
he seeks from Mahajan has any use in his defense, nor to any
issue presently before this Court.

allegation_sentence_1: Azoroh's complaint of prosecutorial misconduct relates primarily to a pay stub found inside the blue pouch that Azoroh carried on the bus.
allegation_sentence_2:
Azoroh also claims that the prosecutor knowingly used
perjured testimony during his trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
On appeal, Azoroh raises six alleged errors in his trial
proceedings: (1) his statements were admitted in violation
of his Miranda rights, (2) there was insufficient evidence to
convict on either count, (3) certain airline tickets should have
been excluded, (4) testimony by an agent based upon another
agent's notes should have been excluded, (5) a narcotics
agent's expert opinion testimony should have been excluded,
and (6) the prosecutor was guilty of misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Thus, there is absolutely no
basis for a finding of prosecutorial misconduct regarding
the pay stub.
misconduct_determination_term1:
no
basis for a finding of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The trial court did not err in admitting the inculpatory
statements made by Azoroh in alleged violation of his
Miranda rights.
misconduct_determination_term2:
court did not err in admitting the inculpatory
statements
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Azoroh has failed to establish reversible error in his trial
proceedings.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
attorneys_judges:
Ira N. Loewy, Edward R. Shohar, Bierman, Shohat,
Loewy & Perry, P.A., Miami, FL, for Defendant–Appellant.

//Before WILSON and ANDERSON, Circuit Judges, and
RESTANI, Judge//WILSON Circuit Judge//
geography_entities: Southern District of Florida//n Venezuela//Argentina//Buenos Aires//Miami
allegation_sentence_1:
Duran now raises five issues on appeal: (1) that
§ 951 is unconstitutionally vague as applied to the facts of
this case; (2) that Federal Rule of Evidence 404(b) character
evidence was admitted for an improper purpose; (3) that
the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct by
improperly commenting on the Rule 404(b) evidence; (4) that
evidence of Duran and his co-conspirators' lack of knowledge
of the notification requirement under § 951 was erroneously
excluded; and (5) that the district court should have admitted
several hearsay statements evidencing Duran's lack of intent
to act as an agent of a *1287 foreign government under §
951.
allegation_sentence_2: Duran alleges that the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct during his closing argument by improperly commenting on the Rule 404(b) evidence, with statements that Duran “spent the last ten years of his life bribing ... officials” and that Duran had been involved in a “life of crime.”
allegation_sentence_3:
Duran argues that the district court abused its discretion by
admitting evidence of Duran and Kauffmann's payment of
illegal kickbacks to various Venezuelan government officials
to establish his motive and intent to commit the charged
crimes under Federal Rule of Evidence 404(b), as well
as to counter his belated claim of entrapment by showing
predisposition to commit the crimes.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because the district court properly
instructed the jury as to the purpose for which Rule 404(b)
evidence was introduced, we find that the prosecutor's
comments did not prejudicially affect Duran's substantial
rights at his trial, and therefore, any error was harmless.
misconduct_determination_term1:
prosecutor's
comments did not prejudicially affect
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The district court did not abuse
its discretion by excluding evidence of Duran's lack of
knowledge of the notification requirement under § 951,
by excluding Duran's hearsay statements, or by admitting
the Rule 404(b) evidence of Duran's kickbacks to various
officials of the Venezuelan government.
misconduct_determination_term2: court did not abuse its discretion
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Finally, although the
Government arguably engaged in prosecutorial misconduct
during closing statements, such error was harmless.

allegation_sentence_1:
Timothy James Whitehead (“Whitehead”) seeks reversal of
his jury conviction for importation of marijuana, see 21
U.S.C. §§ 952, 960 (1994), and importation of marijuana with
intent to distribute, see id. § 841(a)(1), on the ground that
the government infringed upon his Fifth Amendment right
to remain silent.
allegation_term_1:
on the ground that
the government infringed upon his Fifth Amendment right
to remain silent.
allegation_sentence_2:
He further argues that
the government's failure to grant use immunity to Jason
Whitehead intentionally distorted the fact-finding process.
allegation_term_2:
the government's failure to grant use immunity to Jason
Whitehead intentionally distorted
allegation_sentence_3:
“In order to make out a
claim for prosecutorial misconduct, a defendant must show
that the evidence sought from the nonimmunized witness
was relevant and that the government distorted the judicial
fact-finding process by denying immunity to the potential
witness.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Accordingly, we find that the district court did not err in
refusing to order the government to grant use immunity
to Whitehead's brother or in failing to hold an evidentiary
hearing on whether the government intentionally distorted the
fact-finding process.
misconduct_determination_term1:
we find that the district court did not err in
refusing to order the government to grant use immunity
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Furthermore,
Whitehead does not contend that the government granted
immunity to other witnesses while denying immunity to his
brother, and nothing in the record would support such an
argument.
misconduct_determination_term2:
nothing in the record would support such an
argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
For the foregoing reasons, Whitehead's conviction is
AFFIRMED.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Under that law, the government's comment on
Whitehead's exercise of his right to remain silent violated the
Fifth Amendment.
misconduct_determination_term4:
government's comment on
Whitehead's exercise of his right to remain silent violated the
Fifth Amendment.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The prosecutor's reference in closing argument was not so
innocuous and cannot be condoned.
misconduct_determination_term5:
prosecutor's reference in closing argument was not so
innocuous and cannot be condoned.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Thus, the improper references *640 to Whitehead's silence
were not “prejudicial enough to affect the outcome of the
proceedings.” Id. at 653.
misconduct_determination_term6:
improper references *640 to Whitehead's silence
were not “prejudicial enough

allegation_sentence_1: Appellant's final claim is that his conviction should be reversed because the prosecutor engaged in “impermissible intimidation of the defendant and his potential witnesses.”
allegation_sentence_2:
Specifically, appellant claims that the prosecutor intimidated
Moore and Thrower into not testifying by warning them,
through counsel, that they would be committing perjury if
they testified so as to exonerate appellant and that any perjury
would meet with punishment

Instead, appellant

alleged misconduct deprived him

misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Pinkston's motion is untimely, as it was filed
well over one year after his judgment of conviction became final, and the rule established in Alleyne was not made
retroactively applicable to cases on collateral review, 28
U.S.C. § 2255(f)(3); and (3) even if consideration on the
merits were permitted, Alleyne does not authorize relief in his
case.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
He does not allege that one or more
of these circumstances apply here.
misconduct_determination_term3:
In the present case, Pinkston waived his right to bring a
collateral challenge to his sentence except on the basis of
involuntariness, prosecutorial misconduct, or ineffective
assistance of counsel.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
waived his right to bring a
collateral challenge
notes: There are no allegations here related to prosecutorial misconduct

allegation_sentence_1: On appeal, Ehrmann assigns numerous errors, including (1) the denial of his suppression motion; (2) the denial of a fair trial due to the prosecutor's peremptory strike of a prospective juror based on the juror's sexual orientation; (3) the admission at trial of prejudicial videotape evidence; (4) the denial of his right to testify on his own behalf; (5) prosecutorial misconduct; (6) the improper assessment of a two-level sentencing enhancement for obstruction of justice; and (7) Booker sentencing errors
allegation_sentence_2:
In his third assigned error, Ehrmann claims
the district court erred in allowing the government to
introduce prejudicial videotape evidence, the admission
of which, Ehrmann claims, constituted prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_3:
Ehrmann next claims the prosecutor impugned
defense counsel's integrity by revisiting at trial a preliminary
conflict-of-interest issue, which the magistrate judge had
resolved in favor of Ehrmann.
allegation_sentence_4: As a result, Ehrmann claims the prosecutor denied him a right to a fair trial and to effective assistance of counsel.
allegation_term_4: prosecutor denied him a right to a fair trial
allegation_sentence_5:
In his last assigned error, Ehrmann contends the district
court clearly erred in assessing a two-level enhancement
for obstruction of justice under section 3C1.1 of the United
States Sentencing Guidelines (Guidelines).
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
After
reviewing the relevant portions of the trial transcript, we find
no prosecutorial misconduct and no showing of substantial
prejudice to Ehrmann.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Thus, Ehrmann has not established the error affected
his substantial rights, because he cannot demonstrate a
reasonable probability that the district court would have
imposed a more favorable sentence under an advisory
sentencing guidelines regime mandated by Booker.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We conclude
the district court did not abuse its discretion in admitting the
videotape evidence.

allegation_sentence_1: Defendant makes two arguments in support of the double jeopardy claim: (1) the double jeopardy clause precludes retrial since the evidence in the first trial was insufficient to convict defendant of aiding and abetting in the use of a dangerous weapon as charged in the indictment; and (2) instances of prosecutorial misconduct in the first trial invoke the interests protected by the double jeopardy clause and thereby prohibit retrial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant maintains
that in the first trial the government failed to make this
required evidentiary showing and argues that retrial would
therefore transgress the principle that “(t)he Double Jeopardy
Clause forbids a second trial for the purpose of affording the
prosecution another opportunity to supply *1087 evidence
which it failed to muster in the first proceeding.”
allegation_term_2:
government failed to make this
required evidentiary showing
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
A careful review of the allegations of prosecutorial
misconduct made by defendant reveals no gross negligence
or intentional misconduct by the Government
misconduct_determination_term1: no gross negligence or intentional misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
At worst
the prosecutor's conduct amounted to mere mistake
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The
comments were errors made in the heat of trial and nothing
more.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Reasonably zealous prosecution is still permitted.

allegation_sentence_1: Petitioner alleges that the Government's attorney committed prosecutorial misconduct in his closing argument by stating that Petitioner was “arrested twice when in fact he had not been.”
allegation_sentence_2:
. Petitioner first argues that trial counsel was ineffective in
failing to object to the purported prosecutorial misconduct
discussed in the preceding subsection of this Order.
allegation_sentence_3:
Petitioner adduced four arguments: (1)
he suffered prosecutorial misconduct; (2) he had suffered
ineffective assistance of counsel; (3) the Court improperly
instructed the jury; and (4) his sentence violated the doctrine
of Apprendi v. New Jersey, 530 U.S. 466, 120 S.Ct. 2348, 147
L.Ed.2d 435 (2000).
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Therefore, Petitioner's prosecutorial misconduct claim fails both steps of the Sixth Circuit's twostep approach, and the Court will not issue § 2255 relief on this claim.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Therefore, counsel was not deficient in this regard, and Petitioner's fourth ineffective assistance counsel claim is without merit.
misconduct_determination_term2: counsel was not deficient in this regard,
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Petitioner benefitted from this Court's limiting instructions within the jury instructions at the close of trial.
misconduct_determination_term3: Petitioner benefitted from this Court's limiting instructions

allegation_sentence_1: In the motion, Cornell alleged the following claims: (1) the conduct of Special Agent Lucas warrants a new trial; (2) the United States failed to establish the proper foundation, and/or a proper chain of custody, for the admittance of the 154 grams of cocaine; (3) the United States presented perjured and misleading testimony to sustain counts two and three; (4) the court impermissibly instructed the jury; (5) based upon prosecutorial misconduct a new trial must be granted; and (6) counsel provided ineffective assistance of counsel.
allegation_sentence_2: Cornell only argues that the Court clearly erred in its application of law, and the argument fails on each claim.
allegation_sentence_3:
On the issue of the new
Lucas evidence, the Defendant asserts that the Court did not
properly consider the effect the new evidence might have
had on the outcome of his trial because the Lucas evidence
might undermine the entire investigation.
allegation_sentence_4: Finally, the Defendant argues that his remaining claims should not be time-barred because ineffective assistance of counsel caused the delay, and would amount to excusable neglect.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Defendant Cornell does not meet the required standard for the Court to grant reconsideration
misconduct_determination_term1: does not meet the required standard
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
However, the Court
reiterates that it believes there was ample testimony and other
evidence against the Defendant that would not be affected
by any potential new evidence related to Agent Lucas.
misconduct_determination_term2: there was ample testimony and other evidence
misconduct_determination_sentence3: This does not mean, however, that the Court must consider the claim in this forum, and so the Court limits review of the claim to the more appropriate vehicle.
misconduct_determination_term3: Court limits review of the claim
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The Court has previously
considered and rejected this argument, and therefore refused
to grant a Rule 45 time extension on these claims.

allegation_sentence_1: Tirado contends that the government committed prosecutorial misconduct by improperly referring to inadmissible evidence of prior acts when questioning him on cross-examination, and by improperly asking him to comment on the veracity of a federal law enforcement officer.
allegation_sentence_2: He further contends that the district court erred by failing to properly instruct the jury on the intent element of possession with intent to distribute, and by imposing a statutory minimum sentence in the absence of an explicit jury determination of the actual amount of pure methamphetamine involved in the offense.
allegation_sentence_3:
He further contends
that the prosecutor improperly introduced the rebuttal
testimony of Tirado's girlfriend in violation of a prior order
excluding this evidence.
allegation_term_3: prosecutor improperly introduced the rebuttal testimony
allegation_sentence_4:
Tirado also contends that the district court failed
to properly instruct the jury on the requirement that
they find beyond a reasonable doubt that he possessed
methamphetamine with intent to deliver it to another person.
allegation_term_4: failed to properly instruct the jury
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
To the extent the question was improper, any
error did not affect Tirado's substantial rights or diminish
the integrity of the judicial proceedings
misconduct_determination_term1: error did not affect Tirado's substantial rights
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We conclude that the jury
instructions were not misleading or inadequate to guide the
jury's deliberation.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Finally, we reject Tirado's contention that the district
court plainly erred by imposing the 10-year mandatory
minimum sentence
misconduct_determination_term3: reject Tirado's contention that the district court plainly erred

allegation_sentence_1: White first argues that his trial was rendered fundamentally unfair by the prosecutor's misconduct in impeaching White's testimony using the factual details underlying his prior conviction for aggravated criminal sexual abuse.
allegation_sentence_2: White also argues that his trial was further prejudiced by the government's reference during closing argument to the alleged facts supporting this conviction.
allegation_sentence_3: White argues that the district court erred when it refused to allow him to introduce evidence that Adrian Garner was the anonymous tipster who informed the FBI of his whereabouts after the robbery and that the court erred when it did not allow him to introduce into evidence video tapes of the news coverage of the robbery.
allegation_sentence_4: White asserts that it is impermissible double counting to impose both the statutory sentence increase and the Guidelines' sentencing enhancement for the use of two different weapons in the commission of the same underlying offense.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Argument referencing facts not
in evidence is clearly improper, and we conclude that the
prosecutor engaged in misconduct in making the challenged statement.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Considering all of these factors, and our review under the
plain error standard, we conclude that the government's
improper remark did not render White's trial fundamentally
unfair.
misconduct_determination_term2: remark did not render White's trial fundamentally unfair
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We, therefore,
conclude that the district court did not abuse its discretion
when it refused to allow White's cross-examination of a
government witness on the identity of the person who turned
him in.
misconduct_determination_term3: district court did not abuse its discretion

allegation_sentence_1: Appellant also contends that his constitutional rights were violated through prosecutorial misconduct.

In appellant's assertion that the Government offered
perjured testimony and false evidence in order to gain his
conviction, Jones alleges several instances where some minor
inconsistencies existed between certain oral testimony and
documentary evidence adduced at trial and where testimony
given at the suppression hearing slightly differed from

assertion that the Government offered
perjured testimony

Appellant's next contention, that the Government
gathered evidence against him in an unconstitutional search
and seizure of his residence, was raised by Jones on direct
appeal and decided adversely to him.

contention, that the Government

Appellant Jones first contends that the Government

contends that the Government

This list is conclusory and
wholly unsubstantiated.

Here, Jones has completely failed to support

testimony or knowing use of perjured testimony by the
Government.

misconduct_determination_sentence3: Appellant's contention that the Government illegally searched his residence prior to the search considered on Jones' direct appeal is wholly conclusory and unsupported by factual allegations or proof.

allegation_sentence_1:
Bokel maintains that her counsel
provided ineffective assistance and claims prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Specifically, she alleges: (1) that
the prosecutor attempted to withhold favorable evidence to
the defense that could have led to an acquittal; (2) that the
prosecutor knowingly called unreliable witnesses to testify
during the arraignment and trial; (3) that the prosecutor
attempted to sway the jury against Bokel by calling her a
liar and that this opinion was subjective and not supported
by factual evidence; and (4) that the prosecutor petitioned
the court to sentence and re-sentence Bokel to a “prolonged
sentence” in violation of the Constitution. Pet'r Mot. 5-7.
allegation_term_2:
she alleges: (1) that
the prosecutor attempted to withhold favorable evidence
allegation_sentence_3:
The thrust of Bokel's first claim seems to be that the
prosecutor withheld exculpatory evidence in violation of
Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194, 10 L.Ed.2d
215 (1963)
allegation_sentence_4:
Bokel next claims that the prosecutor knowingly called

allegation_sentence_1:

There

purpose for introducing extrinsic evidence of the previous
robberies, the prosecutor's suggestion that those robberies
help to prove that Rice was the carjacker constituted trial
error

the prosecutor's suggestion that those robberies

error

review.

does not survive plain error
review.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:

plea was not prosecutorial misconduct, Cormier's second
claim also fails on the first prong of plain error review.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The
judgments of conviction are therefore AFFIRMED.

allegation_sentence_1:

allegation_sentence_1:
Although Carter now appeals his conviction on four grounds,
we focus primarily on his claim that the prosecution deprived
him of his right to due process and a fair trial under the Fifth
Amendment when the prosecutor committed prosecutorial
misconduct during closing arguments by misstating material
evidence and accusing defense counsel of lying.
allegation_sentence_2:
Carter argues that his conviction should be reversed and
that this case should be remanded for a new trial because
the prosecutor committed flagrant misconduct during closing
arguments.
allegation_term_2:
prosecutor committed flagrant misconduct during closing
arguments
allegation_sentence_3:
Carter further argues
that the prosecutor misled the jury by repeatedly insisting
that defense counsel was lying about Halliburton's testimony.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because we
believe that the prosecutor committed misconduct that was
sufficient to constitute plain error warranting reversal, we
REVERSE the judgment of the district court and REMAND
for a new trial.
misconduct_determination_term1:
we
believe that the prosecutor committed misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Although Carter raises four grounds for appeal in his
brief, we focus on *783 only his prosecutorial misconduct
claim regarding the prosecutor's comments during closing
arguments, as we find such conduct to be reversible error. 3
misconduct_determination_term2: we find such conduct to be reversible error.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In conclusion, Carter has successfully established that
the prosecutor committed misconduct sufficient to warrant
reversal under a plain error analysis
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
In this case, the prosecutor
committed both of these prohibited acts.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
After careful review, we conclude that the prosecutor
knowingly and deliberately made his improper comments
before the jury
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
At the outset, we note our belief that the prosecutor's
misstatement regarding Halliburton's testimony was
inherently prejudicial to Carter.
notes:
"After careful review, we conclude that the prosecutor
knowingly and deliberately made his improper comments
before the jury" [....] To hold that such action does not
seriously affect the integrity of judicial proceedings would be
tantamount to excusing the prosecutor's deliberate disregard
of his duty to uphold the Government's interest in ensuring
that “justice shall be done,” not that “it shall win a case,” and
would render a profound blow to our judicial system's ideal
of providing each defendant with a fair trial.

allegation_sentence_1:
In challenging his conviction and sentence, defendant
asserts five claims of error: (1) that the government did
not timely file notice of possible sentencing enhancement
based on prior convictions; (2) that the sentencing court
improperly considered his two prior drug felony convictions
to be separate offenses even though they arose from a single
criminal episode; (3) that evidence seized in a consensual
search which exceeded the scope of the consent should
have been suppressed; (4) that the government engaged in
prosecutorial misconduct during closing arguments; and (5)
that the conviction was not supported by sufficient evidence
that he knowingly possessed the cocaine.
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant contends the Assistant U.S. Attorney overstepped
his bounds during closing arguments by implying that
defendant had the burden of coming forward with evidence
establishing his innocence.
allegation_term_2:
contends the Assistant U.S. Attorney overstepped
his bounds
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Finding that none
of defendant's claims have merit, we affirm the the district
court's judgment.
misconduct_determination_term1:
none
of defendant's claims have merit
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Since
the claimed innocent purposes of his trip had been alluded
to in officers' testimony and counsel's opening statement, the
prosecuting attorney's comments, viewed in context, appear
not to be improper at all, but appropriate comments on the
“quantitative and qualitative significance of the evidence.”
misconduct_determination_term2:
appear
not to be improper at all
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
There
simply is no basis for concluding that counsel's comments
on the evidence adversely affected defendant's substantial
rights and adversely affected the fairness, integrity or public
reputation of the trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
For the foregoing reasons, all of defendant's claims of error
are overruled and the judgment of the district court is
AFFIRMED.

allegation_sentence_1:
Bowman contends, for the first time on

to Bowman, these comments improperly led the jury to

allegation_sentence_3:

allegation_term_3:

inferred
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because we find no error in the
proceedings below, we affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The statements were therefore proper.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:

trial court.

concur_dissent_sentence_1:
Therefore, I find no prosecutorial vindictiveness in
the handling of the case that lends itself to a conclusion
of prosecutorial misconduct.
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
Nonetheless, the handling of this case reflects
the kind of inattention to detail, carelessness, and neglect for
which there is little reasonable excuse.
concur_dissent_sentence_3:
Further, it was improper to
arraign the appellant on a charge that the Government could
not prove.
concur_dissent_sentence_4:
As he pled guilty to the lesser
included offense of unlawful entry, I find no prejudice to the
appellant.
concur_dissent_sentence_5:
Nonetheless, prosecutorial
misconduct does not in itself mandate dismissal of a charge
or a rehearing in every case.

allegation_sentence_1:
In his motion for relief under § 2255, Coppola presents
thirteen separate grounds for relief: (1) illegal arrest and
false imprisonment; (2) lack of subject matter jurisdiction; (3)
violation of the Speedy Trial Act; (4) ineffective assistance of
pre-trial counsel; (5) prosecutorial misconduct; (6) judicial
bias; (7) impermissible photographic evidence; (8) ineffective
assistance of sentencing counsel; (9) ineffective assistance
of appellate counsel; (10) illegal search and seizure; (11)
wrongful use of prior convictions evidence; (12) Due Process
violation; and (13) a sentencing challenge.

decision_court: United States District Court, C. D. California.
defendant:
Dennis Barry ROBERTS,
Howard Schneider, Defendants
attorneys_judges:
Andrea Sheridan Ordin, U.S. Atty., Robert L. Brosio,
Asst. U.S. Atty., Chief, Criminal Division by Theresa A.
Kristovich, Asst. U.S. Atty., Los Angeles, Cal., for plaintiff//
Hochman, Salkin & DeRoy by Bruce I. Hochman, and
Stephen V. Wilson, Beverly Hills, Cal., for defendant Howard
Schneider//
Alvin S. Michaelson by Bruce I. Hochman, and Stephen
V. Wilson, Beverly Hills, Cal., for defendant Dennis Barry
Roberts.//
HAUK, District Judge.
geography_entities: Los Angeles, Cal.//Beverly Hills, Cal.//
allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant Schneider, joined by defendant
Roberts, has also filed a motion to dismiss the indictment on
grounds of alleged prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendants charge that the Government prosecutor
in charge of the investigation leading to their indictment
was guilty of flagrant misconduct for failure to provide
*1389 exculpatory evidence to the indicting Grand Jury
and for questionable tactics employed during the course of
the investigation.
allegation_sentence_3:
As stated earlier, the Court has a limited
responsibility to oversee the work of grand juries, especially
where serious allegations of prosecutorial abuse are brought
to its attention.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Thus it is clear from the above that the Government is guilty of
prosecutorial misconduct for breaching the understanding
with Judge Pregerson to present all exculpatory evidence
(including not only the testimony of Roland Pagan, but
the polygraph results, the affidavit of Bert Cohen, and the
prior criminal record of Touchard).
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Moreover, the unwise
and prejudicial remarks made during the testimony of the
exculpatory *1390 witness Pagan cannot be condoned.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
All
of this misconduct is clearly inconsistent with and in violation
of Department of Justice guidelines set forth in the United
States Attorney's Manual, Sections 9-11.015 and 9-11.334.
misconduct_determination_term3: violation of Department of Justice guidelines
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Therefore, in addition to deciding that the instant indictment
is invalid because there were not at least twelve “informed”
grand jurors voting to return the indictment, the Court
also rules that the indictment should be dismissed because
of prosecutorial abuse that was arbitrary, capricious and
unreasonable, rising to Constitutional dimensions and
violative of due process.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
It is also clear that the Government was guilty of
prosecutorial misconduct in that (1) the Government
knowingly breached an agreement made in open court
in a prior case, “In re Grand Jury Proceedings, Howard
Schneider,” C.D.Cal.Misc. No. 7929, before Judge Harry
Pregerson of this Central District of California Court to
present all exculpatory evidence to the Kadashaw Grand
Jury as outlined therein in defendant Schneider's “Motion to
Compel The Presentation of Exculpatory Evidence Before
The Grand Jury;” and (2) that the Government impermissibly
manipulated and misled the Grand Jury by depriving it of its
opportunity to evaluate the credibility of witnesses and by
making prejudicial remarks to influence it.
misconduct_determination_term5:
clear that the Government was guilty of
prosecutorial misconduct
prosecutor_named: POSSIBLE Assistant United States Attorney Theresa A. Kristovich
notes: Long culture of politeness -- prosecutor happened to be named in order but not opinion

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit
attorneys_judges: REINHARDT, LEAVY and RYMER, Circuit Judges
allegation_sentence_1:
Aqleh appeals his conviction, arguing that the district
court erred in (1) refusing to dismiss the first superseding
indictment based on prosecutorial misconduct before the
grand jury; (2) refusing to grant a mistrial or a new trial
based on prosecutorial misconduct during trial; (3) allowing
the prosecution to question witnesses about their grant of
immunity; and (4) denying the motion for a new trial or
acquittal based on insufficiency of the evidence.
allegation_sentence_2:
Aqleh claims the government knowingly presented Suhail
Awadallah's perjured testimony to the grand jury, and that
this misconduct required dismissal of the first superseding
indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We affirm in both cases.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The prosecutor did not knowingly present perjured
testimony.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Presenting Awadallah's testimony to the grand jury was not
prosecutorial misconduct.

geography_entities: New York City//
allegation_sentence_1:
Payden seeks dismissal of the indictment based on
prosecutorial misconduct or, in the alternative, disclosure
of Grand Jury minutes, because the prosecutor's alleged
misconduct before the Grand Jury may constitute a sufficient
basis for dismissal of the indictment.
allegation_sentence_2:
There are several
allegations of misconduct.
allegation_sentence_3:
Payden contends that the government's
excessive use of hearsay before the Grand Jury warrants
dismissal of the indictment.
allegation_term_3:
contends that the government's
excessive use of hearsay
allegation_sentence_4:
Finally,
Payden contends that the prosecutor asked questions of a
Grand Jury witness that would associate Payden with a drug
dealer.
allegation_term_4:
contends that the prosecutor asked questions of a
Grand Jury witness
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Under the circumstances of this case, Payden
has failed to show that the government's use of hearsay before
the Grand Jury warrants dismissal of the indictment, or even
inspection of the Grand Jury minutes.
misconduct_determination_term1:
failed to show that the government's use of hearsay before
the Grand Jury warrants dismissal of the indictment
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The misconduct alleged in this case, if it in
fact occurred, does not require dismissal of the indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accordingly, the
motion to inspect the Grand Jury minutes and to dismiss the
indictment based on misconduct occurring before the Grand
Jury is denied.

allegation_sentence_1:
"Johnson challenges his
conviction and sentence on the grounds of insufficiency of the
evidence, prosecutorial misconduct, and the district court's
application of the Sentencing Guidelines. "

On
appeal, Johnson alleges that the prosecutor's remarks were so
prejudicial that he was deprived of a fair trial.
allegation_term_2:
alleges that the prosecutor's remarks were so
prejudicial
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
However, after reviewing
precedent from the United States Supreme Court and the
circuit courts, we conclude that the prosecutor's remarks in
this case were unduly inflammatory and improper.
misconduct_determination_term1:
we conclude that the prosecutor's remarks in
this case were unduly inflammatory and improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We conclude that by urging the jury
to act as a “bulwark against ... putting this poison on the
streets,” the prosecutor in this case appealed to the jurors
to be the conscience of the community in an improper and
inflammatory manner.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Thus, we conclude that the prosecutor's comments constitute
an error prejudicial to Johnson's right to a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term3:
prosecutor's comments constitute
an error prejudicial

allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, Bailey
contests his conviction on the bases of sufficiency of the
evidence, the constitutionality of 18 U.S.C. § 922(o), and
prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
He contends that (1) Agent
Hudson committed perjury regarding certain tape-recorded
evidence, (2) the government failed to disclose that Duke
McCaa was an ATF informant and to produce his ATF
file, (3) the government failed to reveal certain exculpatory
evidence, and (4) the prosecutor's closing *1394 argument
was improper.
allegation_term_2:
the government failed to reveal certain exculpatory
evidence
allegation_sentence_3:
Although Bailey does not cite any
authority for his claim that this information was discoverable
or that the government was tardy in producing it, he appears
to be alleging a Brady violation.
allegation_sentence_4:
Bailey asserts that
the prosecutor's closing argument was improper because it
characterized Bailey's defense as an attack on Agent Hudson,
a responsible ATF agent, and invoked God, passages from
the Bible, and John F. Kennedy in an effort to incite the
passions of the jurors to find Bailey guilty.
allegation_term_4:
asserts that
the prosecutor's closing argument was improper
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Since Bailey has
shown no prejudice to his substantial rights from the alleged
late disclosure of the statements, no relief is warranted.
misconduct_determination_term1: no prejudice to his substantial rights
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
This commentary was not improper when viewed in
context of the detailed evidentiary review that immediately
followed.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
These remarks were entirely appropriate to
counter Bailey's central argument that Agent Hudson had
committed perjury.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We conclude that the challenged remarks of the
prosecutor do not rise to the level of plain error by seriously
affecting the fairness and integrity of the trial
misconduct_determination_term4:
challenged remarks of the
prosecutor do not rise to the level of plain error
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
As we have
explained herein, Bailey's conviction is AFFIRMED.

allegation_sentence_1:
Notwithstanding our holding that the district court
did not abuse its discretion in allowing the government
to reference the 404(b) evidence prior to ruling on its
admissibility, appellants Chirinos, Guerra and Martinez argue
that the prosecutor committed prosecutorial misconduct in
using the 404(b) evidence in his opening statement and seek
reversal of their conviction on this basis.
allegation_sentence_2:
They contend that the prosecutor improperly
commented on their exercise of their right to remain silent and
their right not to present a defense when the prosecutor noted
the defense's failure to contradict Vargas's testimony.
allegation_term_2:
contend that the prosecutor improperly
commented
allegation_sentence_3:
Appellants assert that the following prosecutorial
remarks impermissibly commented on their failure to testify
and present a defense
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
In affirming this criminal case appeal, we reject the
appellants' claims that the evidence was insufficient, that
the prosecutor's remarks in opening and closing arguments
prejudiced the appellants, that the district court erred in
denying requested jury instructions, that the district court
erred in denying a motion to suppress evidence and that the
district court erred in sentencing.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We conclude
that the prosecutor's opening remarks concerning the 404(b)
evidence were not improper because the prosecutor had a
reasonable belief that the district court would admit the 404(b)
evidence at the time he made such statements.
misconduct_determination_term2:
prosecutor's opening remarks concerning the 404(b)
evidence were not improper
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because it is not
improper to comment on the failure of the defense, as opposed
to the defendant, to counter or explain the evidence, we find
no prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
For the reasons stated in this section, we hold that
appellants' claims of prosecutorial misconduct fail as a
matter of law.
misconduct_determination_term4: appellants' claims of prosecutorial misconduct fail
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
For the reasons stated in this opinion, we affirm the
convictions and sentences of all appellants

allegation_sentence_1:
The appellant's briefs present four different, but interrelated,
theoretical bases for relief. These rest on (i) newly discovered
evidence; (ii) withholding of evidence by the government;
(iii) prosecutorial misconduct (related to perjury and the
withholding of evidence); and (iv) manifest injustice.
allegation_sentence_2:
This more defendant-friendly
standard applies, then, to what are colloquially known as
“Brady violations.”
allegation_sentence_3:
As a
preliminary matter, we note the appellant's allegation that all
of this evidence is prejudicial and that almost all of it would
have been available to him at trial but for the government's
wrongful withholding
allegation_term_3:
allegation that all
of this evidence is prejudicial
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Even under the more
defendant-friendly Brady standard, we cannot say that this
evidence undermines our confidence in the jury's verdict or
justifies a finding that the district court abused its discretion
in failing to vacate the judgment and order a new trial.
misconduct_determination_term1:
we cannot say that this
evidence undermines our confidence in the jury's verdict
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Unimpressed by the quality of
this evidence and constrained by a deferential standard of
review, we conclude that the district court acted within the
encincture of its discretion in denying the motion.
misconduct_determination_term2:
we conclude that the district court acted within the
encincture of its discretion in denying the motion.

allegation_sentence_1:
Hennington also
makes that same complaint and, in addition, asserts that two
instances of alleged prosecutorial misconduct entitle him to
a new trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
The second instance of
alleged misconduct was the prosecutor's questions concerning
a notebook/diary, kept by Crystal, in which the prosecutor
asked Hennington, “Do you know why your sister would
write in her notebook one of her aims for the year was to
get Mario [Hennington] to stop making his trips.”
allegation_term_2: alleged misconduct was the prosecutor's questions
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We reject
these contentions and affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
While use
of the conversation recorded on November 7, 1987 and the
mention of Crystal's notebook may have been improper, the
strength of the government's case, combined with the district
court's sustaining the objections made, its curative instruction
regarding the arrest, and the context of and lack of complaint
respecting its ruling on the notebook, lead us to conclude that
the cumulative effect of these two instances over the course
of a five-day trial was at most very slight and that the error,
if any, was harmless.
misconduct_determination_term2:
the error,
if any, was harmless.

motion to declare a mistrial is
denied.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:

the comments made during the

allegation_sentence_1:
Blade challenges
his conviction and sentence, claiming (1) prosecutorial
misconduct and discrimination; (2) ineffective assistance of
counsel; (3) judicial misconduct; and (4) actual innocence.
allegation_sentence_2:
Blade's allegations of prosecutorial misconduct and
discrimination include claims that (1) the grand jury process
was violated with improper evidence and testimony, (2)
charging decisions were vindictive and discriminatory, (3)
handwritten notes were improperly withheld from him, (4)
a witness was threatened, (5) the Government breached a
court order requiring identification of a co-conspirator, (6) the
Government suborned perjury, and (7) the Government used
improper questioning patterns.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: For the following reasons, Blade's Motion is DENIED.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Blade's
request for relief based on prosecutorial misconduct and
discrimination is therefore DENIED.
misconduct_determination_term2:
Blade's
request for relief based on prosecutorial misconduct and
discrimination is therefore DENIED.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The record shows Blade's claims of prosecutorial
misconduct, ineffective assistance of counsel, and judicial
misconduct have no merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Further, Blade's
arguments are futile and the law and record contradict his
allegations.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Even if these grounds were cognizable in a § 2255 proceeding,
Blade has not provided a shred of evidence from the record to
support his allegations.
misconduct_determination_term5: has not provided a shred of evidence

allegation_sentence_1:

misconduct_determination_sentence3:

improper vouching.
misconduct_determination_term3:
does not amount to
improper vouching.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:

prosecutorial misconduct does not require reversal.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:

misconduct_determination_sentence6:

convictions and sentence are
AFFIRMED.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:

in this case

allegation_sentence_1:
Mr. Holmes urges us to hold that improper
comments made by the government during closing arguments
deprived him of his fifth amendment right to a fair
trial.
allegation_term_1:
improper
comments made by the government
allegation_sentence_2:
The district court has broad discretion in controlling
closing arguments, and we overturn a conviction on the
basis of prosecutorial misconduct only upon a showing
that improper remarks, in light of any rulings or curative
instructions by the district court and in light of the trial as a
whole, could reasonably have affected the jury's verdict.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Under this standard, we find that the
cumulative effect of the remarks in this case, coupled with the
exclusion of admissible testimony and the relative weakness
of the government's case, could reasonably have affected the
jury's verdict.
misconduct_determination_term1:
we find that the
cumulative effect of the remarks
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
These types of statements
are highly improper because they improperly encourage the
jury to focus on the conduct and role of Mr. Holmes's attorney
rather than on the evidence of Mr. Holmes's guilt.
misconduct_determination_term2:
These types of statements
are highly improper
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because the government's case was
not strong, witnesses offered by the defense were improperly
excluded, the comments occurred during rebuttal arguments,
*777 and the comments were of a highly prejudicial nature,
we conclude that the defendant should be granted a new
trial. 1
misconduct_determination_term3: the comments were of a highly prejudicial nature
misconduct_determination_sentence4: We reverse and remand for a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: The government made two other potentially prejudicial comments.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
I would not reverse this conviction based on the remarks that
the government's counsel made during closing arguments.
concur_dissent_term_1: I would not reverse this conviction
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
I would uphold this judgment and therefore respectfully
dissent

allegation_sentence_1:
Frost asserts prosecutorial
misconduct, challenges two of the seven violations found
by the district court, claims that the district court revoked
his supervised release without properly considering the
applicable statutory sentencing factors, and assigns error to
the district court's imposition of a condition that restricts
Frost's consumption of alcohol during supervised release.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Finding no merit in Frost's various contentions, we affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The government did
not deprive Frost of a fair hearing on his alleged violations
of supervised release when the prosecutor advised him prior
to the hearing that he was being investigated for criminal
conduct allegedly committed while on supervised release.
misconduct_determination_term2:
The government did
not deprive Frost of a fair hearing
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Thus, the
choice not to testify was his to make and *577 nothing
suggests that the government violated any of Frost's legal
rights by informing him of the possible new criminal charges
against him.
misconduct_determination_term3:
nothing
suggests that the government violated
misconduct_determination_sentence4: AFFIRMED.

allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, Foreman
seeks a new trial, arguing that the district court 1
 committed
reversible error by admitting two documents as business
records under Federal Rule of Evidence 803(6) and that
the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct by
asking her improper questions on cross-examination.

commented on her decision to invoke her constitutional right
to go to trial
allegation_term_2:
claims that the prosecutor improperly
commented
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the
following reasons, we affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We conclude that these questions did not affect the
outcome of the trial.

did not affect the
outcome of the trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Even assuming, without deciding, that the Government's
questions were plainly improper, the errors were not so
prejudicial as to affect the outcome of the trial.
misconduct_determination_term3:
not so
prejudicial as to affect the outcome of the trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the judgment of the
district court.

decision_court: United States District Court, N.D. New York
attorneys_judges:
Thomas J. Maroney, U.S. Atty., N.D.N.Y., Syracuse, NY
(Craig A. Benedict, Asst. U.S. Atty., of counsel), for U.S.//
Bond Schoeneck & King; Syracuse, NY (George H. Lowe, of counsel), for George Jackson.//
Honigman Miller, Schwartz & Cohn, Detroit, MI (Richard
E. Zuckerman, of counsel), for Robert Gehl Tempotech
Industries and Gehl Productions//
NEAL P. McCURN, Senior District Judge
geography_entities: Syracuse, NY//Detroit, MI//
allegation_sentence_1:
More specifically, the Gehl defendants contend that they
are entitled to those various forms of post-verdict relief for
the following reasons: (1) prosecutorial misconduct; (2)
prejudicial surplusage in the indictment; (3) the invalidity of
the New York regulation underlying the Lacey Act counts; (4)
claimed evidentiary errors; (5) count two violated the statute
of limitations; (6) insufficiency of the evidence as to all of the
substantive counts and the forfeiture count; (7) the indictment
does not comply with the Lacey Act and it violates the Fifth
and Sixth Amendments; and (8) the jury instructions were in
error
allegation_sentence_2:
The Gehl defendants vehemently contend that AUSA
Benedict engaged in prosecutorial misconduct in several
ways.
allegation_term_2:
contend that AUSA
Benedict engaged in prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_3:
Second, the Gehl defendants contend that in his
closing argument AUSA Benedict improperly referred to
the residents of New York as victims of contamination.
allegation_term_3:
contend that in his
closing argument AUSA Benedict improperly referred
allegation_sentence_4:
Third, they argue that Benedict made a number of improper
comments in his closing argument, including several remarks
about the defendants' failure to testify or to call witnesses,
and the defendants believe this last comment in particular was
intentional.
allegation_term_4:
improper
comments in his closing argument
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The short answer is that
they did not; the Gehl defendants, quite simply, are unable
to demonstrate to the court's satisfaction the “substantial
prejudice” necessary to prevail on a claim of prosecutorial
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term1:
defendants, quite simply, are unable
to demonstrate to the court's satisfaction the “substantial
prejudice”
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Furthermore, as with
nearly all of the prosecutor's remarks in closing, 20 which the
defendants complain of by this motion, when viewed, as they
must be, “in the context of the entire summation,” 21 the court
cannot find, insofar as the Gehl defendants are concerned, that
AUSA Benedict engaged in prosecutorial misconduct while
giving his summation.
misconduct_determination_term2:
the court
cannot find, insofar as the Gehl defendants are concerned, that
AUSA Benedict engaged in prosecutorial misconduct while
giving his summation.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
But, assuming for the moment
that this particular comment by AUSA Benedict did amount
to misconduct, as should be apparent from the court's earlier
discussion, his other comments in closing and elsewhere
did not constitute misconduct; and so, unlike Hardy, at the
very most, this was an isolated instance of prosecutorial
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term3:
this was an isolated instance of prosecutorial
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The most that can be said of the AUSA's
remarks in this case, particularly his questioning during
summation of the defendants' decision not to call any
witnesses, is that such remarks amounted to prosecutorial
overkill; but, as the case law makes clear, prosecutorial
overkill is not equivalent to prosecutorial misconduct.

Price, Detroit, Mich., for defendant-appellant in No. 83-1099.//

allegation_sentence_1:
Levine argues that he was prejudiced by the denial of his
motion to sever and that severe prosecutorial misconduct
deprived him of a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Levine argues that certain acts of misconduct by the
prosecution, taken in their totality, deprived him of a fair trial.
allegation_term_2:
argues that certain acts of misconduct by the
prosecution
allegation_sentence_3:
The failure of the government to make a timely
disclosure of Brady material.
allegation_sentence_4:
The government improperly vouched for the credibility
of Kassim, based upon remarks by the Assistant United
States Attorney in closing argument to the effect that
Kassim had told the truth in her testimony because she
had no motive to lie.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We are convinced that several instances of
prosecutorial misconduct occurred in the trial of this action.
misconduct_determination_term1:
We are convinced that several instances of
prosecutorial misconduct occurred
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Although we think that the conduct of the prosecutor in this
case was inexcusable, we do not find the facts present a
clear and compelling case for reversal given the substantial
evidence of guilt and the efforts of the trial court to take
corrective measures to eliminate the resulting prejudice.
misconduct_determination_term2:
we do not find the facts present a
clear and compelling case for reversal]
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We also find
merit in Levine's contention that the failure to timely disclose
this Brady material obstructed his ability to prepare for trial
and undermined his ability to present his theory of defense.
misconduct_determination_term3:
the failure to timely disclose
this Brady material obstructed his ability
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Accordingly, the convictions of Krebs and Levine are
affirmed.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Whether or not the
evidence was properly admissible is relevant to the question of whether the outcome of the trial was materially affected,
but inadmissibility does not excuse prosecutorial misconduct.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
Although the question is a close
one, I concur with the conclusion that the actions of the
trial court were *1178 sufficient, but barely sufficient, to
overcome these shortcomings and the negligent conduct of
the prosecution.
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
I would therefore also affirm as to defendant Levine but with
some considerable trepidation.

allegation_sentence_1:
He raises three issues on appeal: 1) the district court erred
in denying his motion to suppress evidence of a statement that
he gave to police; 2) the jury conviction was not supported
by constitutionally sufficient evidence; and 3) prosecutorial
misconduct denied him a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Finally, defendant contends that the government
committed prosecutorial misconduct during opening
statement when the Assistant United States Attorney
(“AUSA”) made the following comments about the upcoming
testimony:
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Any misstatement made in the opening argument was
inadvertent and isolated.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In short, the statements, while regrettable,
do not rise to the level of the “flagrant” and did not so mislead
the jury that defendant was deprived of a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term2: do not rise to the level of the “flagrant”
misconduct_determination_sentence3: The judgment of the district court is affirmed

allegation_sentence_1:
In his pro se brief on appeal, Hinton raises the following
alleged trial errors: (1) ineffective assistance of counsel,
(2) prosecutorial misconduct, (3) insufficient evidence, (4)
erroneous evidentiary rulings, and (5) improper admission
of coconspirator statements.
allegation_sentence_2:
He claims that the
prosecutor acted improperly during his opening statement by
referring to Hinton's prior drug conviction and by stating that
Hinton had threatened to kill a DEA agent and attempted to
run over the agent with a truck when testimony did not support
these statements
allegation_term_2:
claims that the
prosecutor acted improperly
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Upon review, we deny the motion for counsel and affirm the
district court's judgment of conviction.
misconduct_determination_term1:
affirm the
district court's judgment of conviction.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Hinton's assertion of prosecutorial misconduct is
insufficient to warrant a new trial
misconduct_determination_term2: insufficient to warrant a new trial
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We
find no plain error here; testimony was presented on each of
the matters to which the prosecutor alluded in his opening
statement.
misconduct_determination_term3:
We
find no plain error here
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The reference to the prior conviction was not
improper, Hinton having been charged with being a felon in
possession of a firearm.
misconduct_determination_term4:
The reference to the prior conviction was not
improper
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Accordingly, we affirm the district court's judgment of
conviction.
misconduct_determination_term5:
we affirm the district court's judgment of
conviction.

decision_court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
attorneys_judges:
Albert A. Mezzaroba, Masciocchi & Mezzaroba,
Philadelphia, PA, for Edward M. Zinner.//

geography_entities: Philadelphia, PA//
allegation_sentence_1:
Petitioner, Edward M. Zinner, filed a pro se motion
to vacate, set aside, or correct his sentence pursuant to
28 U.S.C.A. § 2255 (West 1994), alleging both ineffective
assistance of counsel and prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Zinner maintains that the Government committed
prosecutorial misconduct by misrepresenting representing
that Zinner's gross receipts from businesses were direct
income to Zinner, misstating that band equipment was
missing, falsely arguing that Zinner failed to disclose
income, misrepresenting Zinner's use of the Harley and
transfer of the Clam House as violations of a Court Order,
and miscalculating the actual loss inflicted at $1,000,000.
allegation_sentence_3:
According to Zinner, the Government violated the plea
agreement by opposing Zinner's request for acceptance of
responsibility.
allegation_term_3:
the Government violated the plea
agreement
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the
following reasons, the Court will deny Zinner's Motion.
misconduct_determination_term1: the Court will deny Zinner's Motion.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The Government quite correctly counters that Zinner can
show no prejudice from the factual disputes surrounding
his allegation of prosecutorial misconduct since the Court
granted the Government's Motion to depart downward
from the Guidelines pursuant to U.S.S.G. § 5K1.1
misconduct_determination_term2:
can
show no prejudice from the factual disputes surrounding
his allegation of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence3: The Government did not breach the Guilty Plea Agreement.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The Government did not mislead the Court with regard to
gross receipts from business ventures, band equipment, rents,
the Florida bank account, the Harley, the Clam House, and
the piano.
misconduct_determination_term4: Government did not mislead the Court
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Accordingly, the Court finds no prosecutorial
misconduct with respect to arguments proffered during
sentencing.
misconduct_determination_term5:
the Court finds no prosecutorial
misconduct

allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, White argues that he
was denied a fair trial as a result of erroneous discovery
rulings, erroneous evidentiary rulings, and prosecutorial
misconduct, and that the district court erred sentencing him
to life in prison.
allegation_sentence_2:
White argues that the prosecutor acted improperly in
conducting a highly prejudicial cross examination of him
at trial.
allegation_term_2:
argues that the prosecutor acted improperly in
conducting a highly prejudicial cross examination
allegation_sentence_3:
White argues that the prosecutor also
committed reversible error in his closing remarks.
allegation_term_3:
argues that the prosecutor also
committed reversible error in his closing
allegation_sentence_4:
White asserts that the prosecutor injected his personal opinion
as to the credibility of witnesses during closing argument.
allegation_term_4: asserts that the prosecutor injected his personal opinion
allegation_sentence_5:
White argues that the prosecutor shifted the
burden of proof during closing argument
allegation_term_5:
the prosecutor shifted the
burden of proof
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the following reasons, we affirm White's
convictions but reverse his sentence and remand to the district
court for re-sentencing in accordance with this opinion.
misconduct_determination_term1:
we affirm White's
convictions but reverse his sentence
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Otherwise, the prosecutor did not act
improperly during his cross-examination of White.
misconduct_determination_term2:
the prosecutor did not act
improperly during his cross-examination
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The one comment in which the
prosecutor committed error was in stating that White had
“never paid taxes in [his] life.”
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
That error alone is not enough to constitute reversible error
on plain error review where we reverse “only in exceptional
circumstances.”
misconduct_determination_term4: not enough to constitute reversible error
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
As in Collins,
comments by the prosecution were wholly unnecessary,
however the errors were harmless as the prosecutor here
largely argued the facts presented to the jury, did not “misle
[a]d the jury” nor did he “remove the issue of credibility of
witnesses from the jury.”
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
"For the forgoing reasons, we find no reversible error and
affirm White's convictions."

allegation_sentence_1:
Second, Petitioner contends that he is entitled to relief
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2255 based upon prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Petitioner has cited four instances of misconduct by the
prosecutor which he asserts entitles him to relief pursuant
to 28 U.S.C. § 2255
allegation_term_2:
cited four instances of misconduct by the
prosecutor
allegation_sentence_3:
Second, Petitioner contends that the Government's
attorney tendered false and misleading evidence to the
jury during his trial in order to obtain his conviction.
allegation_term_3:
contends that the Government's
attorney tendered false and misleading evidence
allegation_sentence_4:
Fourth, Petitioner asserts
that the Government's attorney breached the agreement which
the prosecutor had made with him and his counsel
allegation_term_4:
asserts
that the Government's attorney breached the agreement
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Petition denied
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The Court finds that Petitioner has suffered no prejudice as a
result of any actions taken by the Government's attorney
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accordingly,
the Court finds that Petitioner has failed to show prejudice
from the Government's use of the Deputies' testimony at trial
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The Court also finds that Petitioner was not subjected to
any vindictive prosecution by the Government.
misconduct_determination_term4:
Petitioner was not subjected to
any vindictive prosecution
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Accordingly, the Court finds that Petitioner has failed to
establish prejudice from his failure to appeal his procedurally
defaulted prosecutorial misconduct claim and that, to the
extent that his § 2255 petition is based upon a claim of
prosecutorial misconduct, his petition to vacate, set aside,
or correct his sentence is denied.
misconduct_determination_term5:
Petitioner has failed to
establish prejudice
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Defendant is correct that the
Government technically breached its agreement with him by
failing to call an expert witness to testify that Petitioner's
fingerprints were not found on the firearm at issue in Count
I of his Indictment in exchange for Petitioner's signing four
stipulations used by the Government during the trial
misconduct_determination_term6:
the
Government technically breached its agreement

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant now moves
for this court to vacate his plea and sentence pursuant
to section 2255 on the basis that his counsel was
ineffective, the Assistant United States Attorney committed
prosecutorial misconduct and the undersigned committed
judicial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant next spends a considerable amount of time
asserting that the prosecutor committed misconduct by
concealing grand jury material, prosecuting defendant
because of his race, violating defendant's right to a speedy
trial, and conspiring with defense counsel.
allegation_term_2: asserting that the prosecutor committed misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the
following reasons, the court concludes that the motion and the
files and records conclusively show that defendant is entitled
to no relief and thus denies the motion.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Nevertheless, the court finds that defendant's allegations
of prosecutorial misconduct are utterly without merit and
lack any evidentiary support.
misconduct_determination_term2:
defendant's allegations
of prosecutorial misconduct are utterly without merit

filed a “Motion to Vacate Judgment of Conviction and to
Dismiss, or, in the Alternative for a New Trial” with this
Court in which he alleged that he was entitled to relief
from his convictions and sentence based upon prosecutorial
misconduct
allegation_sentence_2:
Specifically, Petitioner asserts that he
was denied his due process and equal protection rights in
that the Government violated 18 U.S.C. § 201, the Court did
not instruct the jury regarding the Government's violation of
18 U.S.C. § 201, the prosecution labored under a conflict
of interest, and the prosecution violated its obligations
under Brady and Giglio.

the prosecution violated its obligations
under Brady and Giglio.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Ergo, Petitioner's petition pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2255 to
vacate, set aside, or correct his sentence is DENIED.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The Court was aware
of the egregious conduct of the prosecutors in this case when
it denied Petitioner's motion for a new trial.
misconduct_determination_term2: denied Petitioner's motion for a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The Court previously found that the
prosecutors' conduct did not constitute sufficient grounds to
grant Petitioner a new trial, nor does the Court now believe
it to be sufficient grounds to vacate, set aside, or correct
Petitioner's convictions and sentence pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §
2255.

nor does the Court now believe

allegation_sentence_1:
The defendant has set
forth specific portions of the grand jury testimony which
he believes demonstrate grand jury misconduct sufficient to
warrant an in camera review of the prosecutor's statements to
the grand jury.
allegation_sentence_2:
The defendant here argues that the manner of
the prosecution's questioning of witnesses constitutes grounds
for in camera review, and that it “conceivably prejudiced
the defendant by interfering with the grand jury's role as an
independent fact-finder and by influencing its decision in
regard to count three.”
allegation_term_2:
argues that the manner of
the prosecution's questioning of witnesses
allegation_sentence_3:
The defendant questions three aspects of the prosecutor's
conduct before the grand jury: first, the prosecutor's arguably
incorrect characterization of the potential for prosecution
of certain witnesses, as going to their credibility; second,
skeptical, or suggestive questioning by the prosecutor,
argued by the defendant to be planting or vouching for the
prosecution's version of the situation; third, questions by
the prosecution which assumed facts, and according to the
defendant, arguably key facts, not testified to by the witness.
allegation_term_3:
questions three aspects of the prosecutor's
conduct before the grand jury
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
I cannot find that these instances of the
prosecutor's conduct raise concern, let alone particularized
need, so as to warrant an in camera review of other grand jury
materials.
misconduct_determination_term1:
I cannot find that these instances of the
prosecutor's conduct raise concern
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The last instance of alleged prosecutorial behavior offered
by the defendant is, however, more troubling.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because I
have serious concerns as to the impact that the prosecutor's
statements may have had on the grand jury's decision to
indict the defendant, I will examine the grand jury materials
requested in camera and will consider after that review
whether any materials should be shared with the defense.
misconduct_determination_term3:
I
have serious concerns as to the impact that the prosecutor's
statements may have had on the grand jury's

Joseph E. McGettigan, III, Kathy A. Stark, U.S.
Attorney's Office, Philadelphia, PA, for United States of
America//
John J. Griffin, Law Office of John J. Griffin, Hope C.
Lefeber, Philadelphia, PA, for Harold Ford.//POLLAK, District Judge.
geography_entities: Philadelphia, PA//Coatesville, Pennsylvania//
allegation_sentence_1:
Alternatively, in his Rule 29 motion, Ford seeks acquittal on
Count 1 on grounds of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Ford argues that the prosecutor engaged in a pattern
of misconduct that included vouching for the credibility of
the government's witnesses and lodging unfounded attacks
on Ford's counsel-a pattern which, Ford argues, began during
opening statements and culminated in the prosecutor's closing
argument and, in particular, the closing-argument rebuttal.
allegation_term_2:
argues that the prosecutor engaged in a pattern
of misconduct
allegation_sentence_3:
While Ford alleges that the prosecutor engaged in misconduct
throughout the course of the trial, the focal point of
my analysis will be the prosecutor's remarks during the
government's closing-argument rebuttal.
allegation_term_3: alleges that the prosecutor engaged in misconduct
allegation_sentence_4:
Ford contends that, in his rebuttal, the prosecutor
committed misconduct by vouching for the credibility of the
government witnesses and disparaging Ford's counsel.
allegation_term_4:
the prosecutor
committed misconduct by vouching
allegation_sentence_5:
Linked to these vouching claims is Ford's contention that
the prosecutor impugned the truthfulness of Ford's counsel
based on information outside the record.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Instead, the prosecutor relied on the prestige of his office
to counter the suspicions that Ford's counsel attempted to
convey to the jury through arguments that, while aggressive,
were grounded in the record.
misconduct_determination_term1: the prosecutor relied on the prestige of his office
misconduct_determination_sentence2: This is misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accordingly, because I believe that there is a significant
possibility that the fairness of the jury's verdict may have been
threatened by the prosecutorial vouching and attacks on the
defendant's counsel, I will exercise my discretion to set aside
the jury's verdict on count one of the indictment and grant
Ford a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
They bore no relationship
to the evidence at bar, and they were incompatible with
the constraints *395 that guide a prosecutor.
misconduct_determination_term4:
incompatible with
the constraints *395 that guide a prosecutor.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Thus, regardless of whether the prosecutor's
observations were uttered in response to what the prosecutor
perceived to be an inappropriate defense tactic, the prosecutor
engaged in misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Consequently, I must
conclude that there is not a high probability that the
prosecutorial misconduct in this case did not contribute to
the jury's verdict.
misconduct_determination_term6:
Consequently, I must
conclude that there is not a high probability that the
prosecutorial misconduct in this case did not contribute to
the jury's verdict.

allegation_sentence_1:
Convicted for assault on a federal officer with a deadly
weapon and of using a firearm during a crime of violence
Lynn T. Crawford contends, pro se, that the evidence is
insufficient to support his convictions, that the district court
abused its discretion by failing to give his proposed selfdefense
jury instruction, that the jury instructions concerning
reasonable doubt, deliberate ignorance, assault, and intent
were erroneous, that he was subjected to prosecutorial
misconduct, and that the district court failed to adequately
preserve the record.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Crawford has not shown that he was subjected to
prosecutorial misconduct because the prosecutor made
prejudicial remarks during his opening statement, closing
argument, and rebuttal argument
misconduct_determination_term1:
has not shown that he was subjected to
prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Although Crawford lists numerous instances of alleged error,
he has not shown that the prosecutor's comments were
improper or that they affected his substantial rights.
misconduct_determination_term2:
has not shown that the prosecutor's comments were
improper or that they affected his substantial rights.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
As Crawford has not shown any individual instance of
prosecutorial misconduct, his argument that the cumulative
effect of all of the prosecutor's comments denied his right to
a fair trial is without merit.
misconduct_determination_term3:
has not shown any individual instance of
prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Crawford has not shown error on the part of the district
court; his convictions are AFFIRMED.

allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, Henderson initially contends that the
Government's closing argument, as it pertained to an alleged
attempted armed robbery, was improper.
allegation_term_1:
contends that the
Government's closing argument
allegation_sentence_2:
We review a
claim of prosecutorial misconduct “to determine whether
the conduct so infected the trial with unfairness as to
make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.”
allegation_term_2:
We review a
claim of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Finding no error, we affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Even if the remarks could be said to have
prejudiced Henderson by misleading the jury or diverting
its attention, such prejudice was minimal when compared to
the compelling evidence introduced to establish Henderson's
guilt.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Moreover, the remarks at issue comprise
only a fraction of the Government's lengthy closing and
rebuttal arguments.
misconduct_determination_term3:
fraction of the Government's lengthy closing and
rebuttal arguments.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Thus,
we conclude Henderson has failed to establish that the
Government's remarks constitute reversible error
misconduct_determination_term4:
failed to establish that the
Government's remarks constitute reversible error
misconduct_determination_sentence5: Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the district court.

allegation_sentence_1:
