the district court erred in denying his motion for a new
trial based upon improper remarks by the prosecutor during
closing argument. F
allegation_term_1:
improper remarks by the prosecutor during
closing argument
allegation_sentence_2:
To prevail on a claim of prosecutorial misconduct, Blanco
must show: (1) the government's remarks and conduct were
improper; and (2) the remarks or conduct prejudicially
affected his substantial rights so as to deprive him of a
fair trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
Blanco contends that
the prosecutor's comments constituted a plea to convict him
to protect community values, preserve civil order, or deter
commission of future offenses.
allegation_term_3:
contends that
the prosecutor's comments constituted a plea
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Finding no error, we affirm the judgment
misconduct_determination_sentence2:

there was no prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2:
did not err in concluding that
there was no prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The
comments cannot fairly be said to incite the passions and
prejudices of the jurors.
misconduct_determination_term3:
cannot fairly be said to incite the passions and
prejudices of the jurors.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Even if the Government's remarks were improper, Blanco
suffered no prejudice.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The comments objected to by Blanco were isolated and
minimal in nature compared to the rest of the argument by
the prosecutor
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Further, there was overwhelming and
uncontroverted evidence of Blanco's guilt presented at trial
misconduct_determination_term6:
overwhelming and
uncontroverted evidence of Blanco's guilt

allegation_sentence_1:
Mr. Kennedy filed this
petition on April 22, 1997, asserting multiple claims that he
categorizes variously as: (1) prosecutorial misconduct; (2)
commission of error by this Court in allowing the prosecutor
to read the contents of a prejudicial exhibit in the jury's
presence, in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth
Amendment of the United States Constitution; (3) improper
reference to Mr. Kennedy's religious activities during trial,
in violation of the First and Fifth Amendments of the United
States Constitution; and (4) ineffective assistance of trial
counsel in violation of the Sixth Amendment of the United
States Constitution.
allegation_sentence_2:
He alleges that the
prosecution: (1) intentionally, recklessly, or knowingly
intruded into his attorney-client relationship in violation
of the Fifth and Sixth Amendments of the United States
Constitution; (2) failed to disclose exculpatory evidence as
required by Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194,
10 L.Ed.2d 215 (1963); (3) misrepresented material facts to
Mr. Kennedy's trial counsel and the district court during the
WMC case; (4) informally assured prosecutorial immunity to
a grand jury witness; and (5) imposed an obligation of secrecy
on a grand jury witness regarding the scope of the grand jury
process.
allegation_term_2:
alleges that the
prosecution: (1) intentionally, recklessly, or knowingly
allegation_sentence_3:
Mr. Kennedy also contends that the prosecutor failed to
disclose exculpatory information as required by Brady v.
Maryland,
allegation_term_3:
contends that the prosecutor failed to
disclose exculpatory information
allegation_sentence_4:
Mr. Kennedy also avers that AUSA Peters misrepresented
certain facts on two occasions.
allegation_sentence_5:
Mr. Kennedy also claims that the prosecution unfairly
emphasized his religious beliefs during the grand jury process
and the WMC trial.
allegation_term_5:
claims that the prosecution unfairly
emphasized
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because
the petition, files, and records of the case conclusively show
that Mr. Kennedy is entitled to no relief on his claims
for ineffective assistance of counsel and intrusion into his
attorney-client relationship, I deny his petition.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Because the allegedly undisclosed information is immaterial,
Mr. Kennedy's Brady claim is procedurally barred.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because Mr. Danley did not
testify at the WMC trial, the prosecution did not violate Giglio
even if a grant of informal immunity existed.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: When scrutinized, however, it is devoid of merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Accordingly, I ORDER that Defendant–Petitioner's motion to
vacate, set aside, or correct his sentence pursuant to § 2255
is DENIED.

allegation_sentence_1:
In his motion Wallace raised eleven separate
grounds for relief, including claims of ineffective assistance
of counsel, prosecutorial misconduct and challenges to
certain sentencing adjustments.
allegation_sentence_2:
He alleges prosecutorial misconduct by the
Government, including inter alia soliciting and using false
testimony, wrongfully using Wallace's booking photograph
and Florida license photograph at trial, and making improper
references to prejudicial facts not in evidence
allegation_term_2:
making improper
references to prejudicial facts not in evidence
allegation_sentence_3:
Wallace first claims that the Government solicited and used
false testimony of certain Government witnesses, to convict
him.
allegation_term_3:
claims that the Government solicited and used
false testimony
allegation_sentence_4:
Wallace further claims that the Government's attorney made
several improper remarks during closing argument, including
impermissible vouching, comments that impermissibly
shifted the burden of proof to Wallace and comments
assuming facts not in evidence.
allegation_term_4:
impermissible vouching, comments that impermissibly
shifted the burden of proof
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Thus, this claim of prosecutorial misconduct must fail.
misconduct_determination_term1: claim of prosecutorial misconduct must fail.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In short the testimony of Gallinelli, DiBiasio and Preston
was not inherently false, and the Government's use of that
testimony at trial was not improper.
misconduct_determination_term2:
Government's use of that
testimony at trial was not improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The remaining claims concerning the prosecutor's
closing remarks are all devoid of merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
As discussed supra at 285-87,
the prosecutorial remarks that Wallace challenges were not
improper, nor did they violate his due process rights.
misconduct_determination_term4:
the prosecutorial remarks that Wallace challenges were not
improper
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
In light of the host of evidence that the Government presented
during the course of the trial, even if any remarks in the
prosecutor's summation could be deemed improper, there
was no prejudice to Wallace.
misconduct_determination_term5:
there
was no prejudice to Wallace.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Thus, Wallace's claims that the Government prosecutor
assumed facts not in evidence during final arguments are
without merit and, thus, rejected.

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant Tyrone Walker (“defendant” or “Walker”) has
moved for a new trial pursuant to Rule 33 of the Federal Rules
of Criminal Procedure based upon claims of newly discovered
evidence and allegations of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Second, defendant alleges that Peterson's grand
jury testimony constituted Brady impeachment evidence, and
the prosecutors' failure to disclose this evidence constituted
prosecutorial misconduct sufficient to warrant a new trial.
allegation_term_2: prosecutors' failure to disclose this evidence
allegation_sentence_3:
In the present case, defendant claims that a new trial is
mandated because the government failed to disclose material
impeachment evidence concerning a government witness, in
violation of Brady v. Maryland,
allegation_term_3:
defendant claims that a new trial is
mandated because the government
misconduct_determination_sentence1: For the reasons that follow, defendant's motion is denied.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
When viewed in their totality, it is clear that defendant's
arguments are based on little more than rank speculation
insufficient to warrant a new trial.
misconduct_determination_term2: insufficient to warrant a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accepting defendant's contention that Peterson's grand
jury testimony would qualify as newly discovered evidence
under Fed.R.Crim.P. 33, and tended to exculpate the
defendant and impeach the credibility of Pettway, such
testimony would nevertheless not give rise to either a
Brady or Giglio violation.
misconduct_determination_term3:
testimony would nevertheless not give rise to either a
Brady or Giglio violation.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Defendant's claim of prosecutorial misconduct based on
allegations that the government withheld material evidence
in the form of Peterson's grand jury testimony and misled
the jury, is speculative.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Indeed, defendant's allegations
amount to mere speculation and when examined in their
totality, do not constitute prejudicial error sufficient to
warrant a new trial.

allegation_sentence_1:
Finally, we turn to Struckman's contention that the exclusion
of (1) all evidence attributed to “Ted,” (2) Dave Bowden
as a witness at trial, (3) evidence taken from Struckman's
car by Bowden and not disclosed at the time of the
district court's order, and (4) evidence “derived from” the
suppressed evidence was insufficient to cure the government's
Brady/Giglio violations.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We agree that the broad suppression of evidence before trial
was an adequate remedy for the misconduct found, disturbing
as some of it was, and therefore affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We affirm the denial of dismissal as
a remedy.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The
district court's extremely broad, pre-trial suppression order
was sufficient to provide this assurance here.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
With no showing in the record of
prejudice to the defendant and continuing defiance by the
government of an order of the district court to produce
“Ted's” identity, after the government prosecutors, knowingly
or not, repeatedly provided false information to the court and
then defied requests to provide sworn-to information about
“Ted's” identity.
concur_dissent_term_1:
government prosecutors, knowingly
or not, repeatedly provided false information to the court
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
Indubitably, this misbehavior of the government agents and
perhaps of the prosecutors affirmatively prevented the district
court from carrying out the required Roviaro balancing.
concur_dissent_term_2:
misbehavior of the government agents and
perhaps of the prosecutors
concur_dissent_sentence_3:
Here, the prosecutors
at a minimum failed to come forward with declarations
under penalty of perjury when asked; even if one supposes
that it was the agents who refused to provide the sworn
statements, that refusal should have put the prosecutors on
notice that there was a problem and led to a report to the
court, rather than repeated recalcitrance in the face of a court
order.
concur_dissent_term_3:
prosecutors
at a minimum failed to come forward with declarations
under penalty of perjury
notes: crazy case -- see concurring opinion: "I would think that personal sanctions against the offending government agents and, if appropriate, the prosecutors would be available [....] Further, a judicial referral to both the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury for discipline of the individuals involved would also be appropriate. And there may be other alternatives, such as barring the individuals involved from appearance in the district court as witnesses or prosecutors in other cases." // denial of MTD (but finding Brady violations) here: https://1.next.westlaw.com/Document/Iaa2c30001c8911e8b31ea4bd28ebac1b/View/FullText.html?listSource=RelatedInfo&docFamilyGuid=Iab78ad301c8911e8a3aeac357edf7e34&originationContext=judicialHistory&transitionType=HistoryItem&contextData=%28sc.Keycite%29

allegation_sentence_1:
Osuna–Zepeda next argues that it was error for the
AUSA to inquire whether Osuna–Zepeda made a statement
at the time of his arrest.
allegation_term_1:
argues that it was error for the
AUSA to inquire
allegation_sentence_2:
Osuna–Zepeda insists that such
a comment on his failure to make a statement violated
his Fifth Amendment right to remain silent, and that the
AUSA committed prosecutorial misconduct by eliciting
such testimony from the witness.
allegation_sentence_3:
Finally, Osuna–Zepeda argues that the district court
erred in denying his motion for a new trial on the ground
that the AUSA's cross-examination of Padilla–Armenta
prejudiced the trial. 3
allegation_term_3:
AUSA's cross-examination of Padilla–Armenta
prejudiced the trial.
allegation_sentence_4:
Osuna–Zepeda insists
that the AUSA intentionally misrepresented the facts—when
Padilla–Armenta first asserted Osuna–Zepeda's innocence—
in order to mislead the jury, and that this conduct was a
violation of a duty of disclosure *845 or candor.
allegation_term_4:
insists
that the AUSA intentionally misrepresented the facts
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Furthermore,
because the use of the testimony did not violate the Fifth
Amendment, the AUSA did not commit prosecutorial
misconduct by eliciting the testimony.
misconduct_determination_term1:
the AUSA did not commit prosecutorial
misconduct by eliciting the testimony.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
While we do not
advocate or condone the AUSA's conduct, we nevertheless
conclude that the district court did not abuse its discretion
by denying Osuna–Zepeda's motion.
misconduct_determination_term2:
we nevertheless
conclude that the district court did not abuse its discretion
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Considering not only the alleged misconduct,
but also the totality of the evidence and the conduct of the
trial overall, Osuna–Zepeda has not shown that any alleged
error “fatally infected” his trial or resulted in a miscarriage
of justice.
misconduct_determination_term3:
has not shown that any alleged
error “fatally infected” his trial or resulted in a miscarriage
of justice.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
For the reasons stated, we affirm the judgment of the district
court.
misconduct_determination_term4:
we affirm the judgment of the district
court.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
Although I concur in the judgment of the court, I
write separately because I believe Osuna–Zepeda's Fifth
Amendment right to remain silent was violated when, as part
of its case-in-chief, the government elicited comments from
the arresting officer regarding Osuna–Zepeda's silence after
he was arrested but before he received a Miranda warning.
concur_dissent_term_1:
the government elicited comments from
the arresting officer

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendants now seek relief from the jury's verdicts, arguing
that the evidence presented at trial was insufficient to
convict them, that the trial was hopelessly tainted by
prejudicial media coverage, that the Government engaged
in prosecutorial misconduct, and that the Government
improperly withheld critical evidence that casts doubt on
the reliability of the jury's guilty verdicts.
allegation_sentence_2:
Finally, both Ayers
and Dierker argue that the Government withheld exculpatory
evidence that would have altered the outcome of the trial had
it been properly disclosed.
allegation_term_2:
argue that the Government withheld exculpatory
evidence
allegation_sentence_3:
First, Dierker contends that AUSA Porter misled the jury
about Weiss's testimony.

misconduct by comparing Gibson's advances to Medshares to
Dierker's advances to California Psychiatric.
allegation_term_4:
argues that AUSA Porter engaged in
misconduct
allegation_sentence_5:
Ayers and Dierker assert that they are entitled to new
trials because the Government withheld material, exculpatory
evidence in violation of Brady v. Maryland,
allegation_term_5: in violation of Brady v. Maryland,
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the reasons
described below, the Court DENIES each of the Defendants'
motions. 2
misconduct_determination_term1:
the Court DENIES each of the Defendants'
motions.

AUSA McGovern's original question was improper
insofar as she said that Poulsen instructed the healthcare
providers to divert the payments on the receivables away from
National Century.
misconduct_determination_term2: AUSA McGovern's original question was improper
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
This impropriety does not necessitate a
new trial
misconduct_determination_term3:
None of these
statements is improper, let alone flagrant, and Dierker did not
even object to the first two.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
None of these
statements is improper
misconduct_determination_term4:
Because Ayers cannot satisfy the Brady or Rule 33 standards,
his request for a new trial is denied.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: cannot satisfy the Brady or Rule 33 standards
misconduct_determination_term5:
Accordingly, Dierker's motion for a new trial on the grounds
of prosecutorial misconduct is denied.
misconduct_determination_sentence6: denied

allegation_sentence_1:
As his claims are clarified by
counsel, Betterton asserts the following three grounds for
§ 2255 relief: (1) denial of his Fourteenth Amendment 2
right to a fair trial based on allegedly improper comments
made by the prosecutor during trial, which prejudiced the
jury;
allegation_term_1:
allegedly improper comments
made by the prosecutor
allegation_sentence_2:
Betterton's § 2255 counsel also asserts that the prosecutor
misstated the facts of the case and further prejudiced
Betterton during closing argument.
allegation_term_2:
asserts that the prosecutor
misstated the facts
allegation_sentence_3:
He contends that the cumulative effect of the
prosecutor's remarks prejudiced him and deprived him of a
fair trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Here, Betterton's claim of prosecutorial misconduct based
on the prosecutor allegedly asserting that Betterton was
a member of the Ku Klux Klan or eliciting prejudicial
testimony suggesting that Betterton was a member of the
Ku Klux Klan fails on the first prong of the analysis of
a claim of prosecutorial misconduct, because Betterton
cannot show that the prosecutor acted improperly.
misconduct_determination_term1:
Betterton
cannot show that the prosecutor acted improperly.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Betterton is not entitled to any § 2255 relief on the basis of
alleged prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Finally, Betterton has completely failed to identify
any alleged factual misstatements in the prosecutor's closing
argument or to show how any such misstatements were
sufficiently grave and misleading that they prejudicially
affected his substantial rights so as to deprive him of a
fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term3:
completely failed to identify
any alleged factual misstatements in the prosecutor's closing
argument

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant Richard Hawkins is moving to dismiss the
Indictment currently before the Court on grounds that the
prosecution committed numerous errors and engaged in
misconduct in the presentation of evidence before the Grand
Jury,
allegation_term_1:
grounds that the
prosecution committed numerous errors and engaged in
misconduct
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant contends that in obtaining these various
Indictments, the Government engaged in prejudicial conduct
that resulted in the return of an Indictment which contains
allegations for which there is no evidentiary support.
allegation_term_2: the Government engaged in prejudicial conduct
allegation_sentence_3:
More
specifically, defendant asserts that the Government engaged
in the following misconduct in its zeal to obtain the
Indictment in this matter:
allegation_term_3:
asserts that the Government engaged
in the following misconduct
allegation_sentence_4:
These allegations of prosecutorial wrongdoing
can be grouped, for purposes of analysis, as follows:
allegation_sentence_5:
Moreover,
defendant argues that when the Government did respond
to Juror inquiries, it rephrased questions in a way that
concealed exculpatory information and published a version
of facts more favorable to the Government's case.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Defendant's assertions of inaccurate or misleading
testimony presented to the Grand Jury regarding the
allegations contained in paragraphs 24, 28 and 33, when
considered in context, do not establish flagrant conduct on
behalf of the Government.
misconduct_determination_term1:
do not establish flagrant conduct on
behalf of the Government.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Nor has the defendant marshaled a showing of prejudice
warranting dismissal on this record.
misconduct_determination_term2:
showing of prejudice
warranting dismissal on this record.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Having evaluated the parties respective arguments, the
Court agrees with the Government and finds that defendant's
arguments do not give rise to a basis to dismiss the Indictment
in this matter for several reasons.
misconduct_determination_term3: do not give rise to a basis to dismiss the Indictment
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Moreover,
having reviewed Agent Cook's characterization of the January
6 meeting, the Court finds that the record fails to establish
any flagrant prosecutorial misconduct with respect to Agent
Cook's testimony.
misconduct_determination_term4:
to establish
any flagrant prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Therefore, and for the reasons set forth
above, the court DENIES defendant's Motion to Dismiss the
Second Superseding Indictment.

decision_court: U.S. Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces.
defendant:
Marcus T. GOLSTON,
Specialist, U.S. Army, Appellant.
attorneys_judges:
SULLIVAN, J., delivered the opinion of the Court, in
which CRAWFORD, C.J., GIERKE and EFFRON, JJ., and
COX, S.J., joined. GIERKE, J., filed a concurring opinion, in
which COX, S.J., joined.//
For Appellant: Captain Blair T. O'Connor (argued); Colonel
Adele H. Odegard, Major Scott R. Morris, and Captain
Kirsten Campbell–Brunson (on brief); Colonel John T.
Phelps II.//
*62 For Appellee: Captain Katherine M. Kane (argued);
Colonel Russell S. Estey and Captain Mary E. Braisted (on
brief).
geography_entities: Darmstadt and Kaiserslautern, Germany//
allegation_sentence_1:
Appellant has lodged a three-prong attack on the conduct of
trial counsel in his case and asserts that he was substantially
prejudiced by trial counsel's prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Appellant's next argument is that trial counsel actually
“breached” his attorney-client relationship with appellant's
wife and improperly used her confidences to impeach her as
a witness at appellant's court-martial.
allegation_term_2:
trial counsel actually
“breached” his attorney-client relationship
allegation_sentence_3:
Appellant's final argument is that trial counsel engaged
in prosecutorial misconduct when he failed to sua sponte
inform the military judge of a possible conflict of interest
in this case.
allegation_term_3:
failed to sua sponte
inform the military judge of a possible conflict of interest
allegation_sentence_4:
Appellant broadly asserts that such prosecutorial inaction
caused his case to “reek with the appearance of impropriety.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We hold that trial counsel's failure to promptly disclose
his prior attorney-client relationship with appellant's wife, a
defense witness in this case, did not substantially prejudice
appellant's right to a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term1:
did not substantially prejudice
appellant's right to a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Nevertheless, the record before us overwhelmingly
established that trial counsel, as a matter of fact, did not
divulge attorney-client confidences to assistant trial counsel
for purposes of cross-examining appellant's wife.
misconduct_determination_term2:
trial counsel, as a matter of fact, did not
divulge attorney-client confidences
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We conclude that
trial counsel failed in this duty to avoid even the appearance
of wrongdoing in the area of attorney-client relationships.
misconduct_determination_term3: trial counsel failed in this duty
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Nevertheless, we conclude that appellant was not
prejudiced by trial counsel's *67 failure to inform the
military judge and the defense about this possible conflict of
interest.
misconduct_determination_term4:
we conclude that appellant was not
prejudiced by trial counsel's *67 failure
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
I agree that appellant
was not prejudiced.
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
The prosecution team violated the precept
announced in McCluskey and codified in the ABA Code of
Professional Responsibility.
concur_dissent_term_2: The prosecution team violated the precept
concur_dissent_sentence_3:
I
sincerely hope that this case will cause prosecutors to be more
sensitive to the potential for conflicts of interest arising from
multiple military duties.

United States Court of Appeals,

attorneys_judges:

Williams and Brian I. Rademacher (on the brief and argued),

allegation_sentence_1:
Third, Wright maintains that he was denied a fair
trial based on: (1) the district court's exclusion of evidence
under Federal Rule of Evidence 404(b); (2) prosecutorial
misconduct throughout the course of the trial; (3) Wright's
limited access to a mirrored copy of the computer's hard drive;
and (4) an erroneous jury instruction that failed to require the
jury to find Wright knew the files charged in the indictment
existed on his computer and contained child pornography.
allegation_sentence_2:
First, Wright argues that the prosecutor improperly
inserted his personal disbelief of the defense and submitted
his own testimony to the jury.
allegation_term_2:
argues that the prosecutor improperly
inserted his personal disbelief
allegation_sentence_3:
Wright contends that the
prosecutor's statements constitute impermissible vouching.
allegation_sentence_4:
Wright next contends that the prosecutor manipulated or
misstated the evidence and forced Wright to imply that Agent
Andrews lied on the stand.
allegation_term_4:
prosecutor manipulated or
misstated the evidence
allegation_sentence_5:
Finally, Wright argues that the prosecutor improperly
insulted him several times throughout cross-examination
and in the prosecutor's closing argument.
allegation_term_5:
argues that the prosecutor improperly
insulted
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Though the prosecutor's statement might not
technically be viewed as improper vouching, it was certainly
improper, since it “denigrat[ed] the defense as a sham.”
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Similarly, the prosecutor's repeated references to how he
viewed the evidence were also improper
misconduct_determination_term2:
prosecutor's repeated references to how he
viewed the evidence were also improper
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
There was nothing improper
about the prosecutor's conduct in that instance.
misconduct_determination_term3:
nothing improper
about the prosecutor's conduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Wright has not established prejudice.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Accordingly,
the prosecutor's improper statements amounted to harmless
error.
misconduct_determination_term5:
prosecutor's improper statements amounted to harmless
error.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Neither error, on its own,
requires reversal.

in the indictment (“constructive amendment,” duplicity and

allegation_sentence_1:
To that end, Petitioner
raises the following claims in his Section 2255 petition:
(1) Petitioner is Actually and Factually Innocent of the
Government's 18 U.S.C. § 924(c)(1) Charge; (2) Petitioner
was Deprived of Due Process of Law through Prosecutorial
Misconduct for Withholding Information; (3) Petitioner's
Second Amendment Rights were Violated; (4) Petitioner was
Denied Due Process of Law when the Government filed New
Criminal Facts Against Him; (5) Petitioner was Deprived
of his Sixth Amendment Rights due to Sentencing Error;
and (6) Petitioner was Deprived of his Sixth Amendment
Right to Effective Assistance of Counsel. (3:09–cv–362, Doc.
No. 1 at 7–14).
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the reasons that follow, Respondent's Motion
for Summary Judgment will be granted, and Respondent's
Section 2255 Motion will be denied and dismissed
misconduct_determination_term1:
Respondent's
Section 2255 Motion will be denied and dismissed
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
And even though he retained the right to challenge
his conviction and sentence on the ground of prosecutorial
misconduct, Petitioner offers no evidence to support this
assertion and the Court concludes that it is wholly without
merit.
misconduct_determination_term2:
the Court concludes that it is wholly without
merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Petitioner's claim is
without merit.

allegation_sentence_1:
On March 17, 2007, DeMartino applied to this court for
a writ of habeas corpus under 28 U.S.C. § 2255, alleging:
(1) constitutionally ineffective assistance of trial counsel; (2)
prosecutorial misconduct; and (3) judicial bias.
allegation_sentence_2:
Additionally, petitioner claims that the
government suborned perjury in its direct examination of
FBI Special Agent James DeStefano.
allegation_term_2: claims that the government suborned perjury
allegation_sentence_3:
Petitioner alleges
that the government elicited a false statement from the
Agent regarding Campanella's identification of DeMartino
as the shooter.
allegation_term_3:
alleges
that the government elicited a false statement
allegation_sentence_4:
Petitioner also alleges that the government permitted Agent
DeStefano to testify falsely about petitioner's motive or intent
for the shooting.
allegation_term_4:
alleges that the government permitted Agent
DeStefano to testify falsely
allegation_sentence_5:
Finally, petitioner alleges that the government did not fulfill
its production obligations under Brady v. Maryland,
allegation_term_5:
alleges that the government did not fulfill
its production obligations under Brady v. Maryland,
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the reasons set forth below,
petitioner's application is denied.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Even if petitioner's claims were not procedurally barred,
neither the claim of prosecutorial misconduct nor that of
judicial bias has merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Petitioner's claims of prosecutorial misconduct do
not fare better.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The trial transcript does not support
petitioner's claim.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Thus, even absent procedural bar, petitioner's judicial
bias and prosecutorial misconduct claims are without merit
and provide no basis for habeas relief.
misconduct_determination_term5: prosecutorial misconduct claims are without merit

allegation_sentence_1:
And, even if the prosecution did know prior to
the witness taking the stand that she planned to invoke the
Fifth, this prior knowledge alone does not require a finding
of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Therefore, there was not sufficient
evidence to support a finding of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_term1:
not sufficient
evidence to support a finding of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
There is no indication of bad
faith on the part of the prosecution

no indication of bad
faith on the part of the prosecution
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Furthermore, although the opening statement did contain
highly inflammatory material, the judge and the prosecution
both gave the jury limiting instructions that “an opening
statement is neither evidence nor argument,” the prosecutor
did not reiterate the prejudicial statements, and the
government's case was strong.
misconduct_determination_term3:
the prosecutor

if the statements were prejudicial, there were sufficient

allegation_sentence_1:

he argued that the prosecutor improperly withheld a DEA–6

petitioner argued that respondent committed prosecutorial

Court will deny petitioner's motion.

the

as an unfounded misunderstanding of the trial record.

committed prosecutorial misconduct, that the district court
erred in applying an obstruction of justice enhancement to

unreasonable.

and Yildirim now argue that, in making this statement, the

prosecutor mischaracterized evidence

allegation_term_4:

misconduct_determination_sentence1:

precedent, we conclude that the prosecutor's comment in this
case regarding reasonable doubt did not constitute plain error
misconduct_determination_sentence2:

allegation_sentence_1:
Appellant raises three issues on appeal: (1) whether the
Government committed reversible misconduct in closing
argument by attacking the integrity of defense counsel and
commenting on the defendant's partial silence upon arrest;
allegation_term_1:
whether the
Government committed reversible misconduct
allegation_sentence_2:
Appellant argues that such comments
combine two fundamental forms of improper prosecutorial
conduct: asking the jury to draw adverse conclusions from
the defendant's omission of exculpatory facts from prior,
post-Miranda warning statements; and attacking defense
counsel by suggesting without a record basis that consultation
with counsel is a likely source of false defense testimony
allegation_term_2:
combine two fundamental forms of improper prosecutorial
conduct
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendant-appellant further argues that the prosecutor's
comments were an impermissible reference to his post-arrest
silence.
allegation_term_3:
argues that the prosecutor's
comments were an impermissible reference
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Upon review of the prosecutor's comments in the context of
the entire record, we hold that the brief reference to appellant's
lawyer does not amount to an “inflammatory attack” on
defense counsel rising to the level of plain error.
misconduct_determination_term1:
does not amount to an “inflammatory attack” on
defense counsel rising to the level of plain error.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Viewed in context, the prosecutor's

that the venue of his trial should have been changed; that

was improper; and that he was denied effective assistance of
counsel.

the Government destroyed vital evidence.

for postconviction relief.

had little materiality and thus little exculpatory value.

in bad faith

reasons that the Court denied the Brady claim, the Court

allegation_sentence_1:

allegation_sentence_2:
Merrill requests a new trial contending that the
prosecutor engaged in misconduct in the change of the
place of trial, by giving jury instructions on intent, and
in proffering the admission of res gestae evidence in the
form of all Merrill's prescriptions.

contending that the

Noles.
allegation_term_3:
his allegation that
the prosecutor misled the court
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Applying the two-step test
raised in Eckhardt, we find that Mr. Kunz's statements to the
court during the colloquy on Merrill's motion for a judgment
of acquittal were improper.
misconduct_determination_term1:
we find that Mr. Kunz's statements to the
court during the colloquy on Merrill's motion for a judgment
of acquittal were improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Nonetheless, these statements
did not prejudice Merrill as the court expressly stated that
the evidence of track marks was irrelevant to its denial of
Merrill's motion for a judgment of acquittal on counts relating
to Mr. Noles.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: any error on the part of Mr. Kunz was harmless.
misconduct_determination_term3:
In light of
the trial court's cautionary instructions to the jury and the
abundance of other independent evidence concerning Mr.
Noles' death, we find that the prosecutor's misstatements
during closing with regard to the track marks were not plain
error so obvious that the court's failure to correct it, sua
sponte, jeopardized the fairness and integrity of the trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
we find that the prosecutor's misstatements
during closing with regard to the track marks were not plain
error so obvious
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
did not commit prosecutorial misconduct so prejudicial as
to warrant a new trial;
misconduct_determination_term5: For all of these reasons, we AFFIRM the district court.
misconduct_determination_sentence6: we AFFIRM the district court.

allegation_sentence_1:
This appeal from judgments of conviction of six defendants
raises two principal issues: (1) whether the district court
erred in failing to grant a new trial because of prosecutorial
misconduct in allowing the grand jury testimony of
Government witness Moody to be read to Government
witness Stanizzo and the grand jury testimony of Stanizzo to
be read to Moody prior to trial,
allegation_sentence_2:
The charge of prosecutorial misconduct stems from a
meeting between two witnesses, Moody and Stanizzo, and
F.B.I. Agent Fitzpatrick, who had investigated the case.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
After
careful consideration, we have concluded that the contentions
raised by the defendants do not justify reversal of the
convictions.
misconduct_determination_term1:
the contentions
raised by the defendants do not justify reversal
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We hold that at least some of the conduct testified to was
prosecutorial misconduct violative of Rule 6(e), but that this
conduct did not constitute reversible error.
misconduct_determination_term2:
at least some of the conduct testified to was
prosecutorial misconduct violative of Rule 6(e), but that this
conduct did not constitute reversible error.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Therefore, the Government attorney,
perhaps unknowingly, violated Rule 6(e).
misconduct_determination_term3:
the Government attorney,
perhaps unknowingly, violated Rule 6(e).
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Although we find the violation of Rule 6(e)
as testified to by Moody improper, we do not think the
defendants were denied a fair trial under the facts presented
by this record.
misconduct_determination_term4:
the violation of Rule 6(e)
as testified to by Moody improper, we do not think the
defendants were denied a fair trial
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
We emphasize that our holding that the
prosecutorial misconduct in violation of Rule 6(e) does
not require a new trial is limited to the facts of this case.
misconduct_determination_term5:
the
prosecutorial misconduct in violation of Rule 6(e) does
not require a new trial
misconduct_determination_sentence6: The judgments of the district court will be affirmed.

stand over objection, was an improper disparagement of
Henry's version of the events which led to the charge against

misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Based on the following discussion, we AFFIRM

comment did not materially affect the verdict and was
harmless error.

statement by the government as to Henry's silence, was

allegation_sentence_1:
The allegations of prosecutorial misconduct and unlawful
command influence are based on the actions of Major (Maj)
Bloom, the staff judge advocate (SJA) for the special courtmartial
convening authority who forwarded the charges
and recommended trial by general court-martial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Appellant alleges that Maj Bloom had improper, ex parte
contact with the Article 32, UCMJ, 10 USC § 832,
investigating officer; attempted to influence the testimony of
his subordinates at the Article 32 investigation; improperly
coached Lieutenant Colonel (LtCol) Gilbert, the officer
whose orders were allegedly disobeyed, before LtCol Gilbert
testified at the Article 32 investigation; and failed to disclose
a letter of reprimand that the defense could have used to
impeach a government witness at the Article 32 investigation.
allegation_sentence_3:
Appellant also contends that he was singled out for vindictive
and disparate treatment.
allegation_term_3:
contends that he was singled out for vindictive
and disparate treatment.
allegation_sentence_4:
At trial, appellant moved to dismiss the disobedience charges
as overly broad and violative of the First Amendment and to
dismiss all the charges due to unlawful command influence
and selective prosecution.
allegation_sentence_5:
Appellant asserts that the Government failed to disclose
a letter of reprimand received by 2Lt D for adultery.
allegation_term_5: asserts that the Government failed to disclose
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Regarding the first aspect, we hold that Maj Bloom
did not act improperly by requesting the investigating officer
to reopen the investigation.
misconduct_determination_term1:
we hold that Maj Bloom
did not act improperly
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We hold that such ex parte advocacy was improper.
misconduct_determination_term2: such ex parte advocacy was improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
While
we do not condone Maj Bloom's conduct, we hold that
appellant was not prejudiced by Maj Bloom's improper ex
parte contacts with the Article 32 investigating officer.
misconduct_determination_term3:
we hold that
appellant was not prejudiced by Maj Bloom's improper ex
parte contacts
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
On the record before us, there is no evidence that Maj
Bloom influenced or attempted to influence LtCol Gilbert's
testimony.
misconduct_determination_term4:
no evidence that Maj
Bloom influenced or attempted to influence
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The record before us does not present a prima facie
case of vindictive or selective prosecution.
misconduct_determination_term5:
does not present a prima facie
case of vindictive or selective prosecution.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
In this light, the SJA's conduct during the pretrial
investigation cannot on the surface be considered benign
concur_dissent_term_1:
the SJA's conduct during the pretrial
investigation cannot on the surface be considered benign
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
These perceptions of unfairness are
not unreasonable; yet, they do not require reversal where, as
here, no reasonable possibility of prejudice exists.
notes: interesting military opinion -- concurring judge worries about public impression of military justice proceedings

DEFENDANT'S ISSUE XXI: PROSECUTORIAL
MISCONDUCT DURING CLOSING ARGUMENT
OF THE GUILT PHASE REQUIRES THAT
DEFENDANT'S CONVICTION BE SET ASIDE.
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendant contends during the closing arguments of the
guilt phase of the trifurcated proceeding, the United States
made a number of arguments that constituted prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_term_3:
the United States
made a number of arguments that constituted prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_4:

by the United States during closing argument is disparaging
of defense counsel and the proffered defense.
allegation_term_4:
asserts that the following comment made
by the United States during closing argument is disparaging
of defense counsel
allegation_sentence_5:

law by providing a legal explanation that was contrary to a
jury instruction given by the Court.
allegation_term_5:
contends that the United States misstated the
law
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
It appears to the Court that the above statements
were not improper because they were utilized for the
permissible purpose of proving the aggravating factor of an
especially “heinous, atrocious, or cruel” offense.
misconduct_determination_term1:
It appears to the Court that the above statements
were not improper
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The government's
conduct here was clearly improper and violated a direct,
clear Order of the Court.
misconduct_determination_term2:
The government's
conduct here was clearly improper
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The Court finds that the
United States' comments as to this issue were not misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term3: comments as to this issue were not misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The Court finds that the cumulative effect
of prosecutorial misconduct did not deprive Defendant of a
fair trial.

the cumulative effect
of prosecutorial misconduct did not deprive Defendant of a
fair trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
In reviewing the arguments of both
parties and the applicable law, the Court concludes that the
improper statements by attorneys for the United States had
minimal force and almost certainly no effect on the jury's
verdict.

the Court concludes that the
improper statements by attorneys for the United States had
minimal force
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
The Court concludes this situation is more similar to Lopez
than Holmes, and the comments constituted harmless error.

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendants Arnold Sherlock and Benjamin Charley filed this
interlocutory appeal from the district court's order denying
their motion to dismiss their indictments on the basis of
prosecutorial misconduct.

prosecutorial misconduct before the grand jury, claiming
that the government's witness, the police investigator, had
intentionally misstated several pieces of evidence and had
failed to present exculpating evidence.
allegation_term_2:

intentionally misstated
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Thus, under Moreno-Green, the defendants'
allegation that the prosecution failed to present exculpatory
evidence fails to warrant interlocutory review.
misconduct_determination_term1:
allegation that the prosecution failed to present exculpatory
evidence fails to warrant interlocutory review.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Accordingly, we lack jurisdiction to hear
this interlocutory appeal.

allegation_sentence_1:
Fairly argues that the district court erred in denying his
motion for a new trial based on prosecutorial misconduct
and by excluding a taped statement by co-defendant Candler.
allegation_sentence_2:
Fairly objected at trial to the prosecution's alleged
misrepresentation of his marital status, therefore we review
for harmless error.
allegation_sentence_3:
Fairly timely objected to the prosecution's statement
allegedly impugning the integrity of Fairly's defense counsel.
allegation_sentence_4: Prosecution's alleged materially false arguments
allegation_sentence_5:
Fairly objected at trial to the prosecution's argument
that the failure of Fairly's father to testify as to the existence
of the alleged insurance settlement meant that the settlement
did not exist.
allegation_sentence_6:
Defense counsel objected at trial to the prosecution's
alleged arguments to matters not in evidence.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Therefore, the introduction of Fairly's second prior felony was
not plain error.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Therefore, admission of Officer Bell's testimony
that Fairly's father was recently released from prison was not
error.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Therefore, we hold that because the alleged misconduct,
even if true, did not affect the outcome of the district court
proceedings, plain error did not occur.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Therefore, the testimony regarding Fairly's parole
status was more probative than prejudicial and as such, did
not constitute plain error
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
There is no evidence that the prosecution misrepresented
Fairly's marital status in bad faith, thereby deliberately
prejudicing him with the moral implication that he was living
with Candler without having divorced his former wife, Hattie
Cromer (“Cromer”).
misconduct_determination_term5: no evidence that the prosecution misrepresented
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Accordingly, this constitutional error was harmless beyond a
reasonable doubt.

United States District Court,
D. South Dakota,
Central Division
attorneys_judges:

Jones, Senior District Judge,//Mark A.

Office of the United States Attorney,// (Karen E. Schreier,

geography_entities:
South Dakota// Eagle
Butte, South Dakota// on the Cheyenne River Reservation
allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant claims in his Motion that the actions and
conduct of plaintiff's counsel in conjunction with the grand
jury proceedings constituted prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
In support of his
request for dismissal, he alleges that prosecutors
allegation_sentence_3:
At the outset, defendant claims that the prosecutors made
impermissible comments about the evidence to the grand
jury.
allegation_sentence_4:
He next complains about the prosecutors informing
the grand jury that it should not be “surprised” if witnesses
related or sympathetic to defendant had “memory” problems
and of the eventuality of being presented with the case and
asked to return an indictment.
allegation_sentence_5:
Finally, defendant complains
about a statement made by the same prosecutor concerning
various post-mortem photographs of A.B. that were shown to
the grand jury.
allegation_term_5: statement made by the same prosecutor
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
There is certainly nothing iniquitous about
the prosecutor advising the grand jury in general terms
of the nature of an investigation and who the target of
the investigation is.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
It is therefore unlikely that these comments had
much, if any, influence on the grand jury's decision to indict
defendant.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
This Court sees nothing sinister about the
prosecutor's remarks but even if the remarks can be viewed
as a comment about the credibility of the witnesses, the same
did not constitute misconduct that can support a dismissal of
the indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Nor did the prosecutor's statement relating to the
eventual presentment of the case for indictment invade the
province of the grand jury and its independent deliberations
and cause defendant prejudice sufficient to warrant a
dismissal.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
For these reasons, the prosecutor did not abuse the
grand jury process by subpoenaing P.R.E. before the grand
jury and inquiring about the circumstances surrounding A.B.'s
death.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Based on the foregoing and in accordance with 28 U.S.C.
§ 636(b)(1), this Court concludes that prosecutors did not
circumvent the grand jury's autonomy by using flagrant
or overreaching conduct that requires the indictment be
dismissed because of constitutional errors or pursuant
to a court's supervisory powers.

allegation_sentence_1:
Movant's second ground asserts that prosecutorial
tolerance of Garrett's corrupt practices deprived Movant of
due process of law.
allegation_sentence_2:
Movant argues that he was denied due
process because the Government knew or in the exercise of
reasonable diligence should have known that Garrett was an
unreliable source of evidence, yet the prosecution relied on
the police report signed by Garrett and testimony by Detective
Stone when Garrett was the supervising officer during
Movant's arrest.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
As
such, Movant's prosecutorial misconduct claim fails on its
merits.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Movant has not put forth evidence demonstrating the
Government used any false evidence or should have known
of any corrupt practices by Garrett, which would constitute
prosecutorial misconduct at the time of Movant's trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Furthermore, prosecutorial misconduct is not present
because the Government did not use Garrett in the trial
proceedings, and the Movant did not produce evidence
undermining the credibility of the Government's primary
witness, Detective Stone.

attorneys_judges: LINARES, District Judge.
allegation_sentence_1:
In the present motion, Petitioner alleges that: (1) she was
denied effective assistance of counsel; (2) she was denied
a fair trial because the Court did not base its decision on
reliable information; (3) her sentence was not fair because the
Court “erred in finding that [Petitioner] made no objections
to the factual contents in the presentence report;” (4) the
Third Circuit erred in finding that the District Court reviewed
the entire record; (5) her conviction was obtained through
prosecutorial misconduct;
allegation_sentence_2:
These claims
essentially make three broad arguments: that her trial and
appellate attorneys were ineffective, that there were various
legal and factual errors and prosecutorial misconduct at trial
or on appeal, and that she is actually innocent.
allegation_sentence_3: Alleged Prosecutorial Misconduct and Court Errors
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Such claims

allegation_sentence_2:

allegation_sentence_3:
In Ground three, Petitioner characterizes the prosecutor's
argument to the jury that Spellissy was retired from the
Army as “false statements” and contends that the prosecutor's
closing argument was “misleading to the jury.”
allegation_term_3:
contends that the prosecutor's

allegation_sentence_4:
Petitioner's rambling discussion of why he believes his trial
was unfair, whether because of what he believes to have
been false testimony, prosecutorial misconduct, or claimed
Brady 7
 violations, does not meet the threshold for coram
nobis releif, that is, that the claimed errors be “of the most
fundamental character.”
allegation_sentence_5:
Notwithstanding, Defendant continues to malign the
prosecutor by positing “if the prosecutor knew or should
have known that the tape never existed, then he suborned
perjury.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:

makes no showing
of fundamental error in Ground three.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:

Petitioner's claims of prosecutorial misconduct do not rise
to the level of error of the most fundamental character, such
that it rendered his trial “irregular and invalid.”

claims of prosecutorial misconduct do not rise
to the level of error of the most fundamental character
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Nor has he demonstrated

and conviction.

a fundamental miscarriage of justice in the prosecution
misconduct_determination_sentence4:

allegation_sentence_1:
The appeal presents two
issues: (1) whether the Government exercised its peremptory
challenges in violation of the rule established in Batson
v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79, 106 S.Ct. 1712, 90 L.Ed.2d 69
(1986), and (2) whether remarks attributed to the prosecution
deprived defendant of a fair trial.
allegation_term_1:
whether the Government exercised its peremptory
challenges in violation
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant seeks reversal of his conviction because
of perceived prosecutorial misconduct related to allegedly
inflammatory interrogation during trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
] We will presently outline this evidence in considering
the second incident as to which appellant claims
prosecutorial misconduct: *35 the interrogation of Olga
Hall, a defense character witness.
allegation_sentence_4:
Appellant claims that this interrogation was improper because
it raised the “specter of flight and consciousness of guilt
without any foundation or real evidence as to flight.”
allegation_term_4: claims that this interrogation was improper
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We respond in the negative
to both questions and thus affirm defendant's conviction.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Appellant-defendant
has failed to meet his burden in this respect.
misconduct_determination_term2:
Appellant-defendant
has failed to meet his burden
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The evidence against appellant was overwhelming, making
this “incident” as unimportant in the final outcome as was the
other claim of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term3:
unimportant in the final outcome as was the
other claim of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
In the light of this evidence, claims that the alleged
prosecutorial misconduct had any effect on the outcome of
Sgro's conviction are spurious.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
In view of the above, the judgment of the district court is
affirmed.
misconduct_determination_term5:
judgment of the district court is
affirmed.

allegation_sentence_1:
Susi alleges insufficient evidence existed for his convictions,
prosecutorial misconduct, multiple errors at trial, and argues
that his sentence is unreasonable and should be vacated.
allegation_sentence_2:
Susi next argues that “[t]hroughout the course of the trial, the
prosecutor engaged in a pattern of prejudicial misconduct, the
cumulative effect of which destroyed” Susi's right to a fair
trial.
allegation_term_2: prosecutor engaged in a pattern of prejudicial misconduct
allegation_sentence_3:
Susi first objects to certain comments made by the prosecutor
during closing argument.
allegation_term_3: objects to certain comments made by the prosecutor
allegation_sentence_4:
Second, Susi alleges that the prosecutor committed a
so-called “Golden Rule” violation 5
 during closing, asking
“the jury to put themselves into the position of the
victims.”
allegation_term_4:
alleges that the prosecutor committed a
so-called “Golden Rule” violation
allegation_sentence_5:
Finally, Susi objects to the prosecutor's call to the jury
to “send a message” to the community.
allegation_term_5: objects to the prosecutor's call to the jury
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
For the following reasons, we affirm all the convictions as
adjudicated by the district court, but vacate Susi's sentence
and remand for resentencing.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Susi's argument that the prosecutor improperly
commented on the victims' age or vulnerability is without
merit
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
There is also no evidence that the prosecutor's statements
that, for example, the crime was “horrific,” or that Susi
was a “greedy, merciless man,” crossed the line of vigorous
advocacy.
misconduct_determination_term3: There is also no evidence that the prosecutor's statements
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The prosecutor did not improperly appeal to the jurors'
sympathy, nor did he ask the jury to make a decision as
if they were in the victims' position.
misconduct_determination_term4:
prosecutor did not improperly appeal to the jurors'
sympathy
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Even
if we assume the remark to have been improper, it was not
unduly prejudicial.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the district
court did not err in denying Susi's motion for acquittal,
committed no cumulative evidentiary error, and no
prosecutorial misconduct occurred.

allegation_sentence_1:
Basile moves to dismiss RA 27 (conspiracy to distribute
marijuana) and RA 49 (loansharking) on the basis that the
government allegedly made an improper presentation to the
grand jury to establish those predicate acts.
allegation_term_1:
on the basis that the
government allegedly made an improper presentation
allegation_sentence_2:
Basile must show that the
prosecutor in indefinitely adjourning the grand jury engaged
in the type of prosecutorial misconduct proscribed by the
Supreme Court in Williams.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
I have reviewed these minutes, and, satisfied
that no prosecutorial misconduct occurred for the reasons
set forth infra, I decline to order the disclosure of the minutes.
misconduct_determination_term1:
satisfied
that no prosecutorial misconduct occurred
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Furthermore, an in camera review of the grand
jury minutes confirms that before the indictment, the
prosecution did not actively misrepresent the evidence or
make misleading statements about the Defendant to the
grand jury.
misconduct_determination_term2:
the
prosecution did not actively misrepresent the evidence or
make misleading statements
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In this regard, Basile's contention that the
prosecution “misled” the grand jury in presenting postindictment
exculpatory evidence without requiring it to
reconsider the indictment lacks merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
For the reasons stated herein, Basile's motion for in camera
review of the grand jury minutes is GRANTED, and his
motions to preclude the Puglisi conviction, to open the grand
jury minutes, and to dismiss RA 27 and 49 are DENIED.
misconduct_determination_term4: to dismiss RA 27 and 49 are DENIED.

allegation_sentence_1:
prosecutorial misconduct during the Grand Jury
proceeding
allegation_sentence_2:
His complaint that the prosecutor mislead the Grand Jury as to
who shot Officer Sullivan, is belied by the testimony before
the Grand Jury (Grand Jury Transcript 13) that the police
officer had actually been shot by another law enforcement
agent.
allegation_sentence_3:
Nor is there merit to Salazar's claim that the prosecutor
unlawfully induced and coerced Juan Rodriguez to cooperate
as a witness for the government.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
However, even if any error had been made before the
Grand Jury, that error was cured by the trial jury's finding of
Salazar's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
His complaint that the prosecutor mislead the Grand Jury as to
who shot Officer Sullivan, is belied by the testimony before
the Grand Jury (Grand Jury Transcript 13) that the police
officer had actually been shot by another law enforcement
agent.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Nor is there merit to Salazar's claim that the prosecutor
unlawfully induced and coerced Juan Rodriguez to cooperate
as a witness for the government.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Salazar makes this allegation
without foundation and, in particular, without any statement,
affidavit, deposition or testimony of Rodriguez.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Moreover,
Salazar and his co-defendants had an unrestricted opportunity
to cross-examine Rodriguez at trial to demonstrate, if it was
true, that Rodriguez had been coerced.

allegation_sentence_1:
Petitioner alleges ineffective assistance
of counsel and prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Petitioner also contends the Government committed
prosecutorial misconduct and violated the Double Jeopardy
Clause when photographs of clothing were used as evidence,
despite being unable to produce the actual clothing.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The
Government contends, and this Court agrees, Petitioner has
failed to prove that the photographs were not an accurate
depiction of the actual clothing recovered by law enforcement
on the date of the arrest.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Furthermore, Petitioner has failed
to show how the Government's introduction of the clothing
photographs into evidence was so pronounced and persistent
that it permeated the entire atmosphere of the trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Furthermore, the Government again correctly argues, the 18
U.S.C. § 922(g)(1) count, Felon in Possession of a Firearm,
does not violate the rule against multiplicity
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Furthermore, the Government correctly points out the general
double jeopardy test cannot be applied to a charge of 18
U.S.C. § 924(c), Use of a Firearm in Relation to a Crime
of Violence, since such a charge is always predicated upon
the violation of another statutory offense (18 U.S.C. § 2113,
Armed Bank Robbery in Petitioner's case).
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Furthermore, Petitioner has failed to demonstrate
he was subject to prosecutorial misconduct.

allegation_sentence_1:
The government was guilty of prosecutorial
misconduct by failing to present exculpatory evidence.
allegation_sentence_2:
The government was guilty of prosecutorial
misconduct by presenting false and misleading testimony to
the grand jury.
allegation_sentence_3:
The Government failed to present any evidence to the
grand jury that Renteria-Alvarez was an adult, an essential
element of the crimes charged in counts three and four of the
indictment.
allegation_sentence_4:
Ramirez-Robles contends that the government had a duty to
present to the grand jury evidence of a government expert's
opinion that “no identifications were effected” in comparing
Ramirez-Robles' fingerprints with the “ridge detail” on the
pistol, ammunition clip, and live rounds of ammunition.
allegation_sentence_5:
Ramirez-Robles asserts that dismissal of the indictment
is compelled in this matter because the government presented
false and misleading testimony to the grand jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because disclosure of exculpatory evidence is not required
in this circuit, the prosecutor's failure to present the expert's
opinion concerning the incomplete examination of RamirezRobles'
prints was not prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
No showing has been made that the witness intentionally
testified falsely or that the prosecutor who presented the
evidence to the grand jury knowingly presented perjured
testimony.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The district
court did not err in denying the motion to dismiss on this
ground.

allegation_sentence_1:
Petitioner Nicolas Rosario (“Rosario”), appearing pro se,
moves for reconsideration of this Court's denial of his motion
to vacate his conviction pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2255 on
the grounds of newly discovered evidence and prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
In his motion for reconsideration, petitioner alleges that “the
Government deliberately covered-up the fact that Group 33
of the Drug Enforcement Administration was already under
investigation for misdeeds and was beginning to be disbanded
at the time of his trial”, that the Government failed to disclose
this fact, and that this affected the preparation for trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
He asserts that the

allegation_sentence_4:

In connection with his allegations of

he sustained in Cobb County Georgia in 2003—recently
was reduced to a disorderly conduct conviction under Cobb

geography_entities: Philadelphia
allegation_sentence_1: Among the grounds presented for dismissing the indictment are allegations of prosecutorial misconduct and massive prejudicial pre-indictment and pretrial publicity.
allegation_sentence_2: The charge of prosecutorial misconduct consists of an allegation that representatives of the Department of Justice and the United States Attorney's Office of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania released sensational and prejudicial information to the news media with intent to create an atmosphere inimical to the rights of the defendants.

decision_court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
attorneys_judges: The District Court, Robert Holmes Bell, J.
geography_entities: W.D. Michigan, Southern Division
allegation_sentence_1: Movant's first ground in support of her § 2255 motion consists of three arguments: (1) failure of the superceding indictment to use the term “Ponzi scheme” caused it to be defective, (2) the jury instructions were defective because they failed to use the term “Ponzi scheme,” and (3) the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2: First, Movant contends that the failure of the superceding indictment to use the language “Ponzi scheme” caused it to be defective and that through prosecutorial misconduct, removal of the term “Ponzi scheme” from the jury instructions was “per se prejudicial” and violated her Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendment rights.
allegation_term_2: was “per se prejudicial” and violated her Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendment rights.
allegation_sentence_3: Third, Movant also contends that certain actions that occurred during the trial constituted prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: All three arguments listed within Movant's first ground in support of her § 2255 are without merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Movant's generalized allegations of prosecutorial misconduct are without merit and represent conclusions that are simply not supported by the record or Movant's Exhibits. (Compare 1:04–CR–165, Dkt. Nos. 470–78, 491, 513–22, with 1:09–CV–913, Dkt. No. 34, Ex. A–I). Movant's argument requires the Court to make unwarranted inferences from the record to reach the conclusion that prosecutorial misconduct was rampant.
notes: They didn't rule on all of the rulings

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.

Robert STATON, Appellant.
UNITED STATES of America//Patricia CHRISTOPHER, a/k/
a Tammy Williams, Appellant.
attorneys_judges: Before MIKVA, Chief Judge and WALD and BUCKLEY, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: District of Columbia
allegation_sentence_1: Both Christopher and Staton raise sufficiency-ofthe-evidence claims. And both appellants seek reversal in light of what they allege was prosecutorial misconduct at trial.
allegation_sentence_2: Appellants contend that two statements made by the prosecutor during closing argument amount to prosecutorial misconduct justifying reversal.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Because, however, we find that the statements did not “substantially prejudice” appellants at trial, we decline to reverse the convictions on grounds of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We reject appellants' claims and affirm.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.

allegation_sentence_2:
Conroy challenges his convictions, arguing the district court 1 erred in...denying his motion for mistrial based on
prosecutorial misconduct. We affirm.
allegation_sentence_3: Conroy argues the prosecutor's repeated attempts to shift the burden of proof to Conroy during closing arguments constituted reversible misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: comments made by prosecutor during closing argument did not constitute reversible prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The government argues the comments were not improper, then contends even if they were, they were not prejudicial, given the district court's admonishment of the jury following closing arguments as to the government's burden of proof.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
defendant: Shawanna REEVES, a.k.a. Shawanna Halcomb//Michael McShun Reeves, a.k.a. Docious//Thornton Lamar Moss, a.k.a. Slim, Defendants–Appellants.
attorneys_judges: Michelle Lee Schieber, Verda M. Colvin, U.S. Attorney's Office, Macon, GA, for Plaintiff–Appellee.// Larry David Wolfe, Locke Law Firm, Atlanta, GA, John Philip Fox, Fox & Smith, LLC, Doye E. Green, Jr., Miller Green, L. Elizabeth Lane, Attorney at Law, Macon, GA, for Defendants–Appellants.// Before MARCUS and EDMONDSON, Circuit Judges, and VINSON, * District Judge.
geography_entities: Atlanta, Georgia
allegation_sentence_1: Halcomb–Reeves also challenges several of the district court's evidentiary rulings. Specifically, she avers that the district court erred in admitting recorded telephone calls and a co-conspirator's statements against her at trial, as well as in denying her motion for a mistrial after a government case agent improperly revealed her invocation of the right to counsel.
allegation_term_1: improperly revealed her invocation to the right of the council
allegation_sentence_2: Moss asserts that a new trial is warranted because of a series of allegedly improper prosecutorial statements during closing argument.
allegation_sentence_3: Finally, Moss appeals his conspiracy conviction claiming that the government deliberately and repeatedly misstated facts in its closing argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: any Fifth Amendment error arising from agent's commenting on second defendant's purported post-Miranda silence was harmless;
misconduct_determination_sentence2: prosecutor's comments during closing argument were not improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Having reviewed this record, we can discern no reversible error based on the prosecutor's closing argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Furthermore, any error in the prosecutor's comments was harmless because the record contains sufficient independent evidence of Moss's guilt concerning the conspiracy charge, including the presentation of several recorded conversations between Moss and Reeves discussing cocaine purchases.

United States Court of Appeals,
Ninth Circuit.
defendant:
Samuel DeWitt CRENSHAW and David
Allen Gordon, Defendants-Appellants.
UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee,//Dennis Leo LEHMAN, Defendant-Appellant.
attorneys_judges: *1061 Beverly Johnson, Tacoma, Wash., for Crenshaw.//Monte E. Hester, Tacoma, Wash., for Gordon.//Allen R. Bentley, Asst. Federal Public Defender, Seattle, Wash., for Lehman.//C. James Frush, Asst. U.S.//Atty., Tacoma, Wash., for U.S. Appeal from the United States District Court For the Western District of Washington.//Before KENNEDY and SKOPIL, Circuit Judges and JAMESON, * District Judge.
geography_entities: District of Montana
case_outcome: Affirmed in part and reversed and remanded in part.
allegation_sentence_1: prosecutorial misconduct requires reversal; and contends further that (2) in-court identification testimony was so tainted by impermissibly suggestive pretrial identification procedures that he was deprived of due process of law; and (3) the errors and instances of prosecutorial misconduct when examined cumulatively deprived him of a fair trial.
allegation_term_1: deprived him of a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_2: Both Crenshaw and Gordon argue that the district court should have declared a mistrial for prosecutorial misconduct because of (1) statements by the prosecutor during trial and (2) admission of photo identifications of Crenshaw and Gordon by bank employees.
allegation_sentence_3: Finally, Gordon argues that even if each individual error considered separately does not require a reversal, the cumulative effect of the errors was so prejudicial that he was deprived of a fair trial. If evidentiary errors and prosecutorial misconduct are “more probably harmless than not”, this court should affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We find no merit in any of these contentions.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The prejudicial effect of the prosecutor's statements in this case appears minimal and, in any event, was neutralized by the court's limiting instructions.
misconduct_determination_term2: The prejudicial effect of the prosecutor's statements in this case appears minimal
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Considering the case as a whole, we find that Gordon was not significantly *1064 harmed by any cumulative lingering prejudice from purported errors and prosecutorial misconduct.

decision_court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
attorneys_judges: Darius Pettway, Sr., pro se.//George F. May, U.S. Attorney's Office, Mobile, AL, for Respondent.
geography_entities: S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
allegation_sentence_1: Petitioner has also raised nine different instances of prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2: In claim eight, dealing with prosecutorial misconduct, Pettway asserts that the prosecutor misstated evidence
allegation_sentence_3: Pettway's final claim of prosecutorial misconduct, claim ten, is that the prosecutor called him a liar
allegation_sentence_4: misconduct in misstating evidence;
allegation_sentence_5: Cumulative and outrageous conduct by the government in regards to the August 15, 2007 alleged charge (count two of the indictment)
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The Court has reviewed Petitioner's assertions under claim one and finds that there has been no showing that Pettway's substantial rights have been prejudiced. The Court further notes that the jury heard all of the evidence, reconciled the discrepancies in it, and, nevertheless, found Pettway guilty as charged
misconduct_determination_term1: no showing that Pettway's substantial rights have been prejudiced.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The Court finds this claim to be without merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Again, although Petitioner has shown some inconsistencies, the Court cannot say that he has demonstrated prejudice under Reed. The jury heard the evidence and found Pettway guilty of the charge. Petitioner's assertions that the small discrepancies in the evidence on this count rendered his verdict unlawful is without merit.
misconduct_determination_term3: cannot say that he has demonstrated prejudice
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Nevertheless, the Court has reviewed each circumstance as argued and finds no misconduct in any of the Prosecutor's statements.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
attorneys_judges:
*905 Harriett R. Galvin, Anne R. Schultz, Jeanne Marie
Mullenhoff, U.S. Attorney's Office, S.D. of Florida, Miami,
FL, for Plaintiff-Appellee.//Leonard P. Fenn, Defabio & Fenn, P.A., Coral Gables, FL,
for Defendant-Appellant.//Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Florida.//Before ANDERSON, BIRCH and HULL, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the Southern District of Florida
allegation_sentence_1: On appeal, Block contends that the prosecutor committed prosecutorial misconduct by: (1) attacking the integrity and professionalism of Block's counsel because he put forth a “vigorous defense,” Appellant's Initial Brief at 20; (2) asking a question directly to Block in his closing argument and thereby commenting implicitly on Block's failure to testify; and (3) misstating the evidence relating to the money laundering charges against Block when he argued in closing argument that Block had sole control over the LI bank account. Consequently, Block argues that he is entitled to a mistrial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: In this case, we conclude that the district court correctly denied Block's motion for a mistrial.
misconduct_determination_term1: correctly denied Block's motion for a mistrial.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Block's substantial rights were not prejudiced. The government introduced overwhelming evidence of Block's guilt,
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Accordingly, we conclude the outcome would not have been different had the prosecutor not made the improper attack on Block's counsel.
misconduct_determination_term3: outcome would not have been different
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Finally, we conclude that Block's arguments regarding the government's summary of withdrawals from the LI account are without merit.

geography_entities: D. New Jersey.
allegation_sentence_1: Presently before the Court is Defendant's motion to dismiss the Superseding Indictment based on prosecutorial misconduct or, in the alternative, for an evidentiary hearing.
allegation_term_2: Defendant requests that the Superseding Indictment be dismissed for prosecutorial misconduct because the government; (1) violated its Brady 1 obligations; and (2) did not comply with this Court's discovery order and Rule 16 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. In the alternative, Defendant seeks an evidentiary hearing on her allegations.
allegation_sentence_3: requests that the Superseding Indictment be dismissed for prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Defendant has not demonstrated that a Brady violation has occurred, let alone that the government deliberately engaged in such misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term1: has not demonstrated that a Brady violation has occurred
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Accordingly, Defendant's motion for an evidentiary hearing on prosecutorial misconduct is denied.
