defendant: Peter T. COSBY, Machinist's Mate Third Class (E–4), U.S. Navy.
attorneys_judges:
Military Judge: D.M. Hinkley. Review pursuant to Article
66(c), UCMJ, of General Court–Martial convened by
Commander, U.S. Naval Forces, Japan, Yokosuka, Japan.
CAPT Ryan M. Wilson, JAGC, USNR, Appellate Defense
Counsel.//CDR George F. Reilly, JAGC, USN, Appellate Defense
Counsel.//Maj J.Ed Christiansen, USMC, Appellate Defense Counsel.
LtCol K.P. Kelly, USMCR, Appellate Government Counsel.
CDR Robert P. Taishoff, JAGC, USN, Appellate Government
Counsel.//Before PRICE, Senior Judge, CARVER, Senior Judge, and
FALVEY, Appellate Military Judge.
allegation_sentence_1: In three assignments of error, the appellant alleges that the military judge abused his discretion by not declaring a mistrial after the government elicited testimony about prior rapes committed against the alleged victim; that the evidence is factually and legally insufficient to sustain his burglary conviction; and that his sentence is inappropriately severe.
allegation_term_1: the military judge abused his discretion
allegation_sentence_2: The appellant claims that the trial counsel engaged in prosecutorial misconduct when he elicited this information knowing what the answer would be and that it would be hearsay, cumulative, and prejudicial.
allegation_sentence_3: Finally, the appellant claims this alleged error “impaired [his] constitutional right to a fair and impartial trial” and was in direct violation of MILITARY RULE OF EVIDENCE 412, MANUAL FOR COURTS–MARTIAL, UNITED STATES (1998 ed.). Id. at 5.
allegation_term_3: impaired [his] constitutional right to a fair and impartial trial
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We have carefully considered the record of trial, the appellant's assignments of error, and the Government's response. We conclude that the findings and sentence are correct in law and fact and that no error materially prejudicial to the substantial rights of the appellant was committed.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Finally, although the appellant couches his assignment of error in terms of prosecutorial misconduct, we do not view trial counsel's attempt to elicit this testimony as constituting prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2: do not view trial counsel's attempt to elicit this testimony as constituting prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Although this evidence was arguably cumulative with
previously elicited, and unobjected to, testimony, we do not
believe the trial counsel's limited attempt to further explore
the alleged victim's failure to report rose to the level of
prosecutorial misconduct. This is especially true given trial
defense counsel's cross-examination of the alleged victim as
described above.
misconduct_determination_term3: we do not believe the trial counsel's limited attempt to further explore the alleged victim's failure to report rose to the level of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Although the appellant cites twelve cases as allegedly closely related, based upon our review, the appellant has failed to meet the burden of proving that any of the cases is a “closely related” case or that its sentence is “highly disparate” with his.
misconduct_determination_term4: appellant has failed to meet the burden

decision_court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
attorneys_judges:
Michael L. Guisti, Michael L. Guisti Law Offices, Garden
Grove, CA, for Petitioner.//Mark P. Takla, AUSA-Office of US. Attorney, Santa Ana,
CA, for Respondent.//The Honorable DAVID O. CARTER, District Judge.
geography_entities: C.D. California
allegation_sentence_1: On May 29, 2008, Petitioner filed the present Motion arguing that his conviction should be set aside due to ineffectiveness of counsel in violation of the Sixth Amendment and prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_term_1: his conviction should be set aside due to ineffectiveness of counsel
allegation_sentence_2: The Motion aims to vacate, set aside, or correct the sentence based on the following three arguments: (1) Petitioner received ineffective assistance of trial counsel; (2) Petitioner received ineffective assistance of appellate counsel; and (3) the AUSA committed prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_3: Petitioner argues two reasons for prosecutorial misconduct. First, Petitioner claims the AUSA “called Petitioner's wife and mother liars.” Mot. (Dkt.1) at 5. Secondly, Petitioner contends that the AUSA's rebuttal comments repeatedly disparaged Counsel. Id. For example, the AUSA stated “that's lawyers trying to get you to view the law the way they want you to view it,” “what I suspect everyone in this room, other than the defense, realizes is that there are ... a multitude of crimes that will violate both federal and state law,” and finally, repeatedly referring to the defense arguments as “counsel said” and “counsel may say.” Id .
allegation_term_3: AUSA's rebuttal comments repeatedly disparaged Counsel.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The Government argues that the comments made by the AUSA did not disparage Counsel and Counsel claims he did not find the comments offensive or disparaging. Id.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Moreover, Petitioner cites no authority to find the phrases “counsel said” or “counsel may say” indicative of “prosecutorial misconduct.”
misconduct_determination_term2: no authority to find the phrases “counsel said” or “counsel may say” indicative of “prosecutorial misconduct.”
misconduct_determination_sentence3: As Petitioner is unable to establish cause to excuse the procedural default, it is unnecessary to discuss whether Petitioner's allegations of prosecutorial misconduct led to actual prejudice.
misconduct_determination_term3: unnecessary to discuss whether Petitioner's allegations of prosecutorial misconduct led to actual prejudice.

decision_court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
attorneys_judges: Kelvin Summers, Yazoo City, MS, pro se.//Matthew W. Shepherd, W. Brent Woodall, U.S. Attorney's Office, Montgomery, AL, for Respondent.//W. HAROLD ALBRITTON, Senior District Judge.//TERRY F. MOORER, United States Magistrate Judge.
geography_entities: M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
allegation_sentence_1: His trial and appellate counsel were ineffective for failing to challenge prosecutorial misconduct in the government's intentional suppression of audiotape evidence and use of false testimony before the grand jury to obtain his indictment.
allegation_term_1: ineffective for failing to challenge prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2: On August 23, 2009, shortly before Summers's original trial commenced, Summers's trial counsel filed a “Motion to Dismiss Indictment Due to Government's Prosecutorial Misconduct,” arguing that the indictment should be dismissed because the sole government witness to testify before the grand jury, DEA Special Agent Eddie Spivey, had falsely testified that Summers was present during a June 4, 2008, drug transaction involving Summers's codefendant and a confidential informant.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: In denying the motion to dismiss, the district court found that although Agent Spivey was incorrect when testifying that Summers was present at the June 4, 2008, drug transaction, there was no evidence that Agent Spivey's testimony was made in bad faith or that he intentionally gave materially false testimony before the grand jury. Id. at 37. Thus, there was no evidence of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term1: no evidence that Agent Spivey's testimony was made in bad faith
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The court further found there was sufficient other undisputed evidence presented to the grand jury to provide probable cause to believe Summers was, in fact, a coconspirator as charged in the indictment. 7 Id.
misconduct_determination_term2: provide probable cause to believe Summers was, in fact, a coconspirator

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
attorneys_judges:
Kevin C. Danielson, Assistant United States Attorney
(David E. O'Meilia, United States Attorney and Neal B.
Kirkpatrick, Assistant United States Attorney with him on the
brief), Northern District of OK, for Plaintiff–Appellee.//Art Fleak, Attorney at Law, Tulsa, OK, for Defendant Appellant.//Before EBEL, BALDOCK and KELLY, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the Northern District of Oklahoma
allegation_sentence_1: On appeal, Kravchuk challenges the district court's refusal to grant him a new trial on the basis of alleged prosecutorial misconduct and alleged irregularities in admitting evidence regarding prior crimes under Federal Rule of Evidence 404(b). 2
allegation_term_1: alleged prosecutorial misconduct and alleged irregularities in admitting evidence
allegation_sentence_2: Kravchuk proffers two arguments regarding alleged prosecutorial misconduct. First, he argues that the district court erred in denying his motions for a mistrial and new trial when the prosecutor stated in closing that Kravchuk had “lied and lied and lied.” Second, he argues that it constituted prosecutorial misconduct for the prosecutor not to have known ahead of time that a witness would reveal that Kravchuk had threatened his co-participants.
allegation_term_2: proffers two arguments regarding alleged prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Because none of Kravchuk's objections regarding the conduct of the trial have merit, we uphold the district court's denial of a new trial and AFFIRM Kravchuk's conviction.
misconduct_determination_term1: none of Kravchuk's objections regarding the conduct of the trial have merit
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We find that, although the prosecutor's statement may have been improper, it was not reversible error. Although the Tenth Circuit has characterized as “unnecessary” and “unwarranted” a closing argument in which a prosecutor called a defendant a “liar,” United States v. Nichols, 21 F.3d 1016, 1019 (10th Cir.1994), it is not per se prosecutorial misconduct to refer to testimony as a lie, see, e.g., United States v. Hernandez–Muniz, 170 F.3d 1007, 1012 (10th Cir.1999).
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Moreover, the district court had already found, and we agree on review, that because the evidence presented at trial of Kravchuk's participation in the burglary was “overwhelming,” the prosecutor's statement in closing argument about Kravchuk being a liar was at most harmless error.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Accordingly, the prosecutor's statements, although arguably improper, do not merit reversal. The district court did not abuse its discretion in denying Kravchuk's motion for a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: For the reasons stated above, we AFFIRM Kravchuk's conviction. We REMAND, however, to the district court for it to provide an explanation for imposing the term and conditions of supervised release on Kravchuk, including any upward departure it may have chosen to make for the three months of home confinement, or for it to resentence him in accordance with the guidelines. We additionally REMAND for the district court to reduce to writing its factual findings regarding the $9,000 in restitution to which Kravchuk objected in his presentence report.
misconduct_determination_term5: we AFFIRM Kravchuk's conviction. We REMAND, however, to the district court for it to provide an explanation for imposing the term and conditions of supervised release on Kravchuk

allegation_sentence_1: Defendant also moves for dismissal on the ground that the prosecutor engaged in prosecutorial misconduct by failing adequately to inform the grand jury of the context in which witness testimony was obtained during interrogations in Russia.
allegation_sentence_2: Defendant next moves to dismiss for prosecutorial misconduct. Defendant presented evidence that Russian law enforcement officers “routinely” coerce confessions from suspects and witnesses using various methods of threats and intimidation.
allegation_term_2: moves to dismiss for prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Defendant has not shown that the conduct of the prosecutor here reaches the standard required for dismissal under Samango.
misconduct_determination_term1: has not shown that the conduct of the prosecutor here reaches the standard required for dismissal
misconduct_determination_sentence2: For the reasons that follow, the court DENIES the motion to dismiss for prosecutorial misconduct and DENIES the motion for discovery ancillary to a motion to dismiss for a speedy trial violation.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Accordingly, defendant has not presented evidence of prosecutorial misconduct.

defendant: John That LUONG et al., Defendants.

Jeffrey Lewis Staniels, Office of the Federal Defender,
Sacramento, CA, for Defendant Thongsouk Theng
Lattanaphon.//WILLIAM B. SHUBB, District Judge.
geography_entities: E.D. California.
allegation_sentence_1: Luong moves for a new trial pursuant to Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 33, alleging several instances of prosecutorial misconduct and taking issue with the court's jury instruction on evidence admitted under Federal Rule of Evidence 404(b).
allegation_term_1: alleging several instances of prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2: As to Luong's allegations of prosecutorial misconduct, he states that the prosecutor (1) accused counsel and their clients of “a preplanned, concerted effort to have Kevin Lattanaphon testify falsely”; (2) argued that Luong “should have called a witness to testify but failed to do so”; (3) argued certain facts that were not in evidence; (4) misstated the definition of Hobbs–Act robbery to include concealment of the crime; and (5) misstated the element of Hobbs–Act robbery requiring that property be taken from a person or person's presence.
allegation_sentence_3: As to Huynh's additional claims of prosecutorial misconduct, he asserts that during the Government's rebuttal closing argument, the Government improperly “invited the jury” to “cumulate evidence of each of the crimes charged, and to infer a criminal disposition by HUYNH.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1: For the same reasons articulated at that time, the court again rejects Luong's arguments.
misconduct_determination_term1: the court again rejects Luong's arguments.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: After reviewing the relevant portions of the trial transcript (see Trial Tr. Nov. 29, 2007, 119:20–120:11, 121:21–122:8, 123:7–13, 141:9–18), the court finds that the Government's arguments, while perhaps evincing occasional imprecision, did not amount to prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2: did not amount to prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Furthermore, any improper prejudice resulting from the Government's statements were subsequently cured by the court's instructions to the jury regarding the burden of proof and the manner in which each count of the indictment must be considered.
misconduct_determination_term3: any improper prejudice resulting from the Government's statements were subsequently cured

Shepard seeks to demonstrate that the documents produced by the government included multiple duplicates.

allegation_sentence_1: Hubbard's fourth claim—that prosecutorial misconduct compromised his right to a fair trial—has three components.
allegation_term_1: prosecutorial misconduct compromised his right to a fair trial
allegation_sentence_2: Hubbard also states that the government “failed to disclose [ ] Coley's grand jury testimony, which ... should have been made available for purposes of impeachment.” Id. at 6.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: In any event, Hubbard has not attempted to justify his failure to raise his “supplemental instruction” and prosecutorial misconduct claims on appeal, and nothing in the record indicates that Hubbard's neglect was excusable.
misconduct_determination_term1: nothing in the record indicates that Hubbard's neglect was excusable.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Since Hubbard cannot demonstrate that he was prejudiced by his attorney's failure to request “lesser included offense,” “multiple conspiracy,” and “buyer-seller relationship” defense instructions, his ineffective assistance of counsel claims can go no further.
misconduct_determination_term2: his ineffective assistance of counsel claims can go no further.

decision_court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.

geography_entities: D. Oregon.
allegation_sentence_1: Petitioner's allegations may be generally divided into claims of judicial misconduct, prosecutorial misconduct, independent constitutional issues, ineffective assistance of counsel, and actual innocence,
allegation_sentence_2: Ground Three (prosecutorial misconduct): The government vindictively enhanced its charges against petitioner by applying the ACCA to petitioner's charges in retaliation for petitioner not accepting the prosecution's offered plea bargain.
allegation_term_2: The government vindictively enhanced its charges
allegation_sentence_3: Ground Four (prosecutorial misconduct): The government acted improperly by presenting false hearsay testimony to the grand jury that indicted petitioner.
allegation_sentence_4: Ground Five (prosecutorial misconduct): The government committed prosecutorial misconduct by presenting to petitioner a grand jury indictment lacking a foreperson's signature.
allegation_sentence_5: Ground Six (prosecutorial misconduct): The government committed prosecutorial misconduct by failing to prosecute Ms. Donna Morrisson, a passenger in the vehicle.
allegation_term_5: failing to prosecute Ms. Donna Morrisson, a passenger in the vehicle.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: After carefully reviewing the record, I conclude that the facts and the applicable law do not support petitioner's claim.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: However, the requirement that the grand jury foreperson sign an indictment is a formality, and the absence of a signature “is a mere technical irregularity that is not necessarily fatal to the indictment.”
misconduct_determination_term2: not necessarily fatal to the indictment.”

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *895 Ricardo Meza (argued), Office of U.S. Atty., Criminal Division, Chicago, IL, for Plaintiff-Appellee.//John T. Theis (argued), Chicago, IL, for DefendantAppellant.//Before BAUER, RIPPLE and MANION, Circuit Judges.//RIPPLE, Circuit Judge.
geography_entities: Northern District of Illinois
allegation_sentence_1: Mr. Poole alleges that the prosecutor made improper closing remarks *900 when she characterized the circumstances surrounding Mr. Poole's 1996 plea agreement in state court on the cannabis charge.
allegation_term_1: alleges that the prosecutor made improper closing remarks
misconduct_determination_sentence1: prosecutor did not engage in misconduct during closing argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Even if the statement had been improper in isolation, Mr. Poole's argument would fail the second test in our analysis of possible prosecutorial misconduct during closing argument. Mr. Poole testified at trial that he did not know he had a felony conviction and that he did not know that he could have been sentenced to over one year of imprisonment, thereby inviting the prosecutor's comments. Also, Mr. Poole had ample opportunity to refute the prosecutor's argument during his own closing.
misconduct_determination_term2: Poole's argument would fail the second test in our analysis of possible prosecutorial misconduct

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
defendant: Lawrence CHAVEZ; Robert Clarke, aka Bnd or Robert Clark; Melaquias Sandoval; Patrick Henry Zanzucchi; Robert Matthew Zanzucchi, Defendants-Appellants.
attorneys_judges: Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Arizona; Robert C. Broomfield, District Judge, Presiding.//Before CHOY, GOODWIN and BEEZER, Circuit Judges
geography_entities: Arizona
allegation_sentence_1: Hank and Matt argue that several instances of prosecutorial misconduct, although perhaps not enough to prejudice them by themselves, when considered cumulatively denied them a fair trial. They further attack the Office for the United States Attorney for the District of Arizona, and attempt to show a pattern of misconduct which justifies a new trial.
allegation_sentence_2: Matt and Hank argue that although each act of governmental misconduct standing alone may be insufficient to require sanctions, their cumulative effect may require the court to exercise its supervisory powers.
allegation_term_2: require the court to exercise its supervisory powers.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: While the government clearly made mistakes, these mistakes did not rise to the level of misconduct. This case was very long, and errors should be expected. A defendant is entitled to a fair trial, not a perfect one.
misconduct_determination_term1: did not rise to the level of misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2: None of the errors was shown to be intentional and, except for the instances in which we found reversible error, see United States v. Chavez, Slip op. --- (9th Cir. March ----, 1988), none prejudiced the defendants.
notes:
Interesting anecdote: "Among reported decisions there have been only 29 cases
charging prosecutorial misconduct out of 20,000 criminal
cases brought by this Office in the last two decades. There
have been four reported decisions finding misconduct, and
none since 1980. While any misconduct on the part of
prosecutor is cause for concern, especially when it is so
egregious as to require reversal, we cannot say that these cases
establish a pattern of misconduct which would require special
scrutiny of the Northern Arizona United States Attorney's
Office. Diligent advocacy is one thing, groundless attacks
upon opposing counsel is another. Mistakes in this area
destroy credibility."

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
attorneys_judges:
William J. Rea, District Judge,
Presiding.//Before: PREGERSON, REINHARDT, and T.G. NELSON,
Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central District of California, Nos. CV-95-02149- WJR, CR-86-00990-WJR
allegation_sentence_1: Terrell contends that the district court erred by denying his § 2255 motion without holding an evidentiary hearing on his claims that the government committed prosecutorial misconduct when it used perjured testimony to get a conviction, entered into a secret deal with a defense witness, and failed to disclose false and misleading testimony at trial
allegation_term_1: the district court erred by denying his § 2255 motion
allegation_sentence_2: Terrell contends that he is entitled to an evidentiary hearing to consider newly discovered evidence regarding the perjured testimony of Frank Duffy.
allegation_term_2: contends that he is entitled to an evidentiary hearing
allegation_sentence_3: Here, Terrell attempts to relitigate his claim of prosecutorial misconduct by offering new evidence, in the form of affidavits from a private investigator and Duffy, which allegedly support his contention that Duffy entered into a secret agreement with the government to perjure himself during Terrell's trial in exchange for a transfer to any prison of his choice.
allegation_term_3: attempts to relitigate his claim of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The district court found that Terrell's claim of a clandestine deal between Duffy, a defense witness, and the government was speculative at best.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The record does not support Terrell's theory of a secret plot by the government to entice Duffy to perjure himself in exchange for a prison transfer.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Thus, the district court did not abuse its discretion by refusing to conduct an evidentiary hearing. Id. Additionally, the district court did not err by denying relief on Terrell's claim that the government failed to disclose evidence, because it was successive, and Terrell fails to make a colorable showing of factual innocence.
misconduct_determination_term3: the district court did not abuse its discretion

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *689 James Lee Turner, Asst. U.S.//Atty. (argued), Houston, TX, for U.S. Marjorie A. Meyers, Fed. Pub. Def., Timothy William Crooks and Margaret Christina Ling (argued), Asst. Fed. Pub. Defenders, Houston, TX, for Defendant–Appellant.//Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas.//Before WIENER, DENNIS, and CLEMENT, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas
case_outcome: Vacated in part, dismissed in part, and remanded.
allegation_sentence_1: Delgado's counsel argued that the evidence left many unanswered questions, that the informant's testimony was untrustworthy, and that Delgado's consent to search showed that she did not know the marijuana was in the truck.
allegation_term_1: the evidence left many unanswered questions
allegation_sentence_2: She was sentenced to a concurrent term of 100 months imprisonment for each conviction. Delgado appealed.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The Court of Appeals, Dennis, Circuit Judge, held that: [1] evidence was insufficient to support conspiracy conviction, and [2] trial was rendered fundamentally unfair by cumulative effects of several errors.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: For the reasons assigned herein, we vacate her convictions and sentences, dismiss the conspiracy charge of the indictment because the government failed to introduce sufficient evidence to convict her of conspiracy, and remand the case to the district court for further proceedings on the possession with intent to distribute charge.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In addition, Delgado's trial was rendered fundamentally unfair by the cumulative effects of several errors. Two members of the prosecution team engaged in trial misconduct that was unfairly prejudicial to Delgado. The prosecutor, in his closing argument, told the jury that Delgado (who did not take the witness stand) had lied when she told the
investigating government agents that she was unaware that
marijuana had been hidden in the sleeping compartment of
the truck.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: These errors, in the context of this case, were cumulatively sufficient to render the proceedings fundamentally unfair. Delgado is therefore entitled to a new trial as to the remaining charge against her.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: To fit this case into our cumulative error jurisprudence, the majority finds error where none exists and overstates the harm allegedly caused by each error it finds. The result is a decision that makes a muddle of this court's prosecutorial misconduct, conspiracy, and cumulative error doctrines.
notes: Interesting case about a confidential informant: The evidence presented by the prosecution was not sufficient to support a finding by a jury beyond a reasonable doubt that Delgado was guilty of conspiracy. Delgado's unconsummated “agreement” with a produce broker's agent to commingle marijuana with produce in a motor freight shipment was not an actual agreement as required for the crime of conspiracy: the broker's agent was an undercover government informer, who only pretended to agree to the scheme with Delgado pursuant to ICE officers' plan to incriminate Delgado and seize contraband marijuana. The evidence was also not sufficient to support a finding by a jury beyond a reasonable doubt that Delgado agreed with the unknown person who supplied the marijuana, the unknown prospective recipient, or any other person, to commit a crime that amounted to more than a buyer-seller relationship. The district court did not inform the jury that neither an agreement with a government informer who intends to frustrate the conspiracy, nor a simple buyer-seller relationship, is legally sufficient to amount to a conspiracy. Because there was no evidence that Delgado entered into an agreement with anyone other than the informer to engage in anything beyond a simple buyer-seller transaction, the conspiracy charge must be dismissed due to insufficient evidence."

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
defendant: Kenneth Andrew MORRIS, also known as Andy Morris, also known as Kenneth Doerge, Defendant–Appellant.
attorneys_judges: *797 Matthew H. Mead, U.S. Attorney, Cheyenne, WY, Patrick J. Crank, Asst. U.S. Attorney, Casper, WY, for Plaintiff–Appellee.//John H. Robinson, Jamieson & Robinson, Casper, WY, for Defendant–Appellant.//Before KELLY, McKAY, and MURPHY, Circuit Judges
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the District of Wyoming
allegation_sentence_1: He claims *798 that 1) his confession was not sufficiently corroborated by independent evidence, 2) his conviction should be reversed because it was not supported by sufficient evidence, and 3) his conviction should be reversed due to prosecutorial misconduct during closing argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Because the prosecutor's improper argument was in response to defense counsel's similarly improper argument attacking the Government's integrity, we hold that the remarks, in context, do not warrant overturning the conviction.
misconduct_determination_term1: do not warrant overturning the conviction
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Therefore, we agree with the district court that “the comments considered at their very worst as a commentary on the [prosecuting attorney's] belief did not prejudice the defendant.” Rec., Vol. V, at 32–33.

decision_court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Newport News Division.
attorneys_judges: Lisa Rae McKeel, Howard J. Zlotnick, Jonathan A. Ophardt, United States Attorney's Office, Newport News, VA, for Plaintiff.//Jennifer Tope Stanton, J. T. Stanton, P.C., Kim Michelle Crump, Kim Michelle Crump, Esq., Norfolk, VA, for Defendant.
geography_entities: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Newport News Division
allegation_sentence_1: Defendant claims that the Government knowingly used perjured testimony.
allegation_sentence_2: Defendant urges this Court to dismiss the Indictment due to alleged prosecutorial misconduct. ECF No. 215 at 8. Specifically, Defendant argues that, “producing 1800 pages of Jencks material on counsel for the defense a mere five days prior to trial, learning that it was in reality much more than 1800 pages and not disclosing most of the additional material until the trial had already begun, and then disclosing even more Brady /Jencks materials post-trial” constituted prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_3: Defendant further alleges that the “failure to correct the inconsistencies in Calvin Bailey's testimony, providing late and incomplete discovery, failure to provide exculpatory evidence, and the submission of exculpatory evidence after trial of others implicated in the Hatch murder” are additional examples of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_term_3: are additional examples of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The Court finds that Defendant was not prejudiced by the post-verdict Hatch murder disclosures because (1) Defendant has not demonstrated that the disclosures contained any admissible exculpatory evidence; (2) Defendant has failed to show that the disclosed information could potentially lead to admissible exculpatory evidence; and (3) Defendant has failed to establish materiality. Under Brady v. Maryland, “it is only the suppression of ‘material’ exculpatory evidence by the government that violates a defendant's due process rights.”
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Therefore, the Court finds no meritorious reason to dismiss the indictment as a result of a Brady violation or prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Still, the Court has not been presented with any evidence that causes it to question the jury's verdict or otherwise undermines the Court's confidence in Defendant's trial.
misconduct_determination_term3: the Court has not been presented with any evidence that causes it to question the jury's verdict

new_pdf: U.S. v. Martinez, Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (2010).pdf
pdf_link: https://s3.amazonaws.com/text.convert/test_1/federal_sample_20170408/pdf/U.S. v. Martinez, Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (2010).pdf
txt_file: U.S. v. Martinez, Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (2010).txt
txt_link: https://s3.amazonaws.com/text.convert/test_1/federal_sample_20170408/txt/U.S. v. Martinez, Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (2010).txt
decision_court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
defendant: Jose MARTINEZ Roniquike E. Maisonet, Defendants.
attorneys_judges: Thomas S. Duszkiewicz, U.S. Attorney's Office, Buffalo, NY, for United States of America.//A. Joseph Catalano, Harrington and Mahoney, Buffalo, NY, for Defendants.
geography_entities: W.D. New York.
allegation_sentence_1: In his motion, Martinez contends that the government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct before the Grand Jury warranting dismissal of the Superseding Indictment against him.
allegation_sentence_2: Martinez argues that the government prejudiced the Grand Jury by “poisoning their minds” with misleading questions and the use of hearsay statements. He contends that this alleged misconduct was the sole reason he was named in the Superseding Indictment because “there is-there was no other evidence tying [him] to the-to any-any conspiracy.”
allegation_term_2: argues that the government prejudiced the Grand Jury
allegation_sentence_3: Second, he argues that the government allowed Runkle to misleadingly testify about 12 phone calls between Turner and a number allegedly used by Martinez, when in fact the calls were not recorded, the speakers were not identified and the content of the conversation was unknown.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Applying these principles, this Court finds that dismissal of the Superseding Indictment is not warranted. Martinez has not demonstrated that the Grand Jury's decision to indict him was substantially influenced by the government's alleged misconduct, nor has Martinez demonstrated a “grave doubt” that the Grand Jury was not independent or unbiased.
misconduct_determination_term1: dismissal of the Superseding Indictment is not warranted.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Moreover, this Court finds that the testimony elicited concerning the Turner murder, calls between Turner and Martinez, the sale of the car, and the identification of Martinez as “Rico Suave” was not unfairly prejudicial and does not approach extreme prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2: does not approach extreme prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence3: But even assuming the existence of misconduct, this Court finds it harmless in light of the other evidence of Martinez's involvement in the conspiracy that the government presented to the Grand Jury.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
defendant: William David GLADHART, Defendant-Appellant. United States of America, Plaintiff-Appellee,//Emily Sharon Gladhart, Defendant-Appellant.
attorneys_judges:
*785 Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Idaho, Edward J. Lodge, District Judge, Presiding.
D.C. No. CR-01-00197-EJL.//Before: B. FLETCHER, BRUNETTI, and MCKEOWN,
Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the District of Idaho
allegation_sentence_1: The Gladharts challenge the sufficiency of the evidence adduced at their trial, and they contend that they must be granted a new trial because of alleged prosecutorial misconduct that occurred before their grand jury.
allegation_sentence_2: They also argue that the district court erred in denying them a bill of particulars and a special verdict form for the jury to indicate which statement or statements it unanimously found the Gladharts made in violation of § 1014.
allegation_term_2: argue that the district court erred in denying them a bill of particulars
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We find no circumstances in this case that warrant an
exception to the general rule, and accordingly, we hold that
the district court did not abuse its discretion in denying the
Gladharts' motion for a new trial on this ground.
misconduct_determination_term1: the district court did not abuse its discretion
misconduct_determination_term2: Because the Gladharts' arguments are without merit, the judgment of the district court is AFFIRMED.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: without merit

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
attorneys_judges:
*422 Bram Jacobson, Assistant Federal Public Defender,
Phoenix, AZ, for defendant-appellant.//Linda C. Boone, Assistant United States Attorney, Phoenix, AZ, for plaintiff-appellee.// Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Arizona; Stephen M. McNamee, District Judge, Presiding. D.C. No. CR-96-00004-SMM.//Before: SCHROEDER and KLEINFELD, Circuit Judges and
WALLACH, Judge. *
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the District of Arizona
allegation_sentence_1: Etsitty argues next that the prosecutor committed two acts of misconduct during the trial, eliciting testimony from a government witness and presenting closing argument that suggested that Danny's suicide note did not exist. The defense objected to the second incident only.
allegation_term_1: argues next that the prosecutor committed two acts of misconduct
allegation_sentence_2: Etsitty appeals his conviction on four grounds: that the court erred in excluding a suicide note written by his brother; that the prosecutor committed prosecutorial misconduct during his closing argument by leading the jury to believe that no suicide note existed; that Etsitty was denied his rights to a representative jury under the fifth and sixth amendments to the United States Constitution; and that the district court erred in denying Etsitty's motion pursuant to Fed.R.Crim.P. 29 for acquittal of the kidnaping charge.
allegation_sentence_3: Etsitty contends that the prosecutor mischaracterized identification evidence during his closing. This is a case of a misplaced word that was corrected quickly upon objection to eliminate any misunderstanding.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: defendant was not entitled to relief on ground that prosecutor engaged in misconduct when he mischaracterized identification evidence during closing argumen
misconduct_determination_term1: not entitled to relief on ground that prosecutor engaged in misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Nothing in the questioning or the answers given can be construed to reflect an intention by the prosecutor to mislead the jury. It was not clear error to allow the exchange to go without correction. Moreover, after the contents of the suicide note had been excluded from evidence, its existence became irrelevant. There was no inference related to guilt or innocence that the jury could have drawn from the letter's existence. Therefore, had error occurred, it was harmless.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: At most, the prosecutor phrased his argument inartfully. Based on the transcript, we have no reason to believe that the prosecutor intended to mislead the jury into believing that the witness had testified that he knew Danny and the description did not match him. He corrected himself quickly. Moreover, the court's instruction eliminated any prejudice that may have occurred during this courtroom exchange.
misconduct_determination_term3: no reason to believe that the prosecutor intended to mislead the jury
misconduct_determination_sentence4: We find no misconduct, and note that had any occurred, it was harmless.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *820 Bertram T. Kaufmann, Fresno, California, for the defendant-appellant.//William S. Wong, Assistant United States Attorney, Sacramento, California, for the plaintiff-appellee.//Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District of California Robert E. Coyle, District Judge, Presiding. D.C. No. CR 95–5036 REC.//Before: SCHROEDER, FARRIS and TASHIMA, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Eastern District of California
allegation_sentence_1: Peterson also argues that the district court erred in denying his motion for a new trial based on prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The Court of Appeals, Tashima, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) admission of nontestifying codefendant's confession, which was improperly redacted, violated defendant's confrontation rights; (2) erroneous admission of confession was not harmless beyond a reasonable doubt; and (3) defendant was not prejudiced by prosecutor's reading, during closing arguments, from police report that had not been admitted into evidence.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The government argues that any Bruton violation was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt because the evidence against Peterson was “overwhelming.”
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Peterson also argues that the district court erred in denying his motion for a new trial based on prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: The district court concluded that the misconduct did not result in any prejudice to the defendant, and we agree. Peterson has not shown that he was prejudiced by the prosecutor's error of arguing from this unadmitted police report. The district court did not abuse its discretion by denying a mistrial based on this error.
misconduct_determination_term4: the misconduct did not result in any prejudice

allegation_sentence_1: These include a claim of an illegal search and seizure based on alleged lack of probable cause for stop and arrest, an illegal charge against him by the prosecutor, a violation of his Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights based on the government's alleged improper chain of custody of the firearm, and prosecutorial misconduct impaired his right to fair trial.
allegation_sentence_2: Mr. Mims argues that the prosecutor testified as an unsworn witness by assisting the witness in a physical demonstration.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The court adopts its previous analyses and conclusions under the ineffective assistance of counsel analysis in Part I to conclude these challenges have no merit, even under a claim independent of the ineffective assistance argument.

new_pdf: U.S. ex rel. Ruddock v. Briley, 216 F.Supp.2d 737 (2002).pdf

txt_file: U.S. ex rel. Ruddock v. Briley, 216 F.Supp.2d 737 (2002).txt
txt_link: https://s3.amazonaws.com/text.convert/test_1/federal_sample_20170408/txt/U.S. ex rel. Ruddock v. Briley, 216 F.Supp.2d 737 (2002).txt
decision_court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
defendant: Kenneth BRILEY, Warden, Stateville Correctional Center Respondent.
attorneys_judges: *741 Andre Ruddock, Pontiac, IL, Pro se.//Anne Scullen Bagby , Illinois Attorney General's Office, Michael Hoard, Lopez, Hoard, Edwards & Hernandez, LLC, Chicago, IL, for Respondent.//BUCKLO, District Judge.
geography_entities: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
allegation_sentence_1: On appeal, Mr. Ruddock argued that three instances of prosecutorial misconduct deprived him of a fair trial. He argued that the prosecutor: (1) elicited testimony from Officer Carroll falsely implying that Mr. Ruddock told the police where to find the murder weapon; (2) engaged in misconduct during closing argument by stating that Officer Carroll retrieved the gun after asking where “his” gun was; (3) and appealed to the jurors' passion and prejudice by improperly comparing the victims' rights to his own as a defendant.
allegation_term_1: prosecutorial misconduct deprived him of a fair trial
allegation_sentence_2: the trial court erroneously allowed the prosecutor to make improper arguments and engaged in prosecutorial misconduct by allowing the jury to see gruesome photos not admitted into evidence;
allegation_term_2: the trial court erroneously allowed the prosecutor to make improper arguments
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The District Court, Bucklo, J., held that: (1) trial court's evidentiary rulings did not deny petitioner fundamental fairness; (2) petitioner's procedural default of certain claims precluded habeas review; (3) evidence allegedly withheld from petitioner was not material, and thus withholding did not amount to Brady violation; (4) there was sufficient evidence to support convictions; (5) petitioner was not denied due process; (6) alleged prosecutorial misconduct did not deprive petitioner of a fair trial; and (7) petitioner was not denied effective assistance of counsel.
misconduct_determination_term1: alleged prosecutorial misconduct did not deprive petitioner of a fair trial
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The challenged evidentiary ruling was not a denial of fundamental fairness.
misconduct_determination_term2: not a denial of fundamental fairness.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Mr. Ruddock does not indicate anything that suggests that if he had had the record, his appeal would have been successful. He would have had to have raised different arguments than the ones raised here, which were raised when he did have the record.
misconduct_determination_term3: does not indicate anything that suggests that if he had had the record, his appeal would have been successful.

geography_entities: E.D. North Carolina.
case_outcome: motion to dismiss petitioner's § 2255 action is GRANTED.
allegation_sentence_1: Petitioner's 28 U.S.C. § 2255 motion, dated November 8, 2000, but filed on December 4, 2000, 1 claims ineffective assistance of counsel in numerous instances, invalid plea agreement and breach thereof, incorrect criminal history and prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Petitioner's prosecutorial misconduct claims all relate
to conduct known to petitioner prior to her plea and therefore
are barred by the waiver.

new_pdf: Young v. U.S., Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (2012).pdf
pdf_link: https://s3.amazonaws.com/text.convert/test_1/federal_sample_20170408/pdf/Young v. U.S., Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (2012).pdf
txt_file: Young v. U.S., Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (2012).txt
txt_link: https://s3.amazonaws.com/text.convert/test_1/federal_sample_20170408/txt/Young v. U.S., Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (2012).txt
decision_court: United States District Court, N.D. West Virginia.
attorneys_judges: Lance D. Young, White Deer, PA, pro se.//Randolph J. Bernard, U.S. Attorney's Office, Wheeling, WV, for Respondent.//FREDERICK P. STAMP, JR., District Judge.
geography_entities: N.D. West Virginia.
allegation_sentence_1: The petitioner, who is appearing pro se, 1 asserts ten grounds in support of his § 2255 motion, including ineffective assistance of counsel, prosecutorial misconduct, and insufficient evidence to convict, among others.
allegation_sentence_2: The petitioner raises the following issues: (1) prosecutorial misconduct occurred when the Assistant United States Attorney (“AUSA”) made improper comments intended to mislead the jury; (2) there was insufficient evidence to support the finding of the § 924(c) charge in the indictment; (3) trial counsel was ineffective for failing to challenge the § 924(c) charge, for failing to investigate, and for failing to object and preserve as issues for appeal the prosecution's misconduct; (4) appellate counsel was ineffective for failing to argue the precedential case of Watson v. United States, 552 U.S. 74 (2007) on appeal, for failing to obtain a complete set of transcripts, and for failing to challenge Count Five of the indictment. 2
allegation_sentence_3: Specifically, the petitioner argues that in his closing argument, the AUSA inaccurately stated that the petitioner had sold 32 handguns and had traded weapons for heroin in the past.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: After discussing the petitioner's burden to show cause and actual prejudice, the magistrate judge concluded that unless the petitioner can show cause and prejudice for the default, the petitioner's Ground One claim of prosecutorial misconduct and his Ground Two claim of insufficient evidence to support the § 924(c) charge are procedurally defaulted because they could have been, but were not, raised on appeal.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: After reviewing the trial transcript, the magistrate judge concluded that the petitioner's challenge to the AUSA's comments during closing argument has no merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Although the phrase “32 handguns” appears in the trial transcript, it is clear from the context surrounding this phrase that the AUSA was referencing the .32 caliber handgun that was stolen when the petitioner's house was broken into.
misconduct_determination_term3: the AUSA was referencing the .32 caliber handgun
misconduct_determination_sentence4: The magistrate judge found no evidence to support the petitioner's contention that the AUSA's statement so infected the trial with unfairness that the petitioner's conviction was a denial of due process.
misconduct_determination_term4: no evidence to support the petitioner's contention
misconduct_determination_sentence5: In conclusion, the magistrate judge found that the petitioner's claims of prosecutorial misconduct have no support in the record, that no due process violation on that ground exists, and that these claims should be denied. Further, the magistrate judge determined that the claims encompassed in Ground One could have been raised on direct appeal but were not, therefore, they are now procedurally barred.

txt_link: https://s3.amazonaws.com/text.convert/test_1/federal_sample_20170408/txt/U.S. ex rel. Prewitt v. Gilmore, Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (1999).txt
decision_court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
defendant: UNITED STATES of America ex rel. Dennis Prewitt, Petitioner,//Jerry D. GILMORE, Respondent.
attorneys_judges: NORDBERG, District J
geography_entities: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division
allegation_sentence_1: Petitioner appealed, raising eight issues: (1) prosecutorial misconduct for comments made during closing argument not based on evidence presented at trial (statistical probability argument); (2) improper introduction of other crimes evidence; (3) prosecutorial misconduct for insinuating to the jury that Petitioner had criminal tendencies and reference to the existence of other evidence of guilt not presented to the jury;
allegation_term_1: prosecutorial misconduct for comments made during closing argument
allegation_sentence_2: Petitioner's evidentiary claims include: (1) admission of testimony suggesting that Petitioner was involved in other crimes and carried a handgun; (2) admission of “unsupported insinuations of corroborative evidence” supporting identification of Petitioner as the offender; and (3) violation of Petitioner's Sixth Amendment right to confrontation by admission of hearsay evidence to support identification of Petitioner as the offender. 2
allegation_term_2: violation of Petitioner's Sixth Amendment right
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Petitioner's second claim of prosecutorial misconduct, the statement in closing argument that defense counsel may have been trying to confuse a state witness, similarly does not rise to the level of a federal constitutional violation.
misconduct_determination_term1: does not rise to the level of a federal constitutional violation
misconduct_determination_sentence2: This court agrees that the alleged misconduct is of such a minor character that Petitioner suffered no prejudice and holds that Petitioner has thus failed to establish that he is being held in violation of the United States Constitution. Petitioner therefore cannot demonstrate that he fairly presented a federal constitutional violation to the state courts.

geography_entities: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division.
allegation_sentence_1: After an initial screening, the court determined that plaintiff had asserted two claims, as follows: (1) that there was prosecutorial misconduct for a failure to abide by an alleged nol pros agreement; and (2) that she received ineffective assistance of counsel in preparing for the plea and sentencing hearings.
allegation_sentence_2: In support of such contention, petitioner asserts that the government: (1) breached a 2007–2008 agreement not to prosecute; and (2) failed to make a downward departure motion. Id.
allegation_term_2: asserts that the government: (1) breached a 2007–2008 agreement
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Thus, petitioner's claim of prosecutorial misconduct based on a nol pros agreement is wholly without merit as it lacks a plausible factual basis and will be dismissed with prejudice.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Finding that there is no support for a claim of prosecutorial misconduct, such subcontention will be dismissed with prejudice.
misconduct_determination_term2: no support for a claim of prosecutorial misconduct

new_pdf: Gullett v. U.S., Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (1999).pdf
pdf_link: https://s3.amazonaws.com/text.convert/test_1/federal_sample_20170408/pdf/Gullett v. U.S., Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (1999).pdf
txt_file: Gullett v. U.S., Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (1999).txt
txt_link: https://s3.amazonaws.com/text.convert/test_1/federal_sample_20170408/txt/Gullett v. U.S., Not Reported in F.Supp.2d (1999).txt
decision_court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
attorneys_judges: Denny Ray Gullett, Beaver, WV, pro se.//Cheryl J. Sturm, Chadds Ford, PA, Michael E. Froble, The Wooton Law Firm, Beckley, WV, for Petitioner.//Rebecca A. Betts, Esquire, Allen Guthrie & McHugh, Charleston, WV, for Respondent.//HOGG, Magistrate J
geography_entities: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
allegation_sentence_1:
As grounds for relief, movant claims ineffective assistance of counsel, both at trial and on appeal; a denial of his Fifth Amendment rights based upon the use at trial of nonverbal statements derived from movant in violation of Miranda v. Arizona; an improper constructive amendment of the indictment by the United States; a failure of the district court to insure the expert witnesses met the appropriate standard of scientific validity; prosecutorial misconduct; an invalid criminal complaint derived from perjured testimony;
and a lack of federal jurisdiction over the situs of the crime.
allegation_term_2: Movant claims that his trial attorneys failed to properly investigate his case, failed to file timely motions, failed to present witnesses that could have sustained his defense, unreasonably stipulated to a chain of custody of certain scientific evidence, failed to object to prosecutorial misconduct, and failed to contest the district court's errors of admission with regard to scientific evidence.
allegation_sentence_3: failed to object to prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_term_3: He claims that the government attorneys withheld potentially exculpatory evidence in their presentation to the grand jury, that the attorneys engaged in improper closing argument, and that the attorneys committed misconduct by engaging in unjustified extrinsic contact with the jurors during movant's trial.
allegation_sentence_4: the attorneys committed misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Upon careful review of the record, the undersigned magistrate judge concludes that such claims are without merit and the motion should be denied.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: However, a review of the record clearly establishes that even if counsel had performed to movant's satisfaction, the result would have been the same. Even if all of movant's allegations are examined in their totality, they are not sufficient to undermine the confidence in the jury's verdict in this case. As the Court of Appeals recognized in affirming movant's conviction and sentence, the evidence of his criminal culpability was “overwhelming.” United States v. Gullett, 75 F.3d at 946.
misconduct_determination_term2: not sufficient to undermine the confidence in the jury's verdict in this case
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Movant's claim that counsel for the United States engaged in improper argument is equally meritless. The allegation of prosecutorial misconduct is based upon the fact that the United States argued evidence which was contrary to movant's interpretation. Such presentation does not constitute prosecutorial misconduct and movant's claim
just be rejected.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: Andrew B. Banzhoff, Asheville, North Carolina, for Appellant. Thomas Richard Ascik, Asheville, North Carolina, for Appellee.//Before NIEMEYER and WILLIAMS, Circuit Judges, and HAMILTON, Senior Circuit Judge.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Western District of North Carolina, at Asheville.
allegation_sentence_1: Carter's attorney has filed a brief in accordance with Anders v. *684 California, 386 U.S. 738, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 18 L.Ed.2d 493 (1967), arguing that Carter may have received ineffective assistance of counsel or prosecutorial misconduct, but stating that, in his view, there are no meritorious grounds for appeal.
allegation_term_1: Carter may have received ineffective assistance of counsel or prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2: Carter makes no specific allegation of prosecutorial misconduct, and none is apparent in the record on appeal.
allegation_term_2: no specific allegation of prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Finding no reversible error, we affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: As required by Anders, we have examined the entire record and find no meritorious issues for appeal.

decision_court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
defendant: 1. Alton John SMITH, a/k/ a Austin O. Ikeme, Defendant.
attorneys_judges: Matthew T. Kirsch Judith A. Smith, U.S. Attorney's Office, Denver, CO, for Plaintiff.//WILEY Y. DANIEL, Chief Judge.
geography_entities: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
allegation_sentence_1: This matter is before the Court on Defendant's pro se motion styled “Motion for Reconsideration for a New Fed.R.Cr.P Upon Presentation Id [sic] Newly Discovered Evidence of Prosecutorial Misconduct,” [ECF No. 144], filed September 20, 2011.
allegation_term_1: Newly Discovered Evidence of Prosecutorial Misconduct
allegation_sentence_2: First, Defendant complains that the Government mislead the jury in opening and closing statements by stating that Defendant submitted false documents to Wells Fargo Loan Officer David Bliesmer, when Mr. Bliesmer testified that had no personal knowledge that Defendant submitted false documentation.
allegation_term_2: complains the Government mislead the jury
allegation_sentence_3: Next, Defendant asserts that the Government mislead the jury during its opening statement by stating that “no one knew the person buying that house was actually Alton Smith.”
allegation_sentence_4: Finally, Defendant complains that the testimony of FBI Special Agent Donner that his company, Marrick Entertainment, was not actually engaged in business is at odds with other evidence submitted during trial
allegation_term_4: at odds with other evidence submitted during trial
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Defendant raised this argument in his previous motion, and I concluded that his submission did not demonstrate any false or misleading testimony by Mr. Bliesmer or government misconduct. Defendant has not demonstrated that my previous ruling was in error, nor has he submitted any new materials. Therefore, I reject Defendant's request for reconsideration of this issue.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: In conclusion, I find that Defendant has failed to justify reconsideration of the Court's previous ruling on his motion for new trial, nor has he identified any new evidence which would affect his conviction.

allegation_sentence_1: Defendant also alleges that 1) the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct by prosecuting him under 8 U.S.C. § 1326 since the statute lacks an implementing regulation;
allegation_sentence_2: Defendant argues that the Government committed prosecutorial misconduct by knowingly prosecuting him pursuant to a law, 8 U.S.C. § 1326, that is unconstitutional.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: It follows that the Government did not engage in any prosecutorial misconduct in prosecuting Defendant, and that Mr. Rorty's decision not to challenge the constitutionality of 8 U.S.C. § 1326 or the Government's conduct was not ineffective assistance.
