decision_court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division
attorneys_judges: Diane Renae Boss, Alderson, WV, pro se.//Andrew B. Birge, U.S. Attorney, Grand Rapids, MI, for Respondent.//ROBERT HOLMES BELL, Chief United States District Judge.
geography_entities: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division
allegation_sentence_1: Movant filed this § 2255 petition pro se, asserting three grounds for relief: ineffective assistance of counsel, prosecutorial misconduct, and United States v. Booker, 543 U.S. 220, 125 S.Ct. 738, 160 L.Ed.2d 621 (2005).
allegation_sentence_2:
Movant's prosecutorial misconduct claim is based upon her assertion that the government should have moved for a Rule 35(b) sentence reduction based upon her testimony and
documentation that the government was able to use in its case
against the other defendants.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The claim has no merit. The government has no obligation to file a Rule 3 5(b) motion except to the extent it has promised to do so.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Movant's plea agreement was silent with respect to substantial assistance motions. Movant has not alleged any unconstitutional motive in this case, nor does it appear that she would have any grounds to support such a claim. Accordingly, Movant is entitled to no relief on her prosecutorial misconduct claim.
misconduct_determination_term2: no relief on her prosecutorial misconduct claim.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: Before TANG, PREGERSON and ALARCON, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Southern District of California
allegation_sentence_1: On appeal, Williams contends that the district court erred by denying his motion for a new trial based on prosecutorial misconduct. Williams also contends that the district court erred when it denied his motion to suppress evidence of the narcotics.
allegation_term_1: the district court erred by denying his motion for a new trial based on prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2: Specifically, Williams contends that the government vouched for Layton's credibility by: 1) granting Layton immunity in the presence of the jury; 2) mentioning Layton's plea agreement during direct examination; and 3) referring to Layton's obligation to testify truthfully under the agreement during redirect examination.
allegation_term_2: the government vouched for Layton's credibility
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Contrary to Williams's arguments, the prosecutor did not vouch for Layton by telling the jury that she had been granted immunity. Juries are routinely advised that immunity has been granted for a witness's testimony. McGuire v. Estelle, 112 S.Ct. 475, 479 (1991); United States v. Vaccaro, 816 F.2d 443, 455 (9th Cir.1987).
misconduct_determination_term1: prosecutor did not vouch for Layton
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We disagree. In Simtob, a witness was granted immunity after his credibility was attacked on cross-examination. By contrast, Layton was granted immunity before she answered any questions about facts supporting the charges against Williams.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
defendant:
Gregory L. REYES, Defendant–Appellant.
United States of America, Plaintiff–Appellee,//Stephanie Jensen, Defendant–Appellant.
attorneys_judges:
*1072 Amber Rosen, San Jose, CA, for the plaintiffappellee.//Seth P. Waxman, Washington, DC., for defendant-appellant Gregory L. Reyes.//Steven A. Hirsch, Washington, DC., for defendant-appellant Stephanie Jensen.//Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California, Charles R. Breyer, District Judge, Presiding. D.C. Nos. CR–06–00556–1–CRB, CR–06–00556–2–CRB.//Before: MARY M. SCHROEDER and STEPHEN REINHARDT, Circuit Judges, and LOUIS H. POLLAK,*Senior District Judge.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Northern District of California
case_outcome: Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.
allegation_sentence_1: Gregory Reyes and Stephanie Jensen appeal from their convictions for falsifying corporate books and records, and related charges, stemming from their participation in a scheme to reward employees with grants of backdated stock options.
allegation_sentence_2: Reyes moved for a new trial on the basis of prosecutorialmisconduct. He also sought a new trial on the separate basis of what he asserted to be a recantation of Elizabeth Moore's testimony that she did not know about the backdating.
allegation_sentence_3: Reyes goes further on appeal and argues that the misconduct was so flagrant that the indictment should be dismissed.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: [2]prosecutorialmisconduct in making false assertion to jury in closing argument that corporation's finance department did not know backdating of stock options was occurring was not harmless in CEO's trial;
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We reverse Reyes' conviction because of prosecutorialmisconduct in making a false assertion of material fact to the jury in closing argument. We affirm Jensen's conviction but vacate the sentence and remand for resentencing because the sentence improperly included an obstruction of justice enhancement for which responsibility lay primarily with Jensen's lawyer.
misconduct_determination_term2: a false assertion of material fact
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Although we do not agree with the district court that the prosecutor may have been innocent of deliberate false statements, we recognize there were aggressive tactics on both sides.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: We do not conclude the prosecutor's conduct was so egregious as to require dismissal of the prosecution. Reyes' case must be remanded for a new trial.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
defendant: Roy G. POWELL, Defendant-Appellant. UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee,//Dixie Lee POWELL, Defendant-Appellant.
attorneys_judges: Before: WALLACE, Chief Judge, PREGERSON and BEEZER, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Arizona, No. CR-89-00085-ACM
allegation_sentence_1: Mr. Powell argues that his conviction should be reversed because of prosecutorial misconduct during closing argument and cross-examination of both Powells.
allegation_sentence_2: Mr. Powell points to several instances of alleged prosecutorial misconduct, beginning with the government's questioning of Mrs. Powell regarding the inconsistent testimony she gave in her previous trial. Although no objection was made, Mr. Powell did move for a mistrial.
allegation_term_2: several instances of alleged prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_3: Next, Mr. Powell suggests that the prosecutor engaged in misconduct by bringing up that Mr. Powell testified in an earlier proceeding that he had filed returns in the past.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: This questioning certainly did not amount to plain error. Indeed, it was neither improper nor prejudicial. See infra part IV.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We conclude that the alleged instances of prosecutorial misconduct, viewed both individually and in the aggregate, did not have any affect on the verdict. Mr. Powell's claim of prosecutorial misconduct fails.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit
defendant: Ron VEATCH, aka Ronald Veatch, Defendant-Appellant.
attorneys_judges: Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Arizona Richard M. Bilby, Chief Judgeg, Presiding//Before: CHOY and HALL, Circuit Judges, and REAL, *** District Judge.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the District of Arizona
allegation_sentence_1: prosecutorial misconduct by allegedly suppressing the exculpatory testimony of Jack Groce, a witness for the prosecution Judge Bilby found that the ineffective assistance of counsel claims and the bias and prejudice claims had been or could have been raised in the first motion under § 2255.
allegation_sentence_2: Petitioner accuses prosecutor Kenneth Fields of deliberately suppressing the testimony of a witness, Jack Groce.
allegation_term_2: deliberately suppressing the testimony of a witness,
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Considering the remaining contentions on the merits, the court concluded that the Supreme Court's holding in Lopez did not invalidate prosecutions under 18 U.S.C. § 2314 (interstate transportation of stolen property). The court also found that the conviction of the crime of transporting stolen property and the forfeiture of a bond did not offend the jeopardy provisions of the Fifth Amendment.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Finally, the court held that the Petitioner's failure to produce an affidavit or other competent proof of the prosecutor's suppression of Jack Groce's testimony precluded a finding of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2: precluded a finding of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: THE COURT WAS CORRECT IN FINDING THAT PETITIONER HAD NO COMPETENT EVIDENCE TO ESTABLISH A GENUINE ISSUE IN HIS CLAIM OF PROSECUTORIAL MISCONDUCT.
misconduct_determination_term3: NO COMPETENT EVIDENCE TO ESTABLISH A GENUINE ISSUE
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Petitioner has offered no competent evidence to support his allegation. The district court found that Petitioner provided no evidence to support his conclusory statement, only the recitation of a conversation between Mr. Groce and a third person. The alleged statement by Mr. Groce was hearsay and is incompetent as evidence to counter the government's motion for summary judgement. Zoslaw v. MCA Distrib. Corp., 693 F.2d 870, 883 (9th Cir.1982). The mere assertion of prosecutorial misconduct is not in itself sufficient to raise a triable issue of fact.
misconduct_determination_term4: mere assertion of prosecutorial misconduct is not in itself sufficient

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *637 James Lee Turner, Assistant U.S. Attorney, U.S. Attorney's Office, Houston, TX, for Plaintiff–Appellee.//Roland E. Dahlin, II, Federal Public Defender, Molly E. Odom, Federal Public Defender's Office, Houston, TX, for Defendant–Appellant.//Before WIENER, BENAVIDES and STEWART, Circuit Judge.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, USDC No. 5:02–CR–1495–ALL.
allegation_sentence_2: Mendoza–Salinas argues that he did not knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily waive his Sixth Amendment right to conflict-free counsel.
allegation_term_2: argues that he did not knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily waive his Sixth Amendment right
allegation_sentence_3: He contends that the district court erred in failing to conduct an adequate hearing pursuant to United States v. Garcia, 517 F.2d 272, 278 (5th Cir.1975), to determine whether any conflict of interest might exist or arise *638 because of his employer's payment of his legal fees.
allegation_sentence_4: He argues further that the district court erred in failing to conduct a second Garcia hearing when a potential conflict became apparent during the sentencing hearing.
allegation_sentence_5: For the first time on appeal, Mendoza–Salinas argues that improper comments made by the prosecutor during closing argument at trial warrant reversal of his conviction.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: prosecutor's remarks during summation did not amount to prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term1: did not amount to prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Mendoza– Salinas has failed to demonstrate the possibility that his counsel had conflicting loyalties was sufficiently apparent to impose a duty upon the district court to conduct a Garcia hearing.
misconduct_determination_term2: failed to demonstrate the possibility that his counsel had conflicting loyalties
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Mendoza–Salinas's argument is indeed foreclosed.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *509 Kirk N. Kirkconnell, Alan C. Todd, Steven G. Horneffer, Winter Park, Fla., for defendant-appellant.//John L. Briggs, U. S. Atty., Jacksonville, Fla., Kendall W. Wherry, William F. Duane, Asst. U. S. Attys., Orlando, Fla., for plaintiff-appellee.//Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida.//Before WISDOM, AINSWORTH and CLARK, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, at Orlando
allegation_sentence_1: Head asserts that the prosecutor's action in recording the grand jury testimony given by him and his supporting witnesses and at the same time not recording the testimony given by the government's key trial witnesses gave it an unfair tactical advantage at trial because the prosecutor had the transcripts for use in examining defense witnesses, but he was denied similar transcripts of what Wagner and Heuer testified. Thus, Head says this conduct prejudiced him and constituted reversible prosecutorial misconduct which should result in dismissal of the indictment returned or the striking of the testimony of the unrecorded witnesses.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The Court of Appeals, Charles Clark, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) while the prosecutor should not have selectively recorded the testimony of grand jury witnesses, defendant wholly failed to show that this mistake amounted to prosecutorial misconduct warranting dismissal of the indictment or a bar of the use of testimony of witnesses whose testimony was not recorded
misconduct_determination_term1: failed to show that this mistake amounted to prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Clearly there was no prejudice to the grand jury proceedings. The grand jurors heard and saw the witnesses. Nonrecording could not have affected the validity of the indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: In sum, we hold the prosecutor should not have selectively recorded the testimony of grand jury witnesses, but that defendant has wholly failed to show this mistake amounted to a prosecutorial misconduct warranting dismissal of the indictment or a bar of the use of the testimony of the witnesses whose testimony was not recorded.
misconduct_determination_term3: failed to show this mistake amounted to a prosecutorial misconduct warranting dismissal of the indictment

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *630 Robert L. Wyatt, IV, Wyatt Law Office, Oklahoma City, OK, for Defendant–Appellant.//Randal A. Sengel, Assistant U.S. Attorney (John C. Richter, United States Attorney, with him on the brief), Oklahoma City, OK, for Plaintiff–Appellee.//Before BRISCOE, SEYMOUR, and HARTZ, Circuit Judges.//*631 BRISCOE, Circuit Judge.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma
allegation_sentence_1: the district court abused its discretion by admitting into evidence certain testimony regarding gender and homosexuality; and (4) the district court abused its discretion by admitting into evidence images of child pornography, and related exhibits.
allegation_sentence_2: Schene also claims that the government suggested that he was a homosexual, which violated his right to due process and a fundamentally fair trial.
allegation_term_2: violated his right to due process
misconduct_determination_sentence1: the district court did not abuse its discretion in failing to grant a mistrial based on prosecutorial misconduct with respect to the government's references to homosexuality;
misconduct_determination_term1: court did not abuse its discretion
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Nevertheless—and even assuming, arguendo, that Schene preserved this argument for appeal by objecting and moving for a mistrial on this ground earlier in the trial—the district court did not abuse its discretion in failing to grant a mistrial based on the prosecutorial misconduct. The prosecutor's question was “singular and isolated,” United States v. Ivy, 83 F.3d 1266, 1288 (10th Cir.1996) (citation and internal quotation marks omitted), and Officer Elliott quickly refocused his testimony on the fact that the websites “all offered child pornography to view.” Trat 126.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Given the evidence against Schene, moreover, the alleged prosecutorial misconduct was not “flagrant enough to influence the jury to convict on grounds other than the evidence presented.” Ivy, 83 F.3d at 1288 (citations and internal quotation marks omitted). Reversal is not warranted on these grounds.
misconduct_determination_term3: not “flagrant enough to influence the jury

decision_court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
attorneys_judges: GEORGE B. DANIELS, District Judge.
geography_entities: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
allegation_sentence_1: Petitioner sought habeas relief from his 2004 conviction on the grounds of prosecutorial misconduct and ineffective assistance of counsel.
allegation_term_1: prosecutorial misconduct and ineffective assistance of counsel.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: This Court denied habeas relief as to Petitioner's prosecutorial misconduct claim because Petitioner failed to raise this claim on direct appeal and thus was procedurally barred from subsequently bringing the claim in his habeas petition.
misconduct_determination_term1: Petitioner failed to raise this claim on direct appeal
misconduct_determination_sentence2: This Court denied habeas relief with respect to Petitioner's ineffective assistance of counsel claim because the Second Circuit heard and rejected this claim on direct appeal. (Order at 3.) Therefore, this Court was precluded under the mandate rule from reconsidering Petitioner's ineffective assistance of counsel claim during the habeas proceeding.
misconduct_determination_term2: the Second Circuit heard and rejected this claim
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Petitioner has failed to demonstrate that the Court's Order denying his habeas petition is void under Rule 12(b) (4) because the Court did not require submission of attorney affidavits or hold an evidentiary hearing.
misconduct_determination_term3: ailed to demonstrate that the Court's Order denying his habeas petition is void

decision_court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
defendant: Daniel MILIKOWSKY and Macc Holding Corp.
attorneys_judges: *1286 Richard E. Byrne, Peter Levitas, Dwight Dickinson, U.S. Department of Justice, Antitrust Division, Washington, DC, for plaintiff.//Regina G. Malone, Steven A. Steinbach, Williams & Connolly, Washington, DC, David P. Atkins, Zeldes, Needle & Cooper, Bridgeport, CT, for defendants.//ELLEN B. BURNS, Senior District Judge.
geography_entities: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
allegation_sentence_1: witness' testimony was not “false” for purposes of prosecution's duty to correct false testimony; (4) prosecutor's improper comments at closing argument did not deny defendants a fair trial;
allegation_term_1: did not deny defendants a fair trial
allegation_sentence_2: As a second basis for a new trial, the Defendants contend that the government failed to correct, and, indeed, capitalized upon, certain “false” testimony by Benjamin DeBerry regarding when he was first able to identify the location and date of a particular alleged price-fixing meeting with William *1295 Lima and Defendant Milikowsky.
allegation_term_2: contend that the government failed to correct
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendants now contend that a new trial is warranted because the prosecutors failed to correct DeBerry's “false” statements that he believed that he had told prosecutors in May, 1990, that the second price-fixing meeting occurred in Chicago. They contend that, by remaining silent when they knew that DeBerry had spoken incorrectly, the prosecutors impermissibly relied on incorrect testimony, and that, as a result, the jury was left with the false
impression that DeBerry had been consistent about the location and date of the Chicago Hilton meeting since his first meeting with prosecutors.
allegation_term_3: prosecutors failed to correct DeBerry's “false” statements
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Viewing the testimony as a whole in this manner, the Court concludes that the testimony is not “false” for purposes of determining whether the government had a duty to “correct.”
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Had DeBerry stated unequivocally that he knew he told prosecutors about the Chicago meeting in 1990, the Court might find that the statement was “false” for purposes of a prosecutorial misconduct analysis—even had the statement been an honest misapprehension *1299 by the witness. 23 However, DeBerry made no such claim. Rather, he made equivocal and qualified statements that, the Court assumes, honestly reflected his inability to recollect.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Defendants contend that such a lack of intent to testify falsely is immaterial;
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Having found no falsity, the Court also finds that the prosecutors were under no duty to “correct” DeBerry's testimony, even though their recollection of DeBerry's revelation of the Chicago meeting differed from DeBerry's recollection.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: Although it believes, for reasons other than those asserted by the Defendants, that the prosecutor's remarks constituted error (albeit harmless), 27 this Court—having already determined that DeBerry's testimony was not “false”—cannot agree with the Defendants' claim that the prosecutor's remarks “embraced and exploited” false testimony.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: Tanya L. Davis, Belser & Parke, P.A., Asheville, North Carolina, for Appellant. Jill Westmoreland Rose, Office of the United States Attorney, Asheville, North Carolina, for Appellee.//Before MICHAEL, MOTZ, and GREGORY, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Western District of North *317 Carolina, at Asheville.
allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, counsel has filed a brief under Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 18 L.Ed.2d 493 (1967), alleging that there are no meritorious claims
on appeal but raising the following issues: (1) whether trial
counsel provided ineffective assistance of counsel, and (2)
whether the Government's failure to move for a downward
departure for substantial assistance under U.S. Sentencing
Guidelines Manual § 5K1.1 (2001) constitutes prosecutorial
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We do not find that the Government's failure to move for downward departure for substantial assistance constitutes prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term1: do not find that the Government's failure to move for downward departure for substantial assistance constitutes prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: The Government was not obligated under its plea agreement with Rector to so move, United States v. Snow, 234 F.3d 187, 190 (4th Cir.2000), and there is no indication that it refused to make the motion for an unconstitutional motive. Wade v. United States, 504 U.S. 181, 185-86, 112 S.Ct. 1840, 118 L.Ed.2d 524 (1992).
misconduct_determination_term2: no indication that it refused to make the motion
misconduct_determination_sentence3: We have examined the entire record in this case in accordance with the requirements of Anders, and find no meritorious issues for appeal.

decision_court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
defendant: UNITED STATES ex rel. Sherman HOWARD, Petitioner,//George DeTELLA, 1 Respondent.
attorneys_judges: *861 Sherman Howard, Galesburg, IL, pro se.//Bradley P. Halloran, Paul James Chevlin , Illinois Attorney General's Office, Arleen C. Anderson, Attorney General's Office, Chicago, IL, for respondent.//CASTILLO, District Judge.
geography_entities: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
allegation_sentence_1: Howard says that he asked his appellate counsel to raise the following claims, laying the factual and legal basis for them out in detail: (1) the improper admission of confusing, prejudicial, and scientifically unsupported medical testimony regarding hymen regeneration by Dr. Blade–Schlessinger; (2) prosecutorial misconduct; and (3) improper evidentiary rulings by the trial court.
allegation_sentence_2: In it, he argues only that he was deprived of the effective assistance of counsel on his direct appeal, due to his appellate counsel's failure to raise the following arguments: (1) medical expert testimony not generally accepted in the field was improperly admitted; (2) there was an accumulation of prosecutorial misconduct and error involving references to prior criminal conduct and “kidnapping” by Howard;
allegation_term_2: accumulation of prosecutorial misconduct and error
allegation_sentence_3: Many of these instances involved suggestions by the prosecution that Howard was charged with a crime in 1983 related to his alleged abuse of Tamika, and that, as a result of a DCFS investigation that same year, Howard was denied visitation with Tamika.
allegation_term_3: suggestions by the prosecution that Howard was charged with a crime in 1983
misconduct_determination_sentence1: That factor—the weight of the evidence against Howard—leads us to conclude that Howard's right to a fair trial was not unfairly prejudiced by the prosecution's improper remarks.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Accordingly, Howard has failed to demonstrate that his appellate counsel's deficiencies in not raising the issue of prosecutorial misconduct met the prejudice prong of Strickland v. Washington, i.e., that without those deficiencies he would be entitled to the reversal of his conviction or a new trial.
misconduct_determination_term2: Howard has failed to demonstrate that his appellate counsel's deficiencies
misconduct_determination_sentence3: For all of the foregoing reasons, the Court finds that Howard was not denied a fair trial by the ineffective performance of his appellate counsel, and denies Howard's petition for a writ of habeas corpus.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
attorneys_judges: George S. Leone, Esq., Steven G. Sanders, Esq., Office of United States Attorney, Newark, NJ, for United States of America.//Michael Guibilo, Ayer, MA, pro se.//Before: BARRY, SMITH, Circuit Judges and RESTANI, Judge.//SMITH, Circuit Judge.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey
allegation_sentence_1: On appeal, Guibilo alleges seven errors: 1) the Government, in violation of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194, 10 L.Ed.2d 215 (1963), did not produce a copy of a manuscript that he authored; 2) the District Court erred in preventing him from introducing evidence of specific details of his successful work with the FBI; 3) the Government committed misconduct by permitting perjury, manufacturing evidence, and covering up evidence of this alleged prosecutorial misconduct; 4) the District Court committed misconduct by aiding the cover-up of the alleged prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2: Guibilo claims that the Government was complicit in the perjury of Government witnesses, manufactured evidence that Guibilo owed his doctor substantial sums of money, and covered up these transgressions. We have found no evidence on the record that supports any of these contentions.
allegation_term_2: claims that the Government was complicit in the perjury of Government witnesses
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The Court of Appeals, Smith, Circuit Judge, held that: [1] government's belated disclosure of evidence did not violate Brady; [2] specific details of defendant's work with FBI were not admissible; [3] defendant was not entitled to a new trial based on newly discovered evidence; and [4] evidence was sufficient to support robbery convictions.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: For the reasons that follow, we believe that none of Guibilo's claims has merit, and we will affirm the District Court's judgments. 2
misconduct_determination_term2: none of Guibilo's claims has merit
misconduct_determination_sentence3: First, the Government's failure to disclose evidence of Guibilo's manuscript did not violate its obligations under Brady because the manuscript was not material to Guibilo's guilt or punishment.
misconduct_determination_term3: did not violate its obligations under Brady
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Fourth, since we see no evidence of prosecutorial misconduct, we reject Guibilo's claim that the District Court helped cover up any prosecutorial misconduct.

decision_court: U.S. Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces.
defendant: Andrew P. HALPIN, Airman Basic, U.S. Air Force, Appellant.
attorneys_judges: *477 STUCKY, J., delivered the opinion of the Court, in which BAKER, C.J., and RYAN, J., joined. ERDMANN, J., filed a dissenting opinion, in which EFFRON, S.J., joined. For Appellant: Captain Luke D. Wilson (argued).//For Appellee: Captain Brian C. Mason (argued); Colonel Don M. Christensen, Lieutenant Colonel C. Taylor Smith, and Gerald R. Bruce (on brief).//Judge STUCKY delivered the opinion of the Court.
geography_entities: Davis–Monthan Air Force Base, Arizona
allegation_sentence_1: Appellant raised the same issues concerning trial counsel's sentencing arguments before the CCA that he raises now.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We hold that Appellant has not met his burden of showing that he was prejudiced by trial counsel's arguments.
misconduct_determination_term1: as not met his burden of showing that he was prejudiced
misconduct_determination_sentence2: As Appellant did not object to the sentencing arguments at trial, the CCA reviewed for plain error and found that trial counsel's sentencing arguments were not improper, and thus no prosecutorial misconduct, error by the military judge, or ineffective assistance occurred.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: As Appellant was not prejudiced by the sentencing arguments, he cannot have been prejudiced by the military judge's failure to interrupt the arguments or issue a curative instruction, or the failure of his trial defense counsel to object to the arguments.

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
defendant: Rolando STOCKTON, Defendant-Appellant. United States of America, Plaintiff-Appellant,//Rolando Stockton, Defendant-Appellee.
attorneys_judges: *757 ARGUED:G. Godwin Oyewole, Washington, D.C., for Appellant. James G. Warwick, Assistant United States Attorney, Baltimore, MD, for Appellee. ON BRIEF: Thomas M. DiBiagio, United States Attorney, Andrea L. Smith, Assistant United States Attorney, Baltimore, MD, for Appellee.//Before WILLIAMS, TRAXLER, and KING, Circuit Judges
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the District of Maryland
case_outcome: Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded with instructions.
allegation_sentence_1: Stockton argues that the evidence presented at trial was insufficient to support the jury's guilty verdict on each of the counts of conviction, that the district court committed plain error in failing to give the jury a “multiple conspiracies” instruction, and that prosecutorial misconduct during the trial effectively denied him *758 his right to a fair trial.
allegation_term_1: denied him *758 his right to a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_2: The remaining issue Stockton raises on appeal is whether the incidents of alleged prosecutorial misconduct had the effect of denying Stockton his right to a fair trial.
allegation_term_2: whether the incidents of alleged prosecutorial misconduct had the effect of denying Stockton his right to a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: prosecutor's reference during summation to defendant's failure to call a particular individual as a defense witness was a permissible attempt to call attention to inconsistencies between individual's testimony as a prosecution witness and defendant's testimony; (5) prosecution's improper question to defendant on cross-examination did not warrant reversal
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Because the Tasha Gray comment was not improper, the only incident of prosecutorial misconduct was the Government's improper question to Stockton on crossexamination.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Applying these factors to the present case, it is clear that Stockton has not demonstrated reversible prejudice.

decision_court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
defendant: Arnold DiGREGORIO and Gregory Segnit, Defendants.
attorneys_judges: *631 Otto G. Obermaier, U.S. Atty., S.D.N.Y., New York City, for U.S.; Steven M. Cohen, Asst. U.S. Atty., of counsel.//George L. Santangelo, New York City, for defendant Arnold DiGregorio.//Edward S. Panzer, New York City, for defendant Gregory Segnit.
geography_entities: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
allegation_sentence_1: Defendants moved to dismiss indictment with prejudice.
allegation_sentence_2: Finally, they maintain that the Indictment should be dismissed on the grounds of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_term_2: should be dismissed on the grounds of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The District Court, Sweet, J., held that: (1) failure to timely present defendants before magistrate following their arrest did not warrant dismissal of indictment; (2) government conduct was not so outrageous as to violate defendants' due process rights; and (3) fact issue existed as to whether violation of Speedy Trial Act or prosecutorial misconduct warranted dismissal of indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: As discussed below, the facts as described by the Defendants do not support dismissal of the Indictment on the first two asserted grounds. However, because these facts, if true, may support dismissal of the *634 Indictment against the Defendants for violation of the Speedy Trial Act and for prosecutorial misconduct, an evidentiary hearing shall be held as to facts relevant to these claims within thirty days of the filing of this opinion.

txt_file: U.S. v. Tam Minh Nguyen, 234 Fed.Appx. 470 (2007).txt
decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *471 David Reese Jennings, Esq., Office of the U.S. Attorney, Tacoma, WA, Mark N. Bartlett, Esq., Office of the U.S. Attorney, Seattle, WA, for Plaintiff-Appellee.//Michael G. Martin, Esq., Siderius Lonergan & Martin, LLP, Seattle, WA, for Defendant-Appellant.//Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, Ricardo S. Martinez, District Judge, Presiding. D.C. No. CR-04-00468-02-RSM.//Before: BRUNETTI, McKEOWN, and W. FLETCHER, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington
allegation_sentence_1: He appeals his conviction and sentence.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Holdings: The Court of Appeals held that: [1] district court appropriately sustained government's objection during closing argument; [2] any error in sustaining closing argument was harmless; [3] there was neither prosecutorial misconduct nor any infringement of defendant's right to confront witnesses when government allegedly failed to “perfect” its impeachment of defendant's wife;
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Second, there was neither prosecutorial misconduct nor any infringement of Nguyen's right to confront witnesses when the government allegedly failed to “perfect” its impeachment of Nguyen's wife, Hoang Kim Vo. Contrary to Nguyen's contention, after properly using transcripts of Vo's prior inconsistent statements during its cross-examination, the government had no duty under United States v. Hibler, 463 F.2d 455, 461 (9th Cir.1972), to offer the *472 transcripts in evidence.
misconduct_determination_term2: neither prosecutorial misconduct nor any infringement of Nguyen's right

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *340 T. Roger Duncan, Hollywood, Cal., for appellant.//Robert L. Meyer, U. S. Atty., David R. Nissen, Chief, Crim. Div., Andrew R. Willing, Asst. U. S. Atty., Los Angeles, Cal., for appellee.//Before ELY, HUFSTEDLER, and WRIGHT, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Central District of California
allegation_sentence_1: Boke appeals from his conviction for heroin offenses, 21 U.S.C. § 174, 26 U.S.C. § 4705(a).
misconduct_determination_sentence1: there was no error in refusing to instruct the jury that smuggling merchandise, 18 U.S.C. § 545, is a lesser offense included within the offense charged (Palmero v. United States (1st Cir. 1940) 112 F.2d 922); (3) there was no error in refusing to permit Boke to plead to a lesser offense when the Government refused to consent (United States v. Gray (9th Cir. 1971) 438 F.2d 1160; and (4) the record does not support the claim that Boke was prejudiced by prosecutorial misconduct.

allegation_sentence_1: The court will address at length, however, defendant Wilbourn's argument that the government committed prosecutorial misconduct with respect to false testimony by cooperating witness Senecca Williams.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The court therefore finds that Cannon's statements during the government's rebuttal argument, during which she attempted not only to use but also to bolster Williams's false testimony, constituted prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Defendants were thus unfairly prejudiced with respect to any charges on which there was a reasonable probability that the jury would have acquitted had it discounted Williams's overall credibility.
misconduct_determination_term3:
did not prejudicially affect
Wesley's substantial rights

decision_court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
attorneys_judges: Michael Wesley, Pollock, LA, pro se.//Thomas J. Mehan, Office of U.S. Attorney, St. Louis, MO, for Respondent.//
geography_entities: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
allegation_sentence_1: As grounds for his § 2255 motion, Wesley raises one claim of ineffective assistance of counsel and one claim of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Wesley raises two grounds for relief in his § 2255 motion:
1. He received ineffective assistance of counsel for failing
to make a motion to strike the firearm from evidence.
2. The government committed prosecutorial misconduct
by submitting the firearm into evidence with knowledge
that it was not used by petitioner in the charged offenses.
allegation_term_2: submitting the firearm into evidence with knowledge
allegation_sentence_3:
In Ground 2, Wesley argues that the government committed
prosecutorial misconduct by seeking to admit the automatic
pistol into evidence, having knowledge that the gun was
not used in the Missouri robberies. He alleges that he did
not purchase the gun until after the Missouri robberies
were committed.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Here, as discussed
in more detail below, I find that Wesley's claims are either
inadequate or affirmatively refuted by the records and files
before me, and I conclude that no evidentiary hearing is
required.
misconduct_determination_term1:
claims are either
inadequate or affirmatively refuted
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In this case, Wesley has not established that the government's
conduct was improper.
misconduct_determination_term2: not established that the government's conduct was improper
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Furthermore, admission of the gun did not prejudicially affect
Wesley's substantial rights so as to deprive him of a fair
trial. As discussed in detail above, the evidence presented of
Wesley's guilt was overwhelming, even without admission of
the firearm. Therefore, Wesley was not unfairly prejudiced by
the government's actions at trial, and relief is not warranted
on this ground.

U.S. Atty., Los Angeles, CA, for U.S. (original briefs).//Terree A. Bowers, U.S. Atty., Robert L. Brosio, Chief of the Crim. Div., Miriam A. Krinsky, Chief of Crim. Appeals, Jeffrey S. Sinek, Asst. geography_entities:
the United States District
Court for the Central District of California
allegation_sentence_1:
Kojayan's
lawyer, in his opening brief, raised the issue of prosecutorial
misconduct, quoting extensively from the relevant portion
of the transcript.
allegation_term_1:
raised the issue of prosecutorial
misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court of
Appeals, Kozinski, Circuit Judge, held that prosecutor's
statements indicating that reason witness did not testify was
because he had invoked privilege against self-incrimination,
when government had cooperation agreement with witness
pursuant to which witness agreed to testify truthfully,
constituted prosecutorial misconduct of prejudicial nature
which violated due process and required reversal of
convictions.
misconduct_determination_term1: constituted prosecutorial misconduct of prejudicial nature
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The prosecutorial misconduct in this case deprived the
defendants of due process of law.
misconduct_determination_term2:
deprived the
defendants of due process
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
It contaminated their trial,
and we *1325 cannot say it was harmless.
notes:
Good quote: The overwhelming majority of prosecutors
are decent, ethical, honorable lawyers who understand the
awesome power they wield, and the responsibility that goes with it. But the temptation is always there: It's the easiest thing
in the world for people trained in the adversarial ethic to think
a prosecutor's job is simply to win.

decision_court:
United States District Court,
M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
attorneys_judges:
James B. Perrine, Louis V. Franklin, Sr., U.S. Stephen P.
Feaga, U.S. Attorney‘s Office, Joseph L. Fitzpatrick, Jr.,
Attorney General's Office, Public Corruption & White Collar
Alabama State House, Montgomery, AL, Richard C. Pilger,
Department of Justice, Criminal Division, Public Integrity
Section, Washington, DC, for United States of America.//COODY, Chief Magistrate J.
geography_entities:
United States District Court,
M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant Scrushy seeks dismissal of the indictment
against him because of alleged prosecutorial misconduct
and undue delay in unsealing the May 2005 indictment
returned against him.
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant Scrushy raises separately his prosecutorial
misconduct and due process delay in unsealing the
indictment claims.
allegation_sentence_3:
Scrushy vigorously
argues that the unsealing delay was an aspect of the
misconduct by prosecutors leading to prejudice against the
defendant.
allegation_sentence_4:
Scrushy contends that the government's intentional
misleading of his counsel between May and October 2005
about whether a charging decision had been made caused
his lawyers during repeated conversations with government
lawyers to disclose facts about the charges contained in
the sealed indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Two reasons supported the motion to seal, and
there is no evidence that at the time of the acquittal the
government's investigation was not continuing. Indeed, what
authority the court has found is contrary to Scrushy's position.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Scrushy's burden of proof on his prosecutorial
misconduct claim is a heavy one, and he has not sustained
it. He fails to show that the primary purpose of the continued
grand jury sessions was to prepare trial against him.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
While the government's response to Scrushy's
lawyer's charging decision question is reproachable, the
defendant has not demonstrated that he suffered any trial prejudice which approaches the level necessary to warrant
the remedial action of dismissal.

S.D. New York.

geography_entities:
United States District Court,
S.D. New York.
allegation_sentence_1:
Petitioner Luvenia Bartee (“Petitioner”), proceeding pro
se, brings the instant petition for habeas corpus pursuant to
28 U .S.C. § 2255 (“Section 2255”), asking the court to
vacate, set aside, or correct her sentence on the following
grounds: (1) ineffective assistance of counsel; (2) violation of
the Sixth Amendment; (3) error in calculating the sentencing
range; (4) improper dismissal of jurors; and (5) prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Lastly, Petitioner asserts that the government engaged in
prosecutorial misconduct by offering into evidence checks
written to Ebony Worthy and Tracey Rodriguez that the
government knew were forged by a co-defendant using
Petitioner's signature but nonetheless “led the jury to believe
that the checks were in fact written by [Petitioner].”
allegation_term_2:
the government engaged in
prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The government made no factually inaccurate statements
to the jury. Therefore, Petitioner's claim for prosecutorial
misconduct must be denied.

United States District Court,
S.D. Texas,
Houston Division.
attorneys_judges:
Samuel Louis, Financial Litigation, US Attorney's Office
Southern District of Texas, US Pretrial Services, US
Probation, US Marshal, Houston, TX, for Plaintiff–
Respondent.
geography_entities:
United States District Court,
S.D. Texas,
Houston Division.
allegation_sentence_1:
Whether outrageous and material prosecutorial
misconduct by the Government violated Dr. Mauskar's
right to Due Process by the Government's selective
prosecution, wrongful withholding of exculpatory and
mitigating evidence, in violation of Brady; and engaging
in numerous additional instances of illegal and unethical
behavior.
allegation_sentence_2:
In his next claim, Mauskar contends, again in conclusory
fashion, that the Government engaged in misconduct by: (1)
suborning perjury; (2) selectively prosecuting him; and (3)
failing to disclose favorable evidence in violation of Brady v.
Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194, 10 L.Ed.2d 215 (1963).
allegation_sentence_3:
In his next claim of prosecutorial misconduct, Mauskar
maintains that the Government offered perjured testimony
on two issues: (1) whether arthritis can be “cured”; and
(2) whether Houston is an medically under-served area.
allegation_sentence_4:
In the third aspect of his prosecutorial misconduct claim,
Mauskar maintains that he was prosecuted, while others with
the same, or greater, culpability, including Dr. Greenhaw,
were not.
allegation_term_4:
maintains that he was prosecuted, while others with
the same, or greater, culpability, including Dr. Greenhaw,
were not.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
As for the remaining claims of prosecutorial misconduct,
and factual and legal innocence, Mauskar wholly fails to
mention or acknowledge that such claims were addressed and
rejected by the Fifth Circuit on appeal.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Mauskar's
prosecutorial misconduct claim, which is premised on these
allegations of perjury, is therefore procedurally barred from
review. Even if it were not, Mauskar is not entitled to any
relief on the merits of the claim.
misconduct_determination_term2:
This allegation of prosecutorial misconduct is
therefore both procedurally barred, and subject to dismissal
on the merits.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: procedurally barred

allegation_sentence_1:
Williams argues that we must reverse his civil rights
conviction because of two evidentiary errors and alleged
prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_term_1:
we must reverse his civil rights
conviction
allegation_sentence_2:
Williams argues that, for two reasons, these answers were
impermissible opinion testimony. First, he contends that
the officers' testimony violated rule 704(b), which prohibits
experts from testifying that a criminal defendant “did or did
not have the mental state or condition constituting an element. of the crime.” FED.R.EVID. 704(b). Although the officers
did not testify as experts, Williams argues that their opinion
testimony about the reasonableness of the shooting should
be treated as expert testimony because it was “based on ...
specialized knowledge within the scope of [FED.R.EVID.]
702.” FED.R.EVID. 701. Second, Williams contends that the
officers' testimony violated rule 704(a), which prohibits any
witness, expert or lay, from testifying to a legal conclusion.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
prosecutor's improper remarks, forcing
deputy to call other witnesses liars, did not affect deputy's
substantial rights; and (7) prosecutor did not violate deputy's
due process rights in stating that prosecution witness would
be sentenced to at least five months' imprisonment under plea
agreement.
misconduct_determination_term1:
did not affect deputy's
substantial rights
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Third, “the evidence of guilt was overwhelming.”
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The questioning, though inappropriate, is not
reversible error.

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant
further asserts that he is entitled to a new trial under Rule 33
because (1) again, insufficiency of the evidence, (2) improper
jury instructions, and (3) prosecutorial misconduct after
jury selection.
allegation_sentence_2:
Finally, the defendant asserts that he is entitled to a new
trial under Rule 33 because of prosecutorial misconduct
in that Deputy U.S. Marshals, in full presence of the jury,
served defendant with a civil complaint in the courtroom.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The government responds that the defendant has raised no
new issues that have not already been properly addressed by
the Court and thus the Motion should be denied. Further,
the government argues that the defendant's motion and brief
were untimely and warrant dismissal.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Here, even assuming the action of the Deputy

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Sixth Circuit.
attorneys_judges:
Before BOGGS and GUY, Circuit Judges; and EDMUNDS,
District Judge. *
geography_entities:
On Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Western District of Tennessee.
allegation_sentence_1:
White now appeals the
district court's judgment, arguing that the court erred in
denying his motion for acquittal and alternatively that he
is entitled to a reversal of his conviction and a new trial
on the basis of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
White contends that he is entitled to a new trial because
of prosecutorial misconduct. In particular, White points
to references made by the prosecutor to Keith White, the
defendant's son, during his examination of Customs Agent
Crum, and remarks made during the closing argument of the case in which the prosecutor vouched for the
government's witnesses and expressed his personal opinion as
to *617 Keith's veracity.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
In
addition, although there was prosecutorial misconduct in
this case, the defense counsel failed to object in a timely
manner and the misconduct was not sufficiently flagrant to
render White's trial fundamentally unfair.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Although we ultimately agree that
the prosecutor's statements during closing arguments were
improper and even inexcusable, we hold that the prosecutor's
behavior did not amount to reversible error.
misconduct_determination_term2: did not amount to reversible error
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In this case, although the prosecutor's
questioning of Agent Crum was correctly curbed by the trial
court as irrelevant, it did not cross the line into prosecutorial
misconduct since the prosecutor did not express his own
personal opinion.
misconduct_determination_term3:
did not cross the line into prosecutorial
misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
In sum, the relevant factors do not provide
strong support for White's *619 claim that the prosecutorial
misconduct in this case was flagrant, and when combined
with the fact that White bears the burden of demonstrating
that the remarks had an effect on the jury's verdict in this
case, it is apparent that a reversal of White's conviction is
not warranted.
misconduct_determination_term4:
do not provide
strong support for White's *619 claim

allegation_sentence_1:
Mahan claims three instances of prosecutorial
misconduct: The prosecution allegedly (a) failed to disclose
that police officers had promised a reduced sentence to
accomplice Wayne Pennington in exchange for his testimony
against Mahan and had threatened to arrest members of
Pennington's family if he did not so testify; (b) knowingly
presented false testimony by permitting Pennington to testify
that no such bargain had been struck; and (c) failed to disclose
that Pennington had denied his involvement in the bank
robbery before confessing. Mahan raised only the first of
these claims in his section 2255 petition
allegation_term_1:
claims three instances of prosecutorial
misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Even if the prosecution withheld
evidence relating to Pennington's motives for testifying, a
review of the record indicates that the second of these
requirements is not satisfied, because the evidence alleged to
have been suppressed was in fact the subject of testimony
before the jury.
misconduct_determination_term1:
he second of these
requirements is not satisfied

Lastly, the defendant

Brady material, while arguing facts not in evidence which

prosecutorial misconduct which deprived defendant of due

allegation_sentence_2:
the
government's failure to disclose the evidence coupled with

and was contrary to the undisclosed materials, constituted
prosecutorial misconduct entitling defendant to a new trial.
allegation_term_2: entitling defendant to a new trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
The defendant also argues, based on the McQuiston notes,
that the government committed prosecutorial misconduct
which deprived defendant of his Fifth Amendment right to
due process by arguing facts about Deborah McQuiston in
its closing which were not in evidence and which were
contradicted by the non-disclosed McQuiston interview notes
in the government's constructive possession.
allegation_term_3:
defendant of his Fifth Amendment right to
due process
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
(3) no
Brady violation resulted from failure to disclose prior to trial
special agent's notes of interview with defendant's former
part-time bookkeeper; and (4) failure to disclose the special
agent's notes of interview with defendant's former part-time
bookkeeper together with the reference in the closing to facts
contrary to the interview notes did not unfairly prejudice
defendant.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Moreover, the court holds that defendant
has not demonstrated a Brady violation and to the extent that
prosecutorial misconduct occurred in this case, it does not
warrant a new trial. Thus, defendant's motions will be denied.
misconduct_determination_term2:
it does not
warrant a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
For the following reasons, the court finds that both arguments
lack merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Furthermore, the court finds that there is no reasonable
probability that government counsel's overreaching
comments during its closing argument changed the outcome
of these proceedings.
misconduct_determination_term4:
no reasonable
probability that government counsel's overreaching
comments during its closing argument changed the outcome
of these proceedings.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Thus, while the
government's failure to disclose the notes prior to trial
combined with the limited reference in the closing argument
was not proper, that conduct of government's counsel can
not be described as intentional or constituting bad faith.
misconduct_determination_term5: can not be described as intentional or constituting bad faith.

allegation_sentence_1:
Stone challenges the district court's decision to permit
questioning of Anthony Corley on two grounds, arguing that:
(1) the government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct by
attempting to bolster its case through the prejudicial impact
of Corley's repeated invocation of the Fifth Amendment and
(2) his Sixth Amendment right to confront the witnesses
assembled against him was violated by Corley's Fifth
Amendment assertion.
allegation_term_1: the government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct
allegation_sentence_2:
Second, he claims the
government attorney committed prosecutorial misconduct
in exceeding the scope of the recall.
misconduct_determination_term1: district court acted within its discretion
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Given these circumstances, any claim by Stone that
the government's actions produced an error that was obvious
and clear is unavailing.
misconduct_determination_term2:
any claim by Stone that
the government's actions produced an error that was obvious
and clear is unavailing.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
As the
trial court acknowledged, the government exceeded the
boundaries of the recall, venturing into a revelation of Stone's
claimed occupation. Given the court's clear explanation
of the purposes for Agent's Riddle's recall testimony, this
was misconduct. Considered in the context of the entire
proceeding, however, Agent Riddle's statement was not so
prejudicial as to deprive Stone of a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term3:
not so
prejudicial as to deprive Stone of a fair trial.

allegation_sentence_1:
This cause is now before this Court on defendants' separate
motions to dismiss the indictment on two grounds:
(1) That they cannot receive a fair trial because of prosecution
inspired, false, and inflammatory publicity which imputed
either nine deaths or 50 deaths to the defendants, which the
prosecutors knew were not a factor in the trial of the case.
(2) That they are entitled to have the indictment dismissed
because of prosecutorial misconduct before the grand jury
allegation_sentence_2:
In a separate motion to dismiss the defendants move to have
the indictment dismissed on the grounds of prosecutorial
misconduct before the grand jury. Defendants claim that
even though the government admits that deaths are in no way
involved in this case, the prosecutors repeatedly flaunted the
stories of deaths before the grand jury; and that this was done
in such a manner as to inflame unduly the members of the
grand jury, and thereby created such bias in the grand jury that
the indictment is inherently suspect and should be dismissed
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
"since prejudicial pretrial publicity, involving deaths allegedly
attributable to the misbranded drugs, was disseminated to
the press by government prosecutor, the Department of
Justice, and the Food and Drug Administration, and since the
defendants could not be adequately protected by the voir dire,
a continuance, or a change of venue, the only appropriate
remedy, albeit extreme, was dismissal of the indictment, "
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
to raise the specter of homicide before the grand jury in
an effort to obtain an indictment under an act which requires
no mens rea is unconscionable conduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
This Court finds as a fact that bias and prejudice were
created when Mr. Epstein repeatedly referred to deaths from
Abbott I.V. solutions.

allegation_sentence_1:
First, appellants allege that the prosecutor
impermissibly vouched for the credibility of Gelber, the
government's main witness. Primarily, appellants' challenge
the prosecutor's attempts to elicit testimony from Gelber
regarding the truth telling provisions in his plea agreement.
allegation_sentence_2:
Second, appellants contend that the prosecutor made
disparaging remarks about the defense attorneys and other
improper remarks.
allegation_sentence_3:
Appellants contend that reversible error occurred when
the district court precluded them from introducing a witness to
expose Gelber's self-interest, bias, or motive to testify falsely.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
prosecutor
did not engage in misconduct in closing argument; and (6)
court properly excluded evidence of specific bad act proffered
to impeach prosecution witness.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Consequently,
we find that no prosecutorial misconduct occurred with
respect to impermissible vouching.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
While
we do not condone the prosecutor's remarks, we cannot find
that they constitute grounds for reversal.
misconduct_determination_term3:
cannot find
that they constitute grounds for reversal.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We find this contention meritless as the prosecutor properly
commented on the evidence presented to the jury when
he described the close association that appellants shared
with others involved in the kickback scheme prior to and
during their criminal activities.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The district court did not abuse its discretion in excluding
this proposed testimony.

allegation_sentence_1:
Finally, Gibson claims that his right to due process was
violated by the prosecutor's conduct during the trial.
allegation_term_1:
right to due process was
violated
allegation_sentence_2:
Gibson argues that this assertion misstated the
evidence to such a degree that he was denied a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
prosecutorial misconduct
which occurred when evidence was misstated was harmless
error
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Having gone this far to reach the merits of the claim,
however, the court now concludes that Gibson's right to
due process was not violated by the prosecutor's conduct.
misconduct_determination_term2: not violated by the prosecutor's conduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Here, the prosecutor's remark did misstate the evidence, at
least in some respects. George Shaw did testify that Gibson
told him that the Illinois police had the gun as well as some
other evidence of the crime. He did not, however, testify that
Gibson told him that he felt the police “had him.” Nor did
Shaw testify that Gibson told him that he was considering
“copping” a plea. Yet, in the context of the entire trial,
the court cannot conclude that the remark rendered the trial
fundamentally unfair.
misconduct_determination_term3:
cannot conclude that the remark rendered the trial
fundamentally unfair.

geography_entities:
United States District Court,
D. South Dakota,
Western Division.
allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant, Richard Harris Bear Runner, moves for a
mistrial and a new trial based on alleged prosecutorial
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Bear Runner claims he was denied a fair trial
because the prosecutor engaged in improper vouching and
burden shifting during examination of a witness and in
rebuttal closing argumen
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The government resists
this motion and argues that the prosecutor's actions were not
improper, but even if they were, Bear Runner cannot establish
that he was prejudiced when the cumulative effect of the
prosecutor's conduct was minimal, the government offered
substantial evidence of Bear Runner's guilt, and the court's
instructions were curative of any prejudice.
misconduct_determination_term1:
cannot establish
that he was prejudiced
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
While “[a]n improper question by government
counsel may constitute prosecutorial misconduct[,]” the
court finds that neither incident described above rises to
the level of improper prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2:
neither incident described above rises to
the level of improper prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
While it
was incorrect for the prosecutor to attempt to have one witness
address the credibility of another witness, this does not rise to
the level of prosecutorial misconduct. And as the court will
discuss in greater detail below, even if these comments were
improper, they were not prejudicial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The court has now found that two of the remarks were
improper in a prosecutorial misconduct analysis. The
improper comments were made during the most critical
and potentially damaging phase of the trial, during the
prosecutor's rebuttal argument when Bear Runner had no
chance to respond.
misconduct_determination_term4:
two of the remarks were
improper
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
After viewing all the trial evidence and the entirety
of the closing arguments, the court finds the cumulative effect
of the remaining improper comments was slight.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
While the government did engage in improper conduct
during closing arguments, the prosecutor's misconduct did
not affect Bear Runner's substantial rights or prejudice his
case in front of the jury.
misconduct_determination_term6:
prosecutor's misconduct did
not affect Bear Runner's substantial rights

allegation_sentence_1:
Because
Rockman alleged that the prosecution's misconduct deprived
him of a fair trial in violation of his due process rights,
the Illinois Appellate Court appropriately reviewed this
question on appeal.
allegation_term_1:
deprived
him of a fair trial
allegation_sentence_2:
Rockman characterizes the prosecution's statement that
“we know that [Medrano] could see from the vantage point
under the pool table” as improper.
allegation_sentence_3:
Rockman argues that the
prosecution misled the jury into believing that the evidence
conclusively established Medrano's ability to see Rockman
during the shooting.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Thus, we examine the substance of the prosecutor's remarks.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Because nothing in
the record suggests that the prosecutor's statement in any way
focused on Rockman's failure to testify, the prosecutor could
comment upon Medrano's testimony and Rockman's claim of
prosecutorial misconduct is without merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The prosecution's reference to the victim “in his grave
crying out for [a guilty verdict]” is more problematic.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
This
reference to the victim arguably inflamed the emotions of the
jurors and, therefore, was improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Viewing the record as a whole, however, this
Court does not find that the prosecutor's statement deprived
Rockman of a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term5: does not find that the prosecutor's statement deprived
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Thus,
the prosecution's reference to the victim in closing argument,
even if it constituted error, did not so prejudice the trial as
to deprive Rockman of due process.
misconduct_determination_term6: did not so prejudice the trial

the cumulative effect of several errors and instances of

notes:
Court points to similar cases from the same US Attys office: United States v. Roberts, 618 F.2d 530 (9th Cir. 1980); United States v. Bemis, 620 F.2d 311 (9th Cir. 1980). Also in a footnote the court said: "We indicated at oral argument that we are prepared to cite errant prosecutors who persist in such misbehavior and we
shall not hesitate to impose sanctions. Continuing to issue admonitions serves little purpose if we affirm convictions in
criminal cases while tolerating prosecutors who lack judgment, common sense and knowledge of appropriate courtroom
conduct and permissible argument."

case_outcome:
The judgments of the District Court are affirmed, except as
to the judgments against Kaminski on count IX and against
Mount on counts IV and XII, which are reversed. As to
these counts, the indictment is dismissed with prejudice. The
sentences of all defendants remain intact.
allegation_sentence_1:
there were repeated instances
of prosecutorial misconduct which denied them a fair
trial
allegation_sentence_2:
B. Kaminski's next argument for reversal is that repeated
instances of prosecutorial misconduct denied him a fair
trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
Kaminski alleges several instances of misconduct on
the part of government counsel, Douglas A. Kelley.
allegation_sentence_4:
Kaminski points to several other alleged instances of
prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_5:
Mount's final arguments involve instances of claimed
prosecutorial misconduct and the trial court's failure to grant
his motions for severance.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
But of course there is a point at which prosecutorial
misconduct, whether inadvertent or intentional, will have a
sufficient impact to require reversal.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The one
we find most troubling involves Kelley's cross-examination
of defense witness Lloyd Kadish. Kadish, an attorney, represented FGS during the summer of 1979 when it was
being investigated by the Minnesota Securities Commission.
Kadish was called to the stand as a witness for Douglas Payne.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
There is no question
that this was a completely improper form of impeachment.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
The improper impeachment of Kadish
was not crucial in any sense. And if the objectionable question
was prejudicial, the instruction to the jury to disregard it
sufficiently cured the error.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The incidents do not rise to the level of
reversible error when viewed in light of the strength of the
government's case, the length of the trial, and the trial court's
timely corrective actions.
misconduct_determination_term5: do not rise to the level of reversible error

allegation_sentence_1:
He further complains
of prosecutorial misconduct in the cross-examination of
Triplett and in summation.
allegation_sentence_2:
He further complains
that the prosecution repeated the accusation in summation,
referenced Triplett's assertion of her Fifth Amendment rights,
and made “factually untrue” statements.
allegation_sentence_3:
Dixon faults the prosecution for accusing Triplett on
cross-examination of being a liar.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
While the prosecution's repeated use of the words “lie”
and “liar” in cross-examining Triplett was sometimes
argumentative, it was not inflammatory given Triplett's
admission to numerous lies and material omissions in a case in which her credibility was a significant issue.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
That argument was not so inflammatory that it denied
defendant a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Insofar as Dixon faults the prosecution for referencing
Triplett's invocation of the Fifth Amendment, the record
defeats the argument, showing that the government
referenced only the fact that the it had granted Triplett
immunity and that she submitted to a polygraph.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
This
was not improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
In any event, even if the
prosecution had referenced Triplett's assertion of her Fifth
Amendment rights, that would not have prejudiced Dixon in
this case.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
In light of the many facts cited by the government
during summation that undermined Triplett's credibility,
including her lack of access to Dixon's car and her postarrest
conversations with Dixon about the events surrounding
his arrest, the alleged misstatements would not have altered
the outcome of Dixon's trial.

allegation_sentence_1:
Bailey argues that the prosecutor, Jo Lawless, acted
improperly in five ways.
allegation_sentence_2:
First, Bailey argues that Lawless acted improperly
when she told the jury during her closing remarks that, on
the street, “Dope and marijuana are different things. Dope
is crack cocaine.”
allegation_sentence_3:
Bailey argues that the
prosecutor acted improperly in making this claim because,
in doing so, she presented prejudicial facts that were not
supported by the evidence introduced at trial.
allegation_sentence_4:
Bailey also argues that Lawless acted improperly when
she elicited testimony from Agent Hayes about Simmons's
help in the successful prosecution of ten other crack
cocaine offenses.
allegation_sentence_5:
Bailey next argues that Lawless acted improperly when,
in her cross-examination, she forced him either to accuse
other witnesses of lying or to undermine his own testimony.
allegation_sentence_6:
Finally, Bailey argues that the prosecutor acted improperly
when she asked him during cross-examination whether
his prior felony conviction was for “trafficking in
cocaine” (which it was) and then suggested to the jury in
her closing remarks that Bailey's prior cocaine conviction
demonstrated that the drug he sold to Simmons was cocaine
rather than—as he claimed—marijuana.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We agree that some of the statements
that he identifies appear to be questionable, if not downright
improper, under the law of this circuit.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We agree that some of the statements
that he identifies appear to be questionable, if not downright
improper, under the law of this circuit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We agree that some of the statements
that he identifies appear to be questionable, if not downright
improper, under the law of this circuit.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
However, we also
conclude that none is so flagrant as to constitute plain error.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Clearly, the comment was not proper, but
the impropriety does not appear to be sufficiently flagrant to
warrant reversal under plain-error review.
misconduct_determination_term5: does not appear to be sufficiently flagrant
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Clearly, the comment was not proper, but
the impropriety does not appear to be sufficiently flagrant to
warrant reversal under plain-error review.

allegation_sentence_1: Martinez argues that comments made by the prosecutor during closing arguments constituted prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Martinez asserts that the government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct when the prosecutor said: “I don’t think there’s
any question based on the evidence you’ve seen, I don’t think there’s any reasonable doubt whatsoever.... I think based on [the]
evidence, as long as you keep your eye on the ball and don’t let the defense lawyer distract you, which is his job.”
allegation_sentence_3:
Martinez
argues that this statement improperly injected the prosecutor’s personal opinion into the case and attacked defense counsel’s
character. We
allegation_sentence_4:
Martinez also asserts that it was improper for the prosecutor to say: “[I]f it wasn’t a law enforcement investigation, who
knows what might have happened. Thank God it was a law enforcement investigation this time and that there wasn’t an actual
victim.”
allegation_sentence_5: He argues that the prosecutor’s statement improperly inflamed the jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: We do not agree that this remark rises to the level of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We do not agree that this remark rises to the level of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In any event, any problem regarding this comment was cured by the
district court’s instruction to disregard the prosecutor’s statement.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: We reject this argument as well.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: The prosecutor’s comment fairly responded to that argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence6: The government’s conduct in this case was within constitutionally permitted limits.

allegation_sentence_1: The four appellants cite numerous examples of what they label as prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Several aspects of the government’s final argument are raised on appeal as constituting prosecutorial misconduct and requiring
a vacation of the convictions.
allegation_sentence_3:
Chad Robinson describes the “confirmed” statement as bolstering or vouching because earlier, over defense objection, the
government had established that Steffen had agreed “to cooperate and provide truthful testimony” in return for immunity.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: The AUSA admits error in that statement.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: In our view, use of the word “confirmed” does not constitute impermissible vouching.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Finally, we examine the question of whether all of the actions of AUSA Parker, when considered under the totality of the
circumstances, should require a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Thus, it is possible
that the prosecutor’s improper bolstering of the Patricks’ testimony made the difference between conviction and acquittal.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Appellant is entitled to a new trial untainted by improper prosecutorial
vouching.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
For purposes
of the Carter analysis, we find that AUSA Parker’s isolated factual misstatements were improper.

allegation_sentence_1:
The appellants argue that aside from the
testimony of Agent Stirling, the prosecution’s case was comprised mostly of misconduct which denied them a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Each of the appellants also contend that prosecutorial misconduct existed during the trial and that the cumulative effect of the
misconduct denied them a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_3:
Carter, one of the appellants, claimed that this was an improper
comment on his silence in violation of his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.
allegation_sentence_4:
the prosecutor discussed Agent
Mitchell’s testimony with Agent Glass before Agent Glass testified, in violation of the rule of exclusion of witnesses;
allegation_sentence_6: the prosecutor made comments in her closing argument which suggested that the *710 appellants’ courtroom behavior demonstrated a lack of respect for the court and the jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
After reviewing the comment in the context in which it was
made, we hold that the district court did not abuse its discretion in determining that the prosecutor’s comment was not
manifestly intended to comment on Carter’s right not to testify.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In this case, the prosecutor did not engage in conduct so pronounced and persistent that it permeated the entire atmosphere
of the trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Thus, we hold that although the prosecutor should not have made some comments, in the context
of the entire trial, and in the light of the district court’s curative instructions, the statements were of no consequence and
constituted harmless error.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We give considerable weight to the
district court’s assessment of the prejudicial effect of the prosecutor’s remarks and conduct.
