case_outcome:
The government’s motion to dismiss (DE 53) is GRANTED and
petitioner’s § 2255 motion (DE 45) is DENIED. A certificate of appealability is DENIED.
allegation_sentence_1:
the prosecution “knowingly allowed a detective to testify falsely before the grand jury regarding 85 grams of cocaine
base” and encouraged false testimony from Detective Rose Edmonds
allegation_sentence_2: the prosecution failed “to disclose evidence of Detective Edmonds[’s] prior background” of criminal misconduct
allegation_sentence_3: the prosecution “allowed an incomplete and misleading record to be presented regarding several important issues”
allegation_sentence_4:
With respect to petitioner’s claim that the government failed to comply with its obligations under Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S.
83 (1963), petitioner’s guilty plea again forecloses petitioner’s claim.
allegation_sentence_5:
For example, petitioner suggests that the prosecution failed to disclose “potential criminal activity”
by Edmonds as reported in a news article in 2013.
allegation_sentence_6:
Petitioner suggests that the prosecution failed to disclose to him that the drug weight attributed to him at sentencing was
flawed, where it was based on testimony or evidence produced by Edmonds.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The magistrate judge correctly determined that petitioner’s claims alleging prosecutorial misconduct prior to his guilty plea are
without merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In addition, petitioner has not alleged facts to establish a Brady violation or prosecutorial misconduct that would render his
plea fundamentally unfair.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In this manner, petitioner has not alleged exculpatory
evidence so extraordinary as to undermine the knowing and voluntary nature of his plea.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Accordingly, petitioner’s claim based upon prosecutorial misconduct prior to his plea must be denied.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Petitioner again, however, has failed to show
prejudice from any failure by the government to disclose misconduct of Edmonds.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Accordingly, in light of all the circumstances, petitioner has failed to allege prejudice resulting from the prosecution’s failure to
disclose allegedly exculpatory evidence at sentencing.

case_outcome: We will affirm the judgment of conviction, vacate the judgment of sentence, and remand for resentencing.
allegation_sentence_1:
First, he argues that his due process right to a fair trial was
violated because the prosecution informed the jury, through both evidence and argument, that his child pornography files
included deeply abhorrent videos and images of bestiality, bondage, and acts of violence against very young children.
allegation_sentence_2:
that the prosecutor’s closing argument crossed the line by inflaming the passions and emotions of the jury, see, e.g., Mills, 821
F.3d at 458, 460. We consider each allegation in turn.
allegation_sentence_3:
that it
“systematically inject[ed] inadmissible ... evidence” at trial,
allegation_sentence_4:
[15]Welshans argues that the prosecution inflamed the jury, invoking a visceral reaction, by referencing the despicable nature of
some of the child pornography recovered—abhorrent depictions of bestiality, bondage, and violence against very young
children.
allegation_sentence_5:
Specifically, during its closing argument, the prosecutor returned to Exhibit 2 and its detailed and graphic
descriptions of the files.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Regarding his first claim, we agree with Welshans on two points—that the challenged evidence was inadmissible under Rule
403 of the Federal Rules of Evidence and United States v. Cunningham, 694 F.3d 372, 391 (3d Cir. 2012), and that the
prosecutor’s closing argument improperly appealed to the passions of the jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
However, we conclude that the misconduct did
not so infect Welshans’s trial with unfairness as to violate due process.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: We agree with Welshans that the prosecution crossed the line.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: The misconduct in this case was indeed pervasive.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: Nevertheless, we conclude that the errors did not render his trial fundamentally unfair.
misconduct_determination_sentence6: Thus, we agree with Welshans that inadmissible evidence was repeatedly injected at his trial.

allegation_sentence_1:
the government committed prosecutorial misconduct and violated
his Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause rights,
allegation_sentence_2:
the government committed prosecutorial misconduct
and violated his due process rights by improperly bolstering the testimony of the government’s witnesses;
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendant next argues that the government improperly bolstered the testimony of the government’s witnesses by introducing
the plea agreements signed by the co-defendants who testified at Defendant’s trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We are inclined to agree with the government that Defendant opened the door to the prosecutor’s line of questioning, and we
have serious doubts that the prosecutor’s conduct was improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Defendant’s argument lacks merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Here, the prosecutor did not improperly vouch for Sanchez, Williams, or Cortez–Chavez.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Likewise, by questioning its witnesses regarding the terms of their plea agreements, the prosecution in the present case did not
improperly bolster the witnesses’ testimony.

misconduct_determination_sentence1: Plaintiff has not met its heavy burden of proof.

allegation_sentence_1:
VanDyck
argues that the government’s characterization of the child depicted in the photos as a “known victim” of child exploitation who
had been “rescued,” in combination with Agent Campbell’s use of the organizational name “National Center for Missing and
Exploited Children” despite a court ruling that he could only use the acronym, inflamed the jury and materially affected the
verdict.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
First, the government’s description of the photos
as involving a “known victim” of child exploitation who had been “rescued” did not seriously affect the fairness of the trial
because the government did not suggest that VanDyck herself participated in producing the photos or exploiting the child.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In light of the
government’s strong case against VanDyck, it was not “more probable than not” that the aggregate effect of the alleged
prosecutorial misconduct materially affected the jury’s verdict.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Accordingly, there was no plain error and the district court did not abuse its discretion in denying VanDyck a mistrial.

allegation_sentence_1:
We turn first to Maynard’s most serious claim of prosecutorial misconduct, that the *604 prosecutor asked questions of a
government witness in such a way as to intentionally and falsely create the impression before the jury that Maynard had caused
a murder.
allegation_sentence_2:
Maynard now contends that the prosecutor’s conduct, and the trial judge’s subsequent denial of his motion for a mistrial,
denied him a fair trial in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.
allegation_sentence_3:
Maynard also claims that he was denied due process because of prosecutorial misconduct in that the prosecutor developed
testimony falsely implying that Maynard had threatened a witness, based on the following exchange with government witness
Cheryl Rathbun:
allegation_sentence_4:
Maynard contends that the prosecutor developed this line of questioning although he knew there was no evidence such a threat
had been made by Maynard.
allegation_sentence_5:
Maynard next argues that the prosecutor developed testimony which falsely implied that another witness, Donna *608
Gatwood, was not registered under her own name in a motel because she felt threatened by Maynard.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Moreover, it is inescapably clear that the prosecutor knew what Patterson
would say in the testimony which he developed, namely the fact of the young man’s demise.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
From our examination of the record, we conclude that no reversible error is apparent in the actions taken by the judge with
respect to this matter.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
There is no showing in the record that the government intentionally sought to interject the statement about the “jail,” and the
event was not prominent in the trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
In sum, we conclude that the incidents complained of do not demonstrate reversible error, either singly or cumulatively. As
noted earlier, the incident about the young man’s being sent to California, Maynard’s statement that he wanted him dead, and
then a later question and answer showing that the young man was in fact dead, raise substantial concerns.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
There was no reversible error in the conduct
of the trial with respect to the serious prosecutorial misconduct we have considered.

allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant claims that the Assistant United States Attorney (“AUSA”) improperly presented hearsay evidence to the
grand jury and led the grand jury to believe that Defendant had threatened his daughter, Brooke Boettcher, a key witness
against Defendant. Defendant’s argument is based upon a series of comments made by the AUSA and a Special Agent with the
Drug Enforcement Administration (“DEA”) who testified before the grand jury.
allegation_sentence_2:
Defendant cites a comment made by the AUSA in response to a grand juror’s question as to why Brooke Boettcher would not
be testifying before the grand jury.
allegation_sentence_3:
Defendant argues that the AUSA and the DEA agent “created a false aura that Brooke had been threatened by her father” and
that “[t]he grand jury’s concern shifted from making an independent inquiry into [Defendant’s] involvement, to a concern for
the safety of Brooke.”
allegation_sentence_4:
Defendant also suggests that the use of hearsay evidence before the grand jury constituted or at least contributed to
prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
In the present case, the references by the AUSA and DEA agent to Brooke Boettcher’s fear of testifying do not seem to rise to
the level of misconduct present in Hogan.
misconduct_determination_term1: do not seem to rise to the level of misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In addition, the use of hearsay evidence in this case does not appear to be nearly as egregious as the use of such evidence in
Hogan, upon which Defendant relies.
misconduct_determination_term2: does not appear to be nearly as egregious
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In the present case, it appears clear that the AUSA did not attempt to deceive the grand jury as
to the quality of the hearsay testimony.

allegation_sentence_2:
As for his motion to reconsider based on Rule 33, Palivos argues that a Brady violation has occurred insofar as Nick Black had

allegation_sentence_3:
Palivos’ motion to vacate his conviction based on prosecutorial misconduct lists a series of four acts that he considers to be

persuaded the first time that any evidence has been suppressed in this case regarding criminal investigations into Black and, in

attorneys_judges:
Thomas J. Maroney, U.S. Atty., N.D.N.Y., Syracuse, NY (Craig A. Benedict, Asst. U.S. Atty., of counsel), for U.S.//
Bond Schoeneck & King; Syracuse, NY (George H. Lowe, of counsel), for George Jackson.
Honigman Miller, Schwartz & Cohn, Detroit, MI (Richard E. Zuckerman, of counsel), for Robert Gehl Tempotech Industries
and Gehl Productions.//NEAL P. McCURN, Senior District Judge.
allegation_sentence_1: The Gehl defendants vehemently contend that AUSA Benedict engaged in prosecutorial misconduct in several ways.
allegation_sentence_2:
First,
they assert that he improperly referred to the legislative history of 6 N.Y.C.R.R. § 37.1 (“the regulation”)—the regulation
which formed the basis for the Lacey Act counts of this prosecution—and that such references were “inflammatory and
prejudicial.”
allegation_sentence_3:
Second, the Gehl defendants contend that in his closing argument AUSA Benedict
improperly referred to the residents of New York as victims of contamination.
allegation_sentence_4:
Third, they argue that Benedict made a number
of improper comments in his closing argument, including several remarks about the defendants’ failure to testify or to call
witnesses, and the defendants believe this last comment in particular was intentional.
allegation_sentence_5:
Fourth, the defendants contend that
various other comments made by the prosecutor during the course of the trial are part of what they believe to be a “continuous
pattern of intentional misconduct” by the prosecutor such that the court has no choice but to grant this motion for a new trial.
allegation_sentence_6:
The defendants complain in several ways about the prosecutor’s references to the purpose underlying the promulgation of
section 37.1.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Here, even if the prosecutor in his closing statement did refer to the underlying purpose of section 37.1 (but, again, the court
does not read his statement that way), then such references were obviously not extensive; nor were they an integral part of the
prosecution’s strategy.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Moreover, as already explained, because there is more than sufficient
evidence to support these convictions, and because this claimed misconduct, if it occurred, is far from severe, the court cannot
find “substantial prejudice” such as would result in a denial of defendants’s due process rights.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Moreover, as already explained, because there is more than sufficient
evidence to support these convictions, and because this claimed misconduct, if it occurred, is far from severe, the court cannot
find “substantial prejudice” such as would result in a denial of defendants’s due process rights.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: For several reasons, the court finds that these remarks do not rise to the level of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Because of that, at least in
this Circuit, “the statement[s] will not be deemed ground for reversal unless it amounts to a ‘flagrant abuse [;]’ ”
12
and

obviously the prosecutor’s passing references, as just described, certainly do not amount to a “flagrant abuse.”
misconduct_determination_term5: do not amount to a “flagrant abuse.”
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
The most that can be said of the AUSA’s remarks in this case, particularly his
questioning during summation of the defendants’ decision not to call any witnesses, is that such remarks amounted to
prosecutorial overkill; but, as the case law makes clear, prosecutorial overkill is not equivalent to prosecutorial misconduct.

decision_court:
United States District Court,
W.D. Missouri,
Western Division.

allegation_sentence_1:
Eldridge complains about the conduct of the prosecutor, alleging “[m]isconduct by prosecutor in so much as she failed to
inform courts where or by which means Movant received mon[e]tary funds.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Eldridge’s prosecutorial misconduct claim is conclusory and does not allege facts that would excuse his failure to have raised
the issue at trial or on direct appeal.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Further, Eldridge’s claim lacks evidentiary support in the record, and he does not show
actual prejudice that resulted from the alleged error.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because Eldridge fails to explain why his prosecutorial misconduct
arguments could not have been raised at trial or on appeal, or how he was prejudiced, he cannot properly raise this claim in a
section 2255 motion.

allegation_sentence_1:
In particular, defendant avers that “multiple
prosecutions” and prosecutorial misconduct and neglect are prohibitive of a second trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Having carefully considered and thoroughly reviewed the record in its entirety, the Court specifically finds there to be no
“prosecutorial misconduct” nor “prosecutorial overreaching” in the Government’s prior prosecution of the defendant.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Having carefully considered and thoroughly reviewed the record in its entirety, the Court specifically finds there to be no
“prosecutorial misconduct” nor “prosecutorial overreaching” in the Government’s prior prosecution of the defendant.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Having carefully considered and thoroughly reviewed the record in its entirety, the Court specifically finds there to be no
“prosecutorial misconduct” nor “prosecutorial overreaching” in the Government’s prior prosecution of the defendant.
concur_dissent_sentence_1:
I am not prepared to suggest, however, that a prosecutor’s overreaching in revealing to the
jury inadmissible and prejudicial facts or contentions which, under the law, ought to produce a mistrial can escape a double
jeopardy bar to retrial merely because the district judge erroneously permits the prejudicial material to be presented to the jury
and then erroneously declines to grant the mistrial motion which has been forced by prosecutorial misconduct.
concur_dissent_sentence_2:
I am not prepared to suggest, however, that a prosecutor’s overreaching in revealing to the
jury inadmissible and prejudicial facts or contentions which, under the law, ought to produce a mistrial can escape a double
jeopardy bar to retrial merely because the district judge erroneously permits the prejudicial material to be presented to the jury
and then erroneously declines to grant the mistrial motion which has been forced by prosecutorial misconduct.
concur_dissent_sentence_3:
On the other hand, I am certainly not prepared to suggest that every error made by the trial court in the admission of evidence
tendered by the government would bar a retrial even though the evidence thus admitted ought to have produced a mistrial.
concur_dissent_sentence_4: I view the error here to be of the sort not involving overreaching.

allegation_sentence_1: Griffin appeals, arguing that the prosecutor’s improper cross-examination and closing argument were so prejudicial as to deprive him of a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_2: Griffin appeals, arguing that the prosecutor’s improper cross-examination and closing argument were so prejudicial as to deprive him of a fair trial.
allegation_sentence_3: On appeal, Griffin argues that the pair of questions constituted prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_4:
Though his objections were
sustained, Griffin argues that he was nonetheless prejudiced because “the harm is not just in the answer when there is poison in
the question.”
allegation_sentence_5:
Griffin argues that the prosecutor committed prejudicial misconduct when he commented, near the end of his rebuttal
closing argument:
allegation_sentence_6:
Finally, Griffin argues that five other comments by the prosecutor during closing argument were improper expressions of
his personal opinions.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We reject this contention for three reasons-no misconduct occurred because the prosecutor had a good faith basis
to argue the prior conviction was admissible under Rule 609; Griffin’s objections were sustained so the questions went
unanswered; and the court promptly instructed the jury to disregard the questions.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
"We reject this contention for three reasons-no misconduct occurred because the prosecutor had a good faith basis
to argue the prior conviction was admissible under Rule 609; Griffin’s objections were sustained so the questions went
unanswered; and the court promptly instructed the jury to disregard the questions."
misconduct_determination_sentence3: This argument is of doubtful merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
In our view, these comments were proper argument based on the evidence, rather than improper expressions
of personal opinion.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: At a minimum, they fell far short of prosecutorial misconduct.

allegation_sentence_1: Quinn also alleges (though belatedly) prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
Specifically, he asserts that the Government postponed
Johnson’s sentencing until after Quinn’s trial to induce Johnson to invoke his Fifth Amendment privilege.
allegation_sentence_3:
He also claims for the first time that
the prosecution’s request to postpone Johnson’s sentencing until after Quinn’s trial was intended to induce Johnson to invoke
his Fifth Amendment privilege, a deliberate distortion of the factfinding process and thus an act of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_sentence_4:
We next turn to Quinn’s claim that the Government engaged in deliberate *264 distortion of the factfinding process by
delaying Johnson’s sentencing hearing.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Applying both the prosecutorial misconduct test that existed before and after Smith (acts taken with the deliberate intent to
distort the factfinding process) and the complementary test we created in Smith (exclusion of clearly exculpatory and essential
testimony without a strong countervailing government interest) to Quinn’s case, we hold that the Government did not engage in
wrongdoing.
misconduct_determination_term1:
Government did not engage in
wrongdoing.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We cannot conclude it deliberately distorted the factfinding process by delaying Johnson’s sentencing.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
No evidence demonstrates that the Government’s action had any effect on Johnson’s decision to invoke his Fifth Amendment right
not to incriminate himself by his testimony.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Nor did the Government keep clearly exculpatory testimony from Quinn’s trial by
refusing to immunize Johnson.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: In this case, Johnson’s testimony is not clearly exculpatory.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Quinn fails to show that the Government interfered unconstitutionally with Johnson’s
decision not to testify.

allegation_sentence_1:
Manning’s principal appellate claim is that *571 improper comments made by the prosecutor during closing arguments
undermined the fairness of his trial.
allegation_sentence_2: Manning complains of four different comments made by the prosecutor during the course of his closing argument.
allegation_sentence_3:
First,
Manning contends that the prosecutor improperly vouched for the credibility of certain prosecution witnesses during the
following colloquy:
allegation_sentence_4:
Next, Manning argues that the prosecutor engaged in additional improper witness-vouching and inappropriately implied that he
had additional incriminating evidence when, in responding to a defense argument concerning the lack of probative fingerprint
evidence on the items in the brown briefcase, he stated:
allegation_sentence_5:
Third, Manning asserts that the prosecutor impermissibly appealed to the jury’s emotions when, near the conclusion of the
prosecutor’s initial closing argument, the following exchange took place:
allegation_sentence_6: Finally, Manning charges that the prosecutor again impermissibly appealed to the *573 jury’s emotions at the conclusion of his rebuttal argument:
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
After carefully reviewing the record, we conclude that the prosecutor’s comments did so
infect the proceedings below that Manning is entitled to a new trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The government concedes that this passage contains improper witness-vouching by the
prosecution.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Although it is not entirely clear, the government appears to concede that this argument was
improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We find Manning’s reasoning
to be persuasive.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
First, we think that the First and Second Passages contain improper
witness-vouching by the prosecution.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Next, we believe that the Third and Fourth Passages include improper appeals to the jury to act in ways
other than as a dispassionate arbiter of the facts.
notes:
REPEATED MISCONDUCT: For the third time in the last six months, we
find ourselves in the regrettable position of vacating a conviction because a United States Attorney has failed to honor
sufficiently these precepts. See Udechukwu, 11 F.3d at 1106; Arrieta–Agressot, 3 F.3d at 530; see also United States v.
Moreno, 991 F.2d 943, 949–50 (1st Cir.) (Torruella, J., dissenting) (arguing, inter alia, that the prosecutorial misconduct in that
case warranted reversal of defendant’s conviction), cert. denied, 510 U.S. 971, 114 S.Ct. 457, 126 L.Ed.2d 389 (1993).

allegation_sentence_1:
Petitioner first argues that his counsel should have objected to statements by the prosecutor that, he says, expressed the
government’s personal knowledge of his guilt and its endorsement of two witnesses.
allegation_sentence_2:
Petitioner next argues that his counsel provided ineffective assistance in not objecting to statements by the prosecutors that he
says inflamed the passions of the jurors.
allegation_sentence_3:
Petitioner contends that the government attempted to appeal to the passions of the
jurors by alluding to victims that were old and young when the prosecutor said, “On March 6th of this year, a little bit after
8:15 at night, these two men, the defendant Antonio Scott and O’Kene White, ambushed a grandmother who was on her way
home to her family.”
allegation_sentence_4:
Petitioner also argues that the prosecutor should not have said, “They’re the ones who barged
into Rosemarie Hill’s apartment and brutalized and terrorized that family without regard to those consequences.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The underlying claim of prosecutorial misconduct cannot be established because the prosecutor’s statements were
neither patently improper nor prejudicial.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The prosecutor’s remarks during the opening statement, closing statement, and
rebuttal were not improper because—when viewed in context—it was clear that the prosecutor was making arguments based
on the evidence rather than personal convictions.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Similarly, the prosecutor’s comments concerning the credibility of Rajiem Black and Stacy Roberts were not improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: Finally, even if the prosecutor’s statements were improper, they did not create substantial prejudice.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Finally, based on the evidence presented at trial, it is not plausible that the prosecutor’s statements would have
affected the certainty of the conviction.
misconduct_determination_sentence6: Nevertheless, there was no prosecutorial misconduct based on these remarks.

decision_court: U.S. Navy–Marine Corps Court of Criminal Appeals.
defendant: Roberto RODRIGUEZ–RIVERA, Personnelman Second Class (E–5), U.S. Navy.
attorneys_judges:
Ritter, Senior Judge,//Lt Brian Mizer, JAGC, USNR, Appellate Defense Counsel.//
Lt Marcus N. Fulton, JAGC, USN, Appellate Defense Counsel.//
*845 Lt Christopher Burris, JAGC, USNR, Appellate Government Counsel.//

Before CARVER, Senior Judge, RITTER, Senior Judge, and WAGNER, Appellate Military Judge.//
RITTER, Senior Judge://Senior Judge CARVER and Judge WAGNER concur.
allegation_sentence_1:
The appellant contends that the trial counsel committed prosecutorial misconduct by: (1) violating the military judge’s ruling
regarding witness sequestration; (2) improperly coaching the six-year-old victim during a recess taken in the middle of her
direct testimony on the merits; (3) allowing the victim’s parents to improperly coach the victim during the same recess; and (4)
failing to be candid with the military judge concerning the improper coaching of the victim. We disagree, and find no such
misconduct.
allegation_sentence_2:
The appellant contends that the trial counsel committed prosecutorial misconduct by: (1) violating the military judge’s ruling
regarding witness sequestration; (2) improperly coaching the six-year-old victim during a recess taken in the middle of her
direct testimony on the merits; (3) allowing the victim’s parents to improperly coach the victim during the same recess; and (4)
failing to be candid with the military judge concerning the improper coaching of the victim.
allegation_sentence_3:
In his first of four specific contentions of prosecutorial misconduct, the appellant argues that the trial counsel intentionally
violated the military judge’s sequestration order by allowing JK’s parents to discuss with JK the substance of her testimony
during the recess.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We disagree, and find no such
misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: We also find that the trial counsel did not improperly coach JK by discussing her testimony with her during the recess.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Finally, even if we were to find prosecutorial misconduct, which we do not, we would have to determine whether the error
impacted a substantial right of the appellant and, if so, whether the violation was harmless under all the circumstances.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We have considered the appellant’s remaining assignments of error
and find them to be without merit.

Baker next argues that the government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct by threatening to indict his wife unless the case
proceeded quickly.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We have stated that we “find[ ] no impropriety in the government’s warnings that members of [a defendant’s] family could
be indicted.”
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Because Baker presented no evidence of prosecutorial misconduct or judicial impartiality, we affirm his conviction.

allegation_sentence_1:
Mr. Anaya appeals his conviction on four grounds. He argues (A) the evidence was insufficient for the jury to convict him of
conspiracy; (B) prosecutorial misconduct precluded a fair trial; (C) the district court erred by instructing the jury on willful
blindness, and (D) the “total weight of the errors” created a cumulative error that affected the outcome of his trial.
allegation_sentence_2:
Mr. Anaya alleges that six instances of prosecutorial misconduct rendered his trial so unfair as to make his conviction a
violation of due process.
allegation_sentence_3:
Mr. Anaya argues that these exchanges led the jury to believe that the prosecutor had verified the truthfulness of her witnesses
with evidence that was not before the jury.
allegation_sentence_4: Mr. Anaya argues that the prosecutor used evidence that had not been admitted at trial to prove Mr. Anaya’s guilt.
allegation_sentence_5:
Mr. Anaya alleges that three prosecutor statements suggested to the jury that the Government only presents the truth at trial
and the defense counsel’s job is to mislead.
allegation_sentence_6:
Mr. Anaya argues that the prosecutor’s statements distracted the jurors from the evidence by focusing their attention on her
credibility and suggesting his counsel’s job was to trick them.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Her statements were therefore not plainly improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The
prosecutor did not refer to evidence outside of the record. Mr. Anaya did not object, and his argument completely lacks merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Here, the prosecutor’s three statements did not approach in substance the statements found objectionable in Berger.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: The prosecutor’s three statements were not plainly improper.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
The prosecutor’s closing argument challenging Mr. Limon’s credibility was, on its face, within the bounds of closing
argument advocacy.
misconduct_determination_sentence6: Mr. Anaya falls short on this part of his appeal.

attorneys_judges:

allegation_sentence_1:
Presently before this Court is Defendant Jose Martinez’s “Motion to Dismiss Indictment for Prosecutorial Misconduct
before the Grand Jury and/or Outrageous Governmental Conduct.”
allegation_sentence_2:
In his motion, Martinez contends that
the government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct before the Grand Jury warranting dismissal of the Superseding Indictment
against him.
allegation_sentence_3:
Martinez argues that the government prejudiced the Grand Jury by “poisoning their minds” with misleading
questions and the use of hearsay statements.
allegation_sentence_4:
He contends that this alleged misconduct was the sole reason he was named in the
Superseding Indictment because “there is-there was no other evidence tying [him] to the-to any-any conspiracy.”
allegation_sentence_5:
First, Martinez argues that he was
unfairly prejudiced by the government’s presentation of testimony implicating him in the murder of Quincy Turner.
allegation_sentence_6:
Second, he
argues that the government allowed Runkle to misleadingly testify about 12 phone calls between Turner and a number
allegedly used by Martinez, when in fact the calls were not recorded, the speakers were not identified and the content of the
conversation was unknown.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Applying these principles, this Court finds that dismissal of the Superseding Indictment is not warranted.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Martinez has not
demonstrated that the Grand Jury’s decision to indict him was substantially influenced by the government’s alleged
misconduct, nor has Martinez demonstrated a “grave doubt” that the Grand Jury was not independent or unbiased.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Martinez has not
demonstrated that the Grand Jury’s decision to indict him was substantially influenced by the government’s alleged
misconduct, nor has Martinez demonstrated a “grave doubt” that the Grand Jury was not independent or unbiased.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
As an initial matter, this Court rejects Martinez’s argument that, absent the allegedly prejudicial questions by the
government about Turner’s homicide, Martinez would not have been indicted because there is insufficient evidence tying him
to the conspiracy.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Moreover, this Court finds that the testimony elicited concerning the Turner murder, calls between Turner and
Martinez, the sale of the car, and the identification of Martinez as “Rico Suave” was not unfairly prejudicial and does not
approach extreme prosecutorial misconduct.

misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because we reverse Cruz’s conviction for
prosecutorial misconduct, we do not reach his other issues.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
By stating “do the right thing” the prosecutor improperly expressed his
personal opinion to the jury.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Without reference to the
evidence or the burden of proof, the “do the right thing” statement improperly urged the jury to convict on the basis of the
prosecutor’s subjective belief of what was “right,” as opposed to the persuasive force of the evidence.
misconduct_determination_sentence4: The prosecutor’s “do the right thing” statement was prejudicial to Cruz for several reasons.
misconduct_determination_sentence5:
Third, the prosecutor’s rebuttal argument was the last thing the jury heard before
beginning deliberation; this timing increased the risk that the prosecutor’s improper statement influenced the jurors.

attorneys_judges:
Military Judge: Maj M.D. Zimmerman, USMC.//
Convening Authority: Commanding General, 1st Marine Logistics Group, Camp Pendleton, CA.//Staff Judge Advocate’s Recommendation: LtCol E.J. Peterson, USMC.//For Appellant: LT Rey Austria, JAGC, USN.//For Appellee: LT Robert Miller, JAGC, USN; LT James Belforti, JAGC, USN.//RUGH, Judge:
geography_entities: Camp Pendleton, CA.
allegation_sentence_1: The appellant raises two assignments of error (AOE): prosecutorial misconduct and unlawful command influence.
allegation_sentence_2:
The appellant now raises two allegations of prosecutorial misconduct based on a government search of defense counsel spaces
onboard Camp Pendleton and on the actions of two government counsel, Captain (Capt) W and Capt McC, who were
disqualified from serving as trial counsel after becoming witnesses to the conspiracy and obstruction charges.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We disagree
with both.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Likewise, the actions of Capt W and Capt McC did not rise to the level of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2: did not rise to the level of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
The scope of the military
judge’s disqualification of counsel was ambiguous, particularly after his clarification failed to directly address counsels’
questions regarding activities not before the bar. Given the thrust of the military judge’s initial ruling—that the disqualification
arose largely from concerns about member confusion—trial counsels’ interpretation was not so unreasonable as to infringe
upon their mandate in a criminal prosecution “not that it shall win a case, but that justice shall be done.”
misconduct_determination_term3:
was not so unreasonable as to infringe
upon their mandate in a criminal prosecution
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Similarly, nothing in the manner in which Capt W specifically questioned Sgt McNeill raises the specter of misconduct.
That Sgt McNeill would change his testimony to inculpate the appellant after his grant of immunity may be fertile ground for
cross-examination, but it is not shocking to common sense. In light of the facts of this case, such a change in testimony was not
the result of prosecutorial misconduct.
For these reasons, we find no error.

allegation_sentence_1:
WHETHER TRIAL COUNSEL COMMITTED PROSECUTORIAL MISCONDUCT BY (1) VIOLATING THE
MILITARY JUDGE’S ORDERS REGARDING WITNESS SEQUESTRATION; (2) BY IMPROPERLY COACHING
THE SIX–YEAR–OLD COMPLAINING WITNESS DURING HER DIRECT TESTIMONY; (3) BY PURPOSEFULLY
ALLOWING OTHER WITNESSES TO IMPROPERLY COACH THE COMPLAINING WITNESS DURING HER
DIRECT TESTIMONY; (4) BY FAILING TO BE CANDID WITH THE COURT–MARTIAL REGARDING THE
COACHING OF THE WITNESS BY TRIAL COUNSEL AND OTHER WITNESSES; AND (5) BY FAILING TO BE
CANDID WITH THE COURT–MARTIAL ABOUT NOTES PASSED FROM A PROSECUTION WITNESS DURING
THE DEFENSE’S CASE.
allegation_term_1: WHETHER TRIAL COUNSEL COMMITTED PROSECUTORIAL MISCONDUCT
allegation_sentence_2:
Rodriguez–Rivera alleges that the following actions by trial counsel constituted prosecutorial misconduct: (1) violation of the
military judge’s orders regarding witness sequestration; (2) improperly coaching the victim; (3) allowing other witnesses to
coach the victim; (4) failing to be candid with the court-martial regarding the alleged witness coaching; and (5) failing to be
candid with the court-martial about notes received from a prosecution witness during the defense case.
allegation_term_2: alleges that the following actions by trial counsel constituted prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces, Erdmann, J., held that:
[1]
accused did not establish prosecutorial misconduct based on allegation that six-year-old child victim was improperly
coached regarding her testimony by trial counsel, assistant trial counsel, and her parents during recess;
misconduct_determination_term1: accused did not establish prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
As a result, we conclude that there was no prosecutorial misconduct in this
allegation.
misconduct_determination_term2:
no prosecutorial misconduct in this
allegation.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We conclude that the lower court’s finding that
the assistant trial counsel was candid regarding the discussions that occurred during the break was not clearly erroneous.
Therefore, we conclude that there was no prosecutorial misconduct arising from this allegation.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We see no basis in the record to conclude that
the military judge’s finding that trial counsel was candid with regard to this incident was clearly erroneous. Therefore, there is
no basis to conclude that prosecutorial misconduct occurred with regard to these notes.
misconduct_determination_term4: no basis to conclude that prosecutorial misconduct occurred

United States Court of Appeals,

geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Central District of California,
allegation_sentence_1:
On this appeal, Bashaw makes two contentions: (1) That the District Court erred in refusing to grant a mistrial because of
the prosecutor’s inquiry of Bashaw, while a witness in his own behalf, ‘Did you recently plead in state court to possession of
drugs?’ (2) Egregious error by the prosecutor in a comment, made during summation ‘that the defendant’s evidence doesn’t
meet its burden of showing the defendant did not commit the crime charged.’
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court of Appeals held that it was improper
for prosecutor to ask defendant, while a witness in his own behalf, as to whether he had recently pled in state court to
possession of drugs, that it was improper for prosecutor to comment during summation that defendant’s evidence did not meet
its burden of showing that defendant did not commit the crime charged, but that such conduct was legally harmless in light of
prompt and careful curative instructions of district judge and in light of fact that evidence of defendant’s guilt was
overwhelming.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We do not condone the prosecutor’s conduct. In fact, we condemn it, and overzeal on the part of a counsel for the
Government of the United States affords no legitimate excuse for his prosecutorial misconduct. In the light of the prompt and
careful curative instructions of the district judge, however, and in light of the further fact that the evidence of Bashaw’s guilt
was overwhelming, we are impelled to the conclusion that the prosecutor’s misconduct was legally harmless and that the
judgment of conviction should be, and it hereby is,
Affirmed.
misconduct_determination_term2:
the evidence of Bashaw’s guilt
was overwhelming

case falls within exceptions to the appeal waiver for ineffective assistance of counsel and prosecutorial misconduct. He asserts

parte statements constitute, respectively, ineffective assistance and prosecutorial misconduct.

counsel had a duty to object to the district court’s use of the case agent’s testimony and Velazquez’s debriefings does not bring
the issue raised on appeal-that the district court erred at sentencing-into the exceptions *339 to the waiver. As such, we do not
address the merits of Velazquez’s challenge to his sentence.

we do not
address the merits of Velazquez’s challenge to his sentence.

geography_entities: Montgomery, AL,
allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, Rowe argues that the prosecutor committed prosecutorial misconduct at sentencing because, although he recited the
United States Department of Justice’s (“DOJ’s”) policy supporting the elimination of the crack/powder cocaine disparity in the
Sentencing Guidelines, he undermined the DOJ’s policy by arguing for a sentence towards the middle of his guideline range.
He contends that, as a result, the district court refused to vary below the low-end of his guideline range.
allegation_term_1: argues that the prosecutor committed prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because the prosecutor complied with the DOJ’s policy, which required him to inform the district court that the DOJ and the
Obama Administration supported the elimination of the crack/powder cocaine disparity in the Sentencing Guidelines, he did
not commit prosecutorial misconduct, plainly or otherwise, by arguing for a within-guideline sentence.
misconduct_determination_term1:
he did
not commit prosecutorial misconduct

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Fourth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: Sandra J. Barrett, Asheville, North Carolina, for Appellant. Amy Elizabeth Ray, Assistant United States Attorney, Asheville, North Carolina, for Appellee.//Before WILKINSON, KING, and DUNCAN, Circuit Judges.

case_outcome: Dismissed in part; affirmed in part
allegation_sentence_1:
She
appeals, claiming that the district court erred in determining the amount of loss attributable to her for sentencing purposes and
that the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_term_1: the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
After reviewing the record, we conclude that Griffin knowingly and voluntarily waived her right to appeal her conviction and
sentence, retaining only her right to raise claims based on prosecutorial misconduct or ineffective assistance of counsel. We
find that Griffin’s challenges to the calculation of her sentence fall within the scope of the waiver and, therefore, we grant in
part the Government’s motion to dismiss.
misconduct_determination_term1:
grant in
part the Government’s motion to dismiss.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Our review of the record discloses that the prosecutor’s conduct was neither improper nor
prejudicially affected Griffin’s substantial rights. Accordingly, we affirm.
misconduct_determination_term2:
prosecutor’s conduct was neither improper nor
prejudicially affected Griffin’s substantial rights.

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Seventh Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *1081 Alex Menchaca (argued), Office of the United States Attorney, Criminal Division, Barry Rand Elden, Chief of Appeals, Office of the United States Attorney, Criminal Appellate Division, Chicago, IL, for Plaintiff-Appellee.//Marianne Jackson (argued), Chicago, IL, for Defendant-Appellant.//Before CUMMINGS, BAUER, and FLAUM, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities:
the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois,
allegation_sentence_1:
He raises two double
jeopardy arguments concerning his retrial, and he argues that the district court abused its discretion in limiting the scope of
opening statements during his second trial.
allegation_term_1: argues that the district court abused its discretion
allegation_sentence_2:
Doyle presents three arguments on appeal: (1) whether the Fifth Amendment’s Double Jeopardy Clause bars retrial in the
absence of a defense motion for mistrial where prosecutors engaged in misconduct in order to prevent an acquittal they
believed at the time was likely to occur in the absence of such misconduct; (2) whether double jeopardy bars Doyle’s trial for
drug conspiracy when he had previously pleaded guilty to federal charges involving the “same” drug conspiracy and RICO
organization; and (3) whether the district court abused its discretion in granting the government’s motion in limine to bar Doyle
from mentioning prosecutorial misconduct during opening statements.
allegation_term_2: mentioning prosecutorial misconduct during opening statements
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court of Appeals, Bauer, Circuit Judge, held
that: (1) double jeopardy did not bar defendant’s retrial after he prevailed on posttrial motion for new trial based on
prosecutorial misconduct; (2) indictment did not charge defendant with same conspiracy, for double jeopardy purposes, as that
charged in prior federal prosecution; (3) district court did not abuse its discretion when it limited scope of opening statements
to exclude references to prosecutorial misconduct that occurred during defendant’s first trial.
misconduct_determination_term1:
did not bar defendant’s retrial after he prevailed on posttrial motion for new trial based on
prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
We conclude that none of these arguments provide a
basis for affording Doyle relief.
misconduct_determination_term2:
none of these arguments provide a
basis for affording Doyle relief.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
In conclusion, because no evidence shows that the prosecutorial misconduct was undertaken with the intent of goading the
defendants into moving for a mistrial, or with intent to abort the trial, the Kennedy exception does not apply. Rather, the
general double jeopardy rule described in Lockhart v. Nelson, 488 U.S. 33, 38, 109 S.Ct. 285, 289, 102 L.Ed.2d 265 (1988)
permits Doyle’s retrial. We expressly reserve the question of whether Wallach would apply in other circumstances. See Jacob
v. Clarke, 52 F.3d 178, 182 (8th Cir.), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 924, 116 S.Ct. 323, 133 L.Ed.2d 224 (1995) (reserving the
question on the Wallach dicta). Judge Conlon’s denial of the defendants’ motion to dismiss based on double jeopardy is
therefore affirmed.
misconduct_determination_term3: denial of the defendants’ motion to dismiss
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
In fact, as the
government notes in its brief, Doyle has failed to cite even one instance from the record of the second trial in which the defense
sought to introduce evidence of prosecutorial misconduct and Judge Conlon denied the request.
misconduct_determination_term4:
failed to cite even one instance from the record of the second trial in which the defense
sought to introduce evidence of prosecutorial misconduct
notes:
Interesting one. Defendent had a trial, appealled for prosecutorial misconduct, and was granted a new trial. After his 2nd trial, he appealed for prosecutorial miscduct again, but it was denited the 2nd time around: "After a hearing on their post-trial motions, the district
court granted Doyle and two of his co-defendants’ motion for a new trial based on allegations of prosecutorial misconduct.
Doyle was again found guilty on all counts in his retrial. Doyle was sentenced to life imprisonment on Count Three and to two
concurrent twenty-year sentences on each of Counts One and Two. Doyle appeals from his conviction. He raises two double
jeopardy arguments concerning his retrial, and he argues that the district court abused its discretion in limiting the scope of
opening statements during his second trial. We affirm."

allegation_sentence_1:
He alleges that prosecutorial misconduct and the trial judge’s denial of his
motion for a separate trial prejudiced his case.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: Neither contention has merit.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In a well-reasoned opinion, the trial judge found that there had been no
prosecutorial misconduct and that Granito suffered no undue prejudice from either the prosecution’s actions or from joinder.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Our review of the record shows that Granito does not establish actual prejudice from any of the errors he alleges.

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Ninth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *1084 Rita J. Radostitz, Asst. Federal Public Defender, Eugene, Or., for defendant-appellant.//Fred N. Weinhouse, Asst. U.S. Atty., Portland, Or., for plaintiff-appellee.//Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Oregon.//Before PREGERSON, BRUNETTI and T.G. NELSON, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the District of Oregon
case_outcome: Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.
allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant Edward Gordon Westerdahl appeals from a judgment of conviction, following a jury trial, of armed bank robbery, in
violation of 18 U.S.C. §§ 2113(a) and 2113(d) (1988), and carrying a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, in
violation of 18 U.S.C. § 924(c) (1988).
allegation_term_1: appeals from a judgment of conviction
allegation_sentence_2:
On appeal, Westerdahl argues that: (1) the district court’s refusal to grant immunity to Goldsberry violated his due process
right to a fair trial; (2) the failure of the police to preserve potentially exculpatory evidence required dismissal of the indictment
under Youngblood; and (3) there was insufficient evidence to sustain the conviction on the count alleging the possession of a
firearm during the commission of a violent *1086 felony.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
As the majority points out, an exception to the rule that a defendant cannot compel the government to grant immunity to a
witness exists where prosecutorial misconduct intentionally distorts the fact-finding process. In my view, no prosecutorial
misconduct occurred here.

geography_entities: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
allegation_sentence_1:
Defendants, charged in a 22-count indictment with having committed racketeering, securities and bankruptcy fraud and
obstruction of justice, moved for a mistrial, alleging prosecutorial misconduct which resulted in the publication in a national
magazine of a photograph which was allegedly an unredacted version of a government exhibit.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The District Court, Sweet, J.,
held that even if release of the photographs resulted from prosecutorial misconduct, where no jurors saw the unredacted
photograph and the trial was thus unaffected, defendants were not entitled to dismissal of the indictment.
misconduct_determination_term1: defendants were not entitled to dismissal of the indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Indictment is in order. Though the defendants have a right to a trial free from prosecutorial misconduct, U. S. v. Jacobs, 547
F.2d 772 (2d Cir. 1976), the interests of justice require that the defendants’ motion be denied, even assuming, arguendo, that
their allegations of misconduct were true.
misconduct_determination_term2: require that the defendants’ motion be denied,
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Defendants’ motion for mistrial, or alternatively, for dismissal of the Indictment, is denied.

geography_entities:
United States District Court, N.D. California,

Oakland Division.
allegation_sentence_1:
Bhatia previously filed a motion to dismiss on the ground that
the dismissal filed in the Texas civil action precluded the government, under the doctrine of collateral estoppel or res judicata, from pursuing the instant criminal action. (Docket 262.) The Court denied the motion. 2 Nonetheless, Bhatia has now filed another motion to dismiss the indictment based on accusations that Assistant United States Attorney Stephen Corrigan and Federal Bureau of Investigations Agent Alison Berry withheld information from the grand jury in order to secure the indictment.
allegation_term_1: withheld information from the grand jury in order to secure the indictment.
allegation_sentence_2:
In particular, he claims that the deposition testimony of the Abercias proves that that another individual, Gerry
Florent, alone had deceived them into paying the advance fees. (Def.’s Mot. at 3.) Bhatia argues that the information gleaned
from these individuals was available to Agent Berry, who allegedly should have presented it to the grand jury. (Def.’s Mot. to
Dismiss at 12.)
allegation_term_2: deceived them into paying the advance fees.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Even if the evidence relied upon by Bhatia could be construed as exculpatory, the government’s failure to present such
information to the grand jury does not establish prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2: did not amount of prosecutorial misconduct

decision_court:
United States District Court,
E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
attorneys_judges: Patrice Donaldson, FCI-Allenwood, White Deer, PA, pro se.//TARNOW, J.
geography_entities:
United States District Court,
E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
allegation_sentence_1:
In his motion to vacate, Petitioner argued that his trial counsel was ineffective for failing to object to several instances of
prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
In
its order denying the petition for habeas corpus, this Court held that Petitioner could not establish “highly exceptional”
circumstances justifying relitigation of his prosecutorial misconduct claims.
misconduct_determination_term1:
Petitioner could not establish “highly exceptional”
circumstances justifying relitigation
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Petitioner’s ineffective assistance of counsel claim
was based on counsel’s failure to object to the alleged instances of prosecutorial misconduct. Therefore, the Court held that
Petitioner could not establish prejudice.
notes:
interesting circumstance: "Although Petitioner was not able to convince this Court that there are “highly exceptional” circumstances justifying relitigation
of his prosecutorial misconduct claims, the Court finds that Petitioner could convince the Sixth Circuit that such circumstances
exist. In other words, reasonable jurists could disagree with this Court’s holdings. Therefore, the Court certifies the following
issue for appeal:
• Whether Petitioner was denied effective assistance of trial counsel."

decision_court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
attorneys_judges: Mary Jo White, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, (Evan T. Barr, Assistant United States Attorney, of counsel), New York City for U.S.//Philip R. Edelbaum, New York City, for defendant.//BAER, District Judge:
geography_entities: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
allegation_sentence_1:
Rodriguez claims that Postal Inspector Fred Fairchild gave incorrect and misleading testimony before the grand jury indicating
that she had confessed to the crime after she was arrested.
allegation_term_1: claims that Postal Inspector Fred Fairchild gave incorrect and misleading testimony
allegation_sentence_2: Rodriguez argues that this Court should dismiss the indictment pursuant to its supervisory powers.
allegation_sentence_3:
Rodriguez argues that this Court should dismiss the indictment against her because Inspector Fairchild’s testimony was “totally
incorrect and totally misleading.”
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court disagrees for two
reasons. First, the Court does not believe it has the authority to dismiss the indictment for the claimed violations. Second, even
assuming that the Court does have the authority, it concludes that dismissal here would be inappropriate.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Rodriguez has failed to allege, let alone demonstrate, that Inspector Fairchild or the prosecutor violated any clear
constitutional, statutory, or procedural rule. Although she claims that his testimony was incorrect, Rodriguez does not argue
that it was perjurious or that the prosecutor knowingly introduced it as false testimony. Accordingly, even assuming that
Inspector Fairchild’s testimony was inaccurate, the Court must conclude that it lacks the power to dismiss the indictment.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Furthermore, even if the rule in Brito is still valid in this circuit, the Court finds that dismissal of the indictment is
inappropriate.
misconduct_determination_term3:
dismissal of the indictment is
inappropriate.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Again, even assuming that Inspector
Fairchild’s testimony was incorrect and misleading, it does not rise to the level of prosecutorial misconduct warranting the
dismissal of an indictment after a jury conviction.
misconduct_determination_term4: does not rise to the level of prosecutorial misconduct

decision_court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
attorneys_judges: Honorable Peter C. Dorsey.
geography_entities: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
allegation_sentence_1:
Defendant also has filed a motion requesting that the court clarify its
reasons for denying the previously filed motion for judgment of acquittal, particularly with respect to the issues of
prosecutorial misconduct and double jeopardy [doc. # 1317].
allegation_sentence_2:
Second, he contends that the record reveals
the government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct during the presentation of evidence and in its summation at trial.
allegation_term_2: the government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
After reviewing the trial record and Defendant’s “letter
brief,” the court finds no merit to Defendant’s claims.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
In addition, the government’s
summation at the close of trial does not contain any evidence of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2: does not contain any evidence of prosecutorial misconduct.

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Eighth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *859 Anna Wirt O’Flaherty, argued, North Liberty, IA, for appellant.//*860 John S. Courter, AUSA, Argued, Des Moines, IA, for appellee.//Before BYE, BEAM and GRUENDER, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa,
allegation_sentence_1:
Crawford first argues that the Government’s attempt to elicit evidence about gang affiliation violated the district
court’s ruling on his motion in limine.
allegation_sentence_2: Next, Crawford contends that the Government’s reference to a “bad” neighborhood in closing argument was improper.
allegation_sentence_3:
Finally, Crawford argues that the Government’s statement about the lack of turkey or hog farming on the near north side of
Des Moines amounted to the prosecutor testifying during closing argument.
allegation_term_3: amounted to the prosecutor testifying during closing argument.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Gruender, Circuit Judge, held that:
[1]
improper references to gang affiliation did not rise to the level of reversible prosecutorial misconduct;
[2] prosecutor’s reference to defendant’s neighborhood as a bad neighborhood did not amount to prosecutorial misconduct; and
[3] prosecutor’s statement during closing argument about the lack of turkey or hog farming nearby defendant’s residence did not
amount to prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term1: did not rise to the level of reversible prosecutorial misconduct
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Because Crawford did not contest the introduction of
the word “Crip,” the Government’s brief references to the word “gang” were neither improper nor prejudicial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: Because we do not find that the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct, we affirm Crawford’s conviction.
misconduct_determination_term3: do not find that the Government engaged in prosecutorial misconduct

decision_court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
defendant: Christopher PARKER and Spencer Sawyer, Defendants-Appellees.
attorneys_judges:
Before SNEED, MICHEL
2
and THOMAS, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Eastern District of California,
allegation_sentence_1:
But what I will say is that in my view, in this court’s view, the government’s conduct was reckless and deliberately
indif erent to its impact upon the court’s calendar. And that ought to be enough.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
We need not and do not address whether the government was properly forewarned of the dismissal, because the
district court failed to find prosecutorial misconduct and prejudice under Rule 48(b) as construed in our case law.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The district court did find that the “government’s conduct was reckless and deliberately indifferent to its impact upon
the court’s calendar,” but no specific findings of prosecutorial misconduct were made and the district court never implied that
the government was using the delay somehow to gain tactical advantage over the defendants.
misconduct_determination_term2: no specific findings of prosecutorial misconduct were made
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Because the finding relating to any prosecutorial misconduct was premised solely on the government’s disruption of the district
court’s calendar (without any intent to harm the court), that finding is clearly erroneous, rendering the district court’s dismissal
of the indictment an abuse of discretion.
misconduct_determination_term3: without any intent to harm the court
notes:
This was reversed based on a lack of a speedy trial, not prosecutorial misconduct..."The district court did find that the “government’s conduct was reckless and deliberately indifferent to its impact upon
the court’s calendar,” but no specific findings of prosecutorial misconduct were made and the district court never implied that
the government was using the delay somehow to gain tactical advantage over the defendants."

decision_court:
United States District Court,
N.D. Iowa,
Western Division.
attorneys_judges: *1046 United States Attorney’s Office for the Northern District of Iowa, for Plaintiff U.S.//David E. Richter and Matthew D. Wilber of Richter & Wilber, Council Bluffs, IA, for Defendant Health Damon Schneider.//BENNETT, Chief Judge.
geography_entities:
United States District Court,
N.D. Iowa,
Western Division.
allegation_sentence_1:
With respect to the alleged prosecutorial misconduct,
Schneider specifically contends that the government engaged in an improper line of questioning of Toni Marquardt, and that
the prosecutor made a highly improper comment during the rebuttal closing argument.
allegation_term_1: the government engaged in an improper line of questioning
allegation_sentence_2:
With respect to the alleged withholding
of evidence, Schneider specifically contends that the government failed to timely disclose William Heiden’s perjury before the
federal grand jury, and that the government failed to timely disclose prior trips to Mexico by William Heiden and Gail
Swanson during which drugs were illegally obtained.
allegation_sentence_3:
Schneider argues that each one of these allegations of prosecutorial
misconduct, individually, is grounds for a new trial, however, he also argues in the alternative that, in the event the court finds
that each of these instances of alleged misconduct, taken individually, do not rise to the level of prejudice that would justify the
granting of a new trial, the cumulative nature of the prosecutor’s conduct would warrant the granting of a new trial.
allegation_term_3: the cumulative nature of the prosecutor’s conduct would warrant the granting of a new trial.
allegation_sentence_4:
Schneider asserts that the prosecutor committed four separate incidents of prosecutorial misconduct. First, Schneider contends
that, on the second day of trial, the prosecutor informed defense counsel that Heiden had admitted to committing perjury before
the federal grand jury in this case.
allegation_term_4: the prosecutor informed defense counsel that Heiden had admitted to committing perjury
allegation_sentence_5:
Second, Schneider
contends that, on the third day of trial, cooperating witness Toni Marquardt was called to the stand, whereupon the prosecutor asked Marquardt if there was any particular reason she was especially nervous.
allegation_term_5: asked Marquardt if there was any particular reason she was especially nervous.
allegation_sentence_6:
Third, Schneider contends that, at the end of the third day of trial, the FBI case
agent testified that he had been aware, through discussions with Gail Swanson, that Heiden and Swanson made trips to Mexico
wherein drugs had been purchased.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Even assuming that the prosecutor’s statement during the rebuttal closing argument, alone, does not weigh in favor of
granting a new trial, the court finds that the cumulative nature of the prosecutorial impropriety which permeated this trial does
weigh in favor of granting a new trial. It is noteworthy that the prosecutor’s improper statement regarding the lack of the
defendant’s polygraph, as well as the lack of the defendant’s witnesses’ polygraphs, occurred after the prosecutor had been
previously admonished by the court on three separate occasions regarding previous improper conduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The court concludes that based upon its review of the evidence, and viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the
government, a reasonable jury could have found Schneider knowingly and voluntarily participated in an agreement to combine,
conspire, and agree with other persons to commit the following two separate offenses:
misconduct_determination_term2: a reasonable jury could have found Schneider knowingly and voluntarily participated
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
However, the
court concludes that the statement *1071 made by the prosecutor during the rebuttal closing argument, alone, as well as the
cumulative effect of the other three instances of imprudent conduct on the part of the prosecutor, so infected the trial with
unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process. Consequently, the verdict in this case is set aside and
Schneider’s motion for new trial is granted.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
Therefore, although the evidence against Schneider was considerable, it was
not overwhelming, and coupled with a very strong defense and defense counsel’s forceful closing argument, the court
concludes that Schneider has satisfied this second factor. See Boyle v. Million, 201 F.3d 711, 717–18 (6th Cir.2000) (reversing
for prosecutorial misconduct even though the evidence against the defendant was strong); United States v. Francis, 170 F.3d
546, 552 (6th Cir.1999) (same).

decision_court: U.S. Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces.
defendant: Raiden J. ANDREWS, Quartermaster Seaman Apprentice, United States Navy, Appellant
attorneys_judges:
*396 Military Judge: Heather D. Partridge//For Appellant: Lieutenant Commander Jacob E. Meusch, JAGC, USN (argued); Rebecca Snyder, Esq.//For Appellee: Captain Sean M. Monks, USMC (argued); Colonel Valerie C. Danyluk, USMC, Major Kelli A. O’Neil, USMC,
and Brian K. Keller, Esq. (on brief).//Judge SPARKS delivered the opinion of the Court, in which Chief Judge STUCKY, and Judges RYAN, OHLSON, and
MAGGS, joined.//Judge SPARKS delivered the opinion of the Court.
geography_entities: United States Navy,
allegation_sentence_1:
Appellant now contends portions of trial counsel’s argument amounted to prejudicial
prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces, Sparks, J., held that:
[1]
trial counsel’s prosecutorial misconduct constituted plain and obvious error,
misconduct_determination_term1: prosecutorial misconduct constituted plain and obvious error,
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Rather than engage in a long and searching analysis of whether each
complained-of statement was an improper argument, we adopt the lower court’s conclusion that the prosecutorial misconduct
in this case amounted to plain and obvious error.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Accordingly, we conclude the evidence against Appellant was so strong we are “confident that the members convicted the
appellant on the basis of the evidence alone.” Fletcher, 62 M.J. at 184. There was, therefore, no prejudice to Appellant’s
substantial rights.
misconduct_determination_term3:
no prejudice to Appellant’s
substantial rights.

decision_court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
attorneys_judges: *227 Ralph Casas, Coleman, FL, pro se.//Nelson J. Perez–Sosa, United States Attorney’s Office, San Juan, PR, for Respondent.//The District Court, Jay A. GarcÍa–Gregory, J.,
geography_entities: D. Puerto Rico.
allegation_sentence_1:
Petitioner claims that the prosecutor injected testimony and evidence of murder and violence during Petitioner’s trial for drugs,
which swayed the jury to determine *232 that Petitioner was guilty.
misconduct_determination_sentence1: even assuming prosecutorial misconduct which amounted to a constitutional error, such error was harmless.
misconduct_determination_sentence2: Federal habeas corpus review of prosecutorial misconduct claims is “quite limited.”
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
For this reason, we have long and
consistently affirmed that a collateral challenge may not do service for an appeal.”).
misconduct_determination_term3: may not do service for an appeal
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
As a result, for Petitioner to succeed on his prosecutorial misconduct claim he had to demonstrate both cause and actual
prejudice under the Frady test discussed above. Petitioner Casas utterly failed to do so.
misconduct_determination_sentence5: Petitioner’s prosecutorial misconduct claims are procedurally barred and he is therefore not entitled to relief on these claims.
misconduct_determination_sentence6:
Petitioner Casas’
underlying allegations of prosecutorial misconduct are without merit.

geography_entities:
delay of 404 days from completion of trial to action of convening authority did not deny accused his due process right to
