allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal, the appellant asserts: (1) his conviction should be set aside because the convening authority committed
prosecutorial misconduct;
allegation_sentence_2:
Furthermore, the appellant’s lone statement regarding
prejudice, claiming “the delay has prejudiced [the appellant] by delaying his opportunity for his prosecutorial misconduct
grievances to be heard by a disinterested arbiter,
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
delay of 404 days from completion of trial to action of convening authority did not deny accused his due process right to
speedy review and appeal.
misconduct_determination_term1: did not deny accused his due process
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
For the reasons set forth above, we hold that the convening authority did not commit prosecutorial misconduct when he
referred the charges and specifications to trial by court-martial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
He has therefore
failed to establish prejudice under this sub-factor.

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Eighth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *1377 Joseph T. Walbran, Minneapolis, MN, (Francis X. Hermann and Joseph T. Walbran, on the brief), for appellee.//Before McMILLIAN, HANSEN, and MORRIS SHEPPARD ARNOLD, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities:
The United States District Court for the District of
Minnesota,
allegation_sentence_1:
In February 1992, Thompson filed this section 2255 petition, alleging, inter alia, that his conviction was invalid under the
Fourth and Fifth Amendments because of prosecutorial misconduct, that he was denied his right to retain counsel of his own
choice, and that he was denied effective assistance of counsel.
allegation_sentence_2:
In support of his claim for prosecutorial misconduct, Thompson
alleged that Assistant United States Attorney Joseph Walbran, the prosecutor in his case, failed to disclose an investigative
report prepared by FBI Agent James A. Hand, which Thompson argues establishes that the St. Paul police officers who
testified at the suppression hearing lied when they said they arrested Thompson because he matched the informant’s
description of the suspect.
allegation_term_2:
failed to disclose an investigative
report
allegation_sentence_3:
Thompson also alleged Walbran knowingly elicited false testimony from witnesses concerning his
arrest;
allegation_sentence_4:
Thompson argues that the slight changes that have occurred in the
witnesses’ “stories” in each of Thompson’s previous lawsuits support his claim of prosecutorial misconduct.
allegation_term_4: support his claim of prosecutorial misconduct.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Most of Thompson’s claims of prosecutorial misconduct are an attempt to relitigate *1379 the validity of the stop, search,
and seizure that took place incident to his arrest. We have already considered and rejected Thompson’s claims that the officers
lacked probable cause to stop the vehicle and arrest him and that Walbran deceived the courts by introducing a “darkened”
photocopy of Thompson’s license making it appear “rough.”
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
We conclude, therefore, that certain claims were considered on direct appeal and are
not cognizable in this section 2255 motion, see United States v. Holtzen, 718 F.2d 876, 878 (8th Cir.1983) (per curiam), and
other claims could have been raised on direct appeal, and Thompson has not shown cause and prejudice for his default.
misconduct_determination_term3: Thompson has not shown cause and prejudice for his default.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We conclude,
however, that the record is void of any proof that Walbran knowingly elicited false testimony from witnesses concerning
Thompson’s arrest or that Walbran made false representations to the district court and this court.
misconduct_determination_term4: oid of any proof that Walbran knowingly elicited false testimony

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Eighth Circuit.
attorneys_judges: *876 Alan G. Kimbrell, St. Louis, MO, argued, for Appellant.//David M. Rosen, Assistant U.S. Attorney, St. Louis, MO, argued, for Appellee.//Before BOWMAN, 1FLOYD R. GIBSON, and HANSEN, Circuit Judges.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri,
allegation_sentence_1:
District Court did not abuse its discretion in failing to find prosecutorial misconduct as
result of cumulative effect of government’s errors;
allegation_sentence_3:
Bartolotta claims that the government committed prosecutorial misconduct during its cross-examination of Bartolotta’s brother,
Leo, who provided Bartolotta’s primary alibi testimony for the January 12, 1992, burglary of the West Frankfort home.
allegation_term_3: claims that the government committed prosecutorial misconduct during its cross-examination
allegation_sentence_4:
Bartolotta also contends that, during its closing argument, the government improperly suggested that Leo must have been lying
*878 about Bartolotta’s alibi because he failed to inform the authorities about the alibi when he first learned that Bartolotta was
suspected of committing the crime.
allegation_term_4: the government improperly suggested that Leo must have been lying
allegation_sentence_5:
Bartolotta further argues that the government improperly questioned Timothy Hinton about his fear of Bartolotta during its
redirect questioning.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Because we conclude that the district court

2 did not err, we affirm Bartolotta’s conviction and

sentence.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
It is doubtful that the government committed any improper actions in its cross-examination of Leo or in its closing argument.
However, even were we to assume that the government’s actions were improper, we would still conclude that the government
did not engage in prosecutorial misconduct because the prosecutor’s remarks did not prejudice Bartolotta’s right to a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_term2: did not prejudice Bartolotta’s right to a fair trial.
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
Therefore, we conclude that
even if the prosecutor’s cross-examination of Leo or comments during closing argument were improper, Bartolotta’s right to a
fair trial was not prejudiced as a result.
misconduct_determination_term3:
Bartolotta’s right to a
fair trial was not prejudiced as a result.
misconduct_determination_sentence4:
We conclude that the prosecutor was merely clarifying an issue that was opened up by the defense on
cross-examination. See United States v. Braidlow, 806 F.2d 781, 783 (8th Cir.1986). Therefore, the government did not commit
prosecutorial misconduct during its redirect examination of Hinton.

decision_court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
attorneys_judges: Marcus Darnell Dixon, Beaver, WV, pro se.//R. Gregory McVey, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Huntington, WV, for Respondent.//ROBERT C. CHAMBERS, District Judge.
geography_entities: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
allegation_sentence_1:
First, Movant objects to the finding that his claim regarding his indictment was
waived by his guilty plea. Second, he objects to the finding that his claim of prosecutorial misconduct was waived because it
was not presented on direct appeal.
allegation_sentence_2:
Movant argues that the prosecutor in his criminal action committed misconduct by failing to correct “false” testimony by a law
enforcement officer during sentencing.
allegation_term_2: committed misconduct by failing to correct “false” testimony
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
Examining this claim on the merits, it must fail. The agent’s testimony would not have been significantly discredited had the
prosecutor pointed out that later-taken photographs did not show the purported rubber bands.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
Movant therefore fails to demonstrate either
prosecutorial misconduct, or prejudice resulting from such alleged misconduct.
misconduct_determination_term2:
ails to demonstrate either
prosecutorial misconduct, or prejudice
misconduct_determination_sentence3:
However, even if Movant could prove misconduct or prejudice, the claim would still be barred. Movant failed to raise the
issue on direct appeal, and thus defaulted the claim.
misconduct_determination_term3: the claim would still be barred

decision_court:
United States Court of Appeals,
Ninth Circuit.
defendant:
Larry Lee PHILLIPS, Defendant-Appellant.
UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee,//Columbus Lee PHILLIPS, Defendant-Appellant.
attorneys_judges: John P. Moran, Phoenix, Ariz., for defendant-appellant.//Joel D. Sacks, Asst. U. S. Atty., and Allen B. Bickart, Kanne & Bickart & Kaufman, Phoenix, Ariz., on brief; Daniel Drake, Asst. U.S. Atty., for plaintiff-appellee.//*187 Before CHOY and ANDERSON, Circuit Judges, and BARTELS, * District judge.
geography_entities: the United States District Court for the District of Arizona,
allegation_sentence_1:
On appeal to this court, appellants contended that a mistrial should have been granted since they were prejudiced by the
prosecution’s failure promptly to inform the trial court and defense counsel that it would seek to reopen its case because a
Government witness, who had lied on the witness stand, was prepared to recant his testimony.
allegation_term_1: a mistrial should have been granted since they were prejudiced
allegation_sentence_2:
Upon remand, appellants filed a motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that a retrial would violate their constitutional
protection against double jeopardy.
allegation_term_2:
a retrial would violate their constitutional
protection
allegation_sentence_3:
Appellants argue that the double jeopardy clause bars a retrial after a successful appeal by a criminal defendant when reversal
was predicated upon prosecutorial misconduct or overreaching.

2 Appellants contend that this court, in Phillips I, found that the
Government had acted improperly.
misconduct_determination_sentence1:
The Court of Appeals held that where there was no prosecutorial misconduct at defendants’ first trial, the double
jeopardy clause did not bar retrial.
misconduct_determination_sentence2:
The district court issued an order
1
stating that it found no prosecutorial misconduct and

denied appellants’ motion. This appeal followed. We affirm.
misconduct_determination_sentence3: But this court explicitly stated that it did not find prosecutorial misconduct.
